TI- Improving the psychological care of cancer patients and their relatives: The role of specialist nurses.

KP- deficiencies in communication

AB- This article first highlights how deficiencies in communication between health care professionals and cancer patients adversely affect psychological adjustment. Reasons for these deficiencies and the use of communication skills training to overcome them are then discussed. Finally, we consider how specialist cancer nurses trained in such skills can play a key role in improving psychological care providing they are given adequate training, supervision and support. TI- Mood disturbance in community cancer support groups: The role of emotional suppression and fighting spirit.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cordova, Matthew J.
AU- Giese-Davis, Janine
AU- Golant, Mitch
AU- Kronnenwetter, Carol
AU- Chang, Vickie
AU- McFarlin, Sarah
AU- Spiegel, David
AF- Cordova, Matthew J., matthew.cordova@med.va.gov, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, US
AF- Giese-Davis, Janine, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, US
AF- Golant, Mitch, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, US
AF- Kronnenwetter, Carol, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, US
AF- Chang, Vickie, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, US
AF- McFarlin, Sarah, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, US
AF- Spiegel, David, Stanford University School of Medicine, Stanford, CA, US
AD- Cordova, Matthew J., VA Palo Alto Health Care System, (116B) 3801 Miranda Avenue,, Palo Alto, CA, US, 94304, matthew.cordova@med.va.gov
SO- Journal of Psychosomatic Research
VI- 55
IP- 5
SD- Nov, 2003
YR- 2003
PM- Nov, 2003
SI- Psychosocial oncology
PG- 461-467
PC- 7
SP- 461
PU- Netherlands : Elsevier Science
PN- 7
SN- 0022-3999, Print
DO- 10.1016/S0022-3999(03)00510-5
LA- English
KP- coping style
KP- mood disturbance
KP- emotional suppression
KP- cancer patients
KP- fighting spirit
KP- support groups
SU- Coping Behavior; Emotional Control; Emotional States; Neoplasms; Support Groups
AB- Objective: In this cross-sectional study, we tested whether the coping styles of emotional suppression and fighting spirit were associated with mood disturbance in cancer patients participating in professionally led community-based support groups even when demographic, medical, and group support variables were taken into account. Methods: A heterogeneous sample of 121 cancer patients (71% female, 29% male) completed the Courtauld Emotional Control Scale (CECS), the Mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer Scale (Mini-MAC), a measure of perceived group support, and the Profile of Mood States (POMS). Results: Con- sistent with hypotheses, lower emotional suppression and greater adoption of a fighting spirit, in addition to older age and higher income, were associated with lower mood disturbance. Gender, time since diagnosis, presence of metastatic disease, time in the support group, perceived group support, cognitive avoidance, and fatalism were unrelated to mood disturbance. Conclusion: Expression of negative affect and an attitude of realistic optimism may enhance adjustment and reduce distress for cancer patients in support groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Emotional Control; Emotional States; Neoplasms; Support Groups

TI- Is perceived family support a relevant variable in psychological distress? A sample of prostate and breast cancer couples.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Baider, Lea
AU- Ever-Hadani, Pnina
AU- Goldzweig, Gil
AU- Wygoda, Marc R.
AU- Peretz, Tamar
AF- Baider, Lea, baider@cc.huji.ac.il, Sharett Institute of Oncology, Hadassah University Hospital, Jerusalem, Israel
AF- Ever-Hadani, Pnina, Braun School of Public Health, Hebrew University-Hadassah Medical School, Jerusalem, Israel
AF- Goldzweig, Gil, Department of Psychology, ebrew University of Jerusalem, Jerusalem, US
AF- Wygoda, Marc R., Sharett Institute of Oncology, Hadassah University Hospital, Jerusalem, Israel
AF- Peretz, Tamar, Sharett Institute of Oncology, Hadassah University Hospital, Jerusalem, Israel

LA- English
KP- diagnosis
KP- prostate cancer
KP- breast cancer
KP- perception of family support
KP- high psychological distress
KP- couples
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Distress; Family Members; Prostate; Social Support
AB- Objective: In this cross-sectional pilot study of couples in whom the man was diagnosed with prostate cancer or the woman with breast cancer, the purpose was to identify and compare the variables that characterize couples where both spouses are in high psychological distress with couples where the psychological distress of both spouses is within the normal range. Methods: Psychological distress and perception of family support in 574 individuals (118 consecutive prostate cancer patients and their spouses, and 169 randomly selected breast cancer patients and their spouses) were assessed using the Brief Symptom Inventory (BSI) and the Perceived Family Support (PFS) self-report questionnaires. Results: Couples experiencing high psychological distress reported lower levels of perceived family support than couples in whom both spouses reported normal levels of psychological distress. Conclusion: The findings support the notion that perceived family support is associated with the psychological distress in both patients and spouses. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- The hospice patient's primary caregiver: What is their quality of life?
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Gill, Paula
AU- Kaur, Judith S.
AU- Rummans, Teresa
AU- Novotny, Paul J.
AU- Sloan, Jeff A.
AF- Gill, Paula, Mayo Clinic, Department of Hematology, Rochester, MN, US
AF- Kaur, Judith S., kaur.judith@mayo.edu, Mayo Clinic, Department of Medical Oncology, Rochester, MN, US
AF- Rummans, Teresa, Mayo Clinic, Department of Psychiatry, Rochester, MN, US
AF- Novotny, Paul J., Mayo Clinic, Department of Statistics, Rochester, MN, US
AF- Sloan, Jeff A., Mayo Clinic, Department of Statistics, Rochester, MN, US
AD- Kaur, Judith S., Department of Medical Oncology, Mayo Clinic, 200 First Street SW, Rochester, MN, US, 55905, kaur.judith@mayo.edu
SO- Journal of Psychosomatic Research
VI- 55
IP- 5
SD- Nov, 2003
YR- 2003
PM- Nov, 2003
SI- Psychosocial oncology
PG- 445-451
PC- 7
SP- 445
PU- Netherlands : Elsevier Science
PN- 7
SN- 0022-3999, Print
DO- 10.1016/S0022-3999(03)00513-0
LA- English
KP- caregiver quality of life
KP- demands of illness
KP- profile of moods
KP- caregivers
KP- hospice staff
KP- hospice patients
SU- Caregiver Burden; Caregivers; Hospice; Quality of Life; Terminally Ill Patients
AB- The purpose of this study was to (1) assess the quality of life (QOL) of the primary caregivers of hospice patients and (2) to analyze the ability of the hospice staff to accurately judge caregiver QOL. A longitudinal pilot study of QOL of 57 caregivers and patients entering hospice was conducted. Caregivers and hospice personnel completed numerous questionnaires every 2 weeks until patient death. Global QOL and component constructs, as well as the demands of illness on the caregiver and profile of moods, were assessed. Simple descriptive statistics at each time point and summary measures (area under the curve) were calculated to describe the QOL profile of caregivers and staff perceptions of the caregivers. Cronbach's alpha coefficient was applied to verify tool internal consistency in a hospice population. Correlation coefficients were supplemented by Bland-Altman procedures for comparing scales measuring the same construct to compare the scores given by caregivers about themselves and staff ratings of the caregivers. The study had 80% power to detect an intracase difference between caregiver and staff ratings of the caregiver of 0.4 times the standard deviation using a two-sided paired t test with a 5% type 1 error rate. Caregiver QOL was relatively high and stable over time. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Caregiver Burden; Caregivers; Hospice; Quality of Life; Terminally Ill Patients
MN- Death Attitudes; Emotional States; Health Personnel

TI- Waiting for a breast biopsy: Psychosocial consequences and coping strategies.

PU- Netherlands : Elsevier Science

LA- English
KP- distress
KP- coping
KP- perceived personal risk of positive biopsy finding
KP- breast cancer
KP- screening
KP- demographic variables
KP- women
SU- At Risk Populations; Biopsy; Breast Neoplasms; Cancer Screening; Distress
AB- Objective: The aim of this pilot/feasibility study was to describe the experience of women presenting with a suspicious mammogram who are waiting for a breast biopsy and to identify those at risk for distress. Methods: Participants (n=25) were interviewed at two time points: immediately after being put on the waiting list (T1) and again immediately before their biopsy approximately 6 weeks later (T2). Self-report measures of distress and coping were used. Perceived personal risk of a positive biopsy finding and information needs were assessed through open-ended questions. Results: Distress levels were high in this sample. Using cognitive-avoidant coping strategies, being employed, history of previous biopsies, and having a family history of breast cancer were associated with greater distress. Perceived personal risk of a positive biopsy finding was overestimated in one half of the cases and was correlated with greater distress. Conclusion: Waiting period between suspicious mammogram and breast biopsy may be a time of high distress for many women. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- At Risk Populations; Biopsy; Breast Neoplasms; Cancer Screening; Distress
MN- Coping Behavior; Demographic Characteristics; Psychosocial Factors

LA- English
KP- distress
KP- demographic & medical & family history & loss variables
KP- genetic testing
KP- colorectal cancer patients
SU- Colon Disorders; Distress; Genetic Testing; Neoplasms
AB- Objective: The purpose of this paper is to describe pretest psychological functioning in a sample of colorectal cancer (CRC) patients undergoing genetic testing. We also explored the relationship among demographic, medical, family history and loss variables and current pretest distress, and those related to anticipated posttest distress. Methods: This paper reports pretest findings from a prospective, longitudinal psychosocial survey. Data are presented on 220 CRC patients at pretest. Results: We found a subgroup of CRC patients that are currently distressed and anticipate becoming depressed if they receive a positive genetic test result. There were significant associations among pretest distress, family history of CRC and loss related to CRC and anticipation of becoming depressed at posttest. Conclusions: The findings suggest that a subgroup of CRC patient's experience or anticipate distress that may warrant attention. Family history of CRC and losses related to CRC may be important indicators of posttest adjustment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Cancer distress screening: Needs, models, and methods.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Carlson, Linda E.
AU- Bultz, Barry D.

SO- Journal of Psychosomatic Research
VI- 55
IP- 5

PM- Nov, 2003
SI- Psychosocial oncology
PG- 403-409
PC- 7
SP- 403
PU- Netherlands : Elsevier Science

SN- 0022-3999, Print

LA- English
KP- distress
KP- standards
KP- screening
KP- clinical screening programs
KP- computerized quality of life screening
KP- screening instruments
KP- models
KP- economic costs
KP- psychosocial oncology
SU- Cancer Screening; Distress; Models; Neoplasms
AB- This paper summarizes the literature documenting the levels of distress commonly found in cancer patients, followed by discussion of recommended standards for routine distress screening, and a summary of various programs that have attempted to establish clinical screening programs. The computerized quality of life (QL) screening literature is also briefly reviewed as potentially instructive. This review is followed by a theoretical and psychometric assessment of the various screening instruments and screening models that have been suggested in the literature or used clinically and a brief assessment of possible economic costs of psychosocial screening, ending with concrete suggestions for methods and models that could be widely adopted by psychosocial oncology programs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Self-concept as a 'BMT patient', illness intrusiveness, and engulfment in allogeneic bone marrow transplant recipients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Beanlands, Heather J.
AU- Lipton, Jeffrey H.
AU- McCay, Elizabeth A.
AU- Schimmer, Aaron D.
AU- Elliott, Mary E.
AU- Messner, Hans A.
AU- Devins, Gerald M.
AF- Beanlands, Heather J., Ryerson University, Toronto, ON, Canada
AF- Lipton, Jeffrey H., Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, ON, Canada
AF- McCay, Elizabeth A., Ryerson University, Toronto, ON, Canada
AF- Schimmer, Aaron D., Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, ON, Canada
AF- Elliott, Mary E., Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, ON, Canada
AF- Messner, Hans A., Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, ON, Canada
AF- Devins, Gerald M., gdevins@uhnres.utoronto.ca, Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, ON, Canada
AD- Devins, Gerald M., Toronto General Hospital, CW2-300, 200 Elizabeth Street, Toronto, ON, Canada, M5G 2C4, gdevins@uhnres.utoronto.ca
SO- Journal of Psychosomatic Research
VI- 55
IP- 5
SD- Nov, 2003
YR- 2003
PM- Nov, 2003
SI- Psychosocial oncology
PG- 419-425
PC- 7
SP- 419
PU- Netherlands : Elsevier Science
PN- 7
SN- 0022-3999, Print
DO- 10.1016/S0022-3999(03)00509-9
LA- English
KP- illness intrusiveness
KP- self concept
KP- engulfment
KP- bone marrow transplant patients
SU- Bone Marrow; Neoplasms; Organ Transplantation; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Self Concept
AB- The experience of cancer and its treatment by bone marrow transplantation (BMT) can enhance the salience of one's status as a patient in the evolution of self-concept. Illness and the patient role can come to dominate the sense of self, resulting in feelings of hopelessness, helplessness, and distress ("engulfment"). Ninety allogeneic BMT outpatients completed the Illness Intrusiveness Ratings Scale, Modified Engulfment Scale, and a semantic differential measure of self-concept as a BMT patient in an interview context. Illness intrusiveness correlated significantly with engulfment and with self-concept as a BMT patient. Engulfment did not correlate significantly with self-concept as a BMT patient. Multiple regression analysis, controlling for relevant covariates, indicated a significant Illness Intrusiveness×Engulfment interaction effect on self-concept as a BMT patient. Self-concept as a BMT patient increases as cancer and its treatment introduce increasing lifestyle disruptions (illness intrusiveness). These effects are amplified when self-experience is dominated by disease and treatment and patients feel helpless, hopeless, and distressed (engulfment). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Bone Marrow; Neoplasms; Organ Transplantation; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Self Concept
MN- Chronic Illness

TI- Symptomatic distress, hopelessness, and the desire for hastened death in hospitalized cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Jones, Jennifer M.
AU- Huggins, Mary Anne
AU- Rydall, Anne C.
AU- Rodin, Gary M.
AF- Jones, Jennifer M., jennifer.jones@uhn.on.ca, Department of Psychosocial Oncology and Palliative Care, Princess Margaret Hospital, University Health Network, Toronto, ON, Canada
AF- Huggins, Mary Anne, Palliative Care Unit, Princess Margaret Hospital, University Health Network, Canada
AF- Rydall, Anne C., Behavioural Sciences and Health Research Division, Toronto General Hospital, University Health Network, Toronto, Canada
AF- Rodin, Gary M., Department of Psychosocial Oncology and Palliative Care, Princess Margaret Hospital, University Health Network, Toronto, ON, Canada
AD- Jones, Jennifer M., Department of Psychosocial Oncology and Palliative Care, Princess Margaret Hospital, University Health Network, 610 University Avenue, 5th Floor, Room 605, Toronto, ON, Canada, M5G 2M9, jennifer.jones@uhn.on.ca
SO- Journal of Psychosomatic Research
VI- 55
IP- 5
SD- Nov, 2003
YR- 2003
PM- Nov, 2003
SI- Psychosocial oncology
PG- 411-418
PC- 8
SP- 411
PU- Netherlands : Elsevier Science
PN- 8
SN- 0022-3999, Print
DO- 10.1016/S0022-3999(03)00526-9
LA- English
KP- psychological distress
KP- physical symptoms
KP- pain
KP- depression
KP- hopelessness
KP- desire for hastened death
KP- disease stages
KP- cancer patients
SU- Death Attitudes; Distress; Hopelessness; Major Depression; Neoplasms
AB- Objective: This study evaluated the desire for hastened death (DHD) in cancer patients at varying stages of disease to determine its frequency and relationship to physical and psychological distress. Methods: Two hundred twenty-four inpatients at Princess Margaret Hospital completed questionnaires assessing pain, physical symptoms, depression, hopelessness, and DHD. Results: There was significant physical and psychological distress in this sample with a mean of nine physical symptoms reported by each subject. Seven percent reported moderate DHD on the Schedule of Attitudes Towards Hastened Death (SAHD) and 2% reported high DHD. Hopelessness and stage of disease were the only significant independent predictors of DHD and their interaction was associated with increased DHD. Hopelessness and, less so, depression both mediated the pathways between illness-related factors and DHD. Conclusions: Findings suggest that DHD is significantly related to hopelessness and advancing disease. Assessment of this phenomenon prior to the end of life may provide opportunities for intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Death Attitudes; Distress; Hopelessness; Major Depression; Neoplasms
MN- Disease Course; Symptoms; Terminally Ill Patients; Desire
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
PO- Male (30)
PO- Female (40)
PO- Inpatient (50)
LO- Canada
AG- Adulthood (18 yrs & older) (300)
AG- Young Adulthood (18-29 yrs) (320)

AU- Katz, Ernest R.
AU- Rubinstein, Cherryl L.

LA- English
KP- model intervention package
KP- school & social reintegration
KP- 5–17 yr olds newly diagnosed with cancer
KP- 8 mo followup
SU- Early Intervention; Neoplasms; School Adjustment; School Counseling; Social Adjustment
AB- Tested the effectiveness of a model intervention package developed to facilitate the successful school and social reintegration of children and adolescents newly diagnosed with cancer. 37 children (aged 5–17 yrs) completed the Perceived Competence Scale for Children and the Children's Depression Inventory before the intervention was initiated and again at follow-up (mean interim 8.87 mo). Data were also collected from parents, teachers, school records, and physicians. 36 age-matched controls who had been diagnosed within the 36 mo before initiation of the project were assessed once with identical psychological measures. Findings show that the intervention group demonstrated significant improvements following the intervention. Controls tended to exhibit poorer school and social adjustment than Ss; however, no group differences were found on grades or attendance. Results support early structured school and social reintegration interventions for newly diagnosed children who have cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Unaided smoking cessation: Great American Smokeout and New Year's Day quitters.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Gritz, Ellen R.
AU- Carr, Clifford R.
AU- Marcus, Alfred C.
AF- Gritz, Ellen R., U California Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Ctr, Div of Cancer Control, Los Angeles, US
AF- Carr, Clifford R.
AF- Marcus, Alfred C.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6
IP- 3-4
SD- 1988
YR- 1988
PM- 1988
SI- Clinical research issues in psychosocial oncology
PG- 217-234
PC- 18
SP- 217
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v06n03_15
LA- English
KP- target quitting dates & unaided smoking cessation
KP- adult smokers
KP- 1 yr study
SU- Smoking Cessation
AB- Sequentially assigned 554 smokers (mean age 41.4 yrs) in 2 cohorts (Great American Smokeout and New Year's Day) who intended to quit smoking on their own without formalized external aid to a frequent-contact and an infrequent-contact group. All Ss completed a detailed baseline questionnaire and were followed for 12 mo. Findings revealed that neither frequency of interviews nor cohort affected outcome. The rate of nonsmoking at each follow-up point declined from 34% at 1 mo to 25% at 1 yr. 11% of Ss were continuous abstainers, 21% of Ss never stopped smoking, and 68% of Ss who ever quit had relapsed by 1 yr. Continuous abstainers were lighter smokers, less addicted, more aware of the health risks associated with smoking, more highly motivated to stop, more confident of their ability to do so, and more committed to quitting at baseline than other Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Smoking Cessation

TI- Pain management in the cancer patient.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Spiegel, David
AU- Sands, Susan H.
AF- Spiegel, David, Stanford U School of Medicine, CA, US

LA- English
KP- psychosocial differences & effectiveness of intensive psychiatric intervention program
KP- mood disturbance
KP- high vs low pain cancer patients
KP- 2 yr study
SU- Emotional States; Mental Health Programs; Neoplasms; Pain
AB- Compared 39 high pain (HP) cancer patients and 23 low pain (LP) cancer patients on measures of mood disturbance. 20 HPs were randomly assigned to an intensive psychiatric intervention program. Results indicate that HPs scored significantly high on the Beck Depression Inventory; subscales of the Spielberger Depression Inventory; and subscales of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory reflecting strain, fright, and worry. On the Structured Clinical Interview for the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-III), 28% of the HPs had a current diagnosis of major depression, whereas none of the LPs did. Findings confirm earlier reports (e.g., D. Spiegel [1986]) of a link between pain and mood disturbance in cancer patients. While follow-up data on the intervention were insufficient to permit useful analysis, the strong association between pain and depression at baseline suggests that the vigorous treatment of depression in the HPs assigned to treatment should result in improvements in both depression and pain. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional States; Mental Health Programs; Neoplasms; Pain
MN- Longitudinal Studies

KP- perceptions of accessibility of diagnosis & treatment & rehabilitation services for cancer patients & their families
KP- Hispanic vs Chinese vs Vietnamese 50 yr olds & older
SU- Health Care Services; Knowledge Level; Neoplasms; Racial and Ethnic Differences
AB- Assessed the perceptions of 158 Hispanic, 75 Chinese, and 75 Vietnamese volunteers (aged 50+ yrs) about the accessibility of cancer diagnosis, treatment, and rehabilitation services to cancer patients and their families. Ss completed a questionnaire assessing their knowledge about cancer and their use of health care services. Results revealed differences in the amount of information about cancer and attitude toward the disease both between and within groups. Variables that may constitute barriers to the use of health care services are identified, and recommendations for developing a systematic plan for meeting the needs of older people in an ethnic community are offered. LA- English
KP- psychosocial services provision
KP- 35 yr olds & older of different sociocultural status with breast or colorectal or lung cancer
SU- Health Care Delivery; Neoplasms; Sociocultural Factors
AB- Analyzed practice issues involved in providing psychosocial services for patients of different sociocultural status in the context of empirical data from extant research and findings from a study by K. O. Ell et al (1987 [unpublished manuscript]; 1989) of 369 patients (aged 35+ yrs) with a 1st diagnosis of breast, colorectal, or lung cancer. Selected findings indicate that the duration of symptoms before the diagnosis varied by gender and socioeconomic status (SES), with men and lower SES Ss being more likely to have had symptoms for a longer time. Social integration decreased with advancing age and was lower among men, lower SES Ss, and less-educated Ss. Hispanics' perceived adequacy of support was lower than that of Whites and Blacks. Implications for assessment are discussed; intervention with men, the elderly, the poor, and ethnic minorities is emphasized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- cranial irradiation
KP- academic performance & socially adaptive behavior
KP- children with leukemia
SU- Academic Achievement; Leukemias; Radiation Therapy; Social Adjustment
AB- Administered the Wechsler Intelligence Scale for Children—Revised (WISC—R) and the Wide Range Achievement Test to 31 leukemic children (mean age 8 yrs 2 mo) treated with cranial irradiation (CI) and 14 age-matched nonirradiated (NI) leukemic children. Ss' parents supplied each S's developmental history and completed the Deasy-Spinetta Behavioral Questionnaire (DSBQ) and the Adaptive Behavior Inventory for Children. Information was obtained from Ss' teachers via interviews and the DSBQ. Findings indicate that, as a group, CI Ss seemed to be at higher risk for subsequent behavioral problems than were NI Ss. There was a clear relationship between CI Ss' lower academic achievement scores, their apparent learning and information-processing deficits, and their social and adaptive difficulties. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- chemotherapy related nausea & vomiting & behavioral distress
KP- 3–19 yr olds with cancer
SU- Chemotherapy; Drug Therapy; Neoplasms; Side Effects (Drug)
AB- Discusses the scope and determinants of chemotherapy-related nausea, vomiting, and behavioral distress in pediatric cancer patients, focusing on anticipatory symptoms. Findings from a 3-yr prospective study of distress in children and adolescents receiving chemotherapy are summarized. It was found that the behavioral effects of chemotherapy on pediatric patients were determined by many factors and that their behavioral responses to chemotherapy may be best predicted on the basis of most recent experience rather than on usual distress levels. Adolescents experienced significantly higher levels of both anticipatory and postchemotherapy nausea and vomiting than did Ss less than 12 yrs old; their levels of anticipatory distress tended to increase over chemotherapy cycles, while younger Ss experienced decreases in anticipatory distress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- psychosocial sequelae of treatment
KP- 18–60 yr old survivors of testicular cancer
SU- Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Side Effects (Treatment); Testes
AB- Conducted personal interviews and psychological assessments of 39 men treated for seminomatous testicular cancer and 49 men treated for nonseminomatous testicular cancer approximately 45 mo after treatment had ended. All Ss were aged 18–60 yrs. Results indicate that most Ss viewed themselves as healthy and cured of cancer at the time of the interview. Over 80% of the Ss had been debilitated as a result treatment, and for most Ss, the effects lasted an average of 9 mo after treatment. Problems included significant depletion of energy, increased fear of cancer, interference with sleep and cognitive function, and sexual difficulties. No significant differences were found between tumor types, and Ss' scores on psychological tests did not reflect significant levels of symptomatology in the sample as a whole. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Side Effects (Treatment); Testes

LA- English
KP- treatment
KP- work experiences
KP- 18–46 yr old male long term survivors of Hodgkin's disease vs testicular cancer
SU- Job Performance; Neoplasms; Treatment
AB- Compared the work experiences of 85 men (aged 18–46 yrs) who were long-term survivors of Hodgkin's disease with those of 88 survivors of testicular cancer, described by E. R. Gritz et al (see record [rid]1989-37222-001[/rid]). Results suggest that survivors of Hodgkin's disease had more difficulties in completing work tasks. Further analysis of these findings, using a measure of physical performance at work and at leisure, indicated that treatment for Hodgkin's disease had measurable effects on performance of leisure, but not work activities, and that changes in leisure activity had a negative effect on Ss' mood states. LA- English
KP- psychosocial aspects of & attitudes toward stigma of cancer
KP- college students & cancer patients & their spouses
KP- application of social psychological model of victimization
SU- Neoplasms; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Psychosocial Factors; Social Discrimination
AB- Explores aspects of the stigma of cancer using the social-psychological model of victimization. The model is supported with (1) interview data from 53 cancer patients and their spouses over a 3-yr period to assess multiple aspects of psychosocial adaptation and coping and experiences of stigma and (2) survey data on 371 undergraduates' attitudes toward cancer using a stigma inventory. Variables that affect attitudes toward cancer and mediate patients' experiences of stigma are explored, including social support, coping styles, compliance with the medical regimen, and emotional factors. Findings are discussed in terms of the psychosocial morbidity phenomenon, focusing on role and family systems theories and the just world hypothesis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Long-term adjustment in families of children with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Spinetta, John J.
AU- Murphy, Joan L.
AU- Vik, Peter J.
AU- Day, Jacqueline
AU- Mott, Mariam A.
AF- Spinetta, John J., San Diego State U, CA, US
AF- Murphy, Joan L.

AF- Mott, Mariam A.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6

SI- Clinical research issues in psychosocial oncology
PG- 179-191
PC- 13
SP- 179
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 13
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v06n03_12
LA- English
KP- long term adjustment
KP- families with child cancer patients who died vs survived
KP- 5 yr followup
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Family Relations; Terminal Cancer
AB- Administered the Current Adjustment Scale (CAS) in a follow-up study with 38 families of pediatric cancer patients 5 yrs after the children's treatment had ended and 13 families 5 yrs after the children had died. Findings revealed that families with the long-term cancer survivor generally had less difficulty adjusting than families whose child had died. A regression analysis, comparing the families' adjustment during the course of treatment with their adjustment 5 yrs later, confirmed the consistency of family functioning over time. A factor analysis of the CAS resulted in 3 factors associated with family adjustment: (1) the family was able to resolve questions about the cancer and focus on matters unrelated to the disease; (2) the family system was adaptive, healthy, and supportive of its members; and (3) family members were able to seek help when needed. Themes that helped differentiate families that had adjusted well from those that had not are discussed, and suggestions for interventions early in the course of treatment that may help families adjust better over time are offered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Family Relations; Terminal Cancer
MN- Followup Studies; Neoplasms
CL- Cancer (3293)

LA- English
KP- perception & interpretation & responses to cancer
KP- families of children with cancer who died vs survived
KP- 5 yr study
SU- Family Relations; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Terminal Cancer
AB- Investigated how 33 predominantly White, rural, Midwestern families with a child diagnosed as having cancer perceived, interpreted, and responded to childhood cancer. Intensive analysis of interviews with 5 families whose child had died and 5 families whose child had survived during the 5-yr study period revealed 15 themes, including being unprepared for the cancer diagnosis, the need to normalize family life as quickly as possible, fear that the cancer would recur, and fear that a sibling would develop the disease. Nursing interventions suggested by the themes are noted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Problems of families with multiple cancers.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cordoba, Catherine
AU- Cohen, Jerome
AF- Cordoba, Catherine, American Cancer Society, California Div, Oakland, US
AF- Cohen, Jerome
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6
IP- 3-4
SD- 1988
YR- 1988
PM- 1988
SI- Clinical research issues in psychosocial oncology
PG- 193-204
PC- 12
SP- 193
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 12
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v06n03_13
LA- English
KP- problems & needs & changes & adjustment
KP- families with 2 or more cancer patients
SU- Family Members; Family Relations; Neoplasms
AB- Interviewed 38 families in which multiple cancers had occurred. Findings indicate that Ss presented myriad problems, including financial struggles, marital discord, social isolation, depression, and substance abuse. Cancer was the focal point of life for most of the families. Ss expressed fears of dying, pain, afflicting their children, losing contact with others, and the future. In general, Ss were not provided with enough resources to sustain them emotionally, physically, or financially. Results suggest that every cancer patient should be asked about others in his/her immediate family who have or have had cancer to assess the full impact of the disease and to plan for supportive services. The need for a concerted effort to increase resources and services for these special families is emphasized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Family Members; Family Relations; Neoplasms
MN- Adjustment; Needs

TI- Psychosocial responses to cancer in California and western Sweden: A comparative study.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cohen, Jerome
AU- Sullivan, Marianne
AU- Branehog, Ingmar
AF- Cohen, Jerome, U California, School of Social Welfare, Los Angeles, US
AF- Sullivan, Marianne
AF- Branehog, Ingmar
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6
IP- 3-4
SD- 1988
YR- 1988
PM- 1988
SI- Clinical research issues in psychosocial oncology
PG- 29-40
PC- 12
SP- 29
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 12
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v06n03_03
LA- English
KP- psychosocial problems & needs
KP- 20–70 yr olds with cancer & their families
KP- US vs Sweden
SU- Cross Cultural Differences; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Compared the major psychosocial problems and needs of surviving cancer patients in California, where cancer patients are treated under an essentially private fee-for-service system of medical care, and in the western region of Sweden, where the system of universal health insurance and social benefits removes almost all economic consequences of the disease. 810 cancer patients and 142 family members in California and 406 cancer patients and 83 family members in Sweden were interviewed. Results identified the positive effects of each society's interventive actions. In California, individual and family services were more available than in Sweden, whereas economic supports were less available, resulting in more economic-related problems and fewer individual and family difficulties than in Sweden. However, patients in each society had some difficulties in both areas, which required further attention from the health care system. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Cross Cultural Differences; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
MN- Family Members; Needs
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
LO- Sweden

TI- An outdoor adventure program for young adults with cancer: Positive effects on body image and psychosocial functioning.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Rosenberg, Robin S.
AU- Lange, Whitney
AU- Zebrack, Brad
AU- Moulton, Samuel
AU- Kosslyn, Stephen M.
AF- Rosenberg, Robin S., Robin@DrRobinRosenberg.com, Department of Psychiatry, University of California–San Francisco, Menlo Park, CA, US
AF- Lange, Whitney, First Descents, Denver, CO, US
AF- Zebrack, Brad, School of Social Work, University of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI, US
AF- Moulton, Samuel, Harvard Initiative for Learning and Teaching, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, US
AF- Kosslyn, Stephen M., Minerva Schools, Keck Graduate Institute, San Francisco, CA, US

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 5
SD- Sep, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- Sep, 2014
PG- 622-636
PC- 15
SP- 622
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press

DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.936652
LA- English
KP- young adult
KP- cancer survivors
KP- adventure therapy
KP- body image
KP- self-compassion
KP- depression
SU- Body Image; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Survivors; Adventure Therapy
AB- This study evaluated the psychological effects of an outdoor adventure program on young adult cancer survivors (ages 18–39). The 6-day adventure program included personal instruction and supervision on the basics of kayaking, surfing, or climbing. Compared to a wait-list control group, participants who took part in the program for the first time had improved (relative to pretest) body image, self-compassion and self-esteem, and less depression and alienation. Participants who took part for the second time, though also helped by the program in similar ways, were no better off psychologically than participants who took part for the first time. Possible explanations for the positive effects and their apparent short duration are offered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

MN- Major Depression; Self Concept

AF- McLoone, Jordana K., School of Women’s and Children’s Health, UNSW Medicine, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia
AF- Evans, Nadia T., School of Women’s and Children’s Health, UNSW Medicine, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia
AF- Ellis, Sarah J., School of Women’s and Children’s Health, UNSW Medicine, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia
AF- Cohn, Richard J., School of Women’s and Children’s Health, UNSW Medicine, University of New South Wales, Kensington, NSW, Australia

VI- 32

PG- 602-621

P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 20

LA- English
KP- cancer
KP- oncology
KP- pediatric
KP- occupation
KP- work–family conflict
KP- family friendly policies
SU- Family Conflict; Family Work Relationship; Finance; Neoplasms; Occupational Health
AB- Few studies have evaluated the impact of childhood cancer on parents’ occupational/financial status. This study explored parents’ occupational/financial experiences posttreatment. Semistructured interviews were administered to 78 parents (44 mothers) of childhood cancer survivors diagnosed in the preceding 5 years. Transcripts were organized into themes using QSR NVivo8. Parents reported familial, psychological, and practical factors affecting their ability to return to work. Prioritizing family, reinstigating career progression, and negative workplace attitudes were particularly challenging. Parents of children with cancer experience substantial work—family conflict after their child's physical recovery from cancer. Family friendly policies and further research are recommended. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Surviving childhood leukemia in a Latin culture: An explorative study based on young adults’ written narratives.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Zannini, Lucia
AU- Cattaneo, Cesarina
AU- Jankovic, Momcilo
AU- Masera, Giuseppe
AF- Zannini, Lucia, lucia.zannini@unimi.it, Department of Biomedical Sciences for Health, Universita degli Studi di Milano, Milan, Italy
AF- Cattaneo, Cesarina, Department of Biomedical Sciences for Health, Universita degli Studi di Milano, Milan, Italy
AF- Jankovic, Momcilo, Department of Paediatrics, Universita degli Studi di Milano-Bicocca, S. Gerardo Hospital, Monza, Italy

VI- 32

P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 26

DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.936648
LA- English
KP- benefit finding
KP- childhood leukemia
KP- Latin culture
KP- qualitative study
KP- survivorship
KP- written narrative
SU- Early Memories; Leukemias; Narratives; Survivors; Latinos/Latinas
AB- This study investigated memories of childhood leukemia conveyed by survivors belonging to a Latin culture, exploring whether benefit findings was spontaneously reported, as by non-Latin survivors. Three hundred patients previously treated for leukemia were contacted by post/e-mail and asked to write freely about their illness experience. The 106 letters received were analyzed for narrative structure and content, according to a grounded theory approach. Participants expressed most of the themes conveyed by childhood cancer survivors in non-Latin countries, and benefit finding was spontaneously reported. To the latter, the usefulness of creating and maintaining personal narratives on cancer experience, sustained by health care professionals, is discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- An exploration of the existential experiences of patients following curative treatment for cancer: Reflections from a U.K. sample.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Lagerdahl, Anna S. K.
AU- Moynihan, Manus
AU- Stollery, Brian
AF- Lagerdahl, Anna S. K., anna.lagerdahl@gwh.nhs.uk, Cancer Services, Great Western Hospital, Swindon, United Kingdom
AF- Moynihan, Manus, School of Experimental Psychology, University of Bristol, Bristol, United Kingdom
AF- Stollery, Brian, School of Experimental Psychology, University of Bristol, Bristol, United Kingdom

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32

SD- Sep, 2014

PM- Sep, 2014
PG- 555-575
PC- 21

P2- US : Haworth Press

LA- English
KP- cancer
KP- existential
KP- curative
KP- posttreatment
KP- meaning
KP- psychosocial oncology care
SU- Client Attitudes; Life Experiences; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Rehabilitation; Therapeutic Processes
AB- The existential experiences associated with cancer diagnosis and treatment are well researched, but the posttreatment phase is relatively underexplored. Using semistructured interviews and theory-led thematic analysis this qualitative study investigated the existential experiences of eight cancer survivors who had successfully completed curative treatment. Being in remission had led to deep existential reflections (i.e., death anxiety, freedom, isolation, and meaning making), and some participants faced considerable challenges that affected their emotional well-being. Understanding cancer survivors’ existential challenges should enable health care professionals to engage with the emerging shift from the predominantly medically focused posttreatment care to a more holistic approach. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Predictors of benefit finding in the adult children of patients with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Levesque, Janelle V.
AU- Maybery, Darryl J.
AF- Levesque, Janelle V., j.levesque@unsw.edu.au, Ingham Institute for Applied Medical Research, University of New South Wales, South Western Sydney Clinical School, Liverpool, NSW, Australia

LA- English
KP- parental cancer
KP- adult children
KP- benefit finding
KP- post-traumatic growth
KP- emotional experiences
KP- caregiving
SU- Adult Offspring; Caregivers; Emotional States; Neoplasms
AB- This study aimed to investigate the predictors of benefit finding in 311 adult children of patients with cancer. Participants completed a comprehensive online/pen-and-paper survey measuring benefit finding, gender of parent, outcome and duration of illness, caregiving experience, and emotional experiences including reaction to diagnosis and grief and loss. Greater benefit finding was positively associated with stronger emotional experiences, satisfaction with the caregiving role, and outcome of parental cancer, explaining 15.3% of the variance in benefit finding. Higher emotional reactions and outcome of parental cancer as significant predictors of parental cancer provide some support for the applicability of theories of post-traumatic growth to this cohort. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Reciprocal empathy and working alliance in terminal oncological illness: The crucial role of patients’ attachment style.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Calvo, Vincenzo
AU- Palmieri, Arianna
AU- Marinelli, Sara
AU- Bianco, Francesca
AU- Kleinbub, Johann R.
AF- Calvo, Vincenzo, vincenzo.calvo@unipd.it, Department of Philosophy, Sociology, Pedagogy and Applied Psychology, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
AF- Palmieri, Arianna, Department of Philosophy, Sociology, Pedagogy and Applied Psychology, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
AF- Marinelli, Sara, Department of Philosophy, Sociology, Pedagogy and Applied Psychology, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
AF- Bianco, Francesca, Department of Philosophy, Sociology, Pedagogy and Applied Psychology, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
AF- Kleinbub, Johann R., Department of Philosophy, Sociology, Pedagogy and Applied Psychology, University of Padova, Padova, Italy
AD- Calvo, Vincenzo, Department of Philosophy, Sociology, Pedagogy and Applied Psychology, University of Padova, via Venezia 8, Padova, Italy, vincenzo.calvo@unipd.it
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 5
SD- Sep, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- Sep, 2014
PG- 517-534
PC- 18
SP- 517
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.936651
LA- English
KP- attachment
KP- cancer
KP- empathy
KP- working alliance
KP- caregiver
SU- Attachment Behavior; Empathy; Terminal Cancer; Therapeutic Alliance; Therapeutic Processes
AB- Security of attachment is described as an inner resource that may also facilitate the adaptation of individuals during critical life adversity, even when facing end-stage illness and death. This study assessed the relation between attachment styles, patient–caregiver reciprocal empathy, and patient–physician working alliance, in the terminal phase of an oncological disease. We hypothesized that the attachment security of patients, as measured by the Relationship Questionnaire (RQ), is related to the reciprocal empathy with the caregiver, as measured by the Perception of Partner Empathy (PPE) questionnaire, and to the working alliance with the physician, as measured by the Working Alliance Inventory–Short Form (WAI-S). Thirty-seven end-stage cancer patients, their caregivers, and physicians participated in the study. The PPE and WAI-S were administered twice: immediately after the hospice recovery and a week later. Results showed a significant improvement in patient–caregiver empathy and in patient–physician alliance after a week at the hospice. Findings indicated that the patients’ attachment style influenced their perception of reciprocal empathy with the caregiver and the working alliance with the physician. Patients with a secure attachment had a greater capacity to show empathic closeness with their caregivers and enjoyed a better working alliance with their physicians. Caregivers’ attachment security, otherwise, did not show the same influence on empathy and alliance. Findings support the hypothesis that patients’ attachment security plays a crucial role in the relation with their own caregiver and with the physician, even at the terminal phase. Theoretical and clinical implications of these findings are explored in the discussion. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Attachment Behavior; Empathy; Terminal Cancer; Therapeutic Alliance; Therapeutic Processes
MN- Caregivers
CL- Cancer (3293)

LA- English
KP- breast cancer disparities
KP- African American women
KP- predictors
KP- psychological functioning
KP- anxiety
KP- depression
SU- Biopsychosocial Approach; Blacks; Breast Neoplasms; Psychodynamics
AB- This study examined the relationships of biological and psychosocial predictors as contributing factors to the psychological functioning among breast cancer survivors. A sample of (N = 155) African American breast cancer survivors were recruited from California. A general linear model was utilized to examine the relationships. Biological and psychosocial risk factors were significant predictors for anxiety and depression. These predictors can be viewed as contributing factors to the psychological well-being of this cohort. Anxiety and depression are often under-recognized and subsequently undertreated in survivors. Understanding the predictors of depression and anxiety is necessary for incorporating a multidisciplinary approach to address this problem. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- A prospective pilot study of psychosocial functioning in head and neck cancer patient–caregiver dyads.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Nightingale, Chandylen L.
AU- Lagorio, Lisa
AU- Carnaby, Giselle
AF- Nightingale, Chandylen L., Chandylen@gmail.com, Department of Behavioral Science and Community Health, College of Public Health and Health Professions, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, US
AF- Lagorio, Lisa, Department of Speech, Language, and Hearing Sciences, College of Public Health and Health Professions, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, US
AF- Carnaby, Giselle, Department of Behavioral Science and Community Health, College of Public Health and Health Professions, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL, US
AD- Nightingale, Chandylen L., Department of Behavioral Science and Community Health, University of Florida, 1225 Center Drive, P.O. Box 100175 HSC, Gainesville, FL, US, 32610-0175, Chandylen@gmail.com
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 5
SD- Sep, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- Sep, 2014
PG- 477-492
PC- 16
SP- 477
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.936649
LA- English
KP- quality of life
KP- caregiver burden
KP- head and neck cancer
KP- chemoradiation
KP- pilot study
SU- Caregivers; Dyads; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Quality of Life
AB- This study explored the psychosocial functioning of 10 head and neck cancer patient–caregiver dyads over the radiation/chemoradiation (radiation or combined chemoradiation) treatment period, including the interdependence in patient–caregiver quality of life (QOL). Dyads were recruited prior to or at the initiation of radiation/chemoradiation treatment. Patient QOL decreased across the treatment trajectory, and many caregiver QOL subscales decreased during the middle of treatment. Caregiver burden increased over the treatment trajectory with levels remaining relatively low. Patients and caregivers demonstrated interdependence in QOL toward the middle and conclusion of treatment. Patients demonstrated more depression than caregivers at all time points. Results suggest that both members of the dyad should be targeted for psychosocial interventions during radiation/chemoradiation treatment period. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

AU- Kozlowski, Desirée
AU- Provost, Stephen Campbell
AU- Tucker, Julie
AU- van der Zwan, Rick
AF- Kozlowski, Desirée, desiree.kozlowski@scu.edu.au, Discipline of Psychology, Southern Cross University, Coffs Harbour, NSW, Australia
AF- Provost, Stephen Campbell, Discipline of Psychology, Southern Cross University, Coffs Harbour, NSW, Australia

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32

LA- English
KP- asbestos
KP- mesothelioma
KP- support group
KP- social connectedness
KP- psychosocial support
SU- Diagnosis; Family; Hazardous Materials; Peer Relations; Social Support
AB- Individuals with an asbestos-related diagnosis and their carers face burdens including debilitating and life-limiting physical symptoms and medico-legal stressors. Feelings of social isolation are common. Increasing social connectedness can lead to increased feelings of personal empowerment and may inhibit chronic stress responses. The authors report on the development, via a process of participatory action research, of an online peer-to-peer support group, and the first 30-day test phase of this virtual community. Initial indications are that individuals with an asbestos-related diagnosis and their carers can benefit, in psychosocial terms, from membership of an on-line support group comprised of experientially similar others. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Diagnosis; Family; Hazardous Materials; Peer Relations; Social Support

TI- Young adult cancer survivors and the challenges of intimacy.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Robinson, Lynne
AU- Miedema, Baukje
AU- Easley, Julie
AF- Robinson, Lynne, lynne.robinson@dal.ca, School of Health and Human Performance, Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada

LA- English
KP- young adult
KP- cancer
KP- qualitative study
KP- intimate relationships
KP- sexuality
KP- psychosocial
SU- Interpersonal Interaction; Intimacy; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Qualitative Research
AB- The purpose of this study was to explore intimate relationships after a cancer diagnosis, applying constructivist grounded theory to interviews with 55 Canadian young adult cancer survivors. The core category found was the dynamic interplay between participants’ experiences of cancer and their intimate relationships. The authors found four themes within this core category: the mental experience of cancer, challenged sexual intimacy, the relationship response to strain (supportive or nonsupportive), and adapted intimacy. This research demonstrates the importance of intimate relationships for young adults along their cancer trajectory, revealing that those relationships are severely strained by a cancer diagnosis and treatment yet help to limit negative consequences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Summarizing the fifteen scales of the EORTC QLQ-C30 Questionnaire by five aggregate scales with two underlying dimensions: A literature review and an empirical study.

LA- English
KP- European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire-C30
KP- illness perception
KP- cancer
KP- categorical principal component analysis
KP- health-related quality of life
SU- Cognitive Ability; Neoplasms; Psychometrics; Questionnaires; Test Validity
AB- The intercorrelations among the 15 scales of the 30-item Core version of the European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire suggest that one may combine (1) the physical functioning and role functioning scales, (2) the emotional functioning and cognitive functioning scales, and (3) the nine symptom scales. Together with the global health/quality of life scale and the social functioning scale, five measures remain. Principal component analysis of those five measures, using data from Japanese and Dutch breast and lung cancer patients, yielded two dimensions: (1) generalized health related quality of life and (2) health-independent psychological well-being. The correlations of these dimensions with the Brief Illness Perception Questionnaire and Karnofsky performance substantiated this interpretation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Is it helpful to give older people with cancer the same chance at rehabilitation as older general medical patients?

AF- Whitehall, C., Department of Physiotherapy, St. Vincent's Hospital, Melbourne, VIC, Australia

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 4
SD- Jul, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- Jul, 2014
PG- 396-412
PC- 17
SP- 396
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.917141
LA- English
KP- older people with cancer
KP- rehabilitation for older cancer patients
KP- ambulatory care for cancer patients
KP- allied health collaboration
KP- service planning
SU- Geriatric Patients; Medical Diagnosis; Neoplasms; Outpatient Treatment; Rehabilitation
AB- Although the complexity of age combined with a cancer diagnosis can result in unmet supportive care needs there are seldom resources to assess or address such needs for older people with cancer (OPWC). The purpose of this project was to trial a service to improve the care for OPWC through (1) an expanded supportive care screening process and (2) capacity building of subacute ambulatory care services (SACS) staff to increase referrals to community-based rehabilitation. Methods/design: Collaboration between allied health (AH) staff at an inner city general hospital with a large cancer service, a cancer specialist hospital, and a SACS service in Melbourne, Australia, developed an AH geriatric screening assessment (GSA) tool. Parallel to this process training was provided to SACS staff in relation to working with OPWC. Although close to one half (44%) of SACS staff who participated in this program (n = 22) had over 6 years’ experience, 32% had not worked with OPWC. Prior to training, 81% did not feel confident in their knowledge about working with this cohort. After their training 72% were more confident about normal aging and implications for care of OPWC. Of the 491 patients screened, 80% were older than age 65, however, only 25 resided in the SACS catchment area. More than one third of these did not have clear rehabilitation needs, and the remainder were not referred due to ongoing medical issues. Less than one half of the patients in the catchment area were discussed in a Multi-disciplinary Meeting (MDM) but all were referred to allied health and assessed using the GSA. Although this project did not result in referrals of OPWC to SACS the training program for SACS staff was a success and allied health assessments were improved to include GSA factors. The complexity of care for OPWC was further highlighted through interviews with staff involved with the study. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Psychiatric pathology and suicide risk in patients with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

AD- Pompili, Maurizio, Department of Neurosciences, Mental Health and Sensory Functions, Suicide Prevention Center, Sant’Andrea Hospital, Sapienza University of Rome, Via di Grottarossa 1035, 00189, Roma, Italy, maurizio.pompili@uniroma1.it
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 4
SD- Jul, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- Jul, 2014
PG- 383-395
PC- 13
SP- 383
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 13
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.917136
LA- English
KP- psychoncology
KP- cancer
KP- psychiatry
KP- suicide
SU- Neoplasms; Psychopathology; Suicidal Ideation; Suicide
AB- The aims of the study were to assess sociodemographic and clinical factors associated with suicidal ideation in patients with cancer who required a psycho-oncological support. Among 504 participants, there were 136 (23 men and 113 women) cancer patients who completed psychological assessment when admitted to the Psycho-oncology Outpatient Clinic between 2006 and 2011. Suicidal ideation was assessed by Item 9 of the Brief Symptom Inventory, Hopelessness was assessed by the hopelessness subscale of the Mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer Scale, and Depression was assessed by the depression subscale of the Hospital and Anxiety Depression Scale. Around 30% of this sample reported affective symptoms and around 20% reported suicidal ideation and hopelessness. Patients who reported suicidal ideation were more hopeless (18.8 ± 6.7 vs. 15.7 ± 5.2; t(134) = 2.54; p &lt; 0.05) and reported more depression (11.8 ± 4.8 vs. 6.8 ± 4.1; t(134) = 5.30; p &lt; 0.001). It is evident that cancer can result in a strong psychological distress in the patient. It is important, therefore, that cancer patients receive a proper assistance and psychological support and that both the possible presence of depression and suicidal ideation are constantly monitored. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- The role of helplines in cancer care: Intertwining emotional support with information or advice-seeking needs.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ekberg, Katie
AU- McDermott, Joanne
AU- Moynihan, Clare
AU- Brindle, Lucy
AU- Little, Paul
AU- Leydon, Geraldine M.
AF- Ekberg, Katie, k.ekberg@uq.edu.au, School of Health and Rehabilitation Science, University of Queensland, Brisbane, QLD, Australia
AF- McDermott, Joanne, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom
AF- Moynihan, Clare, Institute of Cancer Research, Royal Marsden, London, United Kingdom
AF- Brindle, Lucy, Faculty of Health Science, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom
AF- Little, Paul, University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom
AF- Leydon, Geraldine M., University of Southampton, Southampton, United Kingdom

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 3
SD- May, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- May, 2014
PG- 359-381
PC- 23
SP- 359
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 23
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.897294
LA- English
KP- helplines
KP- cancer care
KP- emotional support
KP- information seeking needs
KP- advice seeking needs
SU- Help Seeking Behavior; Hot Line Services; Information Seeking; Neoplasms; Social Support
AB- Helplines are core feature of the contemporary U.K. health care system, however little is known about callers’ experiences of seeking cancer-related telephone help. Qualitative interviews were conducted with 32 cancer helpline callers. The findings suggest cancer helplines offer callers (1) time to discuss their issues, (2) anonymity, (3) convenience, and (4) an open outlet for anyone affected by cancer including family/friends. Further, the findings highlighted that callers’ help-seeking behavior was multifaceted, with their psychosocial needs being intrinsically intertwined with their information or advice-seeking needs. The implications are discussed in relation to the role of cancer helplines in the healthcare system. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Help Seeking Behavior; Hot Line Services; Information Seeking; Neoplasms; Social Support
MN- Needs
CL- Cancer (3293)
CL- Community & Social Services (3373)
PO- Human (10)
PO- Male (30)
PO- Female (40)

TI- Anticipating posttraumatic growth from cancer: Patients’ and collaterals’ experiences.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Tallman, Benjamin A.
AU- Lohnberg, Jessica
AU- Yamada, Torricia H.
AU- Halfdanarson, Thorvardur R.
AU- Altmaier, Elizabeth M.
AF- Tallman, Benjamin A., tallmaba@crstlukes.com, Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation, St. Luke’s Hospital, Cedar Rapids, IA, US
AF- Lohnberg, Jessica, Psychology Service, Behavioral Medicine Program, VA Palo Alto Health Care System, Palo Alto, CA, US
AF- Yamada, Torricia H., Minneapolis VA Health Care System, Minneapolis, MN, US
AF- Halfdanarson, Thorvardur R., Department of Medicine, Mayo Clinic, Scottsdale, AZ, US
AF- Altmaier, Elizabeth M., Department of Psychological and Quantitative Foundations, University of Iowa, Iowa City, IA, US

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 3
SD- May, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- May, 2014
PG- 342-358
PC- 17
SP- 342
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print

DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.897291
LA- English
KP- anticipated posttraumatic growth
KP- cancer
KP- patient's experiences
KP- collaterals's experiences
KP- diagnosis
KP- treatment
SU- Life Experiences; Neoplasms; Patients; Posttraumatic Growth
AB- Posttraumatic growth has been demonstrated to occur following the diagnosis and treatment of cancer. Still unknown is whether patients expect such growth, how growth is perceived at early points in time that follow the cancer experience, and whether patient reports of growth are corroborated by others. Participants were 87 patients and 55 collaterals who reported their anticipation of growth pretreatment and their perceived growth at a 9-month follow-up. Patients' expectations for their own growth were significantly higher than collaterals' expectations for theirs. When anticipated growth was compared to later reported growth, patients overanticipated growth across all domains and collaterals underanticipated growth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Critical incidents reveal how patients with head and neck cancer construct their “secure base” as a “helping system”.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Isaksson, Joakim
AU- Salander, Pär
AU- Granström, Brith
AU- Laurell, Göran
AF- Isaksson, Joakim, Joakim.isaksson@socw.umu.se, Department of Social Work, Umea University, Umea, Sweden
AF- Salander, Pär, Department of Social Work, Umea University, Umea, Sweden
AF- Granström, Brith, Department of Clinical Sciences, Umea University, Umea, Sweden
AF- Laurell, Göran, Department of Surgical Sciences, Uppsala University, Uppsala, Sweden
AD- Isaksson, Joakim, Department of Social Work, Umea University, 901 87, Umea, Sweden, Joakim.isaksson@socw.umu.se
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 3
SD- May, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- May, 2014
PG- 322-341
PC- 20
SP- 322
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.897289
LA- English
KP- head and neck cancer
KP- psychosocial needs
KP- secure base
KP- helping system
KP- client experiences
KP- patient needs
SU- Health Care Delivery; Health Service Needs; Help Seeking Behavior; Life Experiences; Neoplasms
AB- Most studies of the psychosocial needs of patients with head and neck cancers (HNC) use predefined categories and explicitly ask for specified needs. These studies are important but should be complemented with inductive studies based on patients’ own descriptions of experiences. This qualitative study is such a contribution. In repeated interviews positive and negative incidents were collected from 137 patients with HNC, and these experiences were categorized in dimensions expressing needs. A core category—“being included—neglected by a helping system”— emerged from the narrated incidents and was based on the dimensions engagement, competence, and information. The findings are easily related to attachment theory by stressing the significance of establishing trustful relationships with the health care staff, as attachment figures, who respond flexibly and sensitively to the patient's needs. In the constitution of health care as a helping system, all encounters between the patient and health care staff matters. Further research should preferably focus on the creation of guidelines for the constitution of health care as a helping system, that is, how the found factors of a helping system can be operationalized in clinical practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Health Care Delivery; Health Service Needs; Help Seeking Behavior; Life Experiences; Neoplasms
MN- Client Attitudes; Clinical Practice; Psychosocial Factors; Quality of Care

LA- English
KP- feasibility
KP- online cognitive behavioral based group intervention
KP- adolescent childhood cancer survivors
SU- Cognitive Behavior Therapy; Group Psychotherapy; Neoplasms; Online Therapy; Survivors
AB- The objective of this study was to investigate satisfaction with and feasibility of an online cognitive behavioral-based group intervention (OK Onco Online) for adolescent childhood cancer survivors (CCS). The intervention, carried out by pediatric psychologists, aimed to prevent psychosocial problems. High levels of satisfaction were reported by the psychologists (n &equals; 6) and the CCS (n &equals; 11, age 11&ndash;17). The dropout rate was very low. Some recommendations for optimizing the intervention were mentioned. In conclusion, the positive evaluations by the CCS and the psychologists indicate that the online chat intervention OK Onco Online is a promising innovative group intervention for adolescent CCS. Further research is needed to confirm feasibility and to establish efficacy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Reconceptualizing cancer survivorship through veterans’ lived experiences.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Martin, Lindsey Ann
AU- Moye, Jennifer
AU- Street, Richard L. Jr.

LA- English
KP- cancer
KP- veteran older adult survivors
KP- illness experiences
KP- biopsychosocial impact
SU- Life Experiences; Military Veterans; Neoplasms; Survivors
AB- This study assessed the biopsychosocial impact of cancer on veteran older adult survivors by garnering their accounts of their illness experiences. A narrative analysis of 73 cancer diagnosis and treatment stories reveals five "paths" veterans are taking 18 months postdiagnosis. These paths indicate that cancer survivorship cannot be conceptualized as a one-size-fits-all experience but rather is a process of veterans understanding and making sense of the effects of cancer on their lives. Our future goal is to develop a screening tool to help clinicians identify a patient's "path" to tailor survivorship care to meet specific needs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- The influence of culture on couples coping with breast cancer: A comparative analysis of couples from China, India, and the United States.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Kayser, Karen
AU- Cheung, Peter K. H.
AU- Rao, Nalini
AU- Chan, Yuen Chun L.
AU- Chan, Yu
AU- Lo, Phyllis H. Y.
AF- Kayser, Karen, karen.kayser@louisville.edu, Kent School of Social Work, University of Louisville, Louisville, KY, US
AF- Cheung, Peter K. H., Centre on Behavioral Health, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China
AF- Rao, Nalini, Madras School of Social Work, Madras University, Chennai, India
AF- Chan, Yuen Chun L., Centre on Behavioral Health, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China

AF- Lo, Phyllis H. Y., Centre on Behavioral Health, University of Hong Kong, Hong Kong, China

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32

PG- 264-288
PC- 25
SP- 264
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press

DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.897292
LA- English
KP- couples
KP- breast cancer
KP- cultural influences
KP- dyadic coping
KP- couple-based interventions
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Couples Therapy; Cross Cultural Differences; Sociocultural Factors
AB- This study examines the process of dyadic coping among couples who are managing stress related to a partner's breast cancer diagnosis and identifies cultural factors that affect how couples cope together. Utilizing a qualitative method based on relational psychologies, the “Listening Guide,” the authors analyzed the narratives of 28 couples who where coping with early-stage breast cancer and lived in Hong Kong-China, India, and the United States. Analysis revealed four cultural factors influencing the process of coping with breast cancer. These factors included (1) family boundaries, (2) gender roles, (3) personal control, and (4) interdependence. Some couples were able to transcend prevailing cultural norms to re-establish balance in their lives and adapt to the cancer. Implications for using couple-based interventions with cancer patients in differing cultural contexts are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- The role of social support in posttreatment surveillance among African American survivors of colorectal cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Le, Daisy
AU- Holt, Cheryl L.
AU- Pisu, Maria
AU- Brown-Galvan, Aquila
AU- Fairley, Temeika L.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 3
SD- May, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- May, 2014
PG- 245-263
PC- 19
SP- 245
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print

DO- 10.1080/07347332.2014.897293
LA- English
KP- social support
KP- colorectal cancer
KP- post-treatment surveillance
KP- African American survivors
SU- Colon Disorders; Neoplasms; Posttreatment Followup; Social Support; Survivors
AB- African Americans are less likely than other groups to receive appropriate surveillance after colorectal cancer (CRC) treatment. The objective of this study is to qualitatively explore the role of social support in post-CRC treatment surveillance and ultimately, inform interventions to promote surveillance in African American survivors of CRC. Interviews were conducted with 60 African American survivors of CRC recruited from the Cancer Care Outcomes Research and Surveillance (CanCORS) study and the Alabama Statewide Cancer Registry. Interviews were recorded and transcribed. Transcripts were reviewed and coded independently by the authors. The NVivo software package was used to facilitate coding and data management. Survivors were from 4 to 6 years post diagnosis, 57% female, 60% older than age 65 years, 57% from rural Alabama, 30% with stage 1, 32% with stage 2, and 38% with stage 3 disease. Material and emotional social support from family and one's faith community were cited as playing an important role in coping with the disease and posttreatment surveillance. Survivors who reported being adherent with posttreatment surveillance recommendations (according to stage of disease based on self-report of colonoscopy, computed tomography scans, and blood work) reported more religious material and non-material social support, and support from other survivors of CRC. In these African American survivors of CRC, support from family, other survivors of cancer, and the faith community was perceived as being important for adherence to posttreatment surveillance. Interventions to increase posttreatment surveillance in this population may be enhanced by including components that emphasize familial, other cancer survivor, and religious support. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Camper learning and friendship at pediatric oncology camps in North America.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Martiniuk, Alexandra L. C.
AU- Amylon, Michael D.
AU- Briery, Brandon G.
AU- Shea-Perry, Marci
AU- Kelsey, Kathleen P.

AU- Körver, Sarah
AF- Martiniuk, Alexandra L. C., amartiniuk@georgeinstitute.org.au, George Institute, Sydney, NSW, Australia
AF- Amylon, Michael D., Stanford University, Stanford, CA, US
AF- Briery, Brandon G., Children’s Association for Maximum Potential, Center Point, TX, US
AF- Shea-Perry, Marci, Trillium Childhood Cancer Support Center, Waterford, ON, Canada
AF- Kelsey, Kathleen P., BC Camp Goodtimes, Vancouver, BC, Canada
AF- Lam, Gary W., BC Camp Goodtimes, Vancouver, BC, Canada
AF- Körver, Sarah, University of Sydney, Sydney, NSW, Australia
AD- Martiniuk, Alexandra L. C., Faculty of Medicine, George Institute for Global Health, Level 13, 321 Kent St., Sydney, NSW, Australia, 2000, amartiniuk@georgeinstitute.org.au
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 32
IP- 2
SD- Mar, 2014
YR- 2014
PM- Mar, 2014
PG- 234-244
PC- 11
SP- 234
PU- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
P2- US : Haworth Press
PN- 11
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1080/07347332.2013.874001
LA- English
KP- camper learning
KP- friendship
KP- pediatric oncology camps
KP- therapeutic recreation
SU- Friendship; Pediatrics; Therapeutic Camps; Oncology
AB- Children with cancer and their families often attend specialized camps (therapeutic recreation) through their cancer treatment journey, yet little is known about the effects of these camps. A qualitative cohort study was used to assess learning and friendship development by campers attending one of four pediatric oncology summer camps during 2010 in North America. Standardized perceived change questionnaires developed by the American Camp Association were administered following camp attendance. Five-hundred and eighteen campers were enrolled: 120 (age 6–9 years) and 398 (age 10 and older). The largest positive response from the younger campers was observed for the question, “At camp did you learn to look forward to trying new activities?” For the older campers’ survey, the items “Becoming better at enjoying being with my friends,” “Becoming better at helping my friends have a good time when they are with me,” and “Becoming better at getting to know more things about my friends” were perceived to increase the most for the majority of campers compared to other questions. Items for which older campers most often perceived little change were “Becoming better at choosing people who would be good friends to be with” and “Becoming better at understanding friends’ emotions.” Camp helps children learn new activities as well as enjoy good times with friends. Dealing with one's own mistakes and understanding others’ emotions are areas for improvement. Ultimately it is hoped that these skills gained at camp will help build coping and resiliency for children/siblings affected by pediatric cancers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2014 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Friendship; Pediatrics; Therapeutic Camps; Oncology

TI- Smoking related cancers: A brief report on problem solving, distress, and risk behaviors in patients and caregivers.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

AU- Pinto, Bernardine M.
