TI- Locating breast cancer in the context of women's lives.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Vickberg, Suzanne M. Johnson
AF- Vickberg, Suzanne M. Johnson, suzanne.vickberg@ppfa.org, Planned Parenthood Federation of America, Change Initiatives, New York, NY, US
AD- Vickberg, Suzanne M. Johnson, Planned Parenthood Federation of America, 434 West 33rd Street, New York, NY, US, 10001, suzanne.vickberg@ppfa.org
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 21
IP- 2
SD- 2003
YR- 2003
PM- 2003
PG- 69-88
PC- 20
SP- 69
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v21n02_05
LA- English
KP- breast cancer
KP- distress
KP- negative life circumstances
KP- adjustment
SU- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Distress
AB- Research has generally suggested that positive life circumstances may help alleviate the distress brought on by breast cancer. Little attention has been paid to the effects of negative life circumstances on women's adjustment to the disease. In this study, 110 women answered in writing an open-ended question about life circumstances (positive, negative, or both) that they perceived to have influenced their experience with breast cancer. Many women described both positive and negative circumstances, but negative circumstances were reported more commonly. The women described 28% of the negative circumstances as more salient or more distressing than breast cancer; these circumstances were coded as "negative distracting" circumstances. Exploratory regression analyses found that positive circumstances were associated with better adjustment and negative circumstances were associated with poorer adjustment. In addition, distracting circumstances were associated with better adjustment. Findings suggest that considering breast cancer in the context of women's lives is important. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Distress

TI- A review of peer support in the context of cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Dunn, Jeff
AU- Steginga, Suzanne K.
AU- Rosoman, Nicholas
AU- Millichap, David
AF- Dunn, Jeff, jdunn@qldcancer.com.au, Queensland Cancer Fund, Spring Hill, QLD, Australia
AF- Steginga, Suzanne K., Queensland Cancer Fund, Spring Hill, QLD, Australia
AF- Rosoman, Nicholas, Queensland Cancer Fund, Spring Hill, QLD, Australia
AF- Millichap, David, Queensland Cancer Fund, Spring Hill, QLD, Australia
AD- Dunn, Jeff, Queensland Cancer Fund, P. O. Box 201, Spring Hill, QLD, Australia, 4004, jdunn@qldcancer.com.au
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 21
IP- 2
SD- 2003
YR- 2003
PM- 2003
PG- 55-67
PC- 13
SP- 55
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 13
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v21n02_04
LA- English
KP- peer support
KP- cancer
KP- psychosocial oncology
SU- Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Social Support
AB- Reviewed the research literature on psychosocial oncology over the past decade to assess the prevalence and contribution of articles on peer support. Using CD-Rom databases, 25 articles were retrieved for review. In each article, patients or their family members were the target group for supportive interventions, which were primarily for the delivery of peer support and included either a qualitative or quantitative evaluation of the program. A definitional taxonomy for peer support interventions, which identified eight discrete settings, was derived from three key dimensions: style of supervision, interpersonal context, and mode of delivery. The studies suggested that peer support programs help by providing emotional and informational support from the perspective of shared personal experience. However, a paucity of research-particularly randomized controlled trials-was noted. The reasons may include inherent difficulties in isolating for study what is essentially a naturalistically occurring interpersonal dynamic from the complex social and community contexts from which it emanates. The authors discuss the gap between practice and theory in this area and recommend a broader and more inclusive view of supportive care for people with cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Social Support
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)

TI- Attitudes of patients with breast cancer toward support groups.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Winefield, Helen R.
AU- Coventry, Brendon J.
AU- Lewis, Meg
AU- Harvey, Eileen J.
AF- Winefield, Helen R., hwinefield@medicine.adelaide.edu.au, U Adelaide, Dept of Psychiatry, Adelaide, SA, Australia

SN- 0734-7332, Print

DO- 10.1300/J077v21n02_03
LA- English
KP- patient attitudes
KP- breast cancer
KP- support groups
KP- psychosocial characteristics
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Client Attitudes; Psychosocial Factors; Support Groups
AB- This study explored the psychosocial characteristics of women with a recent diagnosis of breast cancer who were or were not interested in joining support groups. Ninety-three women using breast cancer services at a teaching hospital were interviewed about their decision to attend or not attend a support group. At an average of 7.4 months after the diagnosis, 21.5% of the women had attended a support group, whereas 59.1% reported they would not attend. Attenders were likely to be better educated, to live outside the metropolitan area, and to report poorer mental health. Exploring interviewees' reasons for their decision allowed suggestions for promoting attendance for women who may benefit from attending a support group: explain clearly at the recruitment stage what groups offer, perhaps using videos or testimonials; consider routine screening for psychological distress or perceptions of inadequate support: and accept that many women will feel no need to participate in a support group and probably should not be pressed to do so. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Client Attitudes; Psychosocial Factors; Support Groups

TI- Improving community cancer care: Bringing psychosocial support to a private practice.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Fedorchuk, Mary Kay
AU- Mendiondo, Oscar A.
AU- Matar, Jacqueline R.

LA- English
KP- community cancer care
KP- psychosocial support
KP- radiation oncology
KP- psychosocial assessment
SU- Cancer Screening; Community Services; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Social Support
AB- To address the needs of patients presenting to a radiation oncology practice, a psychosocial assessment was integrated into the initial evaluation. This article presents the findings in 902 19-98 yr old patients evaluated during a two-year period. Although interventions were clustered around groups with poor prognoses and lower economic background, a considerable number of patients with better outlook and support required or benefited from counseling, education, or referral to community resources. The authors propose that psychosocial assessment and proactive interventions should be part of the initial care of every patient diagnosed with cancer. Partnering with agencies with similar goals puts this approach within reach of private practices. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Complementary and alternative medicine: Its emerging role in oncology.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Goldstein, Michael S.
AF- Goldstein, Michael S., msgoldst@ucla.edu, U California, School of Public Health, Los Angeles, CA, US
AD- Goldstein, Michael S., School of Public Health, U California, P. O. Box 951772, Los Angeles, CA, US, 90095-1772, msgoldst@ucla.edu
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 21
IP- 2
SD- 2003
YR- 2003
PM- 2003
PG- 1-21
PC- 21
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v21n02_01
LA- English
KP- complementary and alternative medicine
KP- oncology
KP- patient response
KP- psychosocial oncology
KP- cancer
SU- Alternative Medicine; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment; Oncology
AB- Complementary and alternative medicine (CAM) is a growing aspect of how patients respond to having cancer. CAM is not solely a set of clinical interventions, it is a broad social movement that seeks to recast the meaning of health and illness. Professionals in psychosocial oncology need such a perspective to truly understand why patients are turning toward CAM. CAM's appeal emerges from its five core beliefs: holism, vitalism, spirituality, a positive definition of health, and a distinctive view of the healing process. These five beliefs are well matched to how many people with cancer experience their bodies and illness, and they also form a coherent response to the difficulties many patients have when dealing with conventional medicine. Increasingly, some elements in conventional medicine are accepting of CAM. Hospital chains, managed care organizations, drug companies, and retailers of health care products are less likely to make sharp distinctions between CAM and conventional care. CAM is likely to continue growing as a factor in the professional lives of health professionals who deal with cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Alternative Medicine; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment; Oncology
CL- Cancer (3293)
CL- Specialized Interventions (3350)
PO- Human (10)

TI- Sisyphus and Other Everyday Heroes.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Schnipper, Hester Hill
AF- Schnipper, Hester Hill, hhill@bidmc.harvard.edu, Department of Hematology/Oncology, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Boston, MA, US
AD- Schnipper, Hester Hill, Department of Hematology/Oncology, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, 330 Brookline Avenue, Boston, MA, US, 02115, hhill@bidmc.harvard.edu
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 21
IP- 1
SD- 2003
YR- 2003
PM- 2003
PG- 1-5
PC- 5
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 5
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v21n01_05
LA- English
KP- professional growth
KP- work conference
KP- personal lives
KP- primary reason
KP- social worker
KP- breast cancer
KP- social work
KP- heavy load
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Metaphor; Occupational Success; Social Workers; Work (Attitudes Toward)
AB- Sisyphus has long been a central metaphor for my work. Sharing this myth at a national oncology social work conference many years ago was the beginning of my real professional growth. It clearly struck a chord for many who work day-in, day-out to lighten the burden for others while shouldering a heavy load themselves. In thinking about what oncology social workers do and about courage, I did a lot of reading about heroism. I have been an oncology social worker for 24 years, and I have been a woman living with breast cancer for 10 years. This juxtaposition of my professional and personal lives has taken me on a journey with rewards beyond measure. It becomes increasingly clear that we DO make a difference. There most certainly are situations in which no one can take away the pain, but someone who dares to be human can blunt some of the terror and share some of the sadness. We must become exquisitely aware of our own feelings. We must take care that our own need to be needed--one primary reason we do this work--does not dominate us and our relationships. We do not have to be, and cannot be, "omnicompetent" or a supercaregiver. We must keep our antennae well oiled so we notice when we are feeling irreplaceable. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Metaphor; Occupational Success; Social Workers; Work (Attitudes Toward)
MN- Heroes

AU- Morris, Robin D.

LA- English
KP- children with brain tumors
KP- long term behavior
KP- social problems
KP- social competence
KP- behavioral outcomes
KP- risk factors
SU- Behavior Problems; Brain Neoplasms; Social Skills
AB- This study investigated long-term social and behavioral outcomes in 40 children with brain tumors. Demographic, medical, cognitive, and psychosocial predictors at short-term follow-up at Time 1 (one to two years postdiagnosis) were used to predict long-term social and behavioral outcomes three to four years after diagnosis (Time 2). Below-average social competence and average overall behavioral ratings were reported at Time 2. Multiple medical treatments and lower social competence scores at Time 1 were significant predictors of long-term difficulties concerning social competence, whereas lower socioeconomic status and higher total scores regarding behavior problems at Time 1 were the best predictors of long-term behavioral problems. The results of the study have implications for mental health screening and intervention during the early years after diagnosis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Evaluating a Volunteer Cancer Support Service.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Edgar, Linda J.
AU- Remmer, Jean
AU- Rosberger, Zeev
AU- Rapkin, Bruce
AF- Edgar, Linda J., linda.edgar@nuhc.mcgill.ca, Faculty of Medicine, McGill University, Montreal, PQ, Canada
AF- Remmer, Jean, Hope and Cope, Department of Oncology, Montreal, PQ, Canada

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 21

LA- English
KP- cancer support service
KP- Hope & Cope
KP- breast cancer
KP- colon cancer
KP- psychosocial distress
KP- functional well being
KP- optimism
KP- needs
KP- social support organizations
SU- Family Members; Neoplasms; Support Groups; Well Being
AB- Hope and Cope, a voluntary self-help organization cancer patients and their families, was evaluated as part of a randomized controlled clinical trial of newly diagnosed patients with breast or colon cancer. Measures of psychosocial distress, functional well-being, and optimism were evaluated four months after diagnosis (Time 1) and eight months later (Time 2). There were differences between the users and nonusers at Time 1: Users of Hope and Cope had greater needs but became more satisfied regarding resolution of their needs at Time 2 than did nonparticipants. The outcome of physical well-being was significantly higher for those who took part in Hope and Cope. Participants of voluntary support organizations appear to make appropriate choices on the basis of their needs. Issues of patients' preference have not been given sufficient attention in psychosocial oncology research and may influence the results of such studies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Like a Cleansing Fire: Exploring the Impact of Short-Term Support Groups for Women with Breast Cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Avery, Joanne
AU- Nyhof-Young, Joyce
AF- Avery, Joanne, Joanne.avery@uhn.on.ca, Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, ON, Canada
AF- Nyhof-Young, Joyce, Princess Margaret Hospital, Toronto, ON, Canada
AD- Avery, Joanne, Psychosocial Oncology and Palliative Care, Princess Margaret Hospital, Room 5-612, 610 University Avenue, Toronto, ON, Canada, M5G 2M9, Joanne.avery@uhn.on.ca
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 21
IP- 1
SD- 2003
YR- 2003

PG- 27-51

PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- breast cancer
KP- women's short term support groups
KP- psychoeducational support groups
KP- coping skills
KP- psychosocial issues
KP- psychosocial needs
KP- emotional support
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Human Females; Psychoeducation; Psychosocial Factors; Support Groups
AB- A follow-up questionnaire was administered in 1995 to 26 of 34 women (8 had died) who had attended six psychoeducational support groups for women with breast cancer held between 1990 and 1993. The questionnaire had a response rate of 46% and revealed long-term effects on the participants' adjustment and coping abilities. Results are discussed qualitatively regarding the informational and psychosocial needs of patients with breast cancer. Benefits of the group for these women included acquisition of new information, increased long-term coping skills, spiritual and emotional support, and assistance with psychosocial issues (e.g., self-concept, sharing, emotional expression, family/relationships). Also discussed are issues affecting the groups' success, including patient engagement, structural issues (group topics and size, heterogeneity of membership), the diverse learning styles, patients' needs and levels of literacy, the facilitator's role, and the role of talk and trust in support groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Human Females; Psychoeducation; Psychosocial Factors; Support Groups

TI- Depressive Symptoms in Cancer Patients Compared with People from the General Population: The Role of Sociodemographic and Medical Factors.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Schroevers, Maya J.
AU- Ranchor, Adelita V.
AU- Sanderman, Robbert
AF- Schroevers, Maya J., mschroevers@mesos.nl, Northern Centre for Healthcare Research, Department of Health Sciences, University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands
AF- Ranchor, Adelita V., Northern Centre for Healthcare Research, Department of Health Sciences, University of Groningen, Groningen, Netherlands

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 21
IP- 1

LA- English
KP- depressive symptoms
KP- cancer patients
KP- medical factors
KP- sociodemographic factors
KP- cancer diagnosis
KP- risk factors
SU- Major Depression; Neoplasms; Risk Factors; Symptoms
AB- This study examined depressive symptoms in 475 patients with cancer and in a reference group of 255 individuals without cancer from the general population and the associations of those symptoms with sociodemographic and medical factors. Depressive symptoms were measured at 3 months (Time 1) and 15 months (Time 2) after diagnosis. Patients reported more depressive symptoms than the reference group did at Times 1 and 2. Younger age, specially, was related to the onset of depressive symptoms after a cancer diagnosis. Better-educated patients and those with a lower stage of disease reported a greater decrease in depressive symptoms over time. The authors conclude that certain sociodemographic factors may primarily reflect general dysfunction or vulnerability rather than risk factors for developing depressive symptoms after a diagnosis of cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20

LA- English
KP- long term cancer survivors
KP- older adults
KP- health
KP- racial differences
KP- African Americans
KP- Whites
KP- demographic factors
SU- Demographic Characteristics; Health; Neoplasms; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Survivors
AB- This article focuses on differences between African-American and White older adults who were long-term survivors of cancer regarding reported health problems, symptoms of illness, functional difficulties, health worries and concerns, and overall perceptions of health. A conceptual model examined the relationship between demographic factors (e.g., race, age, cancer- and treatment-related factors) and perceptions of health (e.g., burden of disability, health concerns and worries, and self-rated global health). Regression analysis examined quantitative data from in-person interviews with 180 survivors (older than 58 years of age) of breast, colorectal, or prostate cancer obtained from the tumor registry of the Ireland Cancer Center at University Hospitals Health System of Cleveland. African Americans were oversampled to represent 50% of the total sample. The analysis indicated that African Americans experienced poorer functional health after cancer, even after disease and treatment factors were controlled for. However, compared with White survivors, African Americans did not report significantly more symptoms attributed to either cancer or its treatment, suggesting that their poorer health after cancer may not have been a result of either factor but to other comorbid conditions... (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Hear how I feel: Evaluation of a video depicting the experiences of adolescents and young adults with a parent diagnosed with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Damore-Petingola, Sheila
AU- Lightfoot, Nancy
AU- Vaillancourt, Chantal
AU- Mayer, Carole
AU- Steggles, Shawn
AU- Gauthier-Frohlick, Denise
AF- Damore-Petingola, Sheila, sdamore-petingola@neorcc.on.ca, Northeastern Ontario Regional Cancer Centre, Supportive Care Program, Sudbury, ON, Canada
AF- Lightfoot, Nancy, Northeastern Ontario Regional Cancer Centre, Epidemiology Research Unit, Sudbury, ON, Canada
AF- Vaillancourt, Chantal, Northeastern Ontario Regional Cancer, Supportive Care Program, Sudbury, ON, Canada
AF- Mayer, Carole, Sudbury Regional Breast Health Program, Sudbury, ON, Canada
AF- Steggles, Shawn, Northeastern Ontario Regional Cancer, Supportive Care Oncology Program, Sudbury, ON, Canada

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 4
SD- 2002
YR- 2002
PM- 2002
PG- 57-69
PC- 13
SP- 57
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 13
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n04_04
LA- English
KP- high school population
KP- educational video presentation
KP- cancer
KP- evaluation
SU- Educational Audiovisual Aids; Evaluation; High Schools; Neoplasms; Videotapes
AB- In an effort to heighten the awareness of the high school population, a support group program for young people whose parents were diagnosed with cancer received funding to produce an educational video titled Hear How I Feel. This article reports on the evaluation of the video by 146 high school teachers, guidance counselors, and students; elementary school teachers; university undergraduate social work students; and health care and social service providers. A qualitative analysis of the evaluations indicated that high school teachers and guidance counselors were reluctant to use the video in the high school setting because they could not respond expertly to emotions that might be elicited. The findings suggest that youths desire a forum in which difficult issues can be addressed, teachers and guidance counselors need training that would enhance their skill in responding to students' emotional responses, and cancer patients and their families have psychosocial needs that must be met. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Educational Audiovisual Aids; Evaluation; High Schools; Neoplasms; Videotapes
CL- Curriculum & Programs & Teaching Methods (3530)

TI- Relational coping processes: Couples' response to a diagnosis of early stage breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Zunkel, Gretchen
AF- Zunkel, Gretchen, zunke004@umn.edu, Arizona State U, Coll of Nursing, Tempe, AZ, US
AD- Zunkel, Gretchen, School of Nursing, U Minnesota, 6-101 Weaver-Densford Hall, 308 Harvard Street S.E., Minneapolis, MN, US, 55455-0342, zunke004@umn.edu
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 4
SD- 2002
YR- 2002

PG- 39-55
PC- 17
SP- 39
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n04_03
LA- English
KP- breast cancer diagnosis
KP- coping strategies
KP- couple relationships
KP- partner response
KP- emotional recovery
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Couples; Diagnosis; Emotional Adjustment
AB- A diagnosis of breast cancer requires a woman to cope with a variety of physical and psychosocial challenges that are not faced in isolation. Interpersonal relationships are the context for appraisal, development of coping strategies, and defining of resources for adaptation to a serious illness. Of particular interest is the couple relationship. The level of complexity in understanding the process of adaptation is far greater when considering the impact of each partner's response on the other partner's coping strategies and the interactive management of the emotional recovery. The purpose of this study was to understand the specific processes that developed within the partner relationship as the couple began the process of recovery. Case-intensive interview data were analyzed using an interpretive methodology to construct the dyadic process of the woman and her partner. Ss were 15 couples (men ranged in age from 30 to 54 years; women from 29 to 51 years). The data analysis revealed two types of processes: one process in which the patient's and partner's thoughts, feelings, and emotions were acknowledged; the other in which their thoughts, feelings, and emotions were moderated or minimized in some way. These patterns were present across couples. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Preferences for psychosocial interventions among newly diagnosed cancer patients from a multiethnic population.

LA- English
KP- newly diagnosed cancer patients
KP- psychosocial interventions
KP- preferences
KP- multiethnic population
SU- Health Care Utilization; Intervention; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Racial and Ethnic Groups
AB- This article addresses preferences for psychosocial interventions in newly diagnosed cancer patients in a multiethnic sample consisting of Americans of European, Filipino, Native Hawaiian, and Japanese ancestry. Patients who were diagnosed with cancer four to six months before the study were identified through consecutive registrations on the Hawai'i Tumor Registry. Data were collected through personal interviews using a standardized questionnaire. Among 194 patients who participated in the study, 162 (84%) reported experiencing cancer-related stress. Although few patients had participated in supportive interventions, there was considerable interest in these techniques. Most patients had received information about diagnosis and treatment, but only 10% had received information about psychological counseling. When preferences for supportive interventions were linked with demographic characteristics (e.g., gender, age, and ethnicity), the most consistent finding was higher levels of interest among Filipino patients. Additional research examining ethnic differences in preferences for psychosocial support is warranted. Because of the potential for greater use of behavioral therapies by patients, educating providers about the availability, efficacy, and patients' interest in such... (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

LA- English
KP- cancer patients
KP- physical activity
KP- barriers
KP- exercise therapy
KP- disease symptoms
KP- treatment
SU- Exercise; Neoplasms; Patients; Physical Therapy; Treatment
AB- For individuals who experience cancer, regular adherence to physical activity has been shown to provide benefits ranging from alleviation of symptoms to improvements in physical function and quality of life. However, research about barriers to participation that compromise adherence and subsequent benefits has been identified as needed. The purposes of this article were to (1) systematically review the barriers to research and make recommendations, (2) consider unique symptoms of disease and treatment regarding their barrier-related impact on exercise therapy, and (3) present an organizational framework that will aid the investigation and understanding of barriers as they affect adherence to prescribed exercise therapy for cancer treatment and recovery. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

TI- Posttraumatic growth in women with breast cancer and their husbands: An intersubjective validation study.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology

LA- English
KP- posttraumatic growth
KP- stressful event
KP- breast cancer
KP- cancer experience
KP- personal growth
KP- husbands
KP- wives
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Development; Posttraumatic Stress Disorder; Spouses; Survivors
AB- In the aftermath of a severely stressful event, in addition to reporting negative changes, people also report personal growth. The degree to which reports of posttraumatic growth by 41 women (aged 37-72 yrs old) who survived breast cancer could be corroborated by their husbands was examined. Because the breast cancer experience is an equally stressful event for husbands and may present an opportunity for growth, the degree to which the husbands' reports of posttraumatic growth could be corroborated by their wives also was examined. Moderate positive correlations provided intersubjective validation of individuals' perceptions of posttraumatic growth. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Relations among social support, coping, and negative affect in hospitalized and nonhospitalized cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Hudek-Knežević, Jasna
AU- Kardum, Igor
AU- Pahljina, Rosanda
AF- Hudek-Knežević, Jasna, hudekj@human.pefri.hr, U Rijeka, Dept of Psychology, Rijeka, Croatia
AF- Kardum, Igor, U Rijeka, Dept of Psychology, Rijeka, Croatia
AF- Pahljina, Rosanda, U Rijeka, Dept of Psychology, Rijeka, Croatia
AD- Hudek-Knežević, Jasna, U Rijeka, Dept of Psychology, 5100 Rijeka, I, Klobucarica 1, Croatia, hudekj@human.pefri.hr
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 2
SD- 2002
YR- 2002
PM- 2002
PG- 45-63
PC- 19
SP- 45
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n02_03
LA- English
KP- social support
KP- coping strategies
KP- negative affect
KP- women
KP- breast cancer
KP- gynecological cancer
SU- Coping Behavior; Emotional States; Neoplasms; Social Support
AB- This study examined the effects of 3 sources of perceived social support and 4 coping strategies on measures of negative affect among 44 hospitalized and nonhospitalized women (aged 39-75 yrs old) with breast or gynecological cancer undergoing radiation therapy. The results showed different patterns of relations between the variables in the 2 groups of patients. Among hospitalized patients, support from medical staff and family and problem-oriented coping were the most significant predictors of negative affect. Among nonhospitalized patients, the most significant predictors of negative affect were family support, physical isolation/suppression of emotions, and avoidance coping. The results concerning the relationship between social support and coping strategies among hospitalized patients showed that support from medical staff was a positive predictor of problem-oriented coping, whereas friends' support was a negative predictor of physical isolation/suppression of emotions among nonhospitalized patients. Although the hypothesis of social support as coping assistance was confirmed to some extent, the results suggest that social support does not exert its effects of reducing negative affect predominantly through coping strategies; its effects are direct. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Emotional States; Neoplasms; Social Support

TI- How everyday life is affected: An interview study of relatives of men suffering from testicular cancer.

LA- English
KP- testicular cancer
KP- men
KP- relatives
KP- family members
KP- experiences
KP- attitudes
KP- relations
SU- Attitudes; Family Members; Neoplasms; Testes
AB- The aim of this study was to describe, by means of explorative interviews, the experiences of relatives (mothers, fathers, and wives) of male family members (aged 22-45 yrs old) suffering from testicular cancer. The central questions concerned how the disease and its treatment affected the life of the family, how its daily routines were affected, the form of relationships and closeness during the period of the disease, and how the future was given shape. The results revealed four main themes presented by the relatives during the interviews: the disease and its course, normalization, the long-term consequences of the disease, and the social network. The results showed that relatives of men suffering from cancer live in a vulnerable situation characterized by social isolation. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Mothers of survivors of childhood cancer: Their worries and concerns.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Zebrack, Brad
AU- Chesler, Mark
AU- Orbuch, Terri L.
AU- Parry, Carla
AF- Zebrack, Brad, U California Los Angeles, School of Medicine, Dept of Pediatrics, Los Angeles, CA, US
AF- Chesler, Mark, mchesler@umich.edu, U Michigan, Ctr for Research on Social Organization, Ann Arbor, MI, US
AF- Orbuch, Terri L., Oakland U, Rochester, NY, US
AF- Parry, Carla, U Michigan, Sociology & Social Work, Ann Arbor, MI, US

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 2
SD- 2002
YR- 2002
PM- 2002
PG- 1-25
PC- 25
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 25
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n02_01
LA- English
KP- mothers
KP- survivors
KP- childhood cancer
KP- worries
SU- Anxiety; Mothers; Neoplasms; Survivors
AB- Numerous studies have examined the psychosocial effects of childhood cancer on teenage and young adult survivors. Yet, there is relatively little research on the consequences of survivorship for the parents of these people. This study explored the realities of life for mothers of survivors of childhood cancer. Data from self-report questionnaires with 167 mothers of survivors and follow-up intensive interviews with 29 of them were analyzed. Findings indicated that mothers' worries were not so much a function of "objective" physical consequences of their child's illness. Instead, their worries were significantly related primarily to their own perceptions of their child's worries and the meanings they attached to their own and their child's cancer experience. The implications of the results for intervention with survivors of childhood cancer and their families include hospital-organized information and education programs; supportive counseling; meetings with other parents; and, for parents whose children have actual limitations, supportive rehabilitation services. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Anxiety; Mothers; Neoplasms; Survivors
MN- Mother Child Relations; Parental Attitudes

TI- Decision making about treatment of hypothetical prostate cancer: Is deferring a decision an expert-opinion heuristic?
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Steginga, Suzanne K.
AU- Occhipinti, Stephano
AF- Steginga, Suzanne K., Griffith U, School of Applied Psychology, Nathan, QLD, Australia
AF- Occhipinti, Stephano, S.Occhipinti@mailbox.gu.edu.au, Griffith U, School of Applied Psychology, Nathan, QLD, Australia
AD- Occhipinti, Stephano, Griffith U, School of Applied Psychology, Mt. Gravatt Campus, Nathan, QLD, Australia, 4111, S.Occhipinti@mailbox.gu.edu.au
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 3
SD- 2002
YR- 2002
PM- 2002
PG- 69-84
PC- 16
SP- 69
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n03_05
LA- English
KP- prostate cancer
KP- sociodemographic variables
KP- treatment decisions
KP- ambuguity
KP- risk
KP- psychological variables
KP- decision making involvement
KP- decision making deferment
KP- expert opinion heuristic
SU- Client Characteristics; Decision Making; Involvement; Neoplasms; Treatment Planning
AB- Men diagnosed with prostate cancer must make decisions about medical treatment in a context of high uncertainty. However, when making decisions about treatment, many men prefer to defer decision-making responsibility to their physician. An exploratory study investigated the effect of varying ambiguity and risk and relevant psychological and sociodemographic variables on men's desire for involvement in decision making in a hypothetical treatment scenario. A self-report questionnaire was administered by mail to a community sample of 705 men (aged 26-83 yrs) who were part of an ongoing study into men's health. In addition, the men were randomly allocated to four experimental groups for a 2×2 manipulation of high and low ambiguity with high and low risk for one of four scenarios for choices of treatment. Varying risk and ambiguity did not affect men's desire for involvement in decision making. Deferral of decision-making responsibility to the physician was predicted by high powerful others, low internal locus of control, a preference for black-and-white thinking, and lower levels of education. The results provided preliminary support for the conceptualization of deferral of decision-making responsibility to the physician as a shortcut--the expert-opinion heuristic. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Characteristics; Decision Making; Involvement; Neoplasms; Treatment Planning
MN- Demographic Characteristics; Heuristics; Human Males; Prostate; Psychosocial Factors

LA- English
KP- coping style
KP- quality of life
KP- men
KP- prostate cancer
KP- support group
SU- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Prostate; Quality of Life; Support Groups
AB- This study examined the coping style and quality of life of men who attended a prostate cancer support group. 14 men who attended the support group and 37 controls were assessed using the Mini-Mental Adjustment to Cancer scale (M. Watson et al, 1988) and the 36-item Health Survey. Men in the support group endorsed a coping style of anxious preoccupation and a coping style with low helplessness and hopelessness and high fighting spirit. The Health Survey measured no significant difference in quality of life. Only 3% of the controls reported that they would have attended a support group if they had known about it. 40% said they would not attend, and 57% were not sure. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Women like me: Reflections on health and hormones from women treated for breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bond, Barbara
AU- Hirota, Linda
AU- Fortin, Jennifer
AU- Col, Nananda
AF- Bond, Barbara, bbond@lifespan.org, New England Medical Ctr, Dept of Social Work Services, Women's Oncology, Boston, MA, US

LA- English
KP- hormone replacement therapy
KP- HRT
KP- focus groups
KP- breast cancer
KP- health decisions
KP- decision-making process
KP- menopausal symptoms
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Decision Making; Health Attitudes; Health Behavior; Hormone Therapy
AB- Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) traditionally has been withheld from women with breast cancer to minimize their risk of recurrence. However, the benefits of HRT include relief from menopausal symptoms and protection against osteoporosis and possibly heart disease. Focus groups were conducted among 30 women (aged 36-75 yrs) diagnosed with breast cancer to explore how the women approached health decisions, especially regarding HRT, and to identify factors that influenced their decision-making process. Factors identified included relief of symptoms, fear of cancer, side effects of treatment, attitudes toward risk, perception of risk and mastery, and physicians' recommendations. The article discusses these factors and provides suggestions, such as the following, to care providers who counsel women concerning menopause and HRT: Help patients understand areas in which the evidence is solid, address their possibly unrealistic expectations, and help them articulate their feelings and fears. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Decision Making; Health Attitudes; Health Behavior; Hormone Therapy
MN- Human Females; Menopause
CL- Promotion & Maintenance of Health & Wellness (3365)

LA- English
KP- psychoeducational workshops
KP- problem focused coping
KP- emotion focused coping
KP- breast cancer patients
KP- coping strategies
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Educational Programs; Psychoeducation; Strategies
AB- Two cost-effective one-day workshops presenting either problem-focused or emotion-focused coping strategies for women completing treatment for breast cancer were evaluated for their impact on three robust patterns of coping resulting from a previous factor analysis. A factor analysis was carried out on the Ways of Coping Questionnaire using a sample of 250 patients (mean age 55 yrs) six months after diagnosis. Three factors were found: positive problem solving, escape/avoidance, and seeking social support. These factors were used as dependent variables in a study on the effects of two brief, psychoeducational workshop interventions on coping among 156 women (mean age 51.8 yrs) completing treatment for breast cancer. The women were randomized to either a problem-focused or emotion-focused coping workshop or to a waiting-list. The results indicated that women who were positive problem solvers made gains in this pattern of coping if they participated in the problem-focused workshop, whereas women in the emotion-focused workshop showed a trend to reduce their use of escape/avoidance. The coping pattern of seeking social support was unchanged by either intervention. The workshops were well accepted and cost-effective. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Educational Programs; Psychoeducation; Strategies
MN- Human Females
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)

TI- Racial and education differences in mammography-related perceptions among 1,336 nonadherent women.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Skinner, Celette Sugg
AU- Champion, Victoria
AU- Menon, Usha
AU- Seshadri, Roopa
AF- Skinner, Celette Sugg, celette.skinner@duke.edu, Duke U Medical Ctr, Comprehensive Cancer Ctr., Durham, NC, US
AF- Champion, Victoria, Indiana U School of Nursing, Indianapolis, IN, US
AF- Menon, Usha, U Utah Coll of Nursing, Salt Lake City, UT, US
AF- Seshadri, Roopa, Northwestern U, Feinberg School of Medicine, Chicago, IL, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 3
SD- 2002
YR- 2002
PM- 2002
PG- 1-18
PC- 18
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n03_01
LA- English
KP- African Americans
KP- racial differences
KP- educational level
KP- Caucasians
KP- mammography perceptions
KP- cancer screening
SU- Educational Attainment Level; Health Attitudes; Mammography; Racial and Ethnic Differences
AB- This article identifies differences in mammography-related perceptions between African Americans and Caucasians of differing educational levels and racial differences in beliefs across stages of adoption of mammography among 1,336 women (mean age 66 yrs). African Americans perceived stronger benefits of and lower barriers to mammography and greater self-efficacy regarding mammography than Caucasians did but had less knowledge about breast cancer and stronger cancer fatalism. Within races, the less well-educated women displayed less knowledge and more fatalism. Of seven perceptions, five differed by stage of adopting mammography among Caucasians and three differed by stage among African Americans. For both races, precontemplators had the lowest self-efficacy and knowledge and the highest barriers. However, whereas Caucasian precontemplators perceived the lowest benefits, African-American precontemplators had the highest benefit scores. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Educational Attainment Level; Health Attitudes; Mammography; Racial and Ethnic Differences

TI- The social context of coping with prostate cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ptacek, J. T.
AU- Pierce, Gregory R.
AU- Ptacek, John J.
AF- Ptacek, J. T., ptacek@bucknell.edu, Bucknell U, Dept of Psychology, Lewisburg, PA, US
AF- Pierce, Gregory R., Hamilton Coll, Dept of Psychology, Clinton, NY, US
AF- Ptacek, John J., Mary Greely Medical Ctr, Ames, IA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 1
SD- 2002
YR- 2002
PM- 2002
PG- 61-80
PC- 20
SP- 61
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n01_04
LA- English
KP- social context
KP- coping
KP- prostate cancer
KP- psychological distress
KP- marital satisfaction
KP- strategies
KP- self-blame
KP- wishful thinking
KP- avoidance
SU- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Prostate; Psychosocial Factors; Social Support
AB- This investigation explored the links between coping and psychological outcomes among 57 survivors (mean age 72.40 yrs) of prostate cancer who had been treated with radiation. Analyses revealed that the associations between coping and two outcomes, psychological distress and marital satisfaction, depended on the supportive context in which survivors were coping. Direct associations were observed between perceived support and the use of problem-focused and support-seeking strategies, whereas inverse associations emerged with self-blame, wishful thinking, and avoidance. The association between seeking support and marital satisfaction was strong and positive for men with high perceptions of support but was fairly weak and negative for men with low perceptions of support. Similarly, a high positive correlation emerged between wishful thinking and marital dissatisfaction for men with low perceived support, but a low negative correlation was observed between these variables for men with high perceived support. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Prostate; Psychosocial Factors; Social Support
MN- Attribution; Avoidance; Distress; Marital Satisfaction; Strategies; Survivors

TI- Correlates of adjustment among cancer survivors.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Schnoll, Robert A.
AU- Knowles, James C.
AU- Harlow, Lisa
AF- Schnoll, Robert A., RA_Schnoll@fccc.edu, Fox Chase Cancer Ctr, Psychosocial & Behavioral Medicine Program, Cheltenham, PA, US
AF- Knowles, James C., Fox Chase Cancer Ctr, Psychosocial & Behavioral Medicine Program, Cheltenham, PA, US
AF- Harlow, Lisa, U Rhode Island, Dept of Psychology, Kingston, RI, US
AD- Schnoll, Robert A., Fox Chase Cancer Ctr, 510 Township Line Road, Cheltenham, PA, US, 19012, RA_Schnoll@fccc.edu
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 1
SD- 2002
YR- 2002
PM- 2002
PG- 37-60
PC- 24
SP- 37
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 24
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n01_03
LA- English
KP- adjustment
KP- correlates
KP- cancer survivors
KP- gender differences
KP- demographics
KP- factors
KP- avoidant-type coping
KP- social support
KP- sense of meaning
SU- Adjustment; Demographic Characteristics; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Survivors
AB- Examined demographic, clinical, and psychosocial correlates of adjustment among a sample of cancer survivors (83 females and 26 males, mean age 60.3 yrs). Analyses concerning demographic and clinical variables indicated that being married, having a high income and level of education, and a positive perception of one's health was related to higher levels of adjustment; female survivors and survivors of breast cancer (versus prostate cancer) also reported higher levels of sexual adjustment. Analyses concerning psychosocial predictors of adjustment indicated that survivors who reported higher levels of social support, optimism, and meaning in life, and lower levels of avoidant-type coping exhibited better adjustment. A prediction model of adjustment indicated strong empirical support for a model depicting higher psychosocial adjustment as a function of higher levels of social support and meaning in life and lower levels of avoidant-type coping behaviors. Overall, the findings offer important information for understanding variables associated with adaptation to a cancer diagnosis and provide support for the usefulness of clinical services for survivors that provide social support, minimize the use of avoidant-type coping and help them attain a sense of meaning from their illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Demographic Characteristics; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Survivors
MN- Avoidance; Coping Behavior; Human Sex Differences; Meaning; Social Support

TI- Children's adjustment during the first year of a parent's cancer diagnosis.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Nelson, Elizabeth
AU- While, David
AF- Nelson, Elizabeth, Lnelson@man.ac.uk, U Manchester, National Primary Care Research & Development Ctr, Manchester, England
AF- While, David, U Manchester, School of Education, Ctr for Formative Assessment Studies, Manchester, England
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 20
IP- 1
SD- 2002
YR- 2002
PM- 2002
PG- 15-36
PC- 22
SP- 15
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 22
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v20n01_02
LA- English
KP- children
KP- psychosocial adjustment
KP- parent's cancer diagnosis
KP- low self-esteem
KP- poor parental adjustment
SU- Adolescent Development; Childhood Development; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
AB- This study investigated the psychosocial adjustment of 80 school-age children (34 males and 46 females, aged 8-16 yrs) during the first year of a parent's cancer diagnosis. Based on a cognitive model of stress and coping, the aims were to consider within-group variability in children's responses and to identify the strongest factors associated with good or poor adjustment. Mixed methods of data collection (standardized measures and semistructured interviews) were used to facilitate a more sensitive and reliable assessment of the children's experiences. The study was innovative in triangulating the sources of outcome measures and thus obtained self-reported data as well as assessments from parents and teachers. After multivariate analysis, the two main risk factors shown to be independently associated with poor adjustment in children were low self-esteem (p = .002) and poor adjustment in the parent with cancer (p = .01). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adolescent Development; Childhood Development; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
MN- Diagnosis; Parental Attitudes; Self Esteem

KP- solution-focused brief therapy
KP- cancer patients
KP- families
KP- model
SU- Brief Psychotherapy; Coping Behavior; Family Therapy; Neoplasms; Patients
AB- Solution-focused brief therapy is proposed as a viable approach to working with families that are experiencing and dealing with the impact of cancer on their lives. The authors provide a brief outline of the structure of solution-focused work and a case example (a middle-aged woman) to illustrate some issues related to the model. They express caution about the use of the "miracle question" with cancer patients and their families and offer suggestions for reformulating or rewording the miracle question. TI- Volunteers in an oncology support organization: Motivation, stress, and satisfactions.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Remmer, Jean
AU- Edgar, Linda
AU- Rapkin, Bruce
AF- Remmer, Jean, Sir Mortimer B. Davis-Jewish General Hosp, Hope & Cope, Montreal, PQ, Canada
AF- Edgar, Linda
AF- Rapkin, Bruce
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 19
IP- 1
SD- 2001
YR- 2001
PM- 2001
PG- 63-83

SP- 63
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic

LA- English
KP- motivations to & stress & satisfaction from working in peer-led oncology support service
KP- volunteers
SU- Motivation; Neoplasms; Satisfaction; Stress; Support Groups
AB- Notes that peer-led oncology support services are increasingly important as accessible and affordable adjuncts to medical care. Volunteers involved in these programs frequently have experienced cancer, either their own diagnosis or a family member's. This descriptive study explored the motivations, stress, and satisfaction of 85 18–82 yr old volunteers working in such a service. Using a framework developed by A. Omoto and M. Snyder, which identified 3 stages of the volunteer dynamic—the antecedents, experiences, and consequences—this study identified details about volunteers' motivations, their satisfactions, their relationship with the organization, and the effects of the work on them. Differences in motivations and stress were found between volunteers who had had a cancer diagnosis and those who had not. There was a high level of satisfaction and volunteer continuity, although the more veteran volunteers tended to be less satisfied. Key implications include the importance of a supportive work environment that satisfies motivations and attends to needs of the volunteer as well as the clientele. The authors offer suggestions for organizational structures that can promote volunteer continuity and thus effective provision of service. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Motivation; Neoplasms; Satisfaction; Stress; Support Groups
MN- Volunteers; Oncology

TI- Exploring motivations of bone marrow typing donors.

LA- English
KP- personality & knowledge
KP- motivation to donate bone marrow
KP- student donor & nondonors
SU- Bone Marrow; Knowledge Level; Motivation; Personality Correlates
AB- Explored the issues of personality and knowledge of bone marrow typing in 66 students who participated in a bone marrow typing drive and 47 nonparticipants (all Ss mean age 23 yrs). No differences in personality between the donors and nondonors were found on measures of perceived self-competence, satisfaction with life, and overall fear of medical procedures. However, donors reported greater concern with social desirability and less fear of needles than did nondonors who were aware of the drive. Students who were better educated about the donation procedure were more likely to donate, as were students who had previously donated blood. Nondonors were more likely to identify incorrectly the means by which marrow is typed and to believe that the process is painful. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Attachment needs of adolescent daughters of women with cancer.

LA- English
KP- attachment needs
KP- adolescent daughters of women with cancer
SU- Attachment Behavior; Neoplasms; Parent Child Relations
AB- Notes that adolescent daughters of women who are ill have been identified in several studies as the most distressed of all children with an ill parent. Bowlby's attachment theory holds that dependency is a healthy adaptive response at times of significant stress. Although peer support is important during adolescence, a review of research supports the notion that parents play a vital role in helping adolescents at risk. Attachment may be particularly important for girls, Attachment theory, in a context of female psychological development, suggests dyadic or family focused intervention strategies as well as peer support for adolescent daughters of women with cancer. Implications for practice are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Hopelessness among cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Gil, Sharon
AU- Gilbar, Ora
AF- Gil, Sharon, U Haifa, School of Social Work, Faculty of Social Welfare & Health, Haifa, Israel
AF- Gilbar, Ora
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 19
IP- 1
SD- 2001
YR- 2001
PM- 2001
PG- 21-33
PC- 13
SP- 21
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 13
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v19n01_02
LA- English
KP- social support & depression & age & gender & stage of treatment
KP- hopelessness
KP- 26–77 yr old cancer patients
SU- Client Characteristics; Depression (Emotion); Hopelessness; Neoplasms; Social Support
AB- Explored whether social support, depression, and personal characteristics (age, gender, and stage of treatment) were main effects on hopelessness among 113 cancer patients (aged 26–77 yrs) in 3 phases of the illness: newly diagnosed, adjuvant chemotherapy, and recurrence. The instruments used were the Multidimensional Scale of Perceived Support, the Beck Depression Inventory, and the Beck Hopelessness Scale. The patients were being treated at an oncological medical center in northern Israel. The main findings indicate a strong correlation between hopelessness and depression. Multiple regression analyses, using hopelessness as a dependent variable and social support, illness phase, gender, and age as independent variables, indicate that patients with a high level of social support felt less of a sense of hopelessness. Phase of the illness had no effect on hopelessness. Additional findings indicate that the older the patient, the less his or her feeling of hopelessness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Characteristics; Depression (Emotion); Hopelessness; Neoplasms; Social Support

TI- Reformulating financial problems and interventions to improve psychosocial and functional outcomes in cancer patients and their families.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Francoeur, Richard Benoit
AF- Francoeur, Richard Benoit, Columbia U, School of Social Work, New York, NY, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 19
IP- 1
SD- 2001
YR- 2001
PM- 2001
PG- 1-20
PC- 20
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20

LA- English
KP- financial problems & intervention
KP- biopsychosocial outcomes
KP- cancer patients & their families
SU- Money; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment Outcomes; Treatment
AB- Examines the links between financial stress, strain, and biopsychosocial outcomes of preventive, planned, and proactive interventions for cancer patients and their families. Sections in the article focus on (1) improving and expanding financial referrals, (2) increasing accommodation to financial stress and improving mental health, (3) encouraging patients' compliance with care, and (4) providing recommendations for clinicians. The author concludes by recommending 3 financial interventions for gradual biopsychosocial improvement: (1) expand the scope of financial referrals, (2) focus on enhancing patients' accommodation, adaptation, coping, and compliance with care when improvement in the level of financial stress appears to be limited, and (3) educate elderly patients about cost-saving measures that may reduce their financial worries about the burden of future health care needs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Impact of nursing intervention on cancer patients' ability to cope.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Delbar, Vered
AU- Benor, Dan E.
AF- Delbar, Vered, Ben-Gurion U of the Negev, Faculty of Health Sciences, Recanati School for Community Health Professions, Beer-Sheva, Israel
AF- Benor, Dan E., benor@bgumail.bgu.ac.il
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 19
IP- 2
SD- 2001
YR- 2001
PM- 2001
PG- 57-75
PC- 19
SP- 57
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v19n02_04
LA- English
KP- cancer
KP- coping
KP- self-care
KP- locus of control
KP- nursing intervention
SU- Coping Behavior; Health Attitudes; Home Visiting Programs; Neoplasms; Self Care Skills
AB- Cancer patients' ability to cope with disease- and treatment-related symptoms depends in part on their internal resources. This study examined the impact of a structured nursing intervention on coping resources. Nurses visited 48 patients (mean age 49.08 yrs) treated with chemotherapy, radiation, or both at their homes biweekly for approximately 3 months. The nurses were trained to assess the patients' symptoms and well-being; advise, guide, support, and educate them; and transfer responsibility for symptom control to them according to the self-care model. The assessments of the patients and a matched control group also included a measure of patients' perception of the intensity of their symptoms, independence, familial support, and knowledge needed for symptom control. The intervention patients' scores on a sense of coherence measure indicated significant improvement in all 3 subcategories (comprehensibility, manageability, meaningfulness), and their focus of control became significantly more internal. These results were associated with reduced intensity of symptoms and increased independence, familial support, and knowledge. The findings strongly suggest that the self care approach improves patients' coping abilities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Health Attitudes; Home Visiting Programs; Neoplasms; Self Care Skills

TI- Quality of life of cancer patients in undeserved populations in South Africa.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cooper, Stewart E.
AU- Mullin, Virginia C.
AF- Cooper, Stewart E., Stewart.Cooper@Valpo.Edu, Valparaiso U, Valparaiso, IN, US
AF- Mullin, Virginia C.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 19
IP- 2
SD- 2001
YR- 2001
PM- 2001
PG- 39-56
PC- 18
SP- 39
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v19n02_03
LA- English
KP- cancer
KP- quality of life
KP- cross cultural differences
SU- Cross Cultural Differences; Neoplasms; Quality of Life
AB- The majority of studies on the relationship between cancer and well-being have been conducted in the US and other Western countries. Consequently, a bias might exist that ignores the influence of cultural factors on perceptions of cancer, its etiology, and treatment. This investigation, a pilot study using African languages, attempted to explore the impacts of culture on health-related quality of life by using D. F. Celia's FACT-G scales to study 167 rural Zulu, Pedi, and Tswana patients (mean age 47.3 yrs) of extremely low socioeconomic status. Results suggest that cultural factors may exert a significant influence on the experience of FACT-G measured quality-of-life issues for cancer patients. Specifically, cultural attitudes toward accepting fate, a high level of trust and deference to healers, and a highly collectivistic orientation surrounding treatment decisions and procedures may have had an impact on the patient's scores on all four FACT-G subscales. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Similarities in coping strategies but differences in sources of support among African American and White women coping with breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bourjolly, Joretha N.
AU- Hirschman, Karen B.
AF- Bourjolly, Joretha N., U Pennsylvania, School of Social Work, Philadelphia, PA, US
AF- Hirschman, Karen B.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 19
IP- 2
SD- 2001
YR- 2001
PM- 2001
PG- 17-38
PC- 22
SP- 17
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 22
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v19n02_02
LA- English
KP- breast cancer
KP- social support
KP- coping
KP- race
KP- African Americans
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Racial and Ethnic Differences; Social Support
AB- African American women are less likely to be diagnosed with breast cancer than White women but are more likely to be adversely affected. However, little attention has been paid to how these women cope with the disease or whether they differ from White women in coping with breast cancer. Using a comparative design, this study analyzed the differences in coping strategies and use of social support between African American and White women with breast cancer. 102 women (aged 27–91 yrs) with breast cancer completed measures of coping behavior and social support. Findings suggest that both groups tend to seek social support as a way of coping with their breast cancer but differ in their sources of support. Social workers are urged to consider that there may he differences in sources of social support between racially and ethnically diverse populations. These differences may have an impact on the type of support provided and therefore on patients' need for service. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Social support for patients with prostate cancer: The effects of support groups.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Poole, Gary
AU- Poon, Colleen
AU- Achille, Marie
AU- White, Kate
AU- Franz, Natalie
AU- Jittler, Sandra
AU- Watt, Kelly
AU- Cox, David N.
AU- Doll, Richard
AF- Poole, Gary, gary.poole@ubc.ca, U British Columbia, Dept of Health Care & Epidemiology, Vancouver, BC, Canada
AF- Poon, Colleen
AF- Achille, Marie

AF- Doll, Richard
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- prostate cancer
KP- social support
KP- support groups
KP- coping
KP- quality of life
SU- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Social Support; Support Groups
AB- Questionnaires were administered to 234 patients (mean age 67.7 yrs) with prostate cancer to determine their sources of emotional, informational, and practical support and the relationship between their satisfaction with this support and their self-reports of coping and quality of life. 142 of the respondents attended support groups, 92 did not. Attenders were significantly more likely to cite other patients as sources of all three types of support. Furthermore, attenders cited fellow patients as their most helpful source of informational support, whereas nonattenders cited medical staff. Satisfaction with social support was significantly correlated with coping and quality of life. No significant differences were found between attenders and nonattenders regarding coping, quality of life, or satisfaction with the three types of support. The results are interpreted according to individual differences in how the patients satisfied their needs for support. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- treatment completion & coping skills
KP- women with early stage breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Therapeutic Processes; Treatment Termination
AB- A clear percentage of women with early breast cancer cope with the active period of treatment and then struggle to adjust as medical support becomes less intensive. This study highlights issues that can arise in a phase of illness relatively neglected previously in eight women aged 30–50+ yrs. Recognition of the needs of women at completion of adjuvant chemotherapy and radiotherapy necessitates a new approach to delivery of care with a targeted intervention that specifically addresses their adjustment to potential survivorship. TI- Personality correlates of patients' subjective well-being after surgery for colorectal cancer: An application of the five-factor model.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Courneya, Kerry S.
AU- Bobick, Todd M.
AU- Rhodes, Ryan E.
AU- Jones, Lee W.
AU- Friedenreich, Christine M.
AU- Arthur, Keith
AF- Courneya, Kerry S., U Alberta, Faculty of Physical Education, Edmonton, AB, Canada
AF- Bobick, Todd M.
AF- Rhodes, Ryan E.
AF- Jones, Lee W.
AF- Friedenreich, Christine M.
AF- Arthur, Keith
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 18
IP- 4
SD- 2000
YR- 2000
PM- 2000
PG- 61-72
PC- 12
SP- 61
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 12
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v18n04_04
LA- English
KP- personality & subjective well-being after surgery
KP- Ss with colorectal cancer
SU- Colon Disorders; Neoplasms; Personality Correlates; Surgery; Well Being
AB- The present study examined the relationship between a general personality framework (the five-factor model) and subjective well-being in patients with colorectal cancer. Participants were 56 postsurgical patients with colorectal cancer who completed a mailed, self-administered questionnaire that assessed demographic characteristics, personality, and subjective well-being (life satisfaction, positive affect, negative affect, and affect balance). Pearson correlations indicated that neuroticism had the highest correlation with life satisfaction, affect balance, and negative affect, whereas extroversion had the highest correlation with positive affect. Moreover, hierarchical multiple regression analyses indicated that personality explained an additional 20% to 29% of the variance in subjective well-being after important demographic and medical variables were controlled for. The authors concluded that personality, particularly neuroticism, is strongly related to subjective well-being in patients with colorectal cancer and that clinicians should be aware of its implications for patients' functioning. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Colon Disorders; Neoplasms; Personality Correlates; Surgery; Well Being

TI- Quality of life of long-term survivors of leukemia and lymphoma.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Zebrack, Brad
AF- Zebrack, Brad, UCLA Jonsson Comprehensive Cancer Ctr & Control Research, Div of Cancer Prevention, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology

LA- English
KP- quality of life
KP- 24–82 yr old leukemia & lymphoma survivors
SU- Leukemias; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Survivors
AB- This study examined quality of life among 53 long-term survivors (aged 24–82 yrs) of leukemia and lymphoma. Analyses of data collected from a standardized instrument designed specifically for cancer survivors and from in-depth face-to-face interviews suggest that long-term survivors experience positive outcomes as a result of their cancer experience along with long-term physical and psychosocial sequelae. The author concludes that quality-of-life outcomes partially may be a function of the cognitive frame or meaning that survivors attribute to their experience. Ensuring adequate care and attention to the needs of long-term survivors requires an understanding of the effects of disease on quality of life as well as the varied ways in which long-term survivors adapt and live the remainder of their lives. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- results of status on BRCA1 gene test & breast & ovarian cancer susceptibility
KP- support group desirability
KP- 18–82 yr olds
SU- Attitude Formation; Genetic Counseling; Neoplasms; Support Groups; Susceptibility (Disorders)
AB- This article explores interest in a support group among 218 individuals (aged 18–82 yrs) tested for a mutation in BRCA1, a breast and ovarian cancer susceptibility gene. When queried 4 to 7 months after receiving the BRCA1 test results, approximately one-fourth of the participants expressed interest in a hypothetical support group. A mixed-carrier status and multiple family group was preferred over a carrier-only and single family group. The information about interest in a support group among individuals test for a BRCA1 mutation represents an important step in identifying those who are most receptive to psychosocial interventions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- in-person tailored intervention vs routine care
KP- mammography compliance & perceived risk of breast cancer
KP- 45–64 yr old African American women
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Health Care Services; Health Education; Mammography; Risk Perception
AB- This report describes a tailored intervention to increase compliance regarding mammography and the stage of its adoption among 329 low-income African-American women aged 45–64 years. Two randomly assigned groups received either an in-person tailored intervention or routine care. The intervention was targeted toward perceived risk of breast cancer and perceived benefits of and barriers to breast cancer screening. Participants accrued from a community service center were followed for one year to identify the effect of the intervention on adoption of mammography. TI- Group interventions with cancer patients: Efficacy of psychoeducational versus supportive groups.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Edelman, Sarah
AU- Craig, Ashley
AU- Kidman, Antony D.
AF- Edelman, Sarah, U of Technology, Health Psychology Unit, Sydney, NSW, Australia
AF- Craig, Ashley
AF- Kidman, Antony D.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 18
IP- 3
SD- 2000
YR- 2000
PM- 2000
PG- 67-85
PC- 19
SP- 67
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic

LA- English
KP- efficacy of psychoeducational vs supportive group interventions
KP- adult cancer patients
SU- Group Psychotherapy; Neoplasms; Psychoeducation; Supportive Psychotherapy; Treatment Outcomes
AB- Reviews the psychological outcomes of studies that evaluated group interventions using a predominantly supportive or psychoeducational approach as well as studies that made direct comparisons between the two approaches. Studies were identified via a computerized CD-ROM search on MedLine, Psych Lit, HealthStar, Current Contents and CINAHL. Criteria for inclusion in the review were group psychological intervention with adult cancer patients, use of psychometrically validated instruments, randomized or case-controlled design, and publication in English since 1960. 15 studies were found to be acceptable. Results show the majority of findings suggest that patients who attend psychoeducational groups experience greater benefits than do those who attend purely supportive groups. However, the authors state that further well-designed research in this area is needed to identify specific patient cohorts that are most likely to benefit from each approach (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Partner support and changes in relationships during life-threatening illness: Women's perspectives.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sormanti, Mary
AU- Kayser, Karen
AF- Sormanti, Mary, Columbia U, School of Social Work, New York, NY, US
AF- Kayser, Karen
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 18
IP- 3
SD- 2000
YR- 2000
PM- 2000
PG- 45-66
PC- 22
SP- 45
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 22
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v18n03_04
LA- English
KP- role of primary partnered relationship
KP- adjustment to cancer
KP- women (aged 27–48) receiving cancer treatment & diagnosed 2 mo–2 yrs before study & who are mothers & in a primary partnered relationship
SU- Adjustment; Human Females; Neoplasms; Significant Others; Social Support
AB- Examined the role of the primary partnered relationship as a factor in women's adjustment to cancer. Ss consisted of 40 women (aged 27–48 yrs) that were (1) currently receiving some form of treatment for cancer, (2) had been diagnosed at least 2 mo, but not more than 2 yrs, before the study, (3) were the mother of at least 1 child aged 12 yrs or younger and (4) were currently involved in a primary partnered relationship. Data from semistructured interviews (regarding partners' support and its impact on the primary partnered relationship) and the Mutual Psychological Development Questionnaire (measuring the mutuality of the primary partner relationship, including shared feelings, thoughts, and activity between people in relationships) were used to determine (1) how women with cancer perceive the effect of their illness on their primary partnered relationship, (2) what types of support women receive from their partners during the illness experience, (3) if this support is adequate and (4) the relationship between the mutuality of the primary partner relationship and the support given by the partner. Results indicate that the type of support the partner provides as well as the mutuality of the relationship contribute positively to women's coping. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Human Females; Neoplasms; Significant Others; Social Support

TI- Partners of cancer patients: Part II. Current psychosocial interventions and suggestions for improvement.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Carlson, Linda E.

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- counseling for couples & for partners & family counseling
KP- coping
KP- cancer patients' partners
SU- Coping Behavior; Couples Therapy; Family Therapy; Neoplasms; Significant Others
AB- Reviews literature on interventions that have been developed to help cancer patients' partners through a focus on counseling for couples, counseling for partners and family counseling. The authors conclude that, although interventions targeted at partners of cancer patients have led to improved communication between partners and patients, much more work must be done to develop programs that specifically target the areas in which partners experience the most difficulty. Further, although problem-solving and educational interventions can be useful, interventions that target partners' support and existential needs and foster open communication between partners and patients are likely to prove most effective in alleviating distress in both partner and patient. Suggestions for providing interventions tailored specifically for different populations of partners are provided. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- health-related quality of life
KP- survivors of testicular cancer (aged 18–83) 3–13 yrs after treatment
SU- Health; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Survivors; Testes
AB- Retrospectively studied 277 survivors of testicular cancer (aged 18–83 yrs) to determine health-related quality of life 3–13 yrs after treatment. A packet of questionnaires were mailed to Ss. Questionnaires included were: (1) the Swedish Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire, (2) a questionnaire consisting of 18 specific questions or statement concerning the testicular cancer, and (3) The Gothenburg Quality of Life Instrument. Results were compared with an age-matched group of 122 men in the general population. Results show, overall, the health-related quality of life experienced by the survivors is as good as, or even better than, that of the men in the general population. However, men treated with chemotherapy, either as a single therapy or in combination with other treatments, did score less favorably regarding quality of life. Perceived attractiveness, being fertile, having children and living with a partner are concluded to be the most important aspects of good health-related quality of life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Threat appraisal and adjustment among children with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Fearnow-Kenney, Melodie
AU- Kliewer, Wendy
