LA- English
KP- stressful events
KP- threat appraisal & adjustment
KP- girls & boys (aged 8–19) with cancer and their primary caregivers
SU- Adjustment; Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Stress; Threat
AB- Measured and described appraisals of threat among children with cancer through the development of the Threat Appraisal Questionnaire (TAQ), designed to assess threat to self, threat to others, threat of loss, and threat of physical harm to self. Ss consisted of 14 girls and 26 boys (aged 8–19 yrs) and their primary caregivers. Children were asked to complete the measure in response to a medically-related event, a peer-related event, and a family-related event. Additional measures included (1) demographic data, as provided by the primary caregiver; (2) severity of illness, as assessed by a physician's rating on the Karnofsky Performance Scale; (3) the Children's Hope Scale (CHS), completed by child Ss; and (4) the Personal Adjustment and Role Skills Scale III, completed by caregivers to assess the child's competence and overall psychosocial adjustment. The TAQ and CHS were read aloud to the children by the interviewer. Results indicate that the children's ratings of the 4 types of threat vary with the context of the stressful event. The authors maintain that findings provide initial support for a direct relationship between specific dimensions of threat and measures of adjustment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Stress; Threat

TI- Treatment of the whole person: Incorporating emergent perspectives in collaborative medicine, empowerment, and music therapy.

LA- English
KP- empowerment perspective on use of music therapy as part of collaborative medicine approach to promotion of healing
KP- oncology patients
SU- Empowerment; Interdisciplinary Treatment Approach; Music Therapy; Neoplasms; Treatment
AB- This article is about healing in the context of the oncology hospital setting. It suggests the benefits of collaborative medicine and its enhancement through music therapy. An empowerment perspective guides its emphasis on the necessity of meeting the psychosocial needs of patients, encouraging participation in treatment, and facilitating a psychologically positive hospital experience through the application of music. A review of the literature and an outline of the specific physical and psychological benefits of music in oncology treatment are provided. The authors argue that psychological symptoms, such as depression and anxiety, which are commonly experienced by long-term hospital patients, can be prevented when oncology care teams follow a philosophy of healing the whole person rather than merely treating an illness. They suggest that researchers and care teams further explore the development of creative arts programs in hospital settings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

LA- English
KP- impact of diagnosis & coping & adjustment
KP- male vs female partners of patients diagnosed with cancer
SU- Adjustment; Coping Behavior; Medical Diagnosis; Neoplasms; Significant Others
AB- Because the importance of partners' role in determining the adjustment of patients with cancer has become increasingly evident, partners have become the target of studies more extensively in recent years. In addition, partners often suffer more psychological distress from the impact of the diagnosis than patients do. This 2-part review identifies 3 areas of research that have not been integrated in the literature: (1) the impact of cancer on the partner across different stages of the illness trajectory, (2) gender differences in partners' reactions and adjustment, and (3) psychosocial interventions for partners. Part 1 focuses on the experience of cancer patients' partners, how the illness affects them, and how they adjust to and cope with the illness. Part 2 reviews the interventions that have been developed to help patients' partners and concludes with suggestions for providing interventions specifically tailored for different populations of partners. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- relationship with God or God image & religious coping behavior
KP- long-term adjustment to breast cancer
KP- 39–67 yr old female survivors
SU- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; God Concepts; Religiosity
AB- Explored the role of religious resources in long-term adjustment to breast cancer.32 female survivors (aged 39–67 yrs) were assessed on indexes of religious resources (e.g., God image), nonreligious resources (e.g., optimism), and emotional and spiritual well-being. Results indicated that both relationship with God, or God image, and religious coping behavior were related to the survivors' well-being. However, the relationship of these resources with well-being and other nonreligious resources was complex. Different types of relationship with God (e.g., presence) and religious coping behavior (e.g., religious discontent) demonstrated different associations with aspects of emotional well-being and nonreligious resources (e.g., optimism). For example, women who had a sense of a benevolent God experienced less psychological distress in their current life situation. Finally, religious resources, in general, added to the prediction of emotional well-being for the long-term survivors beyond the contribution of nonreligious resources. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; God Concepts; Religiosity

LA- English
KP- factors influencing attitudes toward & participation in genetic testing for predisposition to cancer
KP- African-American 15–57 yr olds
SU- Genetics; Health Attitudes; Health Screening; Neoplasms; Predisposition
AB- Identification of the genes BRCA1 and BRCA2 offers individuals at high risk for breast, ovarian, colon, or prostate cancer the opportunity to learn if they are genetically predisposed to these diseases. The Department of Medicine at the University of Chicago Medical Center has a program that provides genetic testing for people with a family history of these cancers. However, African Americans do not participate in genetic testing at the same rate European Americans do. Thus, focus groups were conducted to learn more about the factors influencing the participation of African Americans in genetic testing. Ss included 21 African-American males and females aged 15–57 yrs. The findings indicated that several factors influence their participation, including perceptions about cancer survivability and lack of awareness about the role of genetic testing. The article discusses these factors and provides specific recommendations for improving African Americans' access and response to genetic testing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- development of Reunion Day workshop for needs assessment & support
KP- childhood cancer survivors & parents
SU- Health Care Delivery; Health Service Needs; Needs Assessment; Neoplasms; Support Groups
AB- Describes a workshop called "Reunion Day," instituted in 1990 for survivors of pediatric cancer and their families. The objectives of the program were as follows: to provide a supportive forum for former patients and their families to discuss posttreatment experiences, to examine quality of life after cancer treatment, and to assess the former patients' needs by collecting information from them and their parents that would guide the development and expansion of a Pediatric Long-Term Follow-Up Program. 40 former patients (mean age 24.6 yrs) and 44 family members participated. It is suggested that the Reunion Day format can serve as a practical, cost-effective opportunity to conduct a preliminary assessment of survivors' needs while providing a useful service to them at the same time. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- perceived familial cancer risk & psychosocial adjustment & health concerns
KP- cancer patients (aged 18–71 yrs)
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Health Attitudes; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Risk Perception
AB- Explored the psychosocial morbidity and health concerns accompanying individuals' perceived increased risk of cancer. In a Familial Cancer Program, 78 patients (aged 18–71 yrs) were divided into 2 groups: 39 with and 39 without a cancer diagnosis. Questionnaires completed in the clinic before a risk evaluation included the Trait Anxiety Scale, the Medical Outcome Study Questionnaire, the Bipolar Profile of Mood States (POMS-BI), and an investigator-designed open-ended questions reviewed by a panel of experts. Patients' perception of a high lifetime risk ranged from 16% to 88%. A favorable median global mood score was found on the POMS-BI, whereas a distress-specific question revealed an increased level of stress caused by the person's cancer risk. Trait anxiety correlated significantly with most health and psychosocial variables. Patients identified emotional and family concerns and their uncertain situation most often as being difficult in dealing with their risk, and they identified information, support, and screening most often as being helpful. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Health Attitudes; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Risk Perception

TI- Emotional and functional impact of radiotherapy and chemotherapy on patients with primary breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Buick, Deanna L.
AU- Petrie, Keith J.
AU- Booth, Roger
AU- Probert, John

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- psychosocial & functional impact of radiotherapy & chemotherapy
KP- female breast cancer patients (aged 30–70 yrs)
KP- 3 mo study
SU- Activities of Daily Living; Breast Neoplasms; Drug Therapy; Psychosocial Factors; Radiation Therapy
AB- Investigated the psychosocial sequelae of radiotherapy and chemotherapy for primary breast cancer. Negative ,and positive affect and functional impairment were measured at 5 intervals between pretreatment and 3 mo after treatment in 78 patients with primary breast cancer (aged 30–70 yrs) who were undergoing radio- or chemotherapy. The radiotherapy patients' negative affect was greatest when therapy began and declined during therapy, whereas chemotherapy patients' negative affect increased during therapy and lasted up to 1 mo after therapy ended. The patients' functional, recreational, and home management activities were disrupted, predominantly during the first half of the treatment regimen and their sleep and rest behaviors became more disrupted as they progressed through the course of treatment. The chemotherapy patients' social interactions and alertness declined significantly during therapy. The results suggest that psychoeducational interventions would be advantageous before radiotherapy begins and at discrete intervals during and after chemotherapy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Activities of Daily Living; Breast Neoplasms; Drug Therapy; Psychosocial Factors; Radiation Therapy
MN- Chemotherapy; Human Females
CL- Medical Treatment of Physical Illness (3363)

LA- English
KP- biopsychosocial perspective on prostate cancer
SU- Biopsychosocial Approach; Neoplasms; Prostate
AB- The impact of prostate cancer is described from a biopsychosocial perspective. Illness-related demands or stressors, such as symptoms, side effects, and overall life disruption related to diagnosis, staging, monitoring, and treatments are addressed. Although a dearth of psychosocial research exists in this field, there are indications that the sexual sphere—apart from urinary functioning—is primarily affected. Although impotence, urinary obstruction, and incontinence are among the most common complaints from early stage disease on, no statistics have appeared about the prevalence of psychological morbidity. The authors derive salient issues from available evidence; discuss implications for practice, such as the role of and need for psychosocial interventions (e.g., psychoeducation and coping-skills training); and note that age-specific factors may influence the impact of stress associated with the disease. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- experience of fieldwork practicum in oncology setting
KP- social work students (aged 23–50 yrs)
SU- Curricular Field Experience; Medical Treatment (General); Neoplasms; Social Work Education; Oncology
AB- The fieldwork practicum is a major component of social work education and training. It provides a venue for students to integrate theoretical concepts into practice skills. As they begin fieldwork, students experience a variety of stresses as they are challenged to grow professionally. This Study examined, from 15 students' (aged 23–50 yrs) perspectives, experiences related to 2nd-yr field placement in an oncology setting. The study identified the factors considered to be difficult and demanding as well as helpful in the students' overall adjustment to the setting. The authors discuss the implications for field instructors in oncology social work and offer recommendations for graduate students choosing this specialized area of practice. LA- English
KP- development & validity of Cancer Worries Inventory
KP- assessment of illness-related cognitions & worries
KP- 18+ yr old cancer patients
SU- Cognitions; Neoplasms; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Test Construction; Test Validity
AB- Described the development and analyzed the validity of the Cancer Worries Inventory (CWI), which measures the illness-related cognitive concerns or worries of cancer patients. The CWI, containing 60 Likert-like items and 1 open-ended item, was completed by 185 cancer patients (aged 18+ yrs), who also completed 1 of 4 other measures: the Profile of Mood States–Short Form, the Stanford Inventory of Cancer Patient Adjustment, the Revised Impact of Event Scale, and the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy Scale–General. Factor analysis resulted in a shortened, 24-item CWI that contained 5 factors (death and dying, burden, spirituality, chemotherapy, and treatment) and demonstrated good internal consistencies. Construct validity was evidenced by significant inverse relationships with positive mood, self-efficacy for coping with cancer, quality of life, and intrusive thoughts and by a significant positive relationship with 5 measures of negative mood. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Cognitions; Neoplasms; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Test Construction; Test Validity
MN- Anxiety; Inventories

TI- Assessing the perceived needs of patients attending an outpatient melanoma clinic.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bonevski, Billie
AU- Sanson-Fisher, Rob
AU- Hersey, Peter
AU- Paul, Christine
AU- Foot, Glenda
AF- Bonevski, Billie, Royal Newcastle Hosp, Newscastle Inst of Public Health, Newcastle, NSW, Australia
AF- Sanson-Fisher, Rob
AF- Hersey, Peter
AF- Paul, Christine
AF- Foot, Glenda
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 3-4
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 101-118
PC- 18
SP- 101
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n03_06
LA- English
KP- perceived psychosocial & health information & service & other needs
KP- 18–86 yr old outpatients attending melanoma clinic
SU- Client Attitudes; Health; Needs; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Examined the prevalence and intensity of psychosocial and health needs identified by outpatients attending a melanoma clinic. 179 Ss (aged 18–86 yrs) completed the Cancer Needs Questionnaire (G. Foot, 1996; G. Foot and R. Sanson-Fisher, 1995). The questionnaire includes items pertaining to 5 categories of needs: psychological, health information, physical and daily living, patient care and support, and interpersonal communication. 12 melanoma-specific items also were included. The prevalence of individual needs ranged from 14% to 43%, and 6 of the 10 highest-ranked needs concerned health information. Ss' demographic and disease and treatment variables were related to needs within each category. Results show that unmet needs for information persist in this sample of Ss with melanoma. Needs in other domains, such as psychological concerns and problems with health care providers, also were identified in addition to disease-specific needs. The results suggest that more research is needed to measure patients' needs routinely, to identify patient groups with specific needs, and to develop methods to meet their needs effectively. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Attitudes; Health; Needs; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors

TI- Psychotherapeutic trials specific to women with breast cancer: The state of science.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Tapper, Viva J.
AF- Tapper, Viva J., U Washington, School of Nursing, Seattle, WA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 3-4
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 85-99
PC- 15
SP- 85
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n03_05
LA- English
KP- psychotherapeutic interventions
KP- women with breast cancer
KP- 1974–1994 & 1995–1998
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Psychotherapy
AB- Focuses on psychotherapeutic interventions specific to women with breast cancer that were published between 1995 and 1998. Following a brief synopsis of psychotherapeutic interventions for women with breast cancer published between 1974 and 1994, the author highlights what is known and elucidates knowledge gaps in the literature. The author suggests that more information about who is best prepared to provide psychotherapeutic care is needed. The author recommends that there needs to be more specific information about therapeutic interventions that are appropriate for each stage of the disease. In addition, identification of patients who are most likely to benefit from specialized interventions will enable clinicians to screen more effectively. By crystallizing the focus of scholarly inquiries about therapeutic research on breast cancer since 1994 and by addressing the most salient methodological issues and knowledge gaps, the article addresses the need to identify the treatment modalities most likely to provide the greatest potential for use by clinicians and facilitates the application of research to practice. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Stages of breast cancer: An Israeli psychosocial intervention model.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sadeh-Tassa, Dafna
AU- Drory, Margalit
AU- Ginzburg, Karni
AU- Stadler, Jona
AF- Sadeh-Tassa, Dafna, Tel-Aviv Sourasky Medical Ctr, The Breast Health Ctr, Dept of Social Work, Ramat Aviv, Israel
AF- Drory, Margalit
AF- Ginzburg, Karni
AF- Stadler, Jona
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 3-4
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 63-83
PC- 21
SP- 63
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n03_04
LA- English
KP- psychosocial intervention model based on crisis intervention & diagnostic & hospitalization/surgical & recovery stages of disease
KP- females with breast cancer
KP- Israel
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Crisis Intervention; Disease Course; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment
AB- The Breast Health Center at the Tel-Aviv Sourasky Medical Center in Israel provides medical and psychosocial services under 1 roof. The authors describe a model developed for the special needs of Israeli patients with breast cancer. The overall purpose of this intervention model is to offer a comprehensive supportive program to this particular population of women who are currently in a crucial and highly stressful period in their lives. The model is based on the crisis intervention approach (D. C. Aguilera, 1990). The model includes 3 phases of psychosocial intervention: diagnostic, surgical/hospitalization, and recovery. The underlying assumption is that each phase is characterized by specific stressors, each requiring distinctive adjustment and coping mechanisms. The phasic approach enables the therapist to meet the various needs of the patients. This model has been used for 5 yrs with 600 women at the Breast Health Center. The author reports favorable responses from both patients and staff. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Crisis Intervention; Disease Course; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment
MN- Hospitalization; Human Females; Medical Diagnosis; Models; Recovery (Disorders); Surgery

TI- Quality of life and psychosocial outcomes in long-term survivors of breast cancer: A focus on African-American women.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ashing-Giwa, Kimlin
AF- Ashing-Giwa, Kimlin, U California, Dept of Biobehavioral Sciences, Los Angeles, CA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 3-4
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 47-62
PC- 16
SP- 47
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n03_03
LA- English
KP- quality of life & psychosocial concerns of long-term breast cancer survivors
KP- Black females (mean age 61.8 yrs)
SU- Blacks; Breast Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Quality of Life; Survivors
AB- Reports a descriptive study on the quality of life and psychosocial concerns of 117 African-American women (mean age 61.8 yrs) who were long-term survivors of breast cancer. Ss completed a questionnaire consisting of standard measures of quality of life, a measure of socioecological context, and new items generated by earlier qualitative research. The questionnaire also included sections on the following: demographic characteristics, breast cancer and other medical conditions, perceived quality of health care, health beliefs, social support, life stress, living situation, health perceptions, partner support; dating, body image, spirituality; and physical, psychological, sexual, and marital functioning. Results showed that the women relied on spiritual faith and family support to cope with their cancer. However, they also reported difficulty talking about the disease on the one hand and lack of adequate emotional and functional support on the other. The results also suggested that the socioecological and cultural contexts of the women's lives may need closer examination when examining health-related quality of life outcomes after cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Sexual functioning and mood among long-term survivors of clear-cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina or cervix.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Matthews, Alicia K.
AU- Aikens, J. E.
AU- Helmrich, S. P.
AU- Anderson, D. D.
AU- Herbst, A. L.

LA- English
KP- clear-cell adenocarcinoma of genitalia
KP- quality of life & sexual functioning & emotional adjustment & marital partner relationships
KP- female long-term cancer survivors (mean age 40.6 yrs)
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychosexual Behavior; Quality of Life; Sexual Function Disturbances
AB- Although establishing sexual relationships is viewed as an important developmental milestone for adults, sexual functioning has been a neglected area of investigation for survivors of gynecological cancer. This article describes the long-term effects of clear-cell adenocarcinoma, with a specific focus on sexual functioning as a major quality-of-life concern and emotional adjustment of 220 women (mean age 40.6 yrs). The authors hypothesized that Ss with multiple factors that interfered with their sexual functioning would report greater sexual dysfunction, poorer adjustment, and relationship difficulties. Two additional goals were to describe late psychological effects, such as depressive symptoms, and to explore the relationship between health status, coping behavior, social support variables, and depressive symptoms. The findings provide preliminary support for a complex relationship between medical complications, sexual dysfunction, emotional adjustment, and marital/partner relationships: 38% of the Ss reported physical and psychosexual factors interfering with their sexual functioning. Although chronic sexual dysfunction is a legitimate concern by itself, the findings also suggest that sexual difficulties are associated with diverse problems involving mood, quality of life, and adjustment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychosexual Behavior; Quality of Life; Sexual Function Disturbances

TI- Correlates of anxiety among adult daughter caregivers to a parent with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Raveis, Victoria H.
AU- Karus, Daniel
AU- Pretter, Sheindy
AF- Raveis, Victoria H., Columbia U, Joseph L. Mailman School of Public Health, Ctr for Psychosocial Study of Health & Illness, New York, NY, US
AF- Karus, Daniel

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17

PG- 1-26

PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 26
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n03_01
LA- English
KP- correlates of anxiety
KP- 22–57 yr old daughters caring for an elderly parent receiving outpatient cancer treatment
SU- Anxiety; Caregiver Burden; Caregivers; Daughters; Neoplasms
AB- Understanding the factors that increase adult caregiving daughters' vulnerability to poor psychological functioning and thereby threaten their ability to provide adequate informal support and assistance is important to maintaining the chronically ill elderly in the community. On the basis of data obtained from 164 elderly outpatients (aged 60–90 yrs) and their adult caregiving daughters (aged 22–57 yrs), the effect of potential predictors on the caregiving daughters state anxiety scores was estimated using hierarchical regression. The total model suggests that scores of a daughter having a health-limiting condition, a greater sense of filial obligation, and a greater caregiver burden were correlated with higher anxiety scores, whereas having a favorable attitude regarding her caregiving experience, providing care in a greater number of domains of care, and having a higher level of overall satisfaction with the help received in providing care were correlated with lower scores. These findings show the value of considering the situational factors that may constrain or facilitate caregiving when examining emotional distress among familial caregivers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Anxiety; Caregiver Burden; Caregivers; Daughters; Neoplasms

TI- The influence of maternal stress resistance and family relationships on depression in children with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Noojin, Ashley Bryant
AU- Causey, David L.
AU- Gros, Bryan J.
AU- Bertolone, Salvatore
AU- Carter, Bryan D.
AF- Noojin, Ashley Bryant, U Louisville, School of Medicine, Div of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, Louisville, KY, US
AF- Causey, David L.
AF- Gros, Bryan J.
AF- Bertolone, Salvatore
AF- Carter, Bryan D.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 2
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 79-97
PC- 19
SP- 79
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n02_05
LA- English
KP- maternal stress resistance & coping & family relationships
KP- depression
KP- 7–16 yr olds with variety of childhood cancers
SU- Coping Behavior; Major Depression; Mother Child Relations; Neoplasms; Stress
AB- Proposed a theoretical model for explaining the potential influences on child adjustment to the complex and often painful treatment regimens required in the management of childhood cancer. The primary psychosocial factors of parental coping beliefs and behavior were explored, both directly and through their influence on family relationships, for their impact on child depression in pediatric oncology patients. The study sample included mothers and 27 children (aged 7–16 yrs) with a variety of childhood cancers, whose treatment protocols were classified as either "more aggressive" (12) or "less aggressive" (15). Results indicated that maternal confidence in coping efficacy was strongly related to the mother's use of approach coping strategies, the overall quality of the family environment, and the child's self-reported level of depression. Few significant relationships were found between demographic and disease variables and the psychological mediator and outcome variables. Parental education and financial status were found to function as personal resources for the mothers. Maternal confidence in ability to cope was found to decrease with time after diagnosis. Recommendations are made for future studies to minimize the limitations inherent in the present small sample size. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Major Depression; Mother Child Relations; Neoplasms; Stress
MN- Family Relations; Mothers

TI- Elderly cancer patients: Correlates of depressive symptomatology.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Raveis, Victoria H.
AU- Karus, Daniel G.
AF- Raveis, Victoria H., Columbia U, Joseph L. Mailman School of Public Health, New York, NY, US
AF- Karus, Daniel G.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 2
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 57-77
PC- 21
SP- 57
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n02_04
LA- English
KP- correlates of depressive symptomatology
KP- 60–86 yr old outpatients with cancer
SU- Client Characteristics; Comorbidity; Major Depression; Neoplasms; Symptoms
AB- As more elderly people experience a cancer diagnosis and live longer, the psychological sequelae of the disease and its treatment increasingly becomes a central concern. Cancer and its treatment are likely to present significant adaptive challenges to the elderly. Knowledge of the correlates of depressive symptoms in older patients may help to identify patients who are at increased risk for co-morbid depression and to inform the development of programs and services that can help reduce depressive symptoms. Data from 169 outpatients with cancer (aged 60–86 yrs) were included in an analysis to estimate a model of patients' depressive symptoms using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale. The results of regression analyses indicated that a college degree and a lesser impact of the disease on patients' social functioning correlated with lower depression and that feeling separated or set apart from others and a wider range of negative interactions with one's support network correlated with greater depression. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Social support and adjustment to recurrence of breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Brady, Sonya S.
AU- Helgeson, Vicki S.
AF- Brady, Sonya S., U Pittsburgh, Dept of Psychology, Pittsburgh, PA, US
AF- Helgeson, Vicki S.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 2
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 37-55
PC- 19
SP- 37
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n02_03
LA- English
KP- reciprocal relations between social support & adjustment
KP- 34–80 yr old females who had sustained recurrence of breast cancer
KP- 6 mo study
SU- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Relapse (Disorders); Social Support
AB- Explored the reciprocal relations between social support and adjustment following a recurrence of breast cancer. The sample was composed of 30 women (aged 34–80 yrs) who had sustained a recurrence of breast cancer. Social support, coping, and adjustment were measured through telephone interviews on 2 occasions (T1 and T2) separated by 6 mo. Emotional support from a partner and informational support from an oncologist were related to decreased physical problems over time, but were not related to psychological distress over time. Women's use of positive reinterpretation appeared to mediate these relations. Interestingly, psychological distress was related to decreased partner emotional support over time. These results suggest that it is not enough to consider how social support may influence women's adjustment; it is also important to consider how women's adjustment may shape their social support networks. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Relapse (Disorders); Social Support
MN- Human Females

TI- Depression burden, self-help interventions, and social support in women receiving treatment for breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Badger, Terry A.
AU- Braden, Carrie Jo
AU- Longman, Alice J.
AU- Mishel, Merle M.
AF- Badger, Terry A., U Arizona, Tucson, AZ, US
AF- Braden, Carrie Jo
AF- Longman, Alice J.
AF- Mishel, Merle M.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 2
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 17-35
PC- 19
SP- 17
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n02_02
LA- English
KP- interaction of depression burden & self-help interventions
KP- social support
KP- 25–82 yr old females receiving treatment for breast cancer
KP- 3 mo study
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Depression (Emotion); Self Help Techniques; Social Support
AB- The purpose of this article is to describe the interaction effects of depression burden (depressive symptoms experienced as a burdensome side effect) with a set of oncology support interventions on social support for women receiving treatment for breast cancer. A repeated measures design was used with measurement occurring at 3 points in time: T1 (baseline after adjuvant medical treatment was initiated), T2 (6–8 wks after T1), and T3 (3 mo after T2). 247 women (aged 25–82 yrs) were randomly assigned to treatment (n = 194) or control (n = 53). The treatment group consisted of women participating in 3 different, but complimentary self-help interventions. Although not significant, the data demonstrated the influence of depression burden specifically on the ability to marshall needed support resources during illness. Women with high depression burden consistently lost more network members than did women who experienced depression but did not rank it among the top 5 side effects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Depression (Emotion); Self Help Techniques; Social Support
MN- Human Females; Medical Treatment (General)

TI- Feasibility of an audiotape intervention for patients with cancer: A multicenter, randomized, controlled pilot study.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Hack, Thomas F.
AU- Pickles, Tom
AU- Bultz, Barry D.
AU- Degner, Lesley F.
AU- Katz, Alan
AU- Davison, B. Joyce
AF- Hack, Thomas F., Winnipeg Community & Long Term Care Authority, Winnipeg, MB, Canada
AF- Pickles, Tom
AF- Bultz, Barry D.
AF- Degner, Lesley F.
AF- Katz, Alan
AF- Davison, B. Joyce
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 2
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 1-15
PC- 15
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n02_01
LA- English
KP- audiotape of consultation
KP- decisional role preference & anxiety & satisfaction & information recall & perception of oncologist
KP- 34–79 yr olds with prostate or breast cancer
KP- 6 wk followup
SU- Audiotapes; Client Characteristics; Neoplasms; Professional Consultation; Therapeutic Processes
AB- Empirical evidence supports the conclusion that audiotapes of patient–oncologist consultations are well received by the majority of cancer patients. Patients who have received these audiotapes report reduced psychological distress and improved satisfaction. A pilot study evaluated the impact of giving patients a choice of receiving an audiotape of their primary treatment consultation. The participants in the multicentered, randomized, controlled study were 36 patients (aged 34–79 yrs) with breast or prostate cancer. Measures of decisional role preference, anxiety, satisfaction, recall of information, and perceptions of oncologists' likability and expertise were administered before and after the consultation and 6 wks later. At follow-up, recall of information was significantly greater among patients who chose to receive the audiotape. Furthermore, the patients who, at follow-up, recalled the most information had the highest degree of satisfaction with patient–physician communication. Results suggest that the intervention is a practical, effective, and inexpensive means of enhancing patient–physician communication, facilitating recall of information, and fostering patient satisfaction. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Audiotapes; Client Characteristics; Neoplasms; Professional Consultation; Therapeutic Processes
MN- Anxiety; Breast Neoplasms; Client Attitudes; Client Satisfaction; Emotional Adjustment; Medical Patients; Physicians; Preferences; Professional Competence; Recall (Learning)

TI- The COPE model: Its clinical usefulness in solving pain-related problems.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Loscalzo, Matthew J.
AU- Bucher, Julia A.
AF- Loscalzo, Matthew J., Johns Hopkins U Oncology Ctr, Ctr for Cancer Pain Research, Patient & Family Services, Baltimore, MD, US
AF- Bucher, Julia A.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 16
IP- 3-4
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 93-117
PC- 25
SP- 93
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 25
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v16n03_07
LA- English
KP- clinical usefulness of Creativity & Optimism & Planning & Expert Information Model in communication structure & solving pain-related problems
KP- 50–77 yr old patients with cancer pain & their caregivers
SU- Communication Skills Training; Models; Neoplasms; Pain Management
AB- Significant pain is a problem that always compromises the individual's ability to function. Barriers to adequate pain management are complex and are reinforced by societal attitudes, which are manifested by health care professionals, patients, and caregivers alike. Unrelieved cancer pain is acutely distracting and therefore is inimical to the ability to manage the demands and problems of daily living. The Creativity, Optimism, Planning, and Expert Information (COPE) model, a systematic approach to problem-solving, provides the patient and caregiver with the opportunity to work closely with their health care providers and to learn a variety of skills that result in the management of emotions; a specified course of meaningful, focused action; and the ability to reflect on and measure progress toward physical comfort. This article reviews assessment questions that are essential to a psychosocial and behavioral approach to cancer pain and describes four case studies that illustrate how professionals can use the COPE model to structure communication and help patients (aged 50–77 yrs) solve pain-related problems. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Communication Skills Training; Models; Neoplasms; Pain Management
MN- Caregivers; Psychosocial Readjustment

TI- Problem-solving through electronic bulletin boards.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bucher, Julia A.

LA- English
KP- use of electronic bulletin boards in development & reinforcement of skills in problem solving & prevention of crises at home
KP- family caregivers of patients with cancer & other chronic disorders
SU- Caregivers; Chronic Illness; Computer Assisted Instruction; Health Education; Problem Solving
AB- Changes in the organization and financing of health care delivery have resulted in increasing the responsibilities of family members who care for people with cancer and other chronic diseases. These family caregivers need to develop skills in problem-solving and in preventing physical, emotional, and social crises at home. For problem-solving education to affect caregiving behavior, family caregivers need ongoing reinforcement of what they have learned about problem-solving. Such support can come from the creative use of technology, such as computer or voice bulletin boards, which offer a wide array of services that are directly available at home for health education or counseling purposes. This article describes two computer-driven sources of information and support: the Comprehensive Health Enhancement Support System (CHESS) Program and the Telepractice and COPELINE systems, which are specifically designed to reinforce problem-solving learning among family caregivers of people with cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- group education for problem solving skills in caregiving
KP- family caregivers of cancer patients
SU- Caregivers; Family Members; Health Education; Neoplasms; Problem Solving
AB- Family caregivers of people with cancer have been asked to assume markedly increased duties and responsibilities as key members of the health care team. To succeed in their new role, they need information that is organized to guide problem-solving and education as well as support in how to apply an orderly problem-solving process the same way that health care professionals do. This article describes an education program designed to teach the principles of problem-solving to caregivers through the use of case studies, and it summarizes the data obtained during a preliminary evaluation of the program. LA- English
KP- cognitive-behavioral therapy in teaching problem solving for illness & related aspects
KP- mothers of newly diagnosed patients with pediatric cancer
SU- Cognitive Therapy; Mothers; Neoplasms; Problem Solving
AB- This article describes a cognitive-behavioral therapy intervention for teaching mothers of newly diagnosed patients with pediatric cancer to solve their problems, problems related to their child's illness, and the family's emotional reactions to the illness. The authors discuss the challenges and effects of maternal adjustment throughout the various stages of the child's illness, review the characteristics of adult learners, describe a maternal problem-solving therapy program, and provide an overview of the structured educational process, followed by a detailed discussion of a six-step maternal problem-solving therapy intervention. Finally, they describe an inventory that measures the effects of the intervention, which is being tested in a randomized controlled trial. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Cancer and psychological distress: Two investigations regarding the role of social problem-solving.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Nezu, Christine Maguth
AU- Nezu, Arthur M.
AU- Friedman, Stephanie H.
AU- Houts, Peter S.
AU- DelliCarpini, Lisa
AU- Bildner, Cheryl

AF- Nezu, Arthur M.
AF- Friedman, Stephanie H.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 16

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v16n03_03
LA- English
KP- social problem solving & distress reactions to stressful events
KP- diagnosed cancer patients & females who underwent surgery for breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Distress; Neoplasms; Problem Solving; Psychosocial Readjustment
AB- Social problem-solving ability has previously been found to be an important coping mechanism in predicting distress reactions to stressful events in the general population. Two studies evaluate the applicability of these findings to the psychooncology literature by assessing the relationship between distress and problem-solving in two different groups of cancer patients. In Study 1, 105 patients with recently diagnosed cancer completed inventories addressing social problem-solving, symptoms of distress, and cancer specific problems. The results indicated that the patients who were less effective problem-solvers also reported higher levels of anxiety and depression as well as more cancer-related problems. Study 2 involved 64 women who had undergone surgery for breast cancer between 1 and 13.3 years earlier. A self-report of negative life events served to control for the effects of recent stressors. The results of this study indicated that less problem-solving ability was a significant predictor of psychological distress, whereas time since surgery was not associated with cancer-related distress. Together, the two studies provide strong initial support for the existence of an important relationship between social problem-solving and cancer-related distress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Distress; Neoplasms; Problem Solving; Psychosocial Readjustment
MN- Stress; Surgery

TI- Relevance of problem-solving therapy to psychosocial oncology.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

LA- English
KP- therapy in context of problem solving model of stress as cognitive-behavioral intervention for mental health problems & depression
KP- cancer patients
SU- Cognitive Therapy; Mental Disorders; Neoplasms; Problem Solving
AB- Problem-solving therapy is a cognitive-behavioral intervention that has been found to be effective in the treatment of a variety of mental health problems, especially depression. The relevance of this therapy for cancer patients is addressed and is placed within the context of a problem-solving model of stress. This model argues that the likelihood that cancer patients will experience significant and long-lasting emotional difficulties and psychological distress is partially a function of their problem-solving abilities. Research supports this model not only in general but also for cancer patients in particular. A large-scale outcome study is currently underway to evaluate the efficacy of problem-solving therapy with adult cancer patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Cognitive Therapy; Mental Disorders; Neoplasms; Problem Solving
MN- Major Depression; Models; Psychosocial Factors

TI- Prostate cancer and emotional functioning: Effects of mental adjustment, optimism, and appraisal.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bjorck, Jeffrey P.
AU- Hopp, D. Patrick
AU- Jones, Lawrence W.
AF- Bjorck, Jeffrey P., Fuller Theological Seminary, Graduate School of Psychology, Pasadena, CA, US
AF- Hopp, D. Patrick
AF- Jones, Lawrence W.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 1
SD- 1999
YR- 1999
PM- 1999
PG- 71-85
PC- 15
SP- 71
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v17n01_05
LA- English
KP- mental adjustment to & appraisals of cancer & optimism & emotional functioning
KP- males (mean age 75 yrs) with prostate cancer
SU- Client Attitudes; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Optimism; Prostate
AB- This study examined the interrelationships between mental adjustment to cancer (i.e., fighting spirit, helplessness, anxious preoccupation, and fatalism), optimism, appraisals (i.e., harm/loss, threat, and challenge), and emotional functioning (i.e., depression, anxiety, and self-esteem) in a small sample of men (mean age 75 yrs) with prostate cancer. Measures included the Mental Adjustment to Cancer scale, the Life Orientation Test, and the Beck Depression Inventory. Various significant correlational findings were obtained, as hypothesized, and several of these results were supported further by conservative hierarchical multiple regression analyses. Specifically, these latter analyses revealed that increased helplessness was related to decreased self-esteem and that increased anxious preoccupation was related to increased depression. Loss appraisals were related to increased depression and threat appraisals were related to increased anxiety. Finally, optimism was negatively related to increases in both depression and anxiety. The findings are discussed within the framework of previous research and the relevance of psychosocial variables to the well-being of patients with prostate cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Attitudes; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Optimism; Prostate
MN- Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward)

LA- English
KP- disease recurrence & family history of cancer & physical disability & attitudes of medical skepticism toward physicians
KP- psychological distress
KP- cancer survivors aged over 50 yrs
SU- Client Attitudes; Distress; Neoplasms; Physicians; Survivors
AB- The increased efficacy of cancer treatments has resulted in greater numbers of older adults who survive cancer. This study examined the psychological well-being of cancer survivors (with no evidence of disease) and their attitudes of medical skepticism toward physicians. The impact of recurrence, a family history of cancer, and physical functioning were examined. Higher levels of medical skepticism toward physicians were reported by survivors of recurrences and may reflect the intense experience of dealing with physicians over the course of two or more episodes of cancer. Because the research has implications concerning the relationship between cancer survivors and their physicians, physicians should consider the potential for medical skepticism and psychological distress among their patients who are cancer survivors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

LA- English
KP- marital satisfaction
KP- change in emotional distress between 15 & 34 mo after diagnosis
KP- 34–81 yr old females with breast cancer & their 28–82 yr old husbands
KP- longitudinal study
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Distress; Emotional Adjustment; Marital Satisfaction
AB- The Profile of Mood States was used to measure distress in 44 patients (aged 34–81 yrs) with breast cancer at 15 and 34 mo after the diagnosis. Marital satisfaction, measured by the Dyadic Adjustment Scale and completed by both the patients and their husbands, was found to predict change in patients' distress over time. Patients who reported that their marriage was unsatisfactory, regardless of their report of distress 15 mo after the diagnosis, were at greater risk for elevated distress in the future than were those who were satisfied with their marriage. The findings suggest that marital satisfaction could be used as an indicator of a patient's trajectory of distress over time. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Locus of control among Black and White women with breast cancer: A preliminary study.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bourjolly, Joretha N.
AF- Bourjolly, Joretha N., U Pennsylvania School of Social Work, Philadelphia, PA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 17
IP- 1

YR- 1999

PG- 21-31

PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- health locus of control
KP- 27–91 yr old Black vs White females diagnosed with breast cancer
SU- Blacks; Breast Neoplasms; Health Attitudes; Internal External Locus of Control; Whites
AB- Although Black women are less likely to be diagnosed with breast cancer than are White women, they are more likely to be adversely affected. However, little attention has been paid to how these women cope with the disease or whether Black and White women differ in their beliefs regarding control of breast cancer. Using a comparative design, this study analyzed the differences in health locus of control between 41 Black (aged 38–87 yrs) and 61 White women (aged 27–91 yrs) with breast cancer. The findings suggest that the health locus of control among women in both groups tends to be external. They attributed control of their breast cancer to their physicians, to other people, and to chance to a greater extent than to their own control. The findings point to the importance of assessing women with breast cancer for feelings of powerlessness and providing interventions that help them gain a sense of control regarding treatment decisions and prognosis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Blacks; Breast Neoplasms; Health Attitudes; Internal External Locus of Control; Whites

TI- Age-related distress among young women with breast cancer.

LA- English
KP- age
KP- psychosocial adjustment following diagnosis of breast cancer
KP- 22–35 yr old females
SU- Age Differences; Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Evidence suggests that younger women who are diagnosed with breast cancer may be at increased risk for poor psychosocial outcomes. However, only limited work has examined the adaptational challenges these younger women confront. As part of a study examining decision-making about pregnancy after breast cancer, 51 women participated in unstructured interviews. The focus of the present thematic analysis was a group of 34 women who were younger than 36 years (M = 30.6 years). These women spoke of the unique issues associated with being a young woman diagnosed with breast cancer. The predominant stressors they described included (1) coping with the untimeliness of the diagnosis, (2) concerns about the impact of the illness on their husbands, (3) sadness about lost opportunities for childbearing, (4) a feeling of being different and isolated, (5) uncertainty about their future, and (6) concerns about their children. Evidence of altered belief systems about themselves and the world ran through their narratives concerning the adaptive challenges their illness posed for them. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Age Differences; Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Psychosocial Factors

TI- How to tell cancer patients: A contribution to a theory of communicating the diagnosis.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Salander, Pär
AU- Bergenheim, A. Tommy
AU- Bergström, Per
AU- Henriksson, Roger
AF- Salander, Pär, Umeå U, Dept of Oncology, Umeå, Sweden
AF- Bergenheim, A. Tommy
AF- Bergström, Per
AF- Henriksson, Roger
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 16
IP- 2
SD- 1998
YR- 1998
PM- 1998
PG- 79-93
PC- 15
SP- 79
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V16N02_05
LA- English
KP- communicating the diagnosis of cancer to patients
SU- Communication; Neoplasms; Physicians; Terminally Ill Patients; Therapeutic Processes
AB- How to tell patients they have cancer is an important question in cancer care. The question provokes distress in physicians, and a failure in relating the diagnosis may arrest patients' process of coping with anxiety and reduce their subjective well-being. This contribution to a theory of communicating about the diagnosis is empirically based on an earlier study in which patients with malignant brain tumors were interviewed and is theoretically based on contemporary object-relational psychoanalysis. The authors propose that a beneficial physician–patient encounter can be viewed as characterized by the acknowledgement of the physician as an unconscious protection against death and as a facilitating environment for the patient's reconstructive process. The implications of these propositions are discussed. The authors also propose that the transference from the child–parent relationship to the patient–physician relationship enables physicians to use introspection as a means to improve their skillfulness regarding "How to tell." Thus, introspection may provide physicians with guiding knowledge grounded in themselves. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Communication; Neoplasms; Physicians; Terminally Ill Patients; Therapeutic Processes
CL- Professional Psychological & Health Personnel Issues (3400)
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
PT- Journal

TI- Stress responses and psychological adjustment in patients with cancer and their spouses.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ey, Sydney
AU- Compas, Bruce E.
AU- Epping-Jordan, JoAnne E.
AU- Worsham, Nancy
AF- Ey, Sydney, U Memphis, Dept of Psychology, Memphis, TN, US
AF- Compas, Bruce E.
AF- Epping-Jordan, JoAnne E.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 16
IP- 2
SD- 1998
YR- 1998
PM- 1998
PG- 59-77
PC- 19
SP- 59
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic

LA- English
KP- stress responses & symptoms of anxiety & depression
KP- 29–59 yr old cancer patients & their spouses
SU- Anxiety; Major Depression; Neoplasms; Spouses; Stress Reactions
AB- The relationship between husbands' and wives' individual stress responses (intrusive thoughts and avoidance) and symptoms of anxiety and depression was examined shortly after diagnosis in a sample of 58 patients (aged 29–59 yrs) with cancer (43 women, 15 men) and their spouses. Marital partners' symptoms of anxiety or depression were positively correlated with one another's symptoms; however, the patients' and spouses' intrusive thoughts and avoidance were not correlated. The male patients' avoidance was positively correlated with their wives' anxiety or depression. In regression analyses, patients' avoidance uniquely predicted greater distress in both male and female patients. Male patients' avoidance also uniquely predicted greater distress in their wives. No significant interactions were found between patients' and spouses' avoidance in predicting distress in either partner. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Anxiety; Major Depression; Neoplasms; Spouses; Stress Reactions
MN- Psychiatric Symptoms

TI- Participation in exercise, mood, and coping in survivors of early stage breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Pinto, Bernardine M.
AU- Maruyama, Nancy C.
AU- Engebretson, Tilmer O.
AU- Thebarge, Ronald W.
AF- Pinto, Bernardine M., Miriam Hosp, Providence, RI, US
AF- Maruyama, Nancy C.
AF- Engebretson, Tilmer O.
AF- Thebarge, Ronald W.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 16
IP- 2
SD- 1998
YR- 1998
PM- 1998
PG- 45-58
PC- 14
SP- 45
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V16N02_03
LA- English
KP- exercise
KP- mood & coping
KP- women with early stage breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Disease Course; Emotions; Exercise
AB- This cross-sectional study examined the role of exercise in alleviating distress and the association between exercise and coping among women with early stage breast cancer (Stages 0-II). 71 women (mean age 57.4 yrs) diagnosed over the previous 12 months participated in assessments of mood, coping, social support, and exercise behavior. Women who exercised at criterion levels recommended by the American College of Sports Medicine were compared with those who exercised irregularly and those who were inactive. After age and stage of disease were controlled for, both exercise groups reported less confusion and higher levels of social support than the inactive group did, and the women who exercised at criterion levels reported greater vigor than did their inactive peers. Cluster analyses used to explore the relationship between coping behaviors and exercise status revealed that the inactive women were less likely than the women in the other two groups to use either behavioral coping strategies or adaptive cognitive strategies. The implications of the study include the need for further exploration of the relationship between participation in exercise and mood and coping among cancer survivors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Disease Course; Emotions; Exercise

LA- English
KP- accounts of their 8–12 yr old child's difficult experiences & behaviors associated with mother's breast cancer
KP- 35–50 yr old mothers
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Child Attitudes; Experiences (Events); Mother Child Relations
AB- Semistructured interviews were conducted with 26 mothers (aged 35–50 yrs) who had one or more children (N = 36) aged 8–12 years when they were diagnosed with early stage breast cancer. Formal methods were used to analyze the content of the data inductively. Mothers identified times during their diagnosis and treatment that were most difficult for their children, behaviors they observed indicating that the child was having a difficult time, and factors that prevented them from helping the child during those difficult times. The data provide a partial basis for developing materials, programs, and services designed to minimize the children's distress and to enhance the effectiveness of parenting when a mother has early stage breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Self-reported worries among long-term survivors of childhood cancer and their peers.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Weigers, Margaret E.
AU- Chesler, Mark A.
AU- Zebrack, Brad J.
AU- Goldman, Stewart
AF- Weigers, Margaret E., Gallaudet U, Dept of Sociology, Washington, DC, US
AF- Chesler, Mark A.
AF- Zebrack, Brad J.
AF- Goldman, Stewart
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 16
IP- 2
SD- 1998
YR- 1998
PM- 1998
PG- 1-23
PC- 23
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 23
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V16N02_01
LA- English
KP- self-reported worries
KP- 15–21 yr old long-term survivors of childhood cancer
SU- Anxiety; Neoplasms; Survivors
AB- Examined self-reported worries of long-term survivors (aged 15–21 yrs) of childhood cancer. Three stages of analysis were conducted. Stage 1 included a comparative analysis of long-term survivors and young people without a history of cancer. Stage 2 drew on a hospital-based sample of long-term survivors and a qualitative analysis of the open-ended comments from a panel of 20 additional survivors, to examine the reliability and validity of the results from Stage 1. Stage 3 examined factors that influenced variation in degree of worries among survivors in the first sample. A self-report questionnaire was developed to explore experiences, attitudes, and needs of the Ss. A series of 4-point Likert scale items was used to explore degree of worry. The findings suggest that in several related areas of general health and self-image, the survivors worried less than the comparison sample did. However, in areas related specifically to cancer, the survivors' degree of worry was higher than the degree reported by the comparison sample. These results are discussed in the context of the debate about the prevalence of psychopathology and psychological distress among long-term survivors of childhood cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Anxiety; Neoplasms; Survivors
MN- Adolescent Attitudes; Adult Attitudes

LA- English
KP- Caring Assessment Instrument
KP- perceptions of importance of caring behaviors
KP- cancer patients vs medical staff
SU- Client Attitudes; Health Personnel Attitudes; Neoplasms; Therapeutic Processes
AB- Investigated whether cancer patients' and staffs' perceptions differed with regard to the importance of caring behaviors. 32 cancer patients (mean age 57 yrs old) and 30 staff members (mean age 37 yrs old) were asked open-ended questions about their associations to nine preselected behaviors in the Caring Assessment Instrument (CARE-Q). The behaviors elicited similar associations in both groups. The authors concluded that patients and staff do not have different cognitive representations of the CARE-Q behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Participation in sports by long-term survivors of childhood cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Elkin, T. David

LA- English
KP- demographic & medical & health-related variables for participants vs nonparticipants in organized sports
KP- 12–18 yr old survivors of childhood cancer
SU- Athletic Participation; Demographic Characteristics; Neoplasms; Patient History; Sports
AB- Determined the proportion of childhood cancer survivors who participated in organized sports and examined demographic, medical, and health-related variables that discriminated between participants and nonparticipants. The authors surveyed 251 12–18 yr olds who were long-term survivors of childhood cancer. Ss were administered a health behavior questionnaire. A significantly greater percentage of the participant Ss had access to a local health care provider and to health insurance than did nonparticipant Ss. Ss who participated also were more likely to engage in other forms of exercise. The findings are discussed in light of interventions that promote health by targeting physical fitness and exercise for survivors of cancer and the resources necessary for them to engage in health-protective behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Children with cancer: An examination of their coping and adaptive behavior.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Derevensky, Jeffrey L.

LA- English
KP- coping & adaptive behavior
KP- 8–17 yr olds with cancer
SU- Adaptive Behavior; Coping Behavior; Neoplasms
AB- The coping resources (i.e. psychological and social resources) and coping efforts of 21 children, 8–17 yrs old, diagnosed with cancer were assessed and were compared with standardized norms. Within-group differences were explored by subdividing Ss by stage of therapy: (1) newly diagnosed, (2) currently in treatment, and (3) off treatment. The results, using a limited sample, suggested that Ss with cancer differed significantly from typical children on measures of coping effort in that they demonstrated relatively more adaptive and efficient coping behavior than did their normative peers. These findings may well be attributed to the multitude of hospital, school, familial, and psychological supports offered to Ss. The data are analyzed and discussed with reference to mediating factors, including developmental stage, gender, stage of illness, and treatment effects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- A new quality-of-life measure for oncology: The SEIQoL.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Broadhead, James K.
AU- Robinson, John W.
AU- Atkinson, Mark J.
AF- Broadhead, James K., U Calgary, Dept of Psychosocial Resources, Calgary, AB, Canada
AF- Robinson, John W.
AF- Atkinson, Mark J.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 16
IP- 1
SD- 1998
YR- 1998

PG- 21-35
PC- 15
SP- 21
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V16N01_02
LA- English
KP- feasibility reliability of Schedule for Evaluation of Individual Quality of Life for use with oncology population & comparison with EORTC QLQ-C30
KP- patients with early stage prostate cancer
SU- Measurement; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Oncology
AB- Used the Schedule for the Evaluation of Individual Quality of Life (SEIQoL) with an oncology population. The SEIQoL is designed to attain a greater level of individual subjectivity in reports on quality of life than is achieved with standard measures of quality of life. The instrument's feasibility for use in oncology was assessed with a sample of 15 patients with early stage prostate cancer treated with radiotherapy. An overview of its administration, scoring, and depiction of quality of life is provided. The measure also is compared with a standard quality-of-life measure-the European Organization for the Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire (EORTC QLQ-C30). The authors suggest that the most appropriate use for the SEIQoL is as a clinical assessment tool with relatively healthy patients, whereas standard, brief measures may be more practical for use with large samples of patients or relatively unhealthy patients or when predetermined quality-of-life concerns are addressed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Measurement; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Oncology
MN- Medical Patients; Prostate

TI- The Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale as a measure of depressive symptoms in newly diagnosed patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Beeber, Linda S.
AU- Shea, Judy
AU- McCorkle, Ruth
AF- Beeber, Linda S., U Pennsylvania School of Nursing, Ctr for Advancing Care in Serious Illness, Philadelphia, PA, US
AF- Shea, Judy

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 16
IP- 1
SD- 1998
YR- 1998
PM- 1998
PG- 1-20
PC- 20
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- reliability & validity of Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale
KP- measurement of depressive symptoms & mental health & distress
KP- patients with cancer
SU- Major Depression; Neoplasms; Test Reliability; Test Validity
AB- Examined the psychometric performance of the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) in a heterogeneous sample of 453 newly diagnosed patients with cancer to determine its reliability and validity as a measure of the patients' mental health and distress. The authors implemented recent suggestions made by other researchers for evaluating instruments for use in cancer populations. The evaluation included (1) item-level reliability and validity studies, (2) a principal components analysis of hypothesized dimensions of the construct of depressive symptoms purported to be measured by the instrument, (3) a hypothesis-driven investigation of differences in subscales on concurrently measured demographic and clinical variables, and (4) an exploratory analysis of patterns of scores on the instrument. Interesting differences in gender, race, and marital status in the variation of patterns of endorsements suggested that the CES-D is sensitive to differences in how depressive symptoms present in these patients. The data supported the use of the instrument as a reliable and valid measure of depressive symptoms in recently diagnosed patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Major Depression; Neoplasms; Test Reliability; Test Validity
MN- Distress; Mental Health

TI- Unique stressors experienced by unmarried women with breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Gluhoski, Vicki L.
AU- Siegel, Karolynn
AU- Gorey, Eileen
AF- Gluhoski, Vicki L., New York State Psychiatric Inst, New York, NY, US
AF- Siegel, Karolynn
AF- Gorey, Eileen
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 15
IP- 3-4
SD- 1997
YR- 1997
PM- 1997
PG- 173-183
PC- 11
SP- 173
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 11
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v15n03_08
LA- English
KP- unique stressors
KP- 22–42 yr old single females with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Human Females; Single Persons; Stress
AB- Addressed the unique challenges of single women with breast cancer. As part of a study examining decision- making about pregnancy after breast cancer, 16 unmarried women (aged 22–42 yrs) participated in in-depth interviews. They described 5 principal stressors associated with being an unmarried survivor of breast cancer: pessimism regarding future relationships, fears about disclosing their illness to partners, negative body image and impaired sexuality, pain of rejection by partners, and a sense of isolation and inadequate support. These findings suggest that unmarried women with breast cancer may be a vulnerable subpopulation of women with the disease who may benefit from psychosocial interventions tailored to their particular concerns. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Human Females; Single Persons; Stress

TI- Perspectives of cancer survivors interested in unconventional therapies.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Gray, Ross E.
AU- Greenberg, Marlene
AU- Fitch, Margaret
AU- Parry, Natalie
AU- Douglas, Mary S.
AU- Labrecque, Manon
AF- Gray, Ross E., U Toronto, Toronto-Sunnybrook Health Science Ctr, North York, ON, Canada
AF- Greenberg, Marlene
AF- Fitch, Margaret
AF- Parry, Natalie
AF- Douglas, Mary S.
AF- Labrecque, Manon
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 15
IP- 3-4
SD- 1997
YR- 1997
PM- 1997
PG- 149-171
PC- 23
SP- 149
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 23
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v15n03_07
LA- English
KP- issues & perceptions related to interest in unconventional therapies
KP- survivors of cancer
SU- Adult Attitudes; Alternative Medicine; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- Examined issues and perceptions related to interest in unconventional therapies in 32 survivors of cancer. Ss were interviewed concerning the motivation for seeking information about unconventional therapies, the decision-making process, the experiences with such therapies, the attempts to communicate with conventional health-care practitioners, and the perceptions of family's and friend's reactions to their interest. Results show that they had a variety of motivations for their interest. Ss consistently portrayed the mainstream cancer care system as tolerating the use of unconventional approaches while essentially remaining disengaged from the subject. Many of the Ss argued that health care professionals should be more interested in, more informed about, and more willing to discuss unconventional therapies. Ss also believed that personal experience was an important source of evidence for considering treatment options and that health care professionals often ignored this evidence, paying attention only to randomized clinical trials. In general, the Ss made a case for a better response from the health care system regarding consumers' needs concerning unconventional treatment options. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adult Attitudes; Alternative Medicine; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders)

TI- Cancer support groups and group therapies: Part II. Process, organizational, leadership, and patient issues.

LA- English
KP- group process & management & leadership in support groups & group therapies
KP- patients with cancer
SU- Group Dynamics; Group Psychotherapy; Leadership; Neoplasms; Support Groups
AB- The 1st part of this 2-part article reviewed the history and theoretical background of support groups and group therapies and explored the breakthroughs in mental health research showing how these groups enhance patients' quality of life. In Part 2, the author addresses issues regarding group process, group management and leadership, and the curative aspects of groups for patients with cancer. The implication of research is that support groups and group therapies help people with chronic illness and life-threatening disease to heal and possibly live longer. Social work has been ideally positioned to claim its role in having pioneered social group work at the turn of the century. By virtue of its history, values, and education, the profession provides a model for leading and co-leading groups of patients with cancer. When people are confronted with cancer, healing requires both emotional and physical assistance, and support groups can be healing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Sexual functioning and head and neck cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Siston, Amy K.
AU- List, Marcy A.

LA- English
KP- sexual functioning
KP- 31–74 yr olds with head & neck cancer
SU- Head (Anatomy); Neck (Anatomy); Neoplasms; Psychosexual Behavior
AB- This pilot study focused on sexual functioning in patients with head and neck cancer, a subject that has received only limited attention. Thirty-six patients whose treatment had ended at least one year before the study completed the Dyadic Adjustment Scale and two questionnaires dealing with sexual functioning. A relatively high rate of refusal to participate in the study suggested sensitivity and discomfort about discussing sexual issues. At the same time, more than three-fourths of the patients who did participate rated their sex life as "somewhat" to "very important," and half reported sexual problems. The findings suggest that sexual functioning is important to patients with head and neck cancer and that the subject should be addressed although the disease site does not directly affect sexual organs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Head (Anatomy); Neck (Anatomy); Neoplasms; Psychosexual Behavior

LA- English
KP- views & concerns & struggles
KP- 6–18 yr old siblings of bone marrow transplant patients & parents
SU- Attitudes; Bone Marrow; Family Relations; Organ Transplantation
AB- Reports the views, concerns, and struggles of siblings and parents of bone marrow transplant (BMT) patients. 44 siblings (6–18 yrs; 21 donors and 23 nondonors) and 44 parents of surviving pediatric BMT patients were interviewed. It was found that donors had significantly more anxiety, lower self-esteem, and more adaptive skills in school than did nondonors, whereas nondonors exhibited significantly more school problems. Among the siblings, minimal explanation of the transplant procedure, loneliness and lack of attention, donors' lack of choice, and need for support groups emerged as major themes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Relationship between exercise during treatment and current quality of life among survivors of breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Courneya, Kerry S.
AU- Friedenreich, Christine M.
AF- Courneya, Kerry S., U Alberta, Faculty of Physical Education, Edmonton, AB, Canada
AF- Friedenreich, Christine M.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 15
IP- 3-4
SD- 1997
YR- 1997
PM- 1997
PG- 35-57
PC- 23
SP- 35
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 23
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v15n03_02
LA- English
KP- exercise during cancer treatment & current quality of life
KP- female survivors of breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Exercise; Quality of Life; Treatment
AB- This retrospective study examined the relationship between exercise during cancer treatment and current quality of life among 167 survivors of breast cancer. The women had been diagnosed within the previous two years and had completed adjuvant therapy. Each participant completed a mailed, self-administered questionnaire that assessed her exercise behavior at three points (prediagnosis, active treatment, and posttreatment); her current physical, functional, emotional, and social quality of life; and her overall satisfaction with life. The results indicated that (1) levels of exercise declined from prediagnosis to active treatment and then increased from active treatment to posttreatment, (2) exercise during active treatment was associated with a higher quality of life and with overall satisfaction with life, and (3) maintenance of exercise across the three time periods was the optimal pattern for enhanced quality of life and overall satisfaction with life. The authors concluded that  cancer treatment has a negative impact on exercise levels but that the women who maintained their exercise behavior during and after treatment reported a higher quality of life one to two years later. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Exercise; Quality of Life; Treatment
MN- Human Females

TI- Psychosocial factors that affect the survival of adult cancer patients: A review of research.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cwikel, Julie G.
AU- Behar, Lynn C.

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 34
