LA- English
KP- psychosocial factors & interventions
KP- survival from cancer
KP- 1960–96
KP- literature review
SU- Literature Review; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Recovery (Disorders); Treatment
AB- The authors reviewed articles published from 1960 to 1996 that focused on research on psychosocial interventions and factors that affect survival from cancer. In general, they concluded that psychosocial interventions are most effective in the early stages of disease, the strongest predictors of survival are biological, the effects of psychological factors on survival are inconsistent in early stage disease and insignificant in cases of metastatic cancer, sociodemographic variables (high socioeconomic status, private health insurance, and involvement in social networks) are positively correlated with survival, and psychosocial factors are more apparent in patients younger than 55 years. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Literature Review; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Recovery (Disorders); Treatment

LA- English
KP- psychological distress
KP- 18–85 yr old cancer patients
SU- Distress; Neoplasms
AB- Determined the prevalence of psychological distress across the disease continuum in 386 cancer patients (aged 18–85 yrs) selected at random from 12 oncology outpatient departments across the US. Psychological distress was measured with the Brief Symptom Inventory, and quality of life was measured with the Functional Living Index-Cancer. The results indicate that the prevalence of psychological distress did not vary significantly across the disease continuum, with the exception of the terminal phase. TI- Literature on interventions to address cancer patients' psychosocial needs: What does it tell us?
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

LA- English
KP- practical benefits of studies evaluating effects of psychosocial interventions on adjustment to cancer
KP- patients
KP- literature review
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Literature Review; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Readjustment
AB- Describes the practical benefits of 33 studies evaluating the effects of psychosocial interventions on patients' adjustment to cancer. The studies were classified according to methodology: descriptive studies, retrospective and quasi-experimental studies, and controlled clinical outcome trials. The evidence suggests that psychosocial interventions have a positive impact on patients' adjustment and adaptation to cancer. No particular intervention appears to be signficantly more effective than others in helping patients deal with cancer. The methodology of different studies reveals multiple dimensions of psychosocial interventions that cannot be captured by any 1 method alone. Suggestions regarding methodological and clinical factors to consider when evaluating future psychosocial interventions for improving patients' adjustment and quality of life are offered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Literature Review; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Readjustment

LA- English
KP- acceptability of touchscreen computer survey
KP- assessment of physical side effects & anxiety & depression & perceived needs
KP- cancer patients receiving chemotherapy & hormone therapy
SU- Computer Applications; Emotional States; Neoplasms; Side Effects (Treatment); Surveys
AB- Assessed the acceptability of a touchscreen computer survey that assesses levels of physical side effects, anxiety, depression, and perceived needs. 229 cancer patients receiving chemotherapy and hormone therapy completed the touchscreen survey while waiting to see their oncologist. After completing the computer survey, Ss completed a pen-and-paper survey indicating their reaction to the computer survey. Despite the fact that approximately 60% of the Ss had no previous experience with computers, the survey was highly acceptable to them. In addition, 96% of the Ss were happy for their oncologist to receive a summary of their results, and 89% said they would be happy to complete such a survey during each visit to the hospital. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Understanding the breast cancer experience of African-American women.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ashing-Giwa, Kimlin
AU- Ganz, Patricia A.
AF- Ashing-Giwa, Kimlin, U California, Div of Cancer Prevention & Control Research, Los Angeles, CA, US

LA- English
KP- psychosocial need
KP- 38–74 yr old African American females with breast cancer & physicians or nurses or administrators working in cancer prevention area
SU- Blacks; Breast Neoplasms; Human Females; Needs; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Conducted 3 forms of qualitative interviews (key-informant interviews, focus-group interviews, and in-depth interviews) in an effort to gain a better understanding of the psychosocial needs of African-American females with breast cancer. 12 informants (physicians, nurses, and administrators) who had worked in the area of cancer prevention or management for 5–25 yrs participated in the key-informant interviews. 23 38–74 yr old females participated in the focus-group interviews. Eight 38–65 yr old females participated in the in-depth interviews. It was found that most Ss receive inadequate information and support to help them through the initial diagnosis and treatment phases of the breast cancer experience. Many Ss, particularly those with less education and lower incomes, had inadequate medical insurance, received uncoordinated and incomplete medical care, and experienced a poor patient–physician relationship. A primary source of support and coping for these females was their spiritual beliefs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- African-American cancer patients and culturally competent practice.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Pierce, Robert L.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 15

LA- English
KP- culturally competent practice strategies
KP- African American cancer patients & oncology social workers
SU- Blacks; Cultural Sensitivity; Neoplasms; Social Casework
AB- Proposes that through the use of culturally competent practice strategies, oncology social workers can support African-American cancer patients better in their struggle to achieve an optimal level of functioning. The requisites for a culturally competent approach to practice include the workers' ability to (1) become self-aware and recognize the influence of their own world view on their day-to-day behaviors toward African-Americans, (2) increase their knowledge about different cultures, including their own world views and those of African-American patients are likely to result in different interpretations and styles of coping, and (3) recognize and respond skillfully and effectively to the dynamics of differences. The 3 leading cancers (lung, breast, and prostate) among African-Americans are discussed and the health belief system of African-Americans is outlined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Blacks; Cultural Sensitivity; Neoplasms; Social Casework

TI- Cancer support groups and group therapies: Part I. Historical and theoretical background and research on effectiveness.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

LA- English
KP- historical & theoretical background & effectiveness of support groups
KP- cancer patients
SU- Neoplasms; Support Groups
AB- Presents Part 1 of a 2-part review of support groups and group therapies that provides a perspective on the continuum of groups for patients with cancer. This continuum includes many different types of groups, from open-ended, drop-in groups that provide supportive, educational, or self-help group experiences to time-limited or closed groups such as supportive-expressive group therapy based on the principles of existentialism. Part 1 reviews the history and theoretical background of support groups and group therapies and explores the breakthroughs in mental health research showing how these groups enhance patients' quality of life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Parents' emotional reactions related to different prospects for the survival of their children with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Grootenhuis, Martha A.
AU- Last, Bob F.
AF- Grootenhuis, Martha A., U Amsterdam, Emma Kinderziekenhuis, Academical Medical Ctr, Pediatric Psychosocial Dept, Amsterdam, Netherlands

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 15

LA- English
KP- emotional reactions & concerns
KP- parents of children with cancer in remission vs relapsed
KP- Netherlands
SU- Emotional Responses; Neoplasms; Parental Characteristics; Relapse (Disorders); Remission (Disorders)
AB- The emotional reactions and concerns of parents of children with cancer who had different prognoses for survival were investigated. Parents (84 mothers and 79 fathers) of 84 children with cancer who were in remission or had relapsed participated in the study. The mothers and fathers of children who had relapsed reported more feelings of helplessness and uncertainty and also reported their fears more often concerning their child's chances of survival than did the mothers and fathers of children whose cancer was in remission. Mothers of children with a relapse also reported more depression and anxiety. The problems of fathers of children who had relapsed were revealed only with the use of an illness-related questionnaire. Time since diagnosis did not change the emotional reactions of any of the parents. The authors conclude that the parents of children whose cancer has relapsed should be carefully monitored. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Emotional Responses; Neoplasms; Parental Characteristics; Relapse (Disorders); Remission (Disorders)

TI- Pregnancy decision making among women previously treated for breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Siegel, Karolynn
AU- Gorey, Eileen
AU- Gluhoski, Vicki
AF- Siegel, Karolynn, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr, Dept of Social Work, New York, NY, US
AF- Gorey, Eileen
AF- Gluhoski, Vicki
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 15
IP- 1
SD- 1997
YR- 1997
PM- 1997
PG- 27-42
PC- 16
SP- 27
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v15n01_03
LA- English
KP- perceived risks & benefits of pregnancy after treatment completion
KP- 22–44 yr old females with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Pregnancy; Risk Perception
AB- Increasing numbers of women with breast cancer who have not yet had a child or want more children will be faced with deciding whether to attempt pregnancy after their treatment is completed. Through in-depth focused interviews with 50 women who completed treatment for breast cancer at least six months earlier, the perceived deterrents and incentives to having a child were explored. The principal deterrents were fears that (1) the disease would recur, (2) the child might have a birth defect caused by the chemotherapy or radiation they had received, (3) the child would be born with a susceptibility to cancer, and (4) caring for a child would be too stressful. The principal incentives were the beliefs that having a baby (1) is a cherished part of a life plan, (2) is life affirming, (3) will promote a feeling of normalcy again, (4) would make their husband very happy, and (5) would enhance their quality of life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Pregnancy; Risk Perception

TI- Life changes and problems experienced by young adults with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Roberts, Cleora S.
AU- Severinsen, Cindy
AU- Carraway, Christina

LA- English
KP- life changes & specific problems & psychological well being
KP- 22–35 yr old cancer patients
SU- Life Experiences; Mental Health; Neoplasms
AB- Forty-six young adult cancer patients aged 22 to 35 years were surveyed regarding life changes and specific problems they had experienced. The majority of respondents were female, college educated, and married. Although nearly three-fourths of the respondents had completed treatment and were free of symptoms, they rated anxiety about their health and recurrence of their disease as their most stressful problems. Most were worried about their children's future and risk of cancer. Other concerns were physical and financial problems and changes in their life goals. The respondents' scores on the Brief Symptom Inventory showed a moderate elevation of psychological symptoms compared with test norms. The authors concluded that young cancer patients, who have little experience with poor health and confrontation with mortality, may need more psychosocial intervention to deal with existential concerns regarding themselves and their children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Life Experiences; Mental Health; Neoplasms

TI- Sibling adaptation to childhood cancer collaborative study: Cross-cultural aspects.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Dolgin, Michael J.

LA- English
KP- behavioral adaptation & contribution of family relations & parental coping
KP- 6–18 yr old siblings of pediatric cancer patients
KP- Israel vs US
SU- Behavior Problems; Cross Cultural Differences; Neoplasms; Siblings
AB- Cross-cultural aspects of siblings' adaptation to childhood cancer were examined in 2 studies as part of a cooperative multi-institutional investigation in Israel and the US. Study 1 compared the behavioral adaptation of 35 Israeli siblings (aged 6–18 yrs) of patients (aged 2–20 yrs) with childhood cancer with 99 matched clinically referred and normal Israeli children. Study 2 compared the behavioral adaptation of case-matched samples of Israeli and American siblings and assessed the contribution of family relations and parental coping to the siblings' behavioral adjustment. Israeli siblings and normal Ss scored significantly lower on the Child Behavior Checklist (CBCL) than the clinically referred Ss, indicating fewer behavior problems, with no differences between the siblings and normal Ss. CBCL scores of Israeli and American Ss did not differ significantly on the Externalizing and Internalizing subscales and the Total Behavior Problem score. Significant correlations were found in both the Israeli and American Ss between the parental coping and family relations variables and the CBCL summary scores, indicating that greater internal family support and emotional expressiveness and lower conflict were associated with less behavior disturbance in the sibling. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Behavior Problems; Cross Cultural Differences; Neoplasms; Siblings
MN- Coping Behavior; Family Relations; Parental Characteristics

TI- Teleconferencing as a method of educating men about managing advanced prostate cancer and pain.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Glajchen, Myra
AU- Moul, Judd W.
AF- Glajchen, Myra, Cancer Care, Inc., New York, NY, US
AF- Moul, Judd W.

LA- English
KP- interdisiciplinary educational teleconferencing intervention regarding management of prostate cancer & pain
KP- prostate cancer patients
SU- Health Education; Neoplasms; Pain Management; Prostate
AB- Developed an innovative, cost-effective, interdisciplinary educational intervention to address issues regarding the management of advanced prostrate cancer and pain. The intervention was delivered to 107 men using the teleconferencing method. The hour-long program consisted of 3 segments: 25 min of medical information provided by an urologist, 25 min of information about pain management and psychosocial issues provided by a social worker, and 10 min of questions and answers. A posttest was administered by telephone after the intervention, and 57 patients completed a mailed satisfaction survey. The response to the teleconferencing series was overwhelmingly positive. The results of the posttest revealed that patients received up-to-date medical and psychosocial information; Ss also demonstrated a good grasp of the material discussed. Broad participation was achieved in a cost-effective manner. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Health Education; Neoplasms; Pain Management; Prostate
MN- Teleconferencing

TI- Priorities of cancer survivors regarding psychosocial needs.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Charles, Karen
AU- Sellick, Scott M.

LA- English
KP- psychosocial & financial & health care & employment needs
KP- 28–86 yr old cancer survivors
KP- Canada
SU- Employment Status; Health Care Services; Needs; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Examined the needs of 362 adult cancer patients (aged 28–86 yrs) from 2 distinct geographic areas in Ontario, Canada, who had received curative treatment for a malignancy not less than 6 mo before the beginning of the study. Ss completed a questionnaire regarding access to services, quality of care, need for information, financial needs, employment problems, physical changes, health behaviors, and relationship and emotional support issues. In general, the frequency of survivors who expressed a need in any particular area was lower than expected on the basis of qualitative reports in the literature. In fact, survivors tended to express needs related to modifying life-style behaviors and helping others through the treatment and recovery process. Thus, although there is a general impression that the negative consequences of surviving cancer are frequent, the actual prevalence appears to be relatively low. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- 'In sickness and in health': A group intervention for spouses caring for patients with brain tumors.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Horowitz, Sharon
AU- Passik, Steven D.
AU- Malkin, Mark G.
AF- Horowitz, Sharon, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr, Dept of Neurology, New York, NY, US

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14

SD- 1996

SP- 43
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- development & processes of practical & emotional support group
KP- 30–70 yr old spouses of patients with brain tumors
SU- Brain Neoplasms; Group Dynamics; Spouses; Support Groups
AB- Describes the initiation of a group to provide practical and emotional support for spouses of patients with brain tumors. Approximately 20 spouses (aged 30–70 yrs) attended the group, which lasted for 18 mo. The authors describe the formation of the group, group structure, group processes and group transition, which included coping with death, and group termination. The group helped facilitate the patients' home care and reduced the spouses' anxiety and depression, as conveyed by the spouses' verbal reports and their reluctance to terminate the group. The authors attribute the profound meaning of the group to its members to therapeutic factors that are unique to the interpersonal nature of most group processes. These factors include universality, altruism, information, and the instilling of hope. The authors also attribute the group's success to the fact that it served as a "transitional object" for group members undergoing the process of losing a loved one. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Brain Neoplasms; Group Dynamics; Spouses; Support Groups
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)

TI- Development of social skills in boys with brain tumors: A group approach.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Die-Trill, Maria
AU- Bromberg, Jonas
AU- LaVally, Beverly

LA- English
KP- group approach to development of social skills
KP- 10–14 yr old males with brain tumors & their parents
SU- Brain Neoplasms; Group Counseling; Psychosocial Development; Social Skills Training
AB- Describes a structured, time-limited group focused on the development of social skills in boys (aged 10–14 yrs) who have a brain tumor. Social support and medical education were additional components. A parallel group for parents focused on relevant issues that arose in the boys' group and on the parents' general concerns about their child's social integration. The uniqueness of this program stemmed from the combination of development of social skills, specificity and homogeneity of the target population, highly structured group interventions, and parallel parent group. The program's efficacy in developing specific social skills was reported by both the boys and their parents. The authors recommend offering similar group interventions to other medically ill children and their parents, extending the model to female pediatric patients with brain tumors, and comparing time-limited versus ongoing groups for children with brain tumors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Brain Neoplasms; Group Counseling; Psychosocial Development; Social Skills Training
MN- Parents

TI- The effects of a problem-solving intervention with spouses of cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Blanchard, Christina G.
AU- Toseland, Ronald W.
AU- McCallion, Philip

LA- English
KP- problem solving intervention
KP- perceptions of health & psychological well being & coping & social support
KP- male vs female cancer patients & their spouses
SU- Coping Behavior; Health Attitudes; Problem Solving; Social Support; Well Being
AB- The effectiveness of a Coping With Cancer (CWC) intervention program for spouses of cancer patients was compared to the usual services that are offered to the spouses of cancer patients by the Oncology Department of a regional medical center. 66 spouses of cancer patients were recruited and randomly assigned to the CWC program or to usual services. Ss were assessed both before and after the intervention and again 6 mo after the 1st assessment on measures of (1) perceived health status, (2) psychological well-being, (3) social support, and (4) coping behavior. Patients whose spouses received services from the CWC program became significantly less depressed than did patients whose spouses did not. However, no other significant effects of the program were found for patients or spouses. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Health Attitudes; Problem Solving; Social Support; Well Being

TI- Subclinical psychological distress in long-term survivors of breast cancer: A preliminary communication.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Saleeba, Angèle K.
AU- Weitzner, Michael A.
AU- Meyers, Christina A.
AF- Saleeba, Angèle K., U Texas M. D. Anderson Cancer Ctr, Dept of Neuro-Oncology, Houston, TX, US
AF- Weitzner, Michael A.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14

SD- 1996

PG- 83-93

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- depression & anxiety
KP- 36–67 yr old female long-term breast cancer survivors who had been disease free for at least 5 yrs
SU- Anxiety; Breast Neoplasms; Depression (Emotion); Remission (Disorders)
AB- Reports the preliminary results of an ongoing study designed to evaluate the emotional status of 52 36–67 yr old long-term female survivors ("survivors") of breast cancer compared with 88 females who underwent low-risk breast cancer screening ("controls"). The survivors had no history of a psychiatric diagnosis and had been disease-free for at least 5 yrs. The Beck Depression Inventory and the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory were administered. Although the mean level of endorsement of depressive symptoms was within normal limits for the survivors, it was significantly higher than in the control group. The incidence of mild anxiety was also higher in the survivor group. The preliminary results show that mild emotional distress persisted in survivors 5 yrs and longer after the diagnosis of breast cancer. Further study is needed to assess the degree to which other psychosocial factors may contribute to this increased emotional distress in breast cancer survivors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Anxiety; Breast Neoplasms; Depression (Emotion); Remission (Disorders)

TI- Spirituality and patients with advanced cancer: A social work response.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Carr, Elizabeth W.
AU- Morris, Thomas
AF- Carr, Elizabeth W., Thomas Jefferson U Hosp, Dept of Social Work, Philadelphia, PA, US
AF- Morris, Thomas
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14
IP- 1
SD- 1996

SP- 71

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- role in assessment of spirituality as coping behavior of patients with advanced cancer
KP- social workers
SU- Coping Behavior; Social Workers; Spirituality; Terminal Cancer
AB- Social workers and other health care professionals often ignore spirituality, which is part of patients' ability to cope with advanced cancer. However, the social work perspective encourages a holistic approach, including engagement with patients about spiritual issues. The authors offer suggestions to practitioners regarding assessment of the contribution of a patient's spirituality to coping, including noting evidence of the patient's religious affiliation and responding to spiritual references and existential pondering. Interventions that support and reinforce patients' spirituality involve active listening and use of self to help patients explore the essentially unanswerable questions regarding life and death. Referral to a chaplain is particularly important when a patient raises questions about theology or religious rituals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Social Workers; Spirituality; Terminal Cancer
CL- Community & Social Services (3373)

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 29
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v14n01_03
LA- English
KP- marital support & support from other adults & role function & satisfaction with health care
KP- emotional & physical adjustment
KP- husbands of wives with breast cancer
KP- 1 yr study
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Health; Husbands; Social Support
AB- The effect of marital support and support from other adults on the emotional and physical adjustment of 121 husbands of women with breast cancer was examined. Role function and satisfaction with health care (SWHC) also were evaluated as predictors of adjustment. Intact data series were obtained at 7–10 days and at 1, 2, 3, 6, and 12 mo after surgery. At each data-collection point, the Ss completed 4 standardized inventories. Emotional adjustment could be predicted by satisfaction with the patient's response to interactional and emotional needs and by support from other adults. The relationships were significant at concurrent times, across contiguous times, and predictive from the 7–10 day postsurgical period to both the 6-mo and 1-yr end points. Although physical adjustment was predicted by support only at selected times, SWHC was predictive of perceived overall health status at 5 of the data-collection periods. Functional status in vocational domestic, and social roles was significantly related to emotional adjustment at all times with few exceptions and to physical adjustment at selected times. Type of surgery and stage of disease had an effect on selected physical and emotional outcomes over time. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Health; Husbands; Social Support
MN- Health Care Services; Longitudinal Studies; Marital Relations
CL- Cancer (3293)

TI- On the use of checklist measures of coping in studies of adaptation to cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Somerfield, Mark R.
AF- Somerfield, Mark R., American Society of Clinical Oncology, Alexandria, VA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14
IP- 1
SD- 1996
YR- 1996
PM- 1996
PG- 21-40
PC- 20
SP- 21
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v14n01_02
LA- English
KP- usefulness & appropriateness of self-report checklist measures of coping in studies of adaptation to cancer
SU- Adaptation; Coping Behavior; Methodology; Neoplasms; Self Report
AB- Self-report checklist measures of coping continue to be widely used in research on cancer adaptation. The article considers the appropriateness and usefulness of checklist measures for studying the process of coping in this research. Some deficiencies of the conventional application of checklists are discussed, including the failure of checklist data to provide information on (1) the precise character of coping efforts, (2) the intentions underlying the use of specific coping mechanisms, and (3) the natural history or sequencing of coping efforts. Suggested refinements to the checklist methodology, such as the addition of focused probes to follow up endorsed checklist items, are discussed, and the strengths and weaknesses of two promising alternative or complementary methods, diaries and narrative analysis, are outlined. Finally, impediments to and impetuses for change in the assessment of coping are considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)
MJ- Adaptation; Coping Behavior; Methodology; Neoplasms; Self Report
CL- Research Methods & Experimental Design (2260)
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
PT- Journal
PT- Peer Reviewed Journal
AT- Journal Article

TI- Spirituality and the experience of cancer in an African-American community: Implications for psychosocial oncology.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Potts, Randolph G.
AF- Potts, Randolph G., U Hartford, Doctoral Program in Clinical Psychology, West Hartford, CT, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14
IP- 1
SD- 1996
YR- 1996
PM- 1996
PG- 1-19
PC- 19
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v14n01_01
LA- English
KP- spirituality & experience of cancer
KP- 50+ yr old African Americans successfully treated for cancer
KP- implications for psychosocial interventions
SU- Blacks; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders); Spirituality
AB- Examined the role of spirituality in the cancer experiences of 16 African Americans (aged 50+ yrs) living in the southern US. The study was conducted in 2 phases. In the 1st phase, without any investigator-initiated mention of spirituality, Ss referred to 28 categories of spiritual beliefs and practices that were relevant in their experiences with cancer. In the 2nd phase, which specifically explored spirituality, there was greater elaboration on the initial categories, and 7 additional categories were identified. Key findings included (1) the belief in God as the source of healing, (2) the value of prayer as an instrumental practice, (3) a strategy termed "turning it over to the Lord," and (4) the situating of the cancer experience within the larger life narrative. The author suggests that the willingness of care providers to address spiritual and cultural dimensions of cancer may greatly enhance therapeutic relationships and the efficacy of psychosocial interventions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Blacks; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders); Spirituality

TI- A pilot study of cognitive behavioral therapy and social support group interventions with newly diagnosed cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bottomley, Andrew
AU- Hunton, Sandra
AU- Roberts, Gillian
AU- Jones, Lynn
AU- Bradley, Chris
AF- Bottomley, Andrew, Cancer Support Centre, Bradford, England
AF- Hunton, Sandra
AF- Roberts, Gillian
AF- Jones, Lynn
AF- Bradley, Chris
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14
IP- 4
SD- 1996
YR- 1996
PM- 1996
PG- 65-83
PC- 19
SP- 65
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v14n04_05
LA- English
KP- cognitive behavioral therapy vs social support group
KP- psychological distress & coping style
KP- newly diagnosed cancer patients (mean age 53.4 yrs)
SU- Cognitive Therapy; Coping Behavior; Distress; Neoplasms; Social Support
AB- This article describes a study of 31 newly diagnosed, psychologically distressed cancer patients (mean age 53.4 yrs), 9 of whom were assigned to a cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) group and 8, to a social support group. An additional 14 patients were allocated to a "decliners" nonintervention group. When the interventions ended after 8 wks, the scores on the standardized scales for patients in both intervention groups demonstrated limited improvements in their psychological states and coping styles. The coping styles of the CBT patients improved significantly over those of patients in the other 2 groups. CBT may enable patients to overcome some of their psychosocial problems and to modify their coping styles. At the 3-mo follow-up no significant differences were observed between the 2 intervention groups, possibly because 2 CBT patients had died. Results suggest that both interventions, unlike a nonintervention, may buffer patients against psychological distress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Cognitive Therapy; Coping Behavior; Distress; Neoplasms; Social Support

TI- Mind-body partnering for clinical practice.

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

DO- 10.1300/J077v14n04_04
LA- English
KP- conventional & complementary & holistic approaches to cancer treatment
KP- oncology professionals
SU- Alternative Medicine; Holistic Health; Medical Personnel; Neoplasms
AB- Because increasing numbers of cancer patients are seeking a more holistic approach to care, medical professionals need to integrate the best of conventional and complementary approaches to treatment. Why patients are seeking new approaches, which complementary therapies should be used, what the aims of these therapies should be, who should provide them, and who should pay for them are questions that are open to debate. Patients are not waiting for the debate on the efficacy and scientific rigor of these therapies to be resolved. Instead, they are searching for every possible way to benefit from a variety of alternatives. The realities of contemporary cancer care require oncology professionals to determine which forms of complementary medicine are at least neutral rather than harmful and, when possible, determine which are beneficial. By identifying interventions that are safe and effective, practitioners will be better prepared to respond to their patients' questions about additional therapies while encouraging a collaborative approach that incorporates conventional treatments and complementary therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Alternative Medicine; Holistic Health; Medical Personnel; Neoplasms

LA- English
KP- perceptions of role of companions in medical encounters with oncologists
KP- 20–74 yr old cancer patients & 23–71 yr old companions
SU- Medical Patients; Neoplasms; Social Support
AB- To determine the perceptions of the role of cancer patients' companions in medical encounters with oncologists, semistructured telephone interviews were conducted with 18 patients (aged 20–74 yrs) and 17 companions (aged 23–71 yrs). Companions (most often a spouse) attended a medical encounter to provide support and companionship, increase patients' understanding, ask questions, and furnish transportation. Companions viewed themselves as more active than the patients perceived them to be. Patients perceived that the presence of a companion during an appointment resulted in little change in the content of the meeting. The authors concluded that the companion's presence during a medical encounter was important and satisfying to both patients and their companions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- development of For Kids Only program
KP- children from families with cancer patient
SU- Neoplasms; Program Development; Support Groups
AB- This article reviews the literature on the children of cancer patients, outlines several existing programs for children, and describes factors to consider when developing such a program. The program committee is made up of a multidisciplinary team, including nurses, physicians, social workers, psychologists, occupational therapists, plus cancer-survivor volunteers. The "For Kids Only" program was developed to provide children with a safe environment in which they can share their thoughts and feelings and ask questions. Education, support, and screening were established as the goals of the program. The children are given age-appropriate information, and they learn new skills to help them cope more effectively throughout the cancer experience. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- A prospective study of coping and adjustment before and after a parent's death from cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Mireault, Gina C.
AU- Compas, Bruce E.
AF- Mireault, Gina C., Johnson State Coll, Dept of Psychology, Johnson, VT, US
AF- Compas, Bruce E.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14

LA- English
KP- before vs after parent's death from cancer
KP- psychological adjustment
KP- 11–29 yr olds
SU- Age Differences; Death and Dying; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms
AB- 17 adolescents and young adults (aged 11–29 yrs) whose parents had cancer were interviewed before and after the parent's death. They were compared to 17 matched controls whose parents had survived cancer. Ss were divided into 2 groups on the basis of age and measures of psychological adjustment (PSD) used in the study. PSD in the adolescent Ss was assessed with the Youth Self-Report (T.M. Achenbach, 1991) and in the young adult Ss with the Brief Symptom Inventory. The fact that the 2 groups did not differ in degree of anxiety or depression suggests at least short term adaptation to the loss. Adolescents showed more anxiety and depression than did young adults, regardless of group membership. The respondents' adjustment at follow-up was predicted best by their previous adjustment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Exploratory study of residents' perceptions of a housing facility for pediatric patients and family members.

LA- English
KP- residents' perceptions on housing facility
KP- 9–25 yr old patients & their parents
SU- Attitudes; Facility Environment; Housing
AB- Tested the hypotheses that: (1) a number of features of The Children's Inn might be perceived as beneficial to the ill child and family members' emotional well-being; (2) making families responsible for their own daily needs at The Children's Inn would give them a sense of normalcy and a semblance of control over their lives. 102 families (91 parents, 50 patients and 11 siblings [aged 8 yrs and older]) were interviewed. The results supported the stated hypotheses. Nine out of 10 parents reported that The Children's Inn had a positive impact on their child's and their own quality of life. Both parents and patients agreed that staying at The Children's Inn made readjusting to home life easier. In addition, 85% of the parents and patients reported that staying at The Children's Inn made them less resistant to returning to National Institutes of Health. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Desired and perceived social support from family, friends, and health professionals: A panel study in Hong Kong of patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

LA- English
KP- desired & perceived social support from family & friends & health professionals
KP- 10–70+ yr old patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma
KP- Hong Kong
KP- prospective study
KP- September 1992–January 1994
SU- Family Members; Neoplasms; Social Support; Health Personnel
AB- In a panel study of 125 10–70+ yr old patients with nasopharyngeal carcinoma in Hong Kong, the patients reported their desire for and satisfaction with the types of support they received throughout the course of their illness from family members, friends, and health professionals. Results showed that the patients' overall desire for social support was not strong during the diagnostic phase, but it became moderately strong during the treatment and posttreatment phases. Among the 3 sources of support, the patients consistently sought support most often from health professionals, followed by family, then friends. The patients' satisfaction with 4 types of support (informational, emotional, instrumental, and affiliational) from the 3 sources was moderately high in all 3 phases of the illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Quality of life of homebound patients with advanced cancer: Assessments by patients, family members, and oncologists.

AU- Indelli, Monica

AU- Falcini, Fabio
AU- Fabbri, Laura

LA- English
KP- assessment of quality of life
KP- 48–91 yr old homebound patients with advanced cancer receiving palliative care & their relatives & oncologists
KP- Italy
SU- Neoplasms; Quality of Life
AB- Examined, in a home care program in Italy, the concordance between the ratings of 49 48–91 yr old patients with advanced cancer, relatives, and oncologists on a short-form quality of life (QOL) instrument and the concordance between relatives and oncologists on an index of patients' functional independence; and explored the correlations among the QOL ratings provided by the 3 rating sources with a patient-generated QOL instrument and an oncologist-generated rating of patients' performance status. The patients completed the QOL Index (QLI) and the Functional Living Index for Cancer (2–3 wks after admission to the program and 4 wks later), the relatives completed the QLI, and oncologists completed the QLI, Index of Independence in Activities of Daily Living and the Karnofsky Performance Status scale. Overall, the QOL completed by the relatives and oncologists were associated with those of the patients. No difference was found between the QLI ratings of patients and relatives, whereas the oncologists rated the patient's QOL as being worse than the patients did. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- The cancer experience: Responses of patients receiving outpatient radiotherapy.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Eakes, Georgene G.
AU- Rakfal, Susan M.
AU- Keel, Emily
AU- Gaiser, James E.
AF- Eakes, Georgene G., East Carolina U, School of Nursing, Greenville, NC, US
AF- Rakfal, Susan M.
AF- Keel, Emily
AF- Gaiser, James E.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14
IP- 3
SD- 1996
YR- 1996
PM- 1996
PG- 19-30
PC- 12
SP- 19
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 12
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v14n03_02
LA- English
KP- cancer experience
KP- 30–89 yr olds receiving outpatient radiotherapy
KP- posttreatment followup
SU- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Emotional Trauma; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy
AB- Investigated the meaning of the cancer experience for outpatients receiving radiotherapy. Data were collected through interviews with 44 male and female Caucasian and African American patients aged 30–89 yrs before treatment was initiated and within 2 wks after its completion 4–10 wks later. The results identified 3 categories of responses: accepting; coping; and experiencing emotional trauma. These labels were chosen to reflect the essence of the sentiments the patients expressed. Analysis of the responses reinforced the findings of other researchers that the experience of having cancer is emotionally challenging, if not traumatic. Majority of the patients were categorized as "experiencing emotional trauma" at the conclusion of treatment. Consistent with the findings of A. P. O'Connor, et al. (1990) and J. F. Miller (1985), many of the patients relied on the spiritual beliefs as a key source of support. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Emotional Trauma; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy
MN- Client Attitudes; Followup Studies; Outpatients
CL- Medical Treatment of Physical Illness (3363)
CL- Cancer (3293)

PO- Outpatient (60)

TI- Brain tumor as a threat to life and personality: The spouse's perspective.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Salander, Pär
AF- Salander, Pär, Umeå U, Dept of Oncology, Umeå, Sweden
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 14
IP- 3
SD- 1996
YR- 1996
PM- 1996
PG- 1-18
PC- 18
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v14n03_01
LA- English
KP- psychosocial situation
KP- 28–73 yr old spouses of patients with Grade III or IV malignant glioma
KP- prospective study
KP- 1991–93
SU- Brain Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Distress; Spouses; Terminally Ill Patients
AB- Studied the psychosocial situation of the spouses of patients with brain tumors. 24 male and female spouses of patients (aged 28–73 yrs) with Grade III or IV malignant glioma, who were included in a clinical trial between 1991 and 1993, were interviewed regarding experiences with medical care; knowledge and ideas about the disease; and the impact on the patient, family, work, interests, and future plans. Repeated interviews displayed 3 different crisis trajectories: crisis delayed until the disease progressed, immediate crisis, and crisis delayed until the patient returned home. The trajectories were highly dependent on the patient's overall status. Three clinical implications were suggested: spouses should be viewed as separate people with their own needs, spouses should have a physician of their own; and the concepts of mutuality and personal platform may be useful tools for assessing spouse's distress and means of coping with strain. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Brain Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Distress; Spouses; Terminally Ill Patients

TI- Facilitating hopefulness: The determinants of hope.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bunston, Terry
AU- Mings, Deborah
AU- Mackie, Andrea
AU- Jones, Diane
AF- Bunston, Terry, Ontario Cancer Inst/Princess Margaret Hosp, Psychosocial Oncology Program, Toronto, Canada
AF- Mings, Deborah
AF- Mackie, Andrea
AF- Jones, Diane
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 13
IP- 4
SD- 1995
YR- 1995
PM- 1995
PG- 79-103
PC- 25
SP- 79
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 25
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V13N04_05
LA- English
KP- model of determinants of hope
KP- patients with ocular melanoma & head & neck cancer
SU- Hope; Models; Neoplasms
AB- Attempted to build a model of the determinants of hope using path analysis. These results were based on a cross-sectional survey of 194 outpatients: 96 with ocular melanoma and 98 with head and neck cancer. The resulting empirical model emphasizes the importance of locus of control as either a direct determinant of hope or a factor that buffers distress and buttresses coping. The model also underscores the role that demographic characteristics, specifically, age, sex, occupation, and education, play as determinants of hope. The contributions of coping and physical and psychosocial functioning are named as indirect determinants of hope. Contrary to the literature and the hypothesized model, coping difficulties were not found to have a direct impact on hope. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Hope; Models; Neoplasms

TI- The use of weighted scores with the Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT) scales.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

LA- English
KP- use of scores weighted by patient preference
KP- assessment of importance of domains of quality of life with adapted Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy
KP- cancer patients in chemotherapy
SU- Measurement; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Scoring (Testing); Statistical Weighting
AB- An adaptation of the D. F. Cella et al (1993) Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy (FACT) was administered to 102 cancer patients who were undergoing outpatient chemotherapy. Unweighted scores and scores weighted by patient preference were calculated. Additionally, differences in the importance of the different domains of quality of life to the patient sample were explored. Relationship with Doctor was most important to the patients and Physical Well-being was least important. These results suggest that weighted scores can provide potentially important information to clinicians and researchers that is not available with unweighted scores. The weighting method one might choose to use depends on patient and study considerations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Information, support, and decision-making needs and preferences of adolescents with cancer: Implications for health professionals.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Dunsmore, Julie
AU- Quine, Susan
AF- Dunsmore, Julie, Royal North Shore Hosp, Dept of Health Promotion & Education, Sydney, NSW, Australia
AF- Quine, Susan
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 13

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- needs for information & support & decision making participation regarding treatment
KP- 15–24 yr olds with cancer
KP- Australia
KP- implications for communication with health professionals
SU- Client Attitudes; Client Participation; Decision Making; Neoplasms; Treatment
AB- Presents findings from an exploratory study of treatment experiences and preferences of 51 Australian young people (aged 15–24 yrs) with cancer. The objective was to identify their information, support, and decision-making needs and preferences to inform health professionals. A 42-item self-administered questionnaire was developed to collect current and retrospective data. The young people wished to be more involved in treatment decisions. Almost all of them wanted to be informed about bad news, such as ineffective treatment, poor prognosis, and imminent death. Their preferences for involvement with health professionals, family, and peers in different contexts are reported. The qualities of health professionals that facilitated communication, according to the Ss, were the ability to listen, genuine concern, professional expertise, and honesty. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- cross informant variance in perceptions of patient's social & psychological adjustment
KP- 5–13 yr old newly diagnosed pediatric cancer patients
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Social Adjustment
AB- Investigated cross-informant variance and longitudinal predictive relations among the perceptions of children, parents, and teachers of child adjustment in newly diagnosed pediatric cancer patients. Ss were 64 children (aged 5–13 yrs). Measures of adjustment included assessments of depression, anxiety, behavior, social acceptance, and social anxiety. Assessments were made 3 times over 9 mo for most Ss. Consistent with the general empirical literature on children, the results generally demonstrated small to medium effect sizes (rs of .10–.50) across the 3 groups, indicating the need for cross-informant assessment to determine the quality of life of pediatric cancer patients more adequately. Implications for treatment are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- limb salvage procedure vs initial amputation
KP- psychosocial adaptation & psychological symptoms & coping skills
KP- 11–24 yr olds with bone sarcomas
SU- Amputation; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychiatric Symptoms; Social Adjustment
AB- Evaluated 45 bone sarcoma patients (aged 11–24 yrs at diagnosis) who had survived an average of 7 yrs at the time of the study. Ss were assessed with both standardized measures of psychological symptoms and a semistructured clinical interview. No differences were found in the mean psychopathology scores of the 32 treated with a limb salvage procedure vs the 13 treated with initial amputation. Significant differences in psychosocial adaptation were found between the 2 groups. The amputees felt they were not employed at a level appropriate to their skills and training, and they were less likely than the limb salvage group to have married since the diagnosis. Good coping skills protected the limb-spared group, but not the amputees, from having higher scores on the measures of psychopathology, depression, and anxiety. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- nursing practices generating patient's feelings of being cared for
KP- cancer patients & oncology nurses
SU- Hospitalized Patients; Neoplasms; Nursing; Therapeutic Processes; Oncology
AB- Interviewed 8 cancer patients, 8 oncology nurses, and 8 other participants to identify nursing practices and characteristics that make a patient feel cared for. A grounded theory approach was used to analyze and categorize responses. Interrater agreement regarding identified behaviors was acceptable, whereas agreement for categorizations was low. The final categorization included 174 behaviors organized under the headings of social, communicative, organizational, medical-technical competence, and contact with relatives. The groups agreed fairly well on which behaviors make patients feel cared for. All groups mentioned behaviors representing the task-oriented, cognitive, emotional, and social aspects of caring, and members of all 3 groups mentioned behaviors specific for their own group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Correlates of hopelessness in cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ringdal, Gerd Inger
AF- Ringdal, Gerd Inger, U Trondheim, Faculty of Medicine, Dept of Psychiatry & Behavioural Medicine, Trondheim, Norway
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 13
IP- 3
SD- 1995
YR- 1995
PM- 1995
PG- 47-66
PC- 20
SP- 47
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V13N03_03
LA- English
KP- relationship of hopelessness to physical functioning & age & economic situation & survival
KP- 23-78 yr old hospitalized cancer patients
SU- Age Differences; Hopelessness; Mortality Rate; Neoplasms; Socioeconomic Status
AB- Examined correlates of hopelessness in 253 hospitalized cancer patients (aged 23–78 yrs) who were suffering from various diagnoses and were at different stages of disease. A 14-item Hopelessness Scale was found to be one-dimensional and satisfactory in terms of scalability and reliability. The distribution of the scale was skewed to the left, i.e., most patients displayed low feelings of hopelessness. A multiple regression analysis showed that the patients' physical functioning, age, and economic situation were significantly related to their scores on the Hopelessness Scale. A Kaplan-Meier survival analysis showed a significant relationship between survival and hopelessness. However, a multiple Cox regression analysis showed that hopelessness was not significantly related to survival when other relevant covariates were controlled for. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Age Differences; Hopelessness; Mortality Rate; Neoplasms; Socioeconomic Status

TI- The psychological, social, and economic impact of illness among patients with recurrent cancer.

LA- English
KP- psychological & social & economic impact of recurrent cancer & treatment
KP- patients
KP- 4 & 8 mo followups
SU- Economics; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Relapse (Disorders); Treatment
AB- Examined the psychological, social, and economic impact of recurrent cancer and its treatment on an initial sample of 268 patients. Structured interviews were conducted at the initiation of palliative radiation therapy and 4 and 8 mo later, with 161 Ss from the original sample. Data were obtained on health status, psychological functioning, personality attributes, social support, health care utilization, and finances. Except for medical transportation, most of the patients' concrete needs did not change over time. Economic issues independently predicted psychological outcomes. Patients perceived stress, role restriction, self-esteem, and total symptoms decreased over time, whereas their dispositional pessimism increased. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Sibling Adaptation to Childhood Cancer Collaborative Study: Parental views of pre- and postdiagnosis adjustment of siblings of children with cancer.

LA- English
KP- sex & birth order & severity of patient's illness
KP- behavioral & emotional & affective symptoms & positive changes
KP- adjustment after diagnosis of cancer in sibling
KP- 4-18 yr olds
SU- Behavior Problems; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychiatric Symptoms; Siblings
AB- In open-ended interviews, 179 parents of 254 siblings (aged 4–18 yrs) of children with cancer evaluated the pre- and postdiagnosis adjustment of their children. 25% of the siblings were asymptomatic both before and after the diagnosis. Behavior and emotional problems were the most frequently reported problems arising after the diagnosis. Before the diagnosis, less than 12% of the siblings had either behavioral or affective symptoms, whereas 26% had such symptoms after the diagnosis. Type of maladjustment was unrelated to sex, birth order, or severity of the patient's illness. On the positive side, parents also reported favorable changes because of the illness in siblings' maturity, supportiveness, and independence. Positive effects were more likely to occur among adolescent and 1st-born siblings and when the patient's prognosis was poorer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Exploring oncologists' beliefs about psychosocial groups: Implications for patient care and research.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Leis, Anne M.
AU- Haines, Carol S.
AU- Pancyr, Glenn C.
AF- Leis, Anne M., U Saskatchewan, Coll of Medicine, Dept of Community Health & Epidemiology, Louis Schulman Cancer Epidemiology Unit, Saskatoon, Canada
AF- Haines, Carol S.
AF- Pancyr, Glenn C.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 12
IP- 4
SD- 1994
YR- 1994
PM- 1994
PG- 77-87
PC- 11
SP- 77
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 11
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V12N04_05
LA- English
KP- attitudes toward patient psychosocial groups
KP- oncologists
KP- Canada
SU- Group Counseling; Health Personnel Attitudes; Neoplasms; Physicians
AB- Examined the beliefs of medical and radiation oncologists regarding psychosocial (PS) groups for patients with cancer. The willingness of oncologists to initiate referrals routinely to such groups was also examined. 16 adult-care oncologists completed a questionnaire regarding the harm or benefit they expected from PS groups and their views about appropriate intervention targets and timing. Ss were relatively unfamiliar with PS interventions, and referrals to PS services during usual care were scarce. Ss reported that harm to patients was not a major concern, but they did not anticipate much benefit either. Although 75% of Ss believed that initiating a PS program before a patient had accepted and been shown an oncology treatment plan would be harmful, benefits were expected during treatment and after existing therapies failed. Depression, anxiety, anger, and compliance with treatment were selected as appropriate focuses for PS groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Group Counseling; Health Personnel Attitudes; Neoplasms; Physicians

TI- Pediatric bone marrow transplantation: Psychosocial issues for parents after a child's hospitalization.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sormanti, Mary
AU- Dungan, Sheryn
AU- Rieker, Patricia P.
AF- Sormanti, Mary, Dana-Farber Cancer Inst, Boston, MA, US
AF- Dungan, Sheryn
AF- Rieker, Patricia P.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 12
IP- 4
SD- 1994
YR- 1994
PM- 1994
PG- 23-42
PC- 20
SP- 23
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V12N04_02
LA- English
KP- child's bone marrow transplantation
KP- mental outlook & relationships & functional ability & adjustment
KP- parents of children with cancer
SU- Bone Marrow; Family Relations; Organ Transplantation; Parents; Social Adjustment
AB- Examined the long-term impact of children's bone marrow transplants on parents' mental outlook, relationships, and functional activities. A self-report questionnaire that included the Profile of Mood States and the Cancer Patient Behavior Scale was completed by 73 parents whose children successfully completed the transplant between 1–20 yrs prior to the study. The majority of Ss were not experiencing long-term psychosocial problems because of their child's bone marrow transplant. The most difficult period reported by Ss was the child's hospitalization, and the most distressed Ss were those whose child had received the transplant less than 24 mo before the study. Despite a general trend showing a decrease of problems and distress over time, several psychosocial problems remained: concerns about the child, insurance, finances, and the parent's own physical and mental health. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Bone Marrow; Family Relations; Organ Transplantation; Parents; Social Adjustment
MN- Family Members; Neoplasms; World View

TI- Parent-child interactions with pediatric bone marrow transplant patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Lee, Marian L.
AU- Cohen, Sarale E.
AU- Stuber, Margaret L.
AU- Nader, Kathleen
AF- Lee, Marian L., Yeshiva U, Albert Einstein Coll of Medicine, Bronx, NY, US
AF- Cohen, Sarale E.
AF- Stuber, Margaret L.
AF- Nader, Kathleen
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 12
IP- 4
SD- 1994
YR- 1994
PM- 1994
PG- 43-60
PC- 18
SP- 43
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V12N04_03
LA- English
KP- parent child relations
KP- parents & children with cancer before & after bone marrow transplantation
SU- Bone Marrow; Neoplasms; Organ Transplantation; Parent Child Relations
AB- Expanded on the M. L. Stuber et al (see record [rid]1992-20966-001[/rid]) study of the psychosocial impact of bone marrow transplants on 6 young children (aged 3–6 yrs at time of transplant) by examining the interactions between these 6 Ss and their parents. Data were collected from children and parents within a week before the transplant and 3, 6, 12, and 24 mo after the transplant using the Family Interaction Q-Sort with data from 20-min videotapes where parents completed 3 interaction tasks. Data were also collected for 7 control children (aged 3–6 yrs) and their parents. Parental responsiveness (PR) remained stable across time. Less parental education was associated with less responsive parenting. When PR was compared with children's symptoms of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), lower PR was associated with fewer symptoms and higher PR was associated with more symptoms. All parents used multiple coping patterns to handle their children's cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Psychosocial effects of breast cancer on the patient's children.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Howes, Mary J.
AU- Hoke, Lizbeth
AU- Winterbottom, Marian
AU- Delafield, Deborah

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- psychosocial adjustment to mother's breast cancer
KP- 3–18 yr olds
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Mothers; Offspring; Social Adjustment
AB- Examined the relationship of medical and psychological factors in mothers with breast cancer to their children's psychosocial adjustment. 19 White women with breast cancer, who had a total of 32 children (aged 3–18 yrs), responded to a semistructured interview and completed the Child Behavior Checklist, the Psychosocial Adjustment to Illness Scale, and the Family Adaptability and Cohesion Evaluation Scales III. On average, the children fell within the normal range for emotional and behavior problems and competence. Ratings of more emotional and behavior problems were linked with children whose mothers reported more psychological distress and a lack of serious complications in their illness. Mothers who did not experience serious complications of treatment also reported lower overall competence in their children. Family adaptability appeared to be related to the ability of mothers and children to cope with the mother's illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Mothers; Offspring; Social Adjustment

TI- Depressive symptomatology in parents of children with chronic oncologic or hematologic disease.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Nelson, Audrey E.
AU- Miles, Margaret Shandor
AU- Reed, Susan B.

LA- English
KP- coping strategies & perceptions of illness severity & support & depressive symptomatology
KP- parents of children with chronic oncologic or hematologic disorder
SU- Blood and Lymphatic Disorders; Coping Behavior; Major Depression; Parents; Social Support
AB- Examined (1) the frequency of depressive symptomatology (DS) in parents of children (mean age 5.5 yrs) who were recently diagnosed with a chronic oncologic or hematologic disorder and (2) the relationship between intrusion and avoidance coping, parental perceptions of support, perceptions of the severity of the child's illness, and DS. Self-report questionnaires on depression, coping strategies, and perceptions of illness and support were completed by 32 parents within 6 mo of their child's diagnosis (Time 1) and by 21 parents approximately 12 mo later (Time 2). 14 parents at Time 1 and 7 parents (all mothers) at Time 2 had scores indicating DS. No significant change in mean depression scores occurred between Time 1 and Time 2. Avoidance coping was the only variable that significantly predicted DS at Time 1. Neither parents' perceptions of support nor perceptions of the severity of the child's illness were significant predictors for DS. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Blood and Lymphatic Disorders; Coping Behavior; Major Depression; Parents; Social Support
MN- Parental Attitudes; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Severity (Disorders); Symptoms

TI- Fieldwork instruction in oncology social work: Supervisory issues.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sormanti, Mary
AF- Sormanti, Mary, Dana-Farber Cancer Inst, Boston, MA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 12
IP- 3
SD- 1994
YR- 1994
PM- 1994
PG- 73-87
PC- 15
SP- 73
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V12N03_05
LA- English
KP- supervisory issues relating to fieldwork instruction in oncology social work
SU- Neoplasms; Professional Supervision; Social Work Education; Oncology
AB- Examined supervisory issues that arise when working with social work students who are placed in an oncology setting. 10 female hospital oncology supervisors were interviewed in a focus-group setting. Three main themes emerged during the interview. First, oncology social work is different from and perhaps more difficult than social work in other settings, and supervision of beginners differs from supervision of beginners in other specialties. Second, the problems in oncology are difficult to grapple with, and a certain type of student is required to do the work well. Finally, gaps in the curricula of schools of social work have a negative impact on the total learning experience of students in oncology and other medical settings. Concerns that students brought to supervision included somatic reactions, dissynchrony with peers, and countertransference. Recommendations for adequately preparing students for work in an oncology setting are provided. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Professional Supervision; Social Work Education; Oncology
CL- Professional Education & Training (3410)

TI- When a child is diagnosed with cancer: II. Parental coping, psychological adjustment, and relationships with medical personnel.

AU- Larson, Laura S.

LA- English
KP- coping strategies
KP- psychological adjustment & relationships with medical personnel
KP- parents of children in active treatment for cancer
SU- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Parents; Therapeutic Processes
AB- Investigated the relationship between coping strategies and self-reports of psychological adjustment among parents of children with cancer. 17 sets of parents who had a child in active treatment for cancer (CTC) and a control group of 32 sets of parents whose child had the flu completed the Coping Strategies Inventory, the Social Support Questionnaire, the Dyadic Adjustment Scale, the Beck Depression Inventory, and the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory. CTC parents rated their satisfaction with medical staff, and medical staff rated parents' coping styles and their appropriateness. Higher medical staff ratings of parental adjustment were correlated with more years of parental education. Among controls, engaged coping was related to less anxiety and depression and greater marital satisfaction; this relationship was not observed in CTC parents. Disengaged coping was related to greater levels of maladjustment for parents in both groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Coping with breast cancer from the perspectives of husbands and wives.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ptacek, J. T.
AU- Ptacek, John J.

LA- English
KP- coping with stress of radiation therapy
KP- psychological adjustment & marital satisfaction
KP- breast cancer patients & their husbands
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Husbands; Radiation Therapy
AB- Conducted a cross-sectional study to explore the coping and adjustment process of breast cancer sufferers and their husbands. 36 breast cancer patients and their husbands provided information about how each recalled coping with stress during a course of radiation therapy. Spouses also reported on one another's coping efforts and provided information about their own current psychological adjustment and marital satisfaction. Wives engaged in more extensive and varied coping efforts than their husbands did, and the coping strategies that husbands and wives used were largely independent. Self-reported coping related to an individual's own outcomes. Significant crossover associations were found between the coping reports of one spouse and the marital satisfaction and mental health of the other; husbands' outcomes were more strongly correlated with their wives' reports of their own coping than vice versa. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Husbands; Radiation Therapy

TI- The Mini-MAC: Further development of the Mental Adjustment to Cancer scale.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Watson, Maggie
AU- Law, Matthew
AU- dos Santos, Maria
AU- Greer, Steven
AU- Baruch, John
AU- Bliss, Judith
AF- Watson, Maggie, Royal Marsden Hosp, Sutton, England

PG- 33-46

SP- 33

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- extension & refinement of scope of Mental Adjustment to Cancer scale
KP- assessment of coping style
KP- 18–75 yr old cancer patients
SU- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Rating Scales
AB- Extended and refined the scope of the Mental Adjustment to Cancer (MAC) scale (M. Watson et al; see record [rid]1989-03649-001[/rid]), a self-report measure designed to give a rapid assessment of coping style. 573 cancer patients (aged 18–75 yrs) in either early or advanced stages of the disease completed a questionnaire containing the MAC scale and an additional 26-item research scale. A rigorous factor analysis procedure was used to determine the items that would be retained for a new scale: the 29-item Mini-MAC. The scope of the original MAC scale was widened to include items relating to avoidance (an important psychological response), and original response items were clarified and refined. Results suggest that the Mini-MAC should be a useful tool for obtaining a rapid, reliable, and economical assessment of coping style. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Rating Scales

TI- Oncologists' perceptions of the effects of cancer patients' companions on physician-patient interactions.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Beisecker, Analee E.
AU- Moore, William P.
AF- Beisecker, Analee E., U Kansas Medical Ctr, Cancer Ctr, Kansas City, US

LA- English
KP- perceptions of companion's role & effect of presence of cancer patient's companion on interactions with patient
KP- 32–56 yr old oncologists
SU- Family Members; Neoplasms; Physicians; Therapeutic Processes
AB- Interviewed 12 oncologists (aged 32–56 yrs) to determine physicians' perceptions of the effects that the companions of cancer patients have on physician–patient communication. Ss estimated that 75% of their patients brought companions with them to consultations and said that these consultations were more complex for the physician. The behaviors of the companions varied from domination to passive note taking, and the companions who were young professional men or older women who accompanied their husbands were the most assertive and asked the most questions. All possible coalitions were observed during medical visits. Ss perceived that companions and patients often had different agendas and noted differences in the companions' behaviors according to their gender and whether they lived in rural or urban areas. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Family Members; Neoplasms; Physicians; Therapeutic Processes

TI- Satisfaction of breast cancer patients with their medical and psychological care.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Burton, Mary V.
AU- Parker, Ronald W.
AF- Burton, Mary V., Abbots Langley Hosp, England
AF- Parker, Ronald W.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- satisfaction with medical & psychological care at time of surgery & later
KP- breast cancer patients
KP- 1 yr followup
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Client Satisfaction; Surgical Patients
AB- Examined breast cancer patients' satisfaction with their medical and psychological care at the time of surgery and 1 yr later. Interviews were conducted with 162 patients the day before surgery, and 237 follow-up interviews were conducted 1 yr later. Ss reacted more positively than negatively to the service they received. Before surgery, complaints were positively correlated with the fighting spirit or anxious preoccupation style of coping and with anxiety and depression and were negatively correlated with denial and stoic acceptance and with age. Ss in lower SES groups complained less than did those in higher SES groups. A year later, complaints were positively correlated with overall distress scores. Ss with cancer plus other illnesses or with recurrent cancer complained the most. The complaints that were recorded suggest aspects of service that need to be improved, especially regarding physician–patient communication. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Client Satisfaction; Surgical Patients
MN- Followup Studies

TI- Psychiatric and psychosocial aspects of neurooncology.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Passik, Steven D.

LA- English
KP- psychiatric & psychosocial impacts of CNS cancer
KP- psychotherapy for patients & group interventions for spouses & hospital staff
SU- Nervous System Neoplasms; Psychopathology; Psychotherapy; Social Adjustment
AB- Describes the psychiatric and psychosocial impacts of neurooncologic illness and its treatment on patients, families, and staff. The psychiatric and psychosocial impacts of CNS cancer and its treatment are unique, primarily because of their direct effect on the brain and thus on the mind, personality, memory, and concept of self. Patients can undergo dramatic changes in mood, cognitive integrity, and ability to function independently. The impact of these changes affects not only the patient but also the spouse, family, hospital staff, and other caregivers who are called on to provide an exhausting level of care. Psychotherapeutic interventions for patients and group interventions for spouses and hospital staff are also described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Nervous System Neoplasms; Psychopathology; Psychotherapy; Social Adjustment
MN- Medical Personnel; Spouses

KP- cosmetics class
KP- mood & perceptions of own attractiveness
KP- 26–83 yr old breast surgery patients
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Curriculum; Emotional States; Physical Attractiveness; Self Perception
AB- Evaluated the "Look Good, Feel Better" program, a cosmetics class designed to restore the appearance and self-image of women with cancer. Ss were 121 women (aged 26–83 yrs) who were hospitalized for breast surgery. 45 Ss (experimental group) who participated in a class were compared with 76 Ss who had not yet participated in a class. Ss in the experimental group reported significantly greater improvements in their mood and perceptions of their attractiveness when compared with the control group. TI- Some observations on individual and marital therapy with breast cancer patients and spouses.

LA- English
KP- individual vs couples vs group therapy
KP- breast cancer patients & spouses
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Marriage Counseling; Psychotherapy; Spouses
AB- Describes the rationale and method used to provide traditional psychotherapy to 125 patients with Stage I or II breast cancer and their husbands. The patients' complaints of marital difficulties, loss of functioning, exacerbated emotionality, and reactivation of feelings of victimization were treated in individual, couples, or group therapy. Individual or couples therapy was provided to husbands who were overprotective or withdrawn, with or without depression and anxiety. The outcomes of therapy, the criteria for deciding whether to refer patients and husbands for therapy, and the need for a female or male therapist are discussed. In addition to interventions involving the important aspects of support and behavior applications, traditional therapy can be used. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- When a child is diagnosed with cancer: I. Sex differences in parental adjustment.
