DO- 10.1300/J077V12N01_07
LA- English
KP- sex
KP- coping style & adjustment to child's cancer diagnosis
KP- parents
SU- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Fathers; Mothers; Neoplasms
AB- Examined potential sex differences in how parents cope and adjust when a child is diagnosed with cancer. 17 couples whose child had cancer and was in active treatment or follow-up were compared with 32 couples whose child had the flu. Findings did not support the main hypotheses that (1) fathers of cancer patients would use more maladaptive coping strategies and different social support systems than mothers and would be less anxious and depressed and (2) both parents would be more psychologically distressed than the controls. No significant sex-specific differences were observed in the experimental group: The parents appeared to be adjusting well and coping appropriately but were more anxious than the controls. Mothers in both groups reported more engaged coping styles, slightly more depression, and more use of social support than did fathers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Fathers; Mothers; Neoplasms

LA- English
KP- sex
KP- social support & coping strategies & psychosocial adjustment to cancer & cognitive & emotional responses
KP- adult cancer patients
SU- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Human Sex Differences; Neoplasms; Social Adjustment
AB- Examined gender differences in psychosocial adjustment to cancer for 125 men and 206 women. The influence of social support, coping strategies, cognitive response, and emotional response on adjustment were studied. No significant differences by gender were found in the level of distress experienced; however, women made a more positive adjustment, and social support and coping strategies appeared to affect these differences. The impact of social support by gender and the differences in coping are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Responses to AIDS-related bereavement.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Richmond, Brigitte J.
AU- Ross, Michael W.
AF- Richmond, Brigitte J., U New South Wales, National Ctr in HIV Social Research, Sydney, Australia
AF- Ross, Michael W.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 12
IP- 1-2
SD- 1994
YR- 1994
PM- 1994
PG- 143-163
PC- 21
SP- 143
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V12N01_08
LA- English
KP- bereavement following loss of partner or family member to AIDS
KP- 27–57 yr olds
SU- AIDS; Family Members; Grief; Significant Others
AB- Examined the responses of 16 partners and close family members (aged 27–57 yrs) who were bereaved when a partner or family member died of AIDS. Special emphasis was placed on the patterns of bereavement and possible signs of posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD) in the 2 groups of Ss. Ss who had lost lovers or family members to AIDS focused on the positive aspects of death and dying; most of them described loneliness and feelings of emptiness as their worst encounters with bereavement. The format of funerals appeared to encapsulate their feelings about the dead loved one and reactions to the loss. Self-euthanasia also generated ambivalent feelings. Ss received the most support from friends, support groups, or professional counselors rather than from family members. Most Ss showed little or no concern about their own future with regard to HIV or AIDS. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- AIDS; Family Members; Grief; Significant Others

LA- English
KP- perceived stress
KP- psychological distress & adjustment
KP- 13–23 yr old long term survivors of childhood cancer
SU- Distress; Early Experience; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Stress
AB- Investigated the psychological adjustment correlates of perceived stress in 39 survivors (aged 13–23 yrs) of childhood cancer. Ss completed the Adolescent Perceived Events Scale, SCL-90 (Revised), the Self-Perception Profile for Adolescents, and a global severity index of psychological distress. Higher perceived stress statistically predicted increased psychological distress (including depression, anxiety, interpersonal sensitivity, obsessive-compulsiveness, hostility, psychoticism, and paranoid ideation) and lower general self-esteem after controlling for relevant demographic and medical variables. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Health care providers' and cancer patients' preferences regarding disclosure of information about advance directives.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Shore, Andrew D.
AU- Rubin, Haya R.
AU- Haisfield, Mary Ellen
AU- McGuire, Deborah B.
AU- Zabora, James R.

VI- 11

SD- 1993

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- preferences concerning disclosure of information about advance directives
KP- cancer patients vs health care providers
SU- Advance Directives; Client Attitudes; Health Personnel Attitudes; Neoplasms
AB- Examined how health care providers and patients believe information about advance directives (e.g., living wills) should be presented, noting that the Patient Self-Determination Act (PSDA) of 1990 requires hospitals to tell patients about their right to complete an advance directive. When focus groups of 15 providers and 8 patients from a regional cancer center were held, nurses expressed more comfort with the requirements of the PSDA than did physicians, who were particularly concerned about the effect of the PSDA on their ability to treat patients in critical situations. Although patients were in favor of advance directives, they felt that admission was not the best time to learn about them. Testing the effectiveness of distributing written information to patients before admission and using specially trained personnel to discuss advance directives may be worthwhile. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Advance Directives; Client Attitudes; Health Personnel Attitudes; Neoplasms

TI- Self concealment: Implications for stress and empathy in oncology care.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Larson, Dale G.
AF- Larson, Dale G., Santa Clara U, Health Psychology Program, CA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 11
IP- 4
SD- 1993
YR- 1993
PM- 1993
PG- 1-16
PC- 16
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V11N04_01
LA- English
KP- stress & empathy & self concealment in patient interactions
KP- oncology staff
SU- Distress; Empathy; Neoplasms; Self Disclosure; Therapeutic Processes
AB- Explores interactions between distress, empathy, and self-concealment in oncology work. Oncology staff and patients, like all people faced with stressful situations, are confronted with the dilemma of whether to conceal or reveal the distress they are experiencing. For both staff and patients, self-concealment as a coping response increases stress and simultaneously diminishes the likelihood of helpful, empathic responses from others. It is concluded that oncology staff must find safe contexts and confidants for sharing their inevitable fears, self-doubts, and uncomfortable feelings and must help patients resolve the distress-disclosure dilemma that attends the cancer experience. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Distress; Empathy; Neoplasms; Self Disclosure; Therapeutic Processes
MN- Health Personnel; Oncology

LA- English
KP- development & evaluation of computer based Comprehensive Health Enhancement Support System
KP- provision of referral & decision & social support information
KP- younger vs older females with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Computer Applications; Health Care Services; Information Systems; Social Support
AB- Discusses development of a computer-based support system to help women cope with breast cancer. The system, called Comprehensive Health Enhancement Support System (CHESS) contains integrated information, referral, decision, and social support programs. Two preliminary versions of CHESS were tested extensively by 10 younger women (mean age 51 yrs; 1st pilot study) and 20 older women (mean age 57 yrs; 2nd pilot study). Ss suggested several content enhancements and user-friendly aids for the developing system. User surveys indicate that CHESS was easy to use and would be valuable to other women with breast cancer, their partners, and their adult children. The Ss reported that they experienced more positive emotions and fewer negative emotions as a result of using the system. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Laughter therapy for patients with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Erdman, Lynn
AF- Erdman, Lynn, Presbyterian Hosp, Cancer Ctr, Charlotte, NC, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 11
IP- 4
SD- 1993

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- nurses' role in laughter therapy in health care setting
KP- cancer patients
SU- Laughter; Neoplasms; Nursing
AB- Discusses the physiologic, communicative, social-interactive, and psychological benefits of humor in the health care setting. While laughter therapy is not a curative treatment, much suffering has been alleviated through its use. The appropriate use of laughter for health care is discussed, as is initiating humor in the health care setting and developing a humor program. Nurses can assess the laughter needs of patients and interject humor into their nursing care plans. Positive emotions engendered by hospital humor can enhance prescribed medical treatment. One successful approach to introducing humor into a hospital setting is a hall-roving "Laugh Mobile." Its humorous novelties, books, and films help divert the attention of suffering patients to lighter thoughts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Comparison of a function-based model and a meaning-based model of quality of life in oncology: Multidimensionality examined.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Costain, Kirsten
AU- Hewison, Jenny
AU- Howes, Mark
AF- Costain, Kirsten, U Leeds, Dept of Psychology, England
AF- Hewison, Jenny
AF- Howes, Mark
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 11

SD- 1993
YR- 1993

PG- 17-37

SP- 17

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V11N04_02
LA- English
KP- correlation between functional living based Ontario Cancer Institute scale & meaning based Quality of Life Scale
KP- 29–89 yr olds with cancer
SU- Models; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Rating Scales
AB- Compared the view of quality of life (QOL) derived from 2 different conceptual measures of QOL: the Ontario Cancer Institute (OCI) scale and the Quality of Life Scale (QOLS). The OCI scale, a functional living model, focuses on detecting physical and psychological distress and dysfunction. In contrast, the QOLS focuses on the meaning of the experience of illness for the patient, particularly patient beliefs and relationships. 38 cancer patients (aged 29–89 yrs) completed both questionnaires. The QOLS indicated greater dissatisfaction on the pain and depression items, information, and global QOL than did the OCI. No significant correlations between the 2 measures were found for the 3 non-function-specific psychosocial domains of family relationships, information, and social life. The QOLS produced more information on the 3 domains. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Parental intervention in the medical care of children with cancer.

LA- English
KP- roles & interventions in medical care
KP- parents of children with cancer
SU- Medical Treatment (General); Neoplasms; Parental Role
AB- Some parents deal with the medical and psychosocial challenges of childhood cancer by playing an active and assertive role in the medical treatment process. In this study involving 116 parents of children with cancer, 56% reported intervening at some point in the treatment process to prevent or correct a medical mistake. The nature of these interventions varied, but prominent among them were behaviors intended to (1) prevent or correct erroneous administration of drugs, (2) remind the staff of correct or incorrect procedures, (3) alter intravenous procedures, and (4) mediate the staff's style of interacting with ill children. Parents with fairly high levels of income and education and those who were active in a local self-help group reported that they intervened more often. Moreover, parents who reported less satisfaction with the emotional support they received from staff reported intervening more often. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Medical Treatment (General); Neoplasms; Parental Role

TI- Factors relating to a person's ability to find meaning after a diagnosis of cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Thompson, Suzanne C.
AU- Pitts, Jennifer S.
AF- Thompson, Suzanne C., Pomona Coll, Dept of Psychology, Claremont, CA, US
AF- Pitts, Jennifer S.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 11

PG- 1-21

SP- 1

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- optimism & endorsement of irrational life & focus on internal vs external goals
KP- meaningfulness of life after diagnosis
KP- 31–82 yr olds with cancer & their spouses
SU- Goals; Irrational Beliefs; Meaningfulness; Neoplasms; Optimism
AB- Examined 2 hypotheses about factors that would make it easier or more difficult to see one's life as meaningful after a major life stressor. 79 cancer patients (aged 31–82 yrs) and their spouses participated. It was predicted that greater meaning would be associated with positive interpretational styles (optimism and low endorsement of irrational beliefs) and a focus on internal rather than external goals. Results support the hypotheses: Greater meaningfulness was associated with optimism, few irrational beliefs, and endorsement of internal goals, even when physical functioning and depression were controlled for in a multiple regression analysis. Patients reported significant changes regarding irrational beliefs and internal goals subsequent to the diagnosis of cancer. Current beliefs and goals predicted meaningfulness, but reports of prediagnosis beliefs and goals did not. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Goals; Irrational Beliefs; Meaningfulness; Neoplasms; Optimism
MN- Spouses; World View

LA- English
KP- spiritual awareness & personal perspective on death & psychosocial distress
KP- 18–83 yr olds with cancer
SU- Death Attitudes; Distress; Neoplasms; Spirituality
AB- Examined the relationship between transpersonal development and psychosocial distress of cancer patients. The study was based on a theoretical model of transpersonal development conceptualized as a relationship between one's personal perspective on death and one's level of spiritual awareness. 116 Ss (aged 18-83 yrs) with cancer completed a brief questionnaire concerning demographic and oncologic information, the Transpersonal Development Inventory, the Death Attitude Profile, and the Brief Symptom Inventory. A significant negative correlation between level of transpersonal development and level of psychosocial distress supported the major hypothesis. 24% of the variance in psychosocial distress was explained by normalization of death (13%) and age (11%). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

AU- Mullen, Paul M.

LA- English
KP- sense of coherence & spiritual resources & family strengths
KP- perceived level of psychological stress
KP- 31–75 yr olds with cancer & their 42–77 yr old spouses
SU- Family Relations; Neoplasms; Psychological Stress; Self Concept; Spirituality
AB- In a path analysis for 42 cancer patients (aged 31–75 yrs) and 32 spouses (aged 42–77 yrs), sense of coherence (SOC) was the only significant direct predictor of psychological stress. However, spiritual resources and family strengths had significant indirect paths through SOC as the mediator. Refined path models eliminated spiritual resources as a predictor for spouses but retained spiritual resources as an indirect predictor through SOC for patients. The variable of accumulated demands was not a direct predictor of stress for either patients or spouses. This result was contrary to a hypothesis in H. I. McCubbin and J. M. Patterson's (see record [rid]1984-12026-001[/rid]) Double ABCX model. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Patients' and parents' causal attributions for childhood cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bearison, David J.
AU- Sadow, Andrea J.
AU- Granowetter, Linda

LA- English
KP- causal attributions & coping strategies
KP- 4.8–19.4 yr olds with cancer vs their parents
SU- Attribution; Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Parental Attitudes
AB- The kinds of causal attributions that pediatric cancer patients and parents make about cancer were systematically examined to determine whether different types of attributions were associated with different coping strategies. 20 pediatric oncology patients (aged 4 yrs 10 mo to 19 yrs 5 mo) were interviewed to determine the kinds of attributions they made (if any) about their cancer. The parents also were interviewed concerning their causal attributions of their child's cancer and completed the Strategies for Coping with Illness—Parents' Scale to determine their coping strategies. Pediatric oncology nurses rated the children's coping strategies. Findings indicate that both patients and parents who made external types of attributions coped significantly better than did those who made internal types of attributions or accepted the physicians' advice that the cause of pediatric cancers (no attributions) was unknown. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Interactions between patients and providers: An exploratory study of age differences in emotional support.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Rose, Julia Hannum
AF- Rose, Julia Hannum, Fairhill Inst for the Elderly, Geriatric Care Ctr, Cleveland, OH, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 11

LA- English
KP- processes & outcomes of emotional support in interactions with health care providers
KP- 19–40 vs 41–55 vs 56–75 yr olds with cancer
SU- Age Differences; Emotions; Medical Personnel; Neoplasms; Therapeutic Processes
AB- Measured the processes and outcomes of emotional support in interactions between adult cancer patients and health providers. The patients included 21 young (aged 19–40 yrs), 22 middle-aged (aged 41–55 yrs), and 21 older (aged 56–75 yrs) adults. Emotional support processes were assessed as desired support, received support, and congruence. Outcomes were assessed according to patients' evaluative reactions and changed positive mood. During interactions with health care providers, older patients felt that intimacy was most important, whereas young patients felt that being able to ventilate their feelings was most important. In addition, the older patients received less emotional support from providers than did middle-aged patients, but young patients were more inclined than the other 2 groups to feel that the emotional support they received was not congruent with the support they desired. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Age Differences; Emotions; Medical Personnel; Neoplasms; Therapeutic Processes
MN- Social Support

TI- Marital adaptation and interaction of couples after a mastectomy.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Carter, Ross E.
AU- Carter, Charlene A.
AU- Siliunas, Mindas

VI- 11

SD- 1993

PG- 69-82

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- marital adjustment & interactional patterns
KP- married couples assessed 2–3 yrs after wife's single mastectomy for Stage I or Stage II breast cancer
SU- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Marital Relations; Mastectomy
AB- Explored the marital adjustment and interactional patterns of 14 married couples 2–3 yrs after the wife had undergone a single mastectomy for Stage I or II breast cancer. Neither husbands nor wives were found to be psychologically symptomatic, and both had adapted well to the wife's illness. Measures of marital adaptation, however, showed significant differences from norms on cohesion and consensus, with marked patterns of enmeshment and fluidity of adaptation. Such findings generally indicate serious marital pathology. Measures of individual adjustment and the clinical presentation of spouses did not support that conclusion, however. Instead, the authors suggest that the findings regarding marital adjustment indicate a normal reaction to life-threatening events rather than a pathological process. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Marital Relations; Mastectomy
MN- Husbands; Wives

LA- English
KP- age & physical restraint
KP- distress & cooperation & anxiety during lumbar puncture vs bone marrow aspiration
KP- 1.6–12 yr olds with lymphoblastic leukemia or lymphomas
SU- Age Differences; Leukemias; Neoplasms; Physical Restraint; Physical Treatment Methods
AB- Examined 3 issues that affect children being treated for cancer: (1) the relative aversiveness of 2 common diagnostic and treatment procedures, (2) the relationship between observed distress, age, and staff ratings of patients" behavior, and (3) the extent to which physical restraint during invasive procedures is related to the child"s observed distress and staff ratings. 17 children (aged 1.65–12.03 yrs) treated for cancer were observed during diagnostic and treatment procedures. In addition, staff ratings of the children"s cooperation and anxiety and the effects of restraint were collected. The results highlight the differential response of children to the 2 procedures as well as the potential utility of assessing the amount of physical restraint required. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- open ended support group with educational & recreational goals
KP- patients with metastatic prostate cancer & their family members participating in treatment research protocols
SU- Neoplasms; Prostate; Support Groups; Treatment
AB- Describes an innovative, open-ended support group with educational and recreational goals designed to meet the needs of patients and their families participating in prostate cancer research protocols at the National Institutes of Health. Weekly meetings alternated between didactic presentations and recreational outings. The group was developed and led by a social worker and a therapeutic recreation specialist. Guest speakers from many other disciplines contributed to the depth of programming offered. Evaluation of this approach after 4 mo showed that the program was beneficial for these patients, who would not participate in a more traditional support group. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- concerns & needs & mental health & peer & partner support
KP- parents of childhood cancer survivors
SU- Needs; Neoplasms; Parental Attitudes; Parents
AB- A questionnaire survey of 37 parents of childhood cancer survivors (median time from diagnosis = 11 yrs) was conducted to address their concerns. Parents whose child had completed cancer treatment still had pervasive concerns about their child's future health complications and feared the possibility of relapse. This group of parents showed no definite psychopathologies and in general seemed to derive the majority of support from their partner, with mothers receiving significantly more peer support than fathers. An overwhelming majority of these parents expressed a desire to maintain contact with health care providers for psychosocial support and education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- normative decision making model for ethical judgments in clinical oncology
KP- health care professionals
SU- Decision Making; Neoplasms; Professional Ethics; Oncology
AB- Poses a 5-step normative decision-making model to help health care professionals arrive at sound ethical judgments. The process of decision making is explored as it applies to a representative case in clinical oncology. Psychological factors that complicate, and at times confound, ethical decision making also are examined. Finally, a point–counterpoint method is presented to help identify psychological and personal values that can obstruct ethical decision making. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- satisfaction with physical environment of oncology outpatient clinic
KP- 38–78 yr olds with cancer
KP- Canada
SU- Client Satisfaction; Clinics; Facility Environment; Neoplasms; Outpatient Treatment
AB- Presents the results of a 1-mo pilot survey to obtain baseline indicators of cancer patients' satisfaction with the physical environment of an oncology outpatient clinic located in the Montreal metropolitan area. A questionnaire was administered to a convenience sample of 55 patients who were attending the clinic for chemotherapy or follow-up. According to the results, patients were most concerned about 2 aspects of the physical environment in the clinic: lack of privacy, including lack of confidentiality of information, and physical discomfort associated with odors such as disinfectants. LA- English
KP- evaluation of sources of cancer related information
KP- 22–90 yr old females who received mammogram
SU- Client Attitudes; Information; Mammography; Neoplasms
AB- Examined the evaluations of 209 women who had had a mammogram concerning 4 different sources of cancer-related information (physicians, friends and family, organizations, and the media). The Ss were asked to identify the sources of information that had provided the information within the previous 12 mo and then were asked to evaluate the accuracy, credibility, understandability, clarity, usefulness, and novelty of the information. Statistical analyses revealed significant interactions between the women and the sources of information and significant main effects for sources and evaluations. Implications for future cancer control efforts and health marketing campaigns are noted. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- social workers

AB- Describes the role of the social worker in bone marrow transplantation (BMT), including enhancing the patient's and family's coping and their adaptation to the stressors of the treatment in the pretransplant, hospitalization, and posttransplant stages. LA- English
KP- hospital based comprehensive care project
KP- adverse effects of & response to chemotherapy
KP- cancer patients
KP- Sweden
KP- 2 yr study
SU- Chemotherapy; Drug Therapy; Hospital Programs; Neoplasms; Side Effects (Drug)
AB- Describes a Swedish comprehensive cancer care project for patients treated with intensive chemotherapy. The 2-yr project involved a physician from each of 3 wards, a psychologist, a contact nurse on each ward, and a resource group (e.g., a dietician, a medical social worker, a physical therapist). Methods developed for prevention or early detection and treatment of complications associated with chemotherapy included a structured interview at admission, a genogram, problem-mapping lists, a nutrition sheet, and symptom diaries. Patients' relatives also were included in the care efforts. When the results of the project were compared with the results of an evaluation conducted before the initiation of the project, a number of improvements were observed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Kids Can Cope: A group intervention for children whose parents have cancer.

LA- English
KP- psychoeducational group intervention
KP- coping strategies
KP- 5–18 yr olds with parent with cancer
KP- Canada
SU- Coping Behavior; Group Counseling; Neoplasms; Parents; Psychoeducation
AB- Kids Can Cope is a group intervention designed to help children and teenagers (aged 5–18 yrs) who have a parent with cancer. The program is intended to (1) help these young people learn about cancer and its treatment, (2) provide them with opportunities to share their feelings in a safe environment with others in similar situations, and (3) increase their repertoire of coping strategies. Three themes that emerge consistently during the sessions are the universality of the group members' experiences, misconceptions about cancer, and themes specific to developmental age. Specific situations encountered in running the group and how those situations have been resolved are addressed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Self-concept in survivors of childhood and adolescent cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Anholt, Uni V.
AU- Fritz, Gregory K.
AU- Keener, Marcia
AF- Anholt, Uni V.
AF- Fritz, Gregory K.
AF- Keener, Marcia
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 11
IP- 1
SD- 1993
YR- 1993
PM- 1993
PG- 1-16
PC- 16
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V11N01_01
LA- English
KP- self concept
KP- 6–18 yr olds who successfully completed cancer treatment
SU- Neoplasms; Self Concept
AB- Compared the self-concept of 62 children (aged 6–18 yrs) who had completed treatment for childhood cancer with that of 120 healthy children (aged 6–27 yrs). Global self-concept (the Piers-Harris Children's Self-Concept Scale) was found to be similar and within normal limits in both groups. However, the cancer survivors reported more positive feelings about global self-concept than did the comparison group, and they received higher scores on 5 of 6 self-concept subscales. Furthermore, children in the survivor group reported feeling significantly better than the comparison group did about the self-concept aspects of their intellectual and school status, behavior, and overall happiness and satisfaction. The cancer self-concept profile that emerged from this study contributes to the recent literature on the normalcy and healthy psychological status of children who have a chronic illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Self Concept
MN- Survivors

TI- A statewide plan to address the unmet psychosocial needs of people with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Barg, Frances K.
AU- McCorkle, Ruth
AU- Jepson, Christopher
AU- Downes, JoAnn
AU- Ferszt, Ginette G.

KP- Pennsylvania statewide continuing education program to address psychosocial needs of cancer patients
KP- health care professionals
SU- Client Characteristics; Continuing Education; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Health Personnel
AB- Describes the model of a 3-day statewide, standardized, continuing education program that was presented in 19 different southeastern Pennsylvania locations for 409 health professionals who care for cancer patients. As a result of the program, participants felt more comfortable about addressing psychosocial issues in oncology, which led to positive behavioral changes at the work site in the way patients with unmet psychosocial needs were identified, treated, and referred. LA- English
KP- psychosocial factors & pessimism
KP- dietary intervention program participation
KP- 53–67 yr old females with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Diets; Pessimism; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment
AB- 34 participants (aged 53–67 yrs) in a 2-yr dietary intervention program and 24 nonparticipants (aged 54–67 yrs) completed 2 similar Health Belief Questionnaires. 31 participants and 20 nonparticipants completed the Attributional Style Questionnaire to study degree of pessimism. Ss who did not participate showed more pessimism when meeting with failure in their social lives and interpreted misfortunes in a more negative way than did participants. Nonparticipants perceived more barriers to joining the dietary program than did participants. Participants perceived their family and friends as having a more positive attitude toward the diet program than did nonparticipants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- frequency of loss & recovery themes
KP- adult long term survivors of bone marrow transplants for cancer treatment
SU- Bone Marrow; Client Attitudes; Neoplasms; Physical Treatment Methods
AB- Described a study that qualitatively assessed the frequency of loss and recovery themes in a group of long-term survivors of bone marrow transplantation (BMT). Surveys of 135 adult survivors of BMT (survival at least 6 mo and not in life-threatening relapse) compiled medical and demographic information and responses to a number of closed-ended and 9 open-ended questions, designed to bring out themes of loss and recovery. 350 themes of loss and 320 themes of recovery were identified in the comments. Classification of the respondents based on these themes revealed that 51.8% had a balanced view of their lives, whereas 26.7% focused more on loss, and 21.5% more on recovery. No strong pattern of relationships between the frequency of loss themes and survivor characteristics was found; the frequency of recovery themes was often associated with survivor characteristics. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Bone Marrow; Client Attitudes; Neoplasms; Physical Treatment Methods

TI- Causal attribution, control, and adjustment to breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Lowery, Barbara J.

LA- English
KP- causal attribution & perception of control & psychosocial adjustment
KP- adult females with breast cancer
SU- Attribution; Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Social Adjustment
AB- Explored the extent to which causal thinking and perceptions of control were associated with the psychosocial adjustment of women with breast cancer. 195 Ss completed a causal attributions interview, questions about perceived control, and 2 questionnaires about adjustment. Perceived loss of control was the most important factor in predicting overall adjustment, and thinking about "why me?" was the 2nd most important factor; thinking about "why me?" was 1st and perceived loss of control was 2nd in predicting psychological distress. The findings indicated that clinicians who work with cancer patients should be alert to adjustment problems in patients who express concern about "why me?" that feelings of loss may be a valuable feature in assessment, and that education about the growing effectiveness of therapies for breast cancer are especially important for coping. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Attribution; Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Social Adjustment

LA- English
KP- prebiopsy depression & anxiety
KP- adults with head & neck cancer vs benign lesions
KP- replication
SU- Anxiety Disorders; Benign Neoplasms; Biopsy; Major Depression; Neoplasms
AB- Attempted to replicate the findings of A. D. Davies et al (see record [rid]1988-30052-001[/rid]) by assessing various stressors in the lives of 74 patients waiting for a diagnostic evaluation for suspected head and neck cancer. Ss completed the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory, a computerized questionnaire on alcohol use, the Michigan Alcoholism Screening Test, and the Global Assessment of Recent Stress, as well as an interview with a clinical social worker. 38% of the cancer Ss were pathologically anxious and 40% were depressed. However, patients with benign lesions were equally emotionally disturbed. Findings are consistent with the report of Davies et al of a high rate of depression among Ss with head and neck cancer before the biopsy but do not support their report that prebiopsy depression, but not anxiety, is higher in cancer Ss than in those with benign disease. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Anxiety Disorders; Benign Neoplasms; Biopsy; Major Depression; Neoplasms

LA- English
KP- development & evaluation of Family Pain Questionnaire
KP- assessment of family caregiver knowledge of cancer pain
KP- 26–95 yr olds with cancer & their 22–85 yr old caregivers
SU- Caregivers; Neoplasms; Pain; Questionnaires; Test Construction
AB- Reported on the evaluation of the Family Pain Questionnaire (FPQ) to measure family caregivers' experience with and knowledge about cancer pain. 85 patients (aged 26–95 yrs) with cancer pain requiring analgesics were identified. The Ss' primary caregivers were identified and were interviewed, using a demographic data tool, the Profile of Mood States, the Caregiver Burden Scale, the FPQ, and the Family Pain Survey. Caregivers' weakest areas of knowledge involved giving low doses of medication for fear of not having medicine available later, fear of respiratory depression from medication, and fear of addiction. Strongest areas of knowledge involved giving medication before pain was severe and believing in nondrug approaches for pain management. The study identified the impact that cancer pain has on caregivers and their need for education in pain management. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- stage of disease & radiotherapy vs chemotherapy
KP- emotional distress & psychosocial concerns
KP- newly diagnosed cancer outpatients
KP- 6 mo study
SU- Distress; Drug Therapy; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Radiation Therapy
AB- 44 newly diagnosed oncology outpatients (mean age 58.3 yrs) completed self-report forms that assessed their mood state and types and levels of psychosocial concerns at 3 points (at entry and 3 and 6 mo later) during their initial 6 mo of treatment. The levels of their psychosocial concerns were further assessed by auditing their medical records. The data analysis focused on how these measures of psychosocial concerns were related to stage of cancer, type of treatment, and levels of mood disturbance and psychosocial concerns. Stage of disease did not correlate with the levels and types of psychosocial concerns, whereas treatment modality and mood disturbance did. LA- English
KP- patient family interpersonal communication & psychosocial adjustment to illness
KP- 25–90 yr old cancer patients receiving radiation therapy
SU- Adjustment; Family Relations; Interpersonal Communication; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy
AB- Obtained self-report data from 102 cancer patients (aged 25–90 yrs) receiving radiation therapy concerning the relationships between patient–family communication and psychosocial adjustment to illness. Psychosocial adjustment was assessed with the Psychosocial Adjustment to Illness Scale. Data reveal that interactions with family members were important in determining whether a patient had adjusted effectively. Frequency of interactions and emotional support provided in the interactions were important discriminating variables of effective adjustment. Honesty and discussion of unpleasant topics were not identified as important discriminating variables. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- perceived appropriateness of camp remembrance programs for deceased campers
KP- camp directors vs counselors vs children with cancer vs their parents & siblings
SU- Attitudes; Death and Dying; Neoplasms; Therapeutic Camps
AB- Interviewed 9 camp directors, 10 camp counselors, 8 campers with cancer, 3 siblings of cancer patients, and 16 parents of cancer patients about the appropriateness of holding remembrance programs for deceased campers at a camp. The majority of campers and parents and the counselors who either had had cancer or had a sibling with cancer were in favor of holding remembrance programs at camp. They were in substantial agreement that older children should be involved in the decision whether to hold a remembrance program. Counselors who had no personal experience with cancer were uncertain about the beneficial effects of a remembrance program. Results are discussed in terms of the need to educate staff about the psychological and ethical aspects of including children in decision making. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- factors in self help support group participation
KP- cancer patients
SU- Neoplasms; Participation; Support Groups
AB- Examined the participation in 2 support groups of 154 cancer patients treated at a large cancer center. Ss most likely to participate were educated, younger, unmarried participants in other voluntary associations, and help seekers who had consulted mental health professionals. Social support had a complex relationship to participation. Ss with inadequate social support were especially likely to participate, but Ss with high scores on family support and cohesiveness were most likely to attend. Open-ended interviews reveal that the participants' major motivations for attending were to compare their own emotional and physical progress with others, learn more about their illness, and share concerns with other patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Marital quality and quality of life among cancer patients and their spouses.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Fuller, Steffen
AU- Swensen, Clifford H.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- stage of ego development
KP- marital quality & quality of life
KP- 38–79 yr old cancer patients & their spouses
SU- Ego Development; Marital Relations; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Spouses
AB- 50 cancer patients (aged 38–79 yrs) and their spouses were asked to assess their current marital relationship and how they remembered it as being before the cancer diagnosis. Marital quality was assessed by interactional style, level of intimacy, and coping with problems. Personality was assessed by measuring stage of ego development: preconformist, conformist, or postconformist. Affiliation with the spouse had the highest correlation with the patients' quality of life, whereas coping with problems had the highest correlation with the spouses' quality of life. Patients who were at the postconformist stage of ego development were most likely to report that their marital relationship had become stronger over the course of their illness. Results are pertinent to the structuring of differential psychosocial interventions for patients and spouses. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- The impact of secrets in hemophilia and HIV disorders.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Brown, Larry K.
AU- DeMaio, Debra M.
AF- Brown, Larry K., Rhode Island Hosp, Dept of Child Psychiatry, Providence, US
AF- DeMaio, Debra M.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 10
IP- 3
SD- 1992
YR- 1992
PM- 1992
PG- 91-101
PC- 11
SP- 91
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 11
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V10N03_06
LA- English
KP- role of secrecy in emotional adjustment & medical care & other issues
KP- male 8 & 10 yr olds with hemophilia & HIV infection
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Hemophilia; HIV; Medical Treatment (General)
AB- Hemophilia, which had become a manageable chronic illness in the 1970s with the advent of coagulant factor concentrates, became a condition often shrouded in secrecy in the 1980s with the advent of HIV infection and AIDS. To help hemophiliac patients and their families manage the hemophilia and HIV infection, treatment providers must be aware of the variety of secrets that may have an impact on patients, parents, and the health care team. Some secrets, if not properly managed, may interfere with optimal medical care and the patient's subsequent emotional adjustment. Because secrets and their sequelae often become increasingly complicated over time, 2 case examples (males diagnosed with HIV infection at 8 and 10 yrs of age) are presented to illustrate the potential ethical, practical, moral, and legal difficulties that can arise. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Hemophilia; HIV; Medical Treatment (General)
CL- Physical & Somatoform & Psychogenic Disorders (3290)
PO- Human (10)

TI- Development of the Satisfaction with Life Domains Scale for Cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Baker, Frank
AU- Curbow, Barbara
AU- Wingard, John R.
AF- Baker, Frank, Johns Hopkins U, School of Hygiene & Public Health, Baltimore, MD, US
AF- Curbow, Barbara
AF- Wingard, John R.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 10
IP- 3
SD- 1992
YR- 1992
PM- 1992
PG- 75-90
PC- 16
SP- 75
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V10N03_05
LA- English
KP- development of self report Satisfaction with Life Domains Scale for Cancer
KP- long term adult cancer survivors with bone marrow transplants
SU- Life Satisfaction; Neoplasms; Organ Transplantation; Rating Scales; Test Construction
AB- Describes the development of the Satisfaction with Life Domains Scale for Cancer (SLDS-C), a self-report instrument for assessing the subjective quality of life of patients receiving aggressive cancer treatment. The SLDS-C asks respondents to rate their satisfaction with 17 areas of life using 7 faces (3 smiling, 1 neutral, and 3 frowning). The instrument has the following advantages: It is acceptable to patients, is easily understood, and allows different degrees of either positive or negative responses. Evidence is presented of the reliability and validity of the scale based on the responses of 109 long-term cancer survivors who had received bone marrow transplants. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Life Satisfaction; Neoplasms; Organ Transplantation; Rating Scales; Test Construction
MN- Bone Marrow; Self Report

TI- Work-related stress specific to physicians and nurses working with cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Herschbach, Peter
AF- Herschbach, Peter, Technical U of Munich, Inst for Psychosomatic Medicine, Psychotherapy & Medical Psychology, Germany
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 10
IP- 2
SD- 1992
YR- 1992
PM- 1992
PG- 79-99
PC- 21
SP- 79
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v10n02_05
LA- English
KP- work related stress
KP- physicians vs nurses working with patients with vs without cancer
SU- Neoplasms; Nurses; Occupational Stress; Physicians
AB- Compared the work-related stress experienced by 234 physicians and 440 nurses working with patients with cancer and by 65 physicians and 152 nurses working with patients without cancer. Ss completed measures including the Questionnaire for Ascertaining Stress on Doctors and Nurses on which Ss answered the questions according to the relevance and degree of emotional or physical stress caused by 64 situations. Although the oncology and comparison groups experienced the same overall degree of work-related stress and physical complaints, the oncology group suffered more from feelings of emotional involvement and self-doubt. However, oncology staff suffered less from stress connected with institutional factors than did the comparison group despite few objective differences in their situations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Association between personality characteristics and the prevalence and extinction of conditioned nausea after chemotherapy.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Hursti, Timo
AU- Fredrikson, Mats
AU- Börjeson, Sussanne
AU- Fürst, Carl J.
AU- Peterson, Curt
AU- Steineck, Gunnar
AF- Hursti, Timo, Karolinska Inst & Hosp, Dept of Psychiatry & Psychology, Stockholm, Sweden
AF- Fredrikson, Mats
AF- Börjeson, Sussanne
AF- Fürst, Carl J.
AF- Peterson, Curt
AF- Steineck, Gunnar
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 10
IP- 2
SD- 1992
YR- 1992
PM- 1992
PG- 59-77
PC- 19
SP- 59
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v10n02_04
LA- English
KP- personality characteristics
KP- prevalence & extinction of conditioned nausea after chemotherapy
KP- relapse free adult males treated for testicular cancer
SU- Drug Therapy; Nausea; Neoplasms; Personality Traits; Testes
AB- Evaluated the prevalence and correlates of conditioned nausea (CN) in 39 relapse-free men 13–75 mo after completion of chemotherapy for testicular cancer. Ss completed the Eysenck Personality Inventory, State-Trait Anxiety Inventory, and the Autonomic Perception Questionnaire. 66% of Ss reported CN during the 1st 12 mo after treatment, but less than 50% of Ss reported it for more than 12 mo. Relatively high autonomic perceptivity and neuroticism were associated with the prevalence and slow extinction of CN. A history of motion sickness was linked to CN, but extroversion was related only to its prevalence. Ss who had experienced CN had received a greater number of chemotherapy cycles, and those with persistent CN also reported more profound vomiting during chemotherapy. Antiemetic treatment with high-dose metoclopramide during chemotherapy did not prevent development of CN but did tend to contribute to its faster extinction. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Drug Therapy; Nausea; Neoplasms; Personality Traits; Testes
MN- Chemotherapy
CL- Medical Treatment of Physical Illness (3363)

TI- Effects of psychosocial support on patients with metastatic breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

LA- English
KP- psychosocial support group
KP- disease progression
KP- adult females with metastatic breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Disease Course; Support Groups
AB- Reviews findings showing that psychosocial support may influence the progression of cancer, as indicated by differences in length of survival. Psychotherapeutic methods that have proven to be effective involve direct confrontation of fears; expression of affect, including negative feelings; provision of social support; and training in self-hypnosis for analgesia. Possible mechanisms for this psychosocial effect on progression of disease include changes in diet and exercise, better use and provision of health care, and positive effects on the sensitivity of the endocrine and immune systems to stress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- The partnership of empowerment: Caregivers and survivors.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Monaco, Grace P.
AF- Monaco, Grace P., Candlelighters Childhood Cancer Foundation, Washington, DC, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 10
IP- 2
SD- 1992

PM- 1992
PG- 121-133

SP- 121
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 13

LA- English
KP- components of & programs for partnership of empowerment & advocacy involving medical team & family & peer organizations
KP- cancer patients
SU- Advocacy; Empowerment; Neoplasms; Therapeutic Processes
AB- Describes the obstacles of people with cancer involving schooling, military service, employment, and insurance that hinder a full life after cure and suggests strategies for supporting a partnership consisting of the medical team, the patient and family, and peer organizations to overcome these obstacles. The goals of this partnership are to create educated, empowered, competent survivors of cancer who can participate effectively in life. These strengths can be built through acquisition of survivorship skills, which are gained through education and information programs during treatment, continuing information after treatment, and networking with peers and advocacy organizations. Opportunities for patients and families to demonstrate their competence include informed consent procedures, monitoring of medications and other home-based tasks, and dialogs with the medical care team. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- development & focus of Parent Advocate Program within division of pediatric hematology & oncology
KP- parents of children with cancer
SU- Advocacy; Neoplasms; Parents; Pediatrics; Oncology
AB- Describes the historical development and current focus of the Parent Advocate Program (PAP) within the Division of Pediatric Hematology/Oncology at the University of Rochester Medical Center. The PAP is under the auspices of the organization called CURE: Counseling, Understanding, Research, and Education. Responsibilities of parent advocates (PAs) include meeting parents of all pediatric hematology/oncology patients, reporting to appropriate medical or psychological staff situations that arise during visits with parents, and explaining support services available through various community agencies and organizations. The authors discuss potential pitfalls such as emotional involvement with families on the PA's part and present ingredients for the development of a successful program, including careful selection of people who can interact successfully with staff and learn the professional role of PA. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Psychooncology: Where are we, and where are we going?

LA- English
KP- development of & issues & psychobiological research in psychooncology
SU- Health Care Psychology; Neoplasms; Psychobiology
AB- Discusses the development of psychooncology, which addresses the psychological (psychosocial) responses to cancer of patients, families, and caretakers at all stages of disease and the psychological, behavioral, and social (psychobiological) factors that influence risk, detection, and survival. The recent development of a unitary measure that combines length of survival and quality of life may be helpful in weighing the outcome of different primary treatment options. Also addressed is the possible interaction of psychological, endocrine, and immune function variables in cancer morbidity and mortality. Findings may show that interventions based on psychophysiological interactions can have salutary effects on cancer treatment. Patients' responses to holistic programs and coping styles are also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Predictors of strain in families of cancer patients: A review of the literature.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sales, Esther
AU- Schulz, Richard
AU- Biegel, David
AF- Sales, Esther, U Pittsburgh, School of Social Work, PA, US
AF- Schulz, Richard
AF- Biegel, David
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 10
IP- 2
SD- 1992
YR- 1992
PM- 1992
PG- 1-26
PC- 26
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 26
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v10n02_01
LA- English
KP- objective illness stressors & family context variables
KP- prediction of family strain & adjustment & psychosocial problems
KP- families of cancer patients
SU- Adjustment; Family Relations; Neoplasms; Stress
AB- Reviews literature on family adjustment to cancer and identifies the factors that consistently predict the extent of psychosocial problems experienced by family members. A conceptual model is applied that views the degree of family strain as being determined by the objective factors of the illness itself and family context variables. Regarding objective factors, the degree of family strain is affected primarily by the severity of the illness and the patient's own level of distress. Contextual variables such as age, gender, and health of family members; their other life stressors and previous psychological problems; family stage and relational bonds; and social supports of family members contribute to the psychosocial impact of illness on the family. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Family Relations; Neoplasms; Stress

TI- Spirituality and the child: A grandparent's death.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Irizarry, Carol
AF- Irizarry, Carol, Flinders U of South Australia, School of Social Science, Adelaide, Australia
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 10
IP- 2
SD- 1992
YR- 1992
PM- 1992
PG- 39-58
PC- 20
SP- 39
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v10n02_03
LA- English
KP- thoughts & feelings about death & mourning rituals & reactions
KP- 8–12 yr olds & their parents assessed after death of child's grandparent
SU- Death and Dying; Death Attitudes; Grandparents; Grief
AB- 56 children (aged 8–12 yrs) and 19 pairs of their parents were interviewed after the death of each child's grandparent. The children were asked questions about (1) their former relationship with the grandparent, (2) how they learned of the death, and (3) their mourning rituals and reactions. Many of the children's comments seemed straightforward and mature, suggesting a level of insight and self-awareness not usually attributed to children, whereas the parents' comments revealed a lack of awareness regarding their children's thoughts and feelings about the death. Parents who share their insecurities or hesitancies with children, acknowledge their inability to alleviate all the discomfort surrounding a death, and help the children formulate questions rather than attempt to supply them with ready answers may be more effective in helping children develop and in providing them with lasting comfort. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Death and Dying; Death Attitudes; Grandparents; Grief
MN- Parents

AB- Reviews the literature on factors that affect job satisfaction and longevity among various professional groups. Results of a pilot survey of 27 master's level oncology social workers in Michigan designed to explore the perceived impact of variables identified in the literature (personal history, patient-related factors, organizational dynamics, social support, and burnout) on survival in professional practice are reported. LA- English
KP- family functioning & cohesion & other psychosocial issues
KP- families of cancer patients receiving bone marrow transplantation
SU- Bone Marrow; Family Relations; Neoplasms; Organ Transplantation
AB- Bone marrow transplantation (BMT) causes patients significant distress, and their families are expected to play a major role in how patients adapt during hospitalization. The authors initiated a prospective study of 160 significant others to examine the family as a social resource and evaluate family members' psychological functioning. To date, families have provided data about the impact of medical information, their decision making about BMT, the physician's influence, and their belief that treatment will be successful. Preliminary data suggest that families need education before the BMT and may need psychosocial intervention afterward. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

AU- Roberts, Cleora S.

LA- English
KP- psychological health & quality of life & other psychosocial impacts
KP- female 33–87 yr olds with gynecologic cancer treated by hysterectomy vs vulvectomy vs total pelvic exenteration
SU- Gynecological Disorders; Mental Health; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Surgery
AB- 32 women (aged 33–87 yrs) with gynecologic cancer who had been treated with a radical hysterectomy, a vulvectomy, or total pelvic exenteration and were currently disease-free were studied. The patients' average score on the Functional Living Index—Cancer was 124 (i.e., most reported a good quality of life). Their scores on the SCL-90 (Revised) reflected moderately elevated levels of psychological distress that were comparable to levels of breast cancer patients who had participated in an earlier study (C. S. Roberts et al, 1991). The authors found a strong negative correlation between age and psychological distress; younger Ss appeared to be more at risk for psychological problems after radical gynecologic surgery. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Gynecological Disorders; Mental Health; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Surgery

LA- English
KP- weekend retreat program
KP- enhancement of family communication & coping strategies
KP- families of adult cancer patients
SU- Communication Skills Training; Coping Behavior; Family Relations; Neoplasms
AB- Explored the role of communication in family coping and assessed the impact of a weekend intervention designed to enhance communication in families experiencing cancer. Data were collected from 14 families participating in a weekend retreat program (the Massachusetts We Can Weekend). Those families who communicated frequently and used a variety of coping strategies reported less difficulty coping with cancer than did those who used fewer strategies. Findings suggest that participating in interventions such as the We Can Weekend can enhance family members' ability to cope by increasing their use of communication and social support. LA- English
KP- action research approach to service needs & barriers & development
KP- cancer survivors
SU- Health Care Services; Needs Assessment; Neoplasms
AB- Addressing the needs of cancer survivors is an emerging challenge for the coming decade. The authors propose an Action Research approach involving critical decision makers in a cyclic process of fact finding, planning, action, and evaluation in which the fact-finding process serves as a basis for structuring subsequent objectives and actions and for using research results for planning as well as theory development. In addition, the authors provide a framework for the approach and suggest strategies for involving not only administrators and members of the medical team but also survivors themselves in developing effective programs and overcoming potential service barriers. TI- The 'Bear Essentials' program: Helping young children and their families cope when a parent has cancer.

KP- 'Bear Essentials' support group program

KP- young children of 25–48 yr old cancer patients
SU- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Parents; Support Groups
AB- A pilot project called "Bear Essentials" was developed at Missouri Baptist Cancer Center in St. Louis for 30 young children of 21 cancer patients (aged 25–48 yrs) to help families (1) understand how children perceive illness, separation, and loss, (2) discuss the concerns of patients, spouses, and children in a supportive environment, and (3) develop coping strategies to better manage the emotional difficulties caused by a parent's illness. Children and parents met separately in concurrent monthly support groups led by a team composed of a social worker, nurses, and a chaplain. This article examines the literature on the children of cancer patients, describes the process of developing the project, and discusses the content, assessment, and outcomes of the project. It concludes with recommendations for replication, with specific emphasis on the use of an interdisciplinary team approach. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Parents; Support Groups
MN- Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward)

TI- Intimacy and sexuality after cancer treatment: Restoring a sense of wholeness.

LA- English
KP- social work interventions
KP- intimacy & sexuality & sexual functioning problems after medical treatments
KP- adult females with breast cancer & other cancer patients
SU- Neoplasms; Physical Treatment Methods; Sexual Function Disturbances; Social Casework
AB- All cancers affect body image and self-image and thus have the potential to diminish sexual functioning and feelings of sexual attractiveness. Nevertheless, patients and health care professionals often avoid discussions about changes in sexual functioning and intimacy. The oncology social worker is in a unique position to use a portion of the routine biopsychosocial assessment to inquire about changes in sexual functioning and intimacy. The authors review the common psychosocial problems associated with these changes, the timing of the assessment, the oncology social worker's role, and approaches to intervention with patients and their partners. In addition, 2 case examples of 2 women with breast cancer are provided to illustrate these approaches. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Physical Treatment Methods; Sexual Function Disturbances; Social Casework

TI- Cancer and addictions: The potential for family and staff collusion.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Seddon, Carole F.
AU- Zabora, James R.
AU- Smith, Elizabeth D.

LA- English
KP- addictive behaviors & codependency & family coping style
KP- cancer patients & their family members
KP- treatment implications
SU- Addiction; Codependency; Coping Behavior; Family Relations; Neoplasms
AB- Although often sensationalized in the media, addictive behaviors and co-dependency cause painful dilemmas for millions of Americans. Unfortunately, many people with these disorders also are diagnosed with cancer or have a family member with cancer. Addiction and the problematic coping style associated with it are rarely addressed by oncology staff. However, data collected through the Johns Hopkins Cancer Counseling Center indicate that 21 of 36 patients referred for long-term counseling were addicts and that 15 were co-dependent. The authors address the problem of identifying patients and families with these disorders and describe appropriate methods of helping them cope with the added distress caused by the diagnosis of cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- psychological effects of treatment & coping & interpersonal factors affecting prognosis & adjustment
KP- females with breast cancer
KP- literature review
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Literature Review; Psychodynamics; Treatment
AB- Reviews literature on psychological effects of treatment for breast cancer (BC), coping styles as prognostic indicators of survival, and interpersonal factors that affect adjustment to the disease. Results suggest that psychological coping styles and distress should be included as prognostic indicators for BC patients. Better outcomes in the quality of life of BC patients have been noted among women who take an active role in monitoring their health while undergoing diagnosis, treatment, and recovery. Active involvement includes problem solving, the expression of emotion, and restructuring one's lifestyle. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- A training model of a self-help group for patients with cancer of the colon.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

LA- English
KP- self help training program
KP- colostomy patients volunteering to counsel others
SU- Client Education; Colon Disorders; Neoplasms; Self Care Skills; Self Help Techniques
AB- Described a self-help training program for colostomy patients. Eight veteran colostomy patients who were motivated to serve as volunteer counselors for new patients received a 10-wk group training course. The goal was to train group members to help patients adjust and achieve an independent, self-help body. Training was conducted under the guidance of a social worker and a stoma-training nurse. During the 1st yr, the volunteers met with 38 patients. Based on the volunteers' descriptions of their activities, the program appeared to have met its goals. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Psychosocial impact of the phase of cancer on the family: An updated review.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sales, Esther
AF- Sales, Esther, U Pittsburgh, School of Social Work, PA, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9
IP- 4
SD- 1991
YR- 1991
PM- 1991
PG- 1-18
PC- 18
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v09n04_01
LA- English
KP- family problems during different phases of cancer
KP- literature review
SU- Disease Course; Family; Literature Review; Neoplasms; Terminal Cancer
AB- Reviews clinical and research literature on family problems during 6 phases of cancer: diagnosis, hospital, posthospital, adjuvant treatment, recurrence, and terminal. The results extend the data on problems and phases identified by L. Northouse (see record [rid]1985-23011-001[/rid]) in an earlier review. It is suggested that family members need to be included in social service planning from the onset of the patient's illness. Family problems, which often mirror those of patients in both scope and depth, are still too often ignored. By more adequately meeting the variety of psychosocial needs that caregivers and patients encounter at each phase of illness, the service system can help reduce both the immediate and long-term emotional costs for all family members. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Disease Course; Family; Literature Review; Neoplasms; Terminal Cancer
MN- Family Relations; Psychosocial Factors

TI- Psychosocial impact of cancer survival on school-age children and their parents.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Greenberg, Helaine S.
AU- Meadows, Anna T.

LA- English
KP- psychosocial impact of cancer survival
KP- 8–16 yr old patients & their parents
SU- Family Relations; Neoplasms; Psychodynamics; Psychosocial Factors; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- 118 children (aged 8–16 yrs) who had survived cancer and 120 of their parents were interviewed. 47 children commented positively on surviving cancer, in a variety of ways, including denial, and 71 stressed the negative impact. Negative responses concerned worries about health, problems with late effects, anger at having been ill, and family interaction. 92 of the parents' responses were positive and 95 negative. Positive responses concerned support systems, new values and attitudes, and marital adjustment. Negative comments concerned health worries, marital problems, and attitudes such as anger and guilt. The findings support the need for continued clinical intervention for both these populations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- experiences as siblings of children with cancer
KP- 10–21 yr olds
SU- Neoplasms; Siblings
AB- Interviewed 21 children (aged 10–21 yrs) on their experiences as siblings of children with cancer. The Ss almost universally expressed worry and distress about the illness. Home life was typically disrupted, and an atmosphere of sadness prevailed. The Ss generally expressed a wish to care for the ill sibling and often seemed to be aware of the stresses their parents experienced. Some noted that they had attained greater maturity and coping ability. Suggestions for parents and professionals are offered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- efficacy of Omega Screening Instrument
KP- prediction of subsequent emotional distress
KP- patients newly diagnosed with cancer
SU- Distress; Neoplasms; Screening Tests; Statistical Validity
AB- Examined the utility of the Omega Screening Instrument (OSI) for predicting subsequent emotional distress in patients newly diagnosed with cancer. 100 patients in the rural southwest, diagnosed with cancer within the previous month, completed the OSI and the Total Mood Disturbance (TMD) scale of the Profile of Mood States. Ss who were able completed the TMD again after 3 and 6 mo. The OSI was helpful in predicting which patients would develop emotional distress over time, but not as accurately as in an earlier study in a northeastern city (see J. W. Worden, 1983). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Assessing the imagery of cancer: The Cancer Metaphors Test.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Domino, George
AU- Affonso, Dyanne A.
AU- Hannah, Mo T.
AF- Domino, George, U Arizona, Tucson, US

LA- English
KP- reliability & validity of Cancer Metaphors Test
KP- assessment of cancer imagery & attitudes
KP- 12–89 yr old cancer patients vs college students
SU- Imagery; Metaphor; Neoplasms; Test Reliability; Test Validity
AB- Examined the reliability and validity of the Cancer Metaphors Test (CMT). Data from 267 adults (aged 21–89 yrs) suggested 4 meaningful factors: Terminal Pessimism, Future Optimism, Natural Disaster, and Foreign Intruder. Reliability was examined in a study involving 237 college students, convergent and discriminant validity in data from 96 cancer patients (mean age 58.3 yrs), and correlations with quality of life and locus of control scales in, respectively, 47 male colostomy patients, and 26 adolescents (aged 12–21 yrs). A 2nd analysis of factorial validity involved 51 additional patients (mean age 61.6 yrs). The CMT was reliable, and the 4 scales discriminated between cancer patients and nonpatients and between lung cancer and colorectal cancer patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Imagery; Metaphor; Neoplasms; Test Reliability; Test Validity

TI- Cancer patients' knowledge of and willingness to use agency-based services: Toward application of a model of behavioral change.

LA- English
KP- knowledge of & willingness to use agency based services
KP- 21–91 yr old cancer patients in chemotherapy
KP- application of behavioral change model
SU- Chemotherapy; Community Services; Health Care Utilization; Knowledge Level; Neoplasms
AB- Examined 412 cancer patients' (aged 21–91 yrs) knowledge and willingness to use agency-based services as part of a survey documenting the prevalence of the daily living needs of cancer patients receiving chemotherapy. In addition, the efficacy of classifying the patients' readiness to use agency-based services along the stages of change dimension of a model of behavioral change, the transtheoretical model (e.g., J. O. Prochaska and C. C. DiClemente; see record [rid]1983-26980-001[/rid]) was explored. Most Ss reported no past contact with formal service providers. More than two-thirds never used a community resource for instrumental or administrative assistance in daily living, nearly 50% did not know about available services, and 10–22% said they would be unwilling to use such services in the future. The characteristics of Ss who knew about available services or were willing to use services differed as a function of the domain of daily living activities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- The psychosocial impact of laryngectomy: A comprehensive assessment.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Stams, Henderikus J.
AU- Koopmans, Janice P.
AU- Mathieson, Cynthia M.

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- psychological distress & recovery of speech & quality of life
KP- 40–71 yr old & older laryngectomy patients
KP- Canada
SU- Distress; Laryngeal Disorders; Oral Communication; Quality of Life; Surgical Patients
AB- 51 laryngectomees completed a structured interview that yielded data on (1) demographics, (2) illness and surgery variables, (3) social networks and support, (4) preparation at the time of surgery, (5) rehabilitation of communication and related problems, (6) lifestyle changes, (7) identity changes, (8) quality of life, and (9) psychological adjustment. Gender, surgical variables, and the extent of the patient's social support predicted the use of esophageal speech. Preoperative visits by fellow laryngectomees predicted later quality of life. Poor psychological adjustment was related to the length of time spent in the hospital after surgery, dissatisfaction with social support, and changes in lifestyle after surgery. Changes in identity also were predictive of both psychological adjustment and quality of life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Support groups in oncology: Building hope through the human bond.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Vugia, Holly D.
AF- Vugia, Holly D., U California School of Social Welfare, Berkeley, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9
IP- 3
SD- 1991

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- nature & development of support groups in oncology
SU- Neoplasms; Support Groups; Oncology
AB- Applies support group theory to the field of oncology, briefly outlining the role of social support, stress, and mutual aid. Steps in planning and conducting a professionally led oncology support group are reviewed, followed by a discussion of specific themes common to support groups for cancer patients. Support group themes include (1) intrapsychic themes, such as anger, fear of death, denial, depression, and spiritual questions; (2) interpersonal themes, such as marital relationship issues, sexuality, making wills, and the burden of disclosure; (3) social themes, such as isolation, stigma, and changes in lifestyle; and (4) cancer-related themes, such as pain, side effects of treatment, and doctor–patient relationships. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Support Groups; Oncology
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)

TI- Every tomorrow, a vision of hope.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Nowotny, Mary L.
AF- Nowotny, Mary L., Baylor U School of Nursing, Dallas, TX, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9
IP- 3
SD- 1991
YR- 1991
PM- 1991
PG- 117-126
PC- 10
SP- 117
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 10
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v09n03_10
LA- English
KP- use of Nowotny Hope Scale & caregiving strategies for facilitation of hope
KP- cancer patients
SU- Caregivers; Hope; Neoplasms; Rating Scales
AB- Explains how the Nowotny Hope Scale (NHS) by M. Nowotny (1989) can be used to assess patients' hope. The NHS assesses 6 components of hope: confidence in the outcome, relationships with others, belief in the possibility of a future, spiritual beliefs, active involvement, and inner readiness. The subscales of the NHS provide a framework for the development and implementation of strategies to maintain, reinforce, and facilitate hope. Sources of hope as well as conflicts between the hopes of health care providers and cancer survivors are also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Images of cancer: China and the United States.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Domino, George
AU- Lin, Jingyang
AF- Domino, George, U Arizona, Tucson, US
AF- Lin, Jingyang
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9

SD- 1991

LA- English
KP- metaphorical perspective on cancer
KP- adults
KP- China vs US
SU- Adult Attitudes; Cross Cultural Differences; Metaphor; Neoplasms
AB- Administered the Cancer Metaphors Test (CMT) by G. Domino et al (1991), designed to elicit the imagery of cancer, to 98 male and 78 female Chinese respondents and 98 male and 78 female American respondents matched on chronological age (CA) and occupational status. Scores on the 4 CMT scales (terminal pessimism, future optimism, natural disaster, foreign intruder) did not correlate significantly with CA or occupational status, and an analysis of variance (ANOVA) indicated no significant ethnicity-by-scale interaction, with the Chinese Ss scoring higher than Americans on future optimism and lower on natural disaster. An analysis of the individual metaphors rated most and least appropriate indicated both substantial differences and similarities between ethnic groups and gender. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
