TI- The psychosocial effects of an information program involving Spanish breast cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Durà, Estrella
AU- Ibañez, Elena
AF- Durà, Estrella, U València, Facultad de Psicología, Spain
AF- Ibañez, Elena
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9
IP- 2
SD- 1991
YR- 1991
PM- 1991
PG- 45-65
PC- 21
SP- 45
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v09n02_04
LA- English
KP- congruence & completeness & systematic & sequential provision of cancer information
KP- breast cancer patients & their families
KP- Spain
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Health Education
AB- Evaluated the effects of the following factors on 71 breast cancer patients' psychosocial adjustment: (1) the congruence of the information provided to patients and family members and (2) the completeness and systematic, sequential provision of the information. Ss were divided into 3 groups. 24 Ss and their relatives received systematic information about the disease; 22 Ss were given the same information, but their relatives did not participate; and 25 Ss received normally dispensed information. Congruence and type of information had an important influence on Ss' psychosocial adjustment, as mediated by a number of variables related to how information was given (systematically and sequentially) and how the effects of the information were evaluated (short- vs long-term effects and personal vs interpersonal effects). (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Pediatric cancer patients' peer relationships: The impact of an oncology camp experience.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bluebond-Langner, Myra
AU- Perkel, Dale
AU- Goertzel, Ted G.
AF- Bluebond-Langner, Myra, Rutgers U, Camden, NJ, US
AF- Perkel, Dale
AF- Goertzel, Ted G.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9
IP- 2
SD- 1991
YR- 1991
PM- 1991
PG- 67-80
PC- 14
SP- 67
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v09n02_05
LA- English
KP- oncology camp experience
KP- perceptions of advantages vs disadvantages of relationships with other cancer patients vs healthy peers
KP- 7–16 yr old cancer patients
SU- Camping; Neoplasms; Peer Relations; Oncology
AB- Used a case-study quasi-experimental design to examine 50 pediatric cancer patients' (aged 7–16 yrs) perceptions of the advantages and disadvantages of peer relationships developed at a 1-wk camp for pediatric cancer patients. Results of questionnaires and interviews show that Ss went to camp to make new friends and have a good time. Most Ss established relationships that lasted after the camp ended. Ss believed that empathy, understanding, and acceptance were the major benefits of friendships with other young patients. One difficulty in having relationships with other cancer patients was the reminder to Ss that their own disease might return. Ss also wanted to develop and maintain relationships with healthy peers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Camping; Neoplasms; Peer Relations; Oncology

TI- Truth to life: Art therapy with pediatric oncology patients and their siblings.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sourkes, Barbara M.
AF- Sourkes, Barbara M., Montreal Children's Hosp, Dept of Psychology, PQ, Canada
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9
IP- 2
SD- 1991
YR- 1991
PM- 1991
PG- 81-96
PC- 16
SP- 81
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16

LA- English
KP- letter writing with vs without color feeling wheel or change in family or scariest drawing art therapy techniques
KP- pediatric oncology patients & their families
SU- Art Therapy; Neoplasms; Oncology
AB- Art therapy can be a powerful tool to facilitate the emotional expression of children with cancer and their healthy siblings. Three structured art therapy techniques are described: (1) the mandala (color–feeling wheel), (2) the change-in-family drawing, and (3) the "scariest" drawing. A letter-writing technique also is discussed. The structured aspect of these methods allows the therapist to ask highly focused questions and to interpret the drawings within the context of the individual child's reality. The techniques can be adapted for individuals ranging from age 3 yrs to adulthood and can be used in individual, family, or group psychotherapy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- social supports
KP- breast cancer patients & their families
KP- literature review
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Family Members; Literature Review; Social Support
AB- After a discussion of P. Thoits's (1986) model of social supports as an aid to coping, 11 studies (published 1981–1989) are reviewed to examine the role of social supports for breast cancer patients and their families. Variables examined across the studies include demographic factors, stage of disease and treatment, the types of social support patients received, and how the support was measured. An attempt is made to evaluate the relationship between stages of the disease process and the type of social support best suited to the individual patient and her family. TI- Effects of individual and marital variables on coping with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Hannum, James W.

LA- English
KP- psychological stress & marital cohesion & satisfaction & history
KP- coping strategies
KP- 30–70 yr old breast cancer patients & their husbands
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Marital Relations; Psychological Stress; Spouses
AB- Examined coping as an interpersonal process by assessing psychological distress, marital cohesion, marital satisfaction, marital history, and use of several coping strategies of 22 breast cancer patients (aged 30–70 yrs) and their husbands. Measures included the SCL-90 (Revised). Husbands' coping behaviors and ratings of the relationship were the best predictors of wives' psychological distress, whereas husbands' distress depended on a combination of their own and their wives' coping behaviors. Results suggest that interpersonal variables are equal to, or more important than, individual variables in the effectiveness of coping. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Use of the Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale with adult cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Curbow, Barbara
AU- Somerfield, Mark
AF- Curbow, Barbara, Johns Hopkins U, School of Hygiene & Public Health, Baltimore, MD, US
AF- Somerfield, Mark
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9
IP- 2
SD- 1991
YR- 1991
PM- 1991
PG- 113-131
PC- 19
SP- 113
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 19
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v09n02_08
LA- English
KP- role of self esteem & use of Rosenberg Self Esteem Scale
KP- cancer patients
SU- Neoplasms; Rating Scales; Self Esteem
AB- Discusses the role of self-esteem in cancer research. The Rosenberg Self-Esteem Scale (RSE), developed by M. Rosenberg (1965), is described, and results of 16 studies (published 1979–1989) that have used this measure are reviewed. No definitive picture of self-esteem in cancer patients has emerged because of differences in scoring the RSE. Global self-esteem, as measured by the RSE, may not be the only aspect of self-concept that is relevant to cancer patients. Self-esteem, although routinely considered to be an outcome variable in cancer research, also can be conceptualized as a causal agent. The relationship between hypothetical mechanisms of how self-esteem is involved in adapting to cancer and possible interventions is addressed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Rating Scales; Self Esteem
CL- Personality Scales & Inventories (2223)

LA- English
KP- treatment
KP- sexual dysfunction
KP- cancer survivors
SU- Neoplasms; Sexual Function Disturbances; Treatment
AB- Although the incidence of sexual dysfunction among cancer survivors is high, many oncology professionals have little or no training in human sexuality. This article briefly reviews the normal human sexual response, offers a format for evaluating sexual function after cancer treatment, and discusses the clinical issues involved in the treatment of sexual dysfunction after cancer treatment is completed. Problems in the desire, excitement, and orgasm phases are discussed in addition to special considerations that apply when cancer patients need sex counseling or sex therapy. P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- demands on life & reaction to disease & sensitivity to patient's needs & impact on relationship
KP- male 28–63 yr old partners of females with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Lifestyle; Male Female Relations; Responses; Significant Others
AB- Interviewed the 67 partners (aged 28–63 yrs) of women diagnosed with breast cancer to identify the demands that the illness experience made on their lives. The men described how they reacted to the partner's disease, their sensitivity to her needs, and the impact of the illness on their relationship. They also commented on the difficulties they encountered in negotiating the disease experience and how they adapted their lifestyles to meet the demands of the illness. The men shared their concerns about what the future might hold and described their attempts to minimize the effects of the illness. The author's findings can serve as a guide for caregivers in the delivery of family-level services. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Social support, self-esteem, and communication in patients receiving chemotherapy.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ward, Sandra
AU- Leventhal, Howard
AU- Easterling, Douglas
AU- Luchterhand, Charlene
AU- Love, Richard
AF- Ward, Sandra, U Wisconsin, School of Nursing, Madison, US
AF- Leventhal, Howard
AF- Easterling, Douglas
AF- Luchterhand, Charlene
AF- Love, Richard
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 9
IP- 1
SD- 1991
YR- 1991
PM- 1991
PG- 95-116
PC- 22
SP- 95
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 22
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v09n01_05
LA- English
KP- standard vs enhanced vs shared information & perceived social support & communication with significant other
KP- self esteem
KP- adults with cancer undergoing chemotherapy
SU- Chemotherapy; Interpersonal Communication; Neoplasms; Self Esteem; Social Support
AB- In Study 1, a cross-sectional study of 81 adult patients, the Ss perceived high levels of social support, but those who communicated most about cancer had the lowest self-esteem. The data suggest that communicating with significant others about the disease may damage a patient's self-esteem even when the others are perceived as generally extremely supportive. In Study 2, 99 adult patients were assigned to standard information, enhanced information, and shared information conditions. In the 1st condition, the inverse relationship between communication and self-esteem was replicated. In the 2nd, no relationship was found between self-esteem and communication. In the 3rd, higher levels of communication were associated with greater self-esteem. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Chemotherapy; Interpersonal Communication; Neoplasms; Self Esteem; Social Support
MN- Drug Therapy; Significant Others
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
AG- Adulthood (18 yrs & older) (300)

TI- Quality-of-life and psychosocial oncology research in Europe: State of the art.

LA- English
KP- research on quality of life & psychosocial oncology
KP- Great Britain & Europe vs US
SU- Experimentation; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Quality of Life; Oncology
AB- Surveyed British and European research groups to review current research on quality of life and psychosocial oncology. 28 groups responded. Active areas of research include (1) methods of assessing quality of life (validation studies, instrument comparison and translation, new scales, cross-cultural comparisons), (2) integration of quality-of-life measures into clinical trials, (3) the coping process, and (4) rehabilitation and supportive care. In contrast, US researchers focused on the more pragmatic aspects of psychosocial oncology, especially the psychosocial sequelae of a cancer diagnosis. This divergence in approach may relate to cultural characteristics as well as differences in the research funding process. Most of the survey respondents were enthusiastic about pursuing cooperative research with North American investigators, and the review identified many areas for potential collaboration. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Experimentation; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Quality of Life; Oncology
MN- Cross Cultural Differences
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
LO- Europe
LO- Great Britain
LO- US

LA- English
KP- physical & psychological factors in etiology & biopsychosocial model for evaluation of sexual dysfunction
KP- cancer patients
SU- Biopsychosocial Approach; Etiology; Neoplasms; Sexual Function Disturbances
AB- Summarizes the findings regarding sexual dysfunction (SD) for various types of cancers in men and women and expands on the physical and psychological factors in the etiology of such dysfunction. The methods of assessment for SD are reviewed and critiqued, and a biopsychosocial model for evaluating them is presented that recognizes the importance of partners and the need to include them in the evaluation. A test battery and interview that take approximately 1 hr and 15 min to administer are proposed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Biopsychosocial Approach; Etiology; Neoplasms; Sexual Function Disturbances
MN- Psychosocial Factors

TI- Is there a relationship between family environment and dropping out of chemotherapy?
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Gilbar, Ora
AF- Gilbar, Ora, U Haifa School of Social Work, Israel
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 8
IP- 4
SD- 1990
YR- 1990

LA- English
KP- family environment & dropout vs completion rate for chemotherapy treatment
KP- cancer patients
SU- Drug Therapy; Family Relations; Neoplasms; Treatment Compliance; Treatment Dropouts
AB- Examined 53 cancer patients receiving chemotherapy and 53 controls to determine whether the family environment of the patient who drops out of chemotherapy treatment is worse than that of the patient who completes treatment. Ss were interviewed in their homes. The majority of Ss in both groups said they had been accompanied to the clinic during treatment (research group, 31; control group, 33). No proof was found that family environment influences cancer patients to drop out of treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Drug Therapy; Family Relations; Neoplasms; Treatment Compliance; Treatment Dropouts
MN- Chemotherapy; Home Environment

TI- Preferred coping styles of pediatric cancer patients during invasive medical procedures.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Smith, Karen E.
AU- Ackerson, Joseph P.
AU- Blotcky, Alan D.
AU- Berkow, Roger
AF- Smith, Karen E., U Texas Medical Branch, Dept of Pediatrics Div of Pediatric Psychology, Galveston, US

LA- English
KP- behavioral coping strategies during invasive medical procedures
KP- 6–18 yr old cancer patients
SU- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Physical Treatment Methods
AB- Interviewed 24 male and 20 female pediatric oncology patients (aged 6–18 yrs) to assess behavioral coping strategies during invasive medical procedures. The behavioral strategies of 42 Ss were subsequently categorized into information seeking, information avoiding, and mixed coping styles (COSs). COS was unrelated to age and gender but was significantly related to measures of disease chronicity and number of previous procedures. No differences were found among Ss who had different COSs on subjective ratings of anticipatory fear and degree of pain experienced or on behavioral observations of distress during invasive procedures. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Physical Treatment Methods

LA- English
KP- psychosocial effects of diagnosis of transfusion related HIV
KP- 3–20 yr old cancer patients at pediatric cancer institute & their family members & health care team
SU- Blood Transfusion; HIV; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
AB- The diagnosis of transfusion-induced infection with the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) in 5 pediatric patients (aged 3–20 yrs) at a cancer institute had a widespread and powerful psychosocial effect. The effects of these diagnoses on patients infected with HIV with and without symptoms, on patients still at risk, on patients' families, and on members of the health care team are discussed. The helplessness everyone experienced evoked memories of pediatric cancer treatment more than 25 yrs ago and stimulated reflections on the assumptions, motivations, and satisfactions of caregivers in a pediatric oncology setting. Suggestions for limiting anxiety and maximizing open communication are given. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Blood Transfusion; HIV; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
MN- Family Members; Medical Personnel

LA- English
KP- family functioning & prenatal reactions & psychosocial adjustment variables after successful treatment
KP- children with cancer & their parents
KP- 2–7 yr followup
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Family Relations; Neoplasms; Parents; Treatment
AB- Explored the relationship between various facets of adaptation to cancer and psychosocial outcome variables assessed in survivorhood. 44 children (mean age 10.34 yrs) and their parents were assessed 2–7 yrs after the children had completed treatment. Parental reactions to the Ss' illness were related to a variety of psychosocial variables (e.g., perceived financial burden concerning the costs of the illness and its treatment). Most important, parental coping was associated with the long-term adjustment of both parents and the Ss. The amount of emotional distress that parents experienced was related to their ability to establish and maintain socially supportive ties with other people. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Family Relations; Neoplasms; Parents; Treatment
MN- Followup Studies; Psychosocial Factors

TI- Psychosocial adaptation to illness by women with breast cancer and women with cancer at other sites.

LA- English
KP- psychosocial adaptation & variation in response to illness
KP- 24–76 yr old females with breast or gynecologic or other cancer
SU- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Human Females; Neoplasms
AB- Interviewed 14 women with breast cancer, 14 women with gynecologic cancer, and 8 women with cancer at other sites. All Ss were aged 24–76 yrs. Considerable interindividual variation in psychosocial response to cancer was found, but the variation was not associated with the site of the disease. Breast cancer Ss tended to adapt more effectively to their illness than did the others. Age, marital status, time since primary treatment, and prognosis were not significantly associated with psychosocial status, but severity of physical impairment and discomfort were powerful predictors of psychosocial status. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Human Females; Neoplasms
MN- Psychosocial Factors

TI- Adjustment to breast cancer: A replication study.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Friedman, Lois C.

LA- English
KP- psychosocial adjustment & coping behavior & fighting spirit
KP- females with breast cancer
KP- replication
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Reported a replication of an earlier study by L. C. Friedman et al (see record [rid]1996-72938-001[/rid]) of how women cope with and adjust to breast cancer. 49 women with breast cancer completed self-administered instruments that measured coping, fighting spirit, and psychosocial adjustment to illness. Fighting spirit was related reliably to better psychosocial adjustment, and coping by avoidance was related reliably to poorer adjustment. Denial was not related reliably to any of the adjustment measures. Similarly, reliable relationships were not found between either disease status or duration of illness and adjustment to the illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Psychosocial Factors
MN- Experimental Replication

TI- Complicated grief reactions in women who were sexually abused in childhood.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Clark, Graeme T.
AU- Cole, Gordon

LA- English
KP- familial childhood sexual abuse & own or parent's diagnosis of cancer
KP- complicated grief reactions
KP- females
SU- Early Experience; Grief; Human Females; Incest; Neoplasms
AB- Explores how familial sexual abuse can lay the foundation for complicated bereavement in adult life when a diagnosis of cancer is involved. The unique vulnerabilities and needs of this population are illustrated in a discussion of 7 women who exhibited unusually intense grief and anticipatory grief reactions. Six of the Ss had been sexually abused by their fathers and 1 S had been sexually abused by her stepfather. The literature on the long-term psychosocial impact of sexual abuse in childhood and to normal and complicated grief is reviewed. Two case studies are followed by a discussion of the intrapsychic and interpersonal processes that maintain complicated patterns of grief. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Early Experience; Grief; Human Females; Incest; Neoplasms
MN- Child Abuse

LA- English
KP- behavioral treatment
KP- pain management
KP- cancer patients
SU- Behavior Therapy; Neoplasms; Pain
AB- Describes the behavioral treatment of several common pain problems encountered with cancer patients. Problem assessment is illustrated with case examples. Guidelines are given for choosing a potentially fruitful treatment approach and for presenting the approach to patients and their families. Descriptions and case examples of the psychobehavioral techniques used to treat the cognitive, behavioral, and physical aspects of cancer pain are outlined. Discussion includes the establishment of a treatment strategy; the teaching of specific techniques (e.g., relaxation) to cancer patients; and the evaluation of the treatment process. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- pain associated with cancer & diagnostic & treatment procedures
KP- 2–19 yr olds
SU- Medical Diagnosis; Medical Treatment (General); Neoplasms; Pain
AB- A survey of 77 child and adolescent outpatients (aged 2–19 yrs) at a cancer clinic and their parents showed that many children suffered pain from the cancer, the diagnostic and monitoring procedures, and the treatment. Alternatives to painful diagnostic and treatment procedures are recommended, including the evaluation of analgesic regimens, the development of more efficient and effective psychological techniques, and the development of treatment protocols with fewer invasive tests. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- drug & other types of symptom control
KP- pain &/or anorexia &/or nausea &/or asthenia
KP- patients with advanced cancer
SU- Drug Therapy; Medical Treatment (General); Neoplasms; Symptoms
AB- Reviews the etiology, assessment, and management of several symptoms that are commonly associated with advanced cancer, including pain, anorexia, nausea, and asthenia. Although a better awareness of cancer pain has resulted in major advances in the ability to manage the problem, research is needed on the natural history and management of other symptoms associated with advanced cancer, some of which can be more distressing and more difficult to manage than pain. TI- Quality of life: Principles of the clinical paradigm.

LA- English
KP- clinical concept of quality of life & measurement issues
KP- cancer patients
SU- Measurement; Neoplasms; Quality of Life
AB- Discusses the concept of "quality of life," which has become a relatively precise, operationally defined, patient-outcome measure. Discussion includes the evolution of the concept and its potential application to the evaluation of outcome, both for individual patients and for clinical trials. These concepts and applications are examined in 4 parts: conceptual foundations (components and operational characteristics), the design of measurement tools, the conduct of trials, and the interpretation of results. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- pain syndromes

LA- English
KP- stress coping responses
KP- nurses in bone marrow transplant unit
SU- Coping Behavior; Hospital Environment; Nurses; Stress
AB- Examined the coping responses of 11 nurses in a bone marrow transplant unit who were exposed to a stressful series of events. Ss completed an assessment battery of 6 instruments. Significant differences in reactions to stress were observed; these differences were related to factors such as coping strategies, job involvement, role conflict, and home–work conflict. Further analysis included comparisons of the unit data with a large normative sample of nurses at the same hospital. Results support the usefulness of a transactional process-oriented model in addressing the issue of stress in oncology settings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Health promotion in oncology: A cancer wellness doctrine.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cella, David F.
AF- Cella, David F., Rush-Presbyterian-St Luke's Medical Ctr, Rush Cancer Ctr Psychological Services, Chicago, IL, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 8
IP- 1
SD- 1990
YR- 1990
PM- 1990
PG- 17-31
PC- 15
SP- 17
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v08n01_02
LA- English
KP- wellness promotion model as basis for intervention
KP- cancer patients
SU- Health Education; Neoplasms
AB- Describes an approach to promoting wellness in people with cancer which is broader than a skill training model. It combines popular stress-management techniques with a set of 8 beliefs (e.g., responsibility, hope) that are useful for cognitive restructuring. These beliefs, modified with qualifiers introducing appropriate realism, constitute a wellness doctrine that can serve as a basis for intervention with a variety of common clinical problems. Case examples (including a 61-yr-old male with prostate cancer) are presented, and 4 subtypes (realists, opportunists, zealots, and fighters) of patients who present for wellness promotion are described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Health Education; Neoplasms
MN- Cognitive Restructuring; Stress Management

LA- English
KP- level of debilitation
KP- social support
KP- 45–90 yr olds with cancer
SU- Neoplasms; Severity (Disorders); Social Support
AB- Tested the hypothesis that cancer patients who are more debilitated receive less social support than do others. A structured interview, including 3 social support measures, was completed for 707 newly diagnosed cancer patients (aged 45–90 yrs). Several characteristics of the disease were associated with lower levels of social activity: pain, perceptions of a poor prognosis, impaired functioning, and number of days recently spent in bed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Perceptions about breast cancer patients: The effect of the type of relationship with the patient.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Hailey, B. Jo
AU- Lalor, Karen M.

LA- English
KP- type of relationship with hypothetical patient
KP- perceptions of cancer patients
KP- college students
SU- Family Relations; Friendship; Neoplasms; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward)
AB- 52 male and 103 female undergraduates read 1 of 3 descriptions of a breast cancer patient that were identical except for the degree of relationship (mother, neighbor, or family friend) they were to imagine that they had with the patient. They then completed a 12-item questionnaire concerning their perceptions of and reactions to the patient. For all instances in which a significant effect for condition emerged, the neighbor or the family friend received more negative reactions than did the mother. Males were less likely than were females to believe that the patient could return to work within 3 mo after hospitalization and to fear they would get cancer after visiting the patient. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- concurrent validity of measure of biological energy expended during physical performance at work & leisure
KP- male survivors of Hodgkin's disease
SU- Energy Expenditure; Leisure Time; Measurement; Neoplasms; Statistical Validity
AB- Examines the concurrent validity of a measure consisting of the individual's activity patterns at work and at leisure and weighted by a factor associated with the expenditure of biological energy. Results obtained from 85 men who had been treated for Hodgkin's disease indicate that more sedentary activity patterns are positively correlated with scores on the fatigue subscale of the Profile of Mood States (POMS), whereas more active patterns are positively correlated with scores on the POMS vigor subscale, self-reports of energy level, and self-ratings of health status. Perceived energy levels interact with activity patterns at leisure but not at work. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- self esteem & well being
KP- 35–77 yr old females with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Self Esteem; Well Being
AB- Knowledge of the impact that breast cancer has on self-esteem and well-being has been limited, conceptually, by the failure to consider potentially positive outcomes after diagnosis and treatment and, methodologically, by an overall lack of focus on well-being. Sixty-four women with breast cancer and 64 age-matched women without cancer completed three measures of self-esteem and five measures of well-being. The results supported the theoretical notion that the potential impact of breast cancer on a woman's self-esteem and well-being can be positive as well as negative. The results also highlighted the importance of considering the full impact of cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved) (journal abstract)

KP- collaboration on bone marrow transplant
KP- hematologists & mental health professionals
KP- illustrative cases of male 7 yr old & female 25 yr old
SU- Collaboration; Interdisciplinary Treatment Approach; Mental Health Personnel; Organ Transplantation; Physicians
AB- Discusses the collaboration between hematologists and mental health professionals on a bone-marrow transplant team and suggests that such a collaboration reflects the recognition that emotional stress is a significant component of life-threatening diseases. This new professional relationship relieves the pressures on the physician and nursing staff, provides psychological continuity in patient care, broadens the scope of the team's knowledge of patients and their families, and allows for preventive intervention. The cases of a 7-yr-old boy and a 25-yr-old woman illustrate the collaboration. (8 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- The role of patient delay in the evaluation of breast self-examination.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Funch, Donna P.
AF- Funch, Donna P., State U New York, Buffalo
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 2
IP- 3-4
SD- Fal-Win 1984
YR- 1984
PM- Fal-Win 1984
PG- 31-39
PC- 9
SP- 31
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 9
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v02n03_03
LA- English
KP- regular practice of breast self examination & immediate vs delayed seeking of treatment for symptoms of breast cancer
KP- female breast cancer patients
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Health Behavior; Health Care Utilization; Human Females; Prevention
AB- Examined the relationship between breast self-examination (BSE) and delay in seeking treatment in 129 female breast cancer patients, who were interviewed in their homes for 90 min. Ss were divided into 2 groups with respect to BSE: those who examined their breasts at least once a month (n = 57) and those who did so less frequently or not at all (n = 72). Results show that the regular practice of BSE was unrelated to the immediate seeking of treatment for symptoms of breast cancer. Ss who practiced BSE and delayed seeking treatment were older than other Ss who practiced BSE, and they were more likely to have had a family member who had experienced prolonged or painful deterioration because of breast cancer. Both BSE and delay were significantly associated with the stage of breast cancer at diagnosis, and Ss who practiced BSE and sought treatment quickly were most likely to be diagnosed at an early stage. (37 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Health Behavior; Health Care Utilization; Human Females; Prevention
CL- Promotion & Maintenance of Health & Wellness (3365)
PO- Human (10)

KP- psychoactive medication
KP- pediatric oncology patients
SU- Drug Therapy; Neoplasms
AB- Discusses the use of psychoactive medication to treat psychopathology in pediatric oncology patients, noting that psychoactive medications are often required to treat anxiety, depression, pain, and psychotic-organic brain syndromes. In general, the most familiar psychoactive medication, prescribed at the minimal effective dose, should be used for short-term relief of symptoms. Psychoactive medications may be the most useful in conjunction with other forms of therapy. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Psychosocial characteristics of cancer patients who choose Laetrile therapy.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Barbour, John S.
AU- Redding, Karen
AU- Beutler, Larry E.
AU- Jones, Stephen E.
AU- Meyskens, Frank
AF- Barbour, John S., U Arizona Health Sciences Ctr, Tucson

VI- 2

SD- Fal-Win 1984
YR- 1984
PM- Fal-Win 1984
PG- 93-108
PC- 16
SP- 93
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

DO- 10.1300/J077v02n03_08
LA- English
KP- decision to choose laetril & skepticism & alienation from medical establishment
KP- cancer patients
SU- Client Attitudes; Decision Making; Drug Therapy; Neoplasms
AB- Two studies examined the attitudes of Laetrile patients and their physicians. In Exp I, 12 patients (mean age 56 yrs) who elected to receive Laetrile were matched and contrasted with 12 patients (mean age 58.8 yrs) who agreed to undertake Phase II treatments (i.e., therapy that is endorsed by the medical community). Results suggest that the Laetrile patients were more skeptical and alienated from the medical establishment than were the Phase II patients. In Exp II, a survey of 8 physicians and 2 nurses revealed that they had a general skepticism toward Laetrile and a tendency to perceive patients who took Laetrile as more depressed and anxious than patients who undertook more conventional treatments. (11 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Attitudes; Decision Making; Drug Therapy; Neoplasms

KP- parents of children with cancer
SU- Group Counseling; Neoplasms; Parents; Participation; Self Help Techniques
AB- Examined characteristics of 53 female and 42 male participants (n = 36) and nonparticipants (n = 59) in a self-help group for parents of children with cancer. Ss were interviewed for approximately 90 min to assess the nature of the diagnosis, the course of the illness, problems the family encountered, social support, and experiences with medical staff. Results show that participants and nonparticipants did not differ on the bases of gender, education, income, or attitudes toward the medical system. However, parents who lived closer to the hospital, whose children had been diagnosed 1–4 yrs previously, and who reported a high degree of stress from their child's illness were more likely to participate in the group. The importance of self-help groups as a resource for parents of children with serious and chronic illnesses is discussed. (72 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Group Counseling; Neoplasms; Parents; Participation; Self Help Techniques
MN- Social Support

TI- The validity of emotional control as a trait in breast cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Pettingale, Keith W.
AU- Watson, Maggie
AU- Greer, Steven
AF- Pettingale, Keith W., U London King's Coll School of Medicine & Dentistry, Rayne Inst Faith Courtauld Unit, England
AF- Watson, Maggie
AF- Greer, Steven
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 2
IP- 3-4
SD- Fal-Win 1984
YR- 1984
PM- Fal-Win 1984
PG- 21-30
PC- 10
SP- 21
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 10
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v02n03_02
LA- English
KP- validity of emotional control as personality trait
KP- females with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Control; Human Females; Personality Correlates
AB- Investigated emotional control in 30 breast cancer patients and 27 women who had attended a breast-screening clinic and had no evidence of a malignant breast tumor. Stress was manipulated experimentally through the use of 3 videotapes (2 emotionally challenging tapes and 1 emotionally neutral tape). Measures of personality (e.g., the State-Trait Personality Inventory), behavior (Ss' behavioral responses were videotaped throughout the stress manipulation), and mood state (linear analog scales) were taken. Ss completed the personality measures and one of the analog scales before viewing the tapes. After viewing each tape, Ss completed the 2nd analog scale and a questionnaire on their reactions to the tape. Results support the hypothesis that the breast cancer patients would be more emotionally inhibited. Self-report measures indicated that although the patients tended to control or repress their emotional reactions, they were more anxious and disturbed as a result of the stress manipulation than were the controls. Findings are discussed in relation to current theories of emotion and to psychobiological models. (30 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Control; Human Females; Personality Correlates

KP- accrual & attrition of Ss in study of psychosocial & coping responses
KP- patients with advanced lung cancer
SU- Coping Behavior; Experimental Subjects; Neoplasms
AB- Examined S accrual and attrition in a study of psychosocial responses and effectiveness of coping among patients with advanced lung cancer. 73 of the 136 potential Ss refused to participate. 20 of 63 patients for whom consent was obtained later withdrew from the study. Reasons for S accrual and attrition are discussed. (3 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Relations with children after breast cancer: The mother–daughter relationship at risk.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Lichtman, Rosemary R.
AU- Taylor, Shelley E.
AU- Wood, Joanne V.
AU- Bluming, Avrum Z.
AU- Dosik, Gary M.
AU- Leibowitz, Robert L.
AF- Lichtman, Rosemary R., U California, Los Angeles
AF- Taylor, Shelley E.

PG- 1-19

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- relationship with sons vs daughters
KP- 29–78 yr old mothers with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Daughters; Mother Child Relations
AB- Interviews with 78 29–78 yr old breast cancer patients were analyzed to document perceptions of changes in their relationships with their children. The significant others of 63 of the patients were also interviewed. Results show that although the majority of mother–child relationships were reported to have stayed strong or to have grown stronger following breast cancer, deterioration was evident in 12% of the relationships. Problems with children were more likely when the patients had a poor prognosis, more severe surgery, poorer psychological adjustment, and, to a lesser extent, more difficulty with radiation therapy or chemotherapy. The mothers' relationships with their daughters were at a significantly greater risk than were the relationships with their sons. The fear of inheriting breast cancer and the mother's demands on the daughter for support were judged to be major contributing factors to the difficulties with adolescent and postadolescent daughters. (31 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Daughters; Mother Child Relations

TI- Relationship of the social environment and patients' physical status to depression in lung cancer patients and their spouses.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Goldberg, Richard J.
AU- Wool, Margaret S.
AU- Glicksman, Arvin
AU- Tull, Robert
AF- Goldberg, Richard J., Rhode Island Hosp, Dept of Psychiatry, Providence

LA- English
KP- physical health status & social environment
KP- depression
KP- lung cancer patients & their spouses
SU- Depression (Emotion); Health; Lung Disorders; Neoplasms; Social Environments
AB- Examined the relationship of patients' physical health status and social environment to depression in 21 White lung cancer patients (mean age 61.8 yrs) and 18 of their spouses. Psychosocial and physical data on the patients and spouses were gathered for 6 mo after the patients' diagnosis to determine the relationship of the social environment and the patients' physical status to depressive symptoms (the Profile of Mood States) in patients and spouses. It was found that physical status was related to depressive symptoms in patients but not in their spouses. The spouses' depressive symptoms were independent of the patients' physical status but were related to a measure of involvement in the social environment (the Psychosocial Adjustment to Illness Scale). Findings highlight the importance of screening spouses of cancer patients for psychosocial impairment and the fact that such impairment cannot be predicted from the patients' physical status. (30 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Depression (Emotion); Health; Lung Disorders; Neoplasms; Social Environments

TI- Psychosocial distress in oncology outpatients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Farber, John M.
AU- Weinerman, Brian H.

LA- English
KP- level & nature & prevalence of psychosocial distress
KP- oncology outpatients
SU- Distress; Neoplasms; Outpatients; Oncology
AB- Assessed the level, nature, and prevalence of psychological distress in a heterogenous group of 141 patients attending a major Canadian oncology outpatient clinic using the SCL-90. For purposes of comparison, a psychosocial profile was plotted for the psychiatric outpatient norm group reported by L. R. Derogatis (1977). Ss' reported levels of psychological distress were elevated in comparison to the psychiatric outpatient norm group but fell within normal limits. The distribution of scores, however, suggests that about one-third of all oncology outpatients can be expected to experience a high and clinically significant level of psychological distress. Results are discussed in relation to other studies, the limitations of the present study, and the need for better methods of identifying patients in distress. It is concluded that it is important for clinicians to provide patients with a realistic description of the psychosocial sequelae of cancer. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Coping with hospice work stress.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Yancik, Rosemary
AF- Yancik, Rosemary, National Cancer Inst, Div of Cancer Prevention & Control, Bethesda, MD
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 2
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1984

PG- 19-35

PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print

DO- 10.1300/J077v02n02_02
LA- English
KP- coping techniques for occupational stress
KP- 22–64 yr old hospice staff members
SU- Coping Behavior; Hospice; Medical Personnel; Occupational Stress
AB- Analyzed the responses of 93 22–64 yr old staff members at 3 hospices in relation to 2 outcomes—emotional distress and role fulfillment—that were considered manifestations of occupational stress. Data were obtained from self-administered questionnaires completed at the work site. Results show that Ss called on different resources for coping with various selected problems. Such psychological characteristics and internal resources as self-esteem and a sense of mastery were effective in sustaining Ss against the emotional distress that arose in their work situations. External resources—help and support from others—and cooperative efforts contributed to Ss' feelings of role fulfillment. It is concluded that the special nature of hospice work requires a structured form of interaction among workers who perform similar functions. (44 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- treatment information received by mail vs just before vs after appointment
KP- effectiveness of information booklet in patient preparation
KP- cancer center outpatients
SU- Client Attitudes; Client Education; Medical Patients; Neoplasms; Treatment
AB- Interviewed 161 cancer patients who received a general information booklet that prepared them for their 1st visit to a cancer center in 1 of 3 ways: Group 1 received the booklet by mail before their appointment, Group 2 received the booklet when they arrived for their appointment, and Group 3 received the booklet after the interview. Results indicate that Group 1 felt better informed, and early distribution had a more positive psychological effect than later distribution. TI- Helping children communicate about serious illness and death.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Adams-Greenly, Margaret
AF- Adams-Greenly, Margaret, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr, Dept of Social Work, New York, NY
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 2

LA- English
KP- principles of intervention
KP- assistance for expression of inner experiences & concerns about illness & death
KP- seriously ill children
SU- Death and Dying; Death Attitudes; Interpersonal Communication; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward)
AB- Outlines 7 principles of intervention to help seriously ill children express inner experiences and their concerns about serious illness and death, arguing that the perceptions of this population should be ascertained as part of treatment. It is noted that children often use symbolic language to communicate their worries and commonly fantasize that they are responsible for their own illness. Seriously ill children's trust in their parents must be maintained and supported, and their self-esteem can be promoted through mastery. In approaching a child with cancer or any other serious illness, the caretaker should attempt to be free of assumptions so as to be open to what each encounter can teach. Examples of caretakers' interactions with children affected by cancer are provided. (40 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Adolescents with cancer report their psychosocial needs.

LA- English
KP- assessment of psychosocial needs
KP- 11–20 yr old cancer patients
SU- Medical Patients; Needs Assessment; Neoplasms
AB- Nine 11–20 yr old cancer patients in a pediatric oncology program participated in a 3-mo support group led by a pediatrician and a clinical nurse-specialist as part of an assessment program to determine Ss' psychosocial needs. 12 1½-hr sessions were conducted. The topics discussed included the behavior of physicians and nurses (including retaliatory actions), the physician–patient relationship, the reactions of peers and parents to the cancer patient, and reintegration into school and social life. Ss stressed the need for physicians to share personal information with patients and for patients to have positive attitudes toward recovery, to be included in decisions about treatment, and not to be allowed to use their illness. It is concluded that the behavior of health care providers can influence the ability of adolescents to cope with malignancy or chronic illness. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Attitudes, knowledge, and behaviors of school peers of adolescent cancer patients.

LA- English
KP- attitudes & knowledge & behavior
KP- classmates of 12–18 yr old cancer patients
SU- Knowledge Level; Medical Patients; Neoplasms; Peer Relations; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward)
AB- Administered a 50-item questionnaire to 65 classmates of 11 12–18 yr old cancer patients to study whether patients' feelings of being rejected, avoided, and misunderstood by their peers (classmates) were consistent with reality. Data show a high level of knowledge about cancer and generally positive attitudes and behaviors among peers of patients. These Ss expressed a desire to support and help cancer patients, and they supported the idea of a visiting program for teenagers hospitalized with cancer. Although the question of the discrepancy between cancer patients' and their peers' perceptions needs further investigation, it is suggested that patients' perceptions of rejection by their peers may be biased by depression and the effects of the disease on self-concept. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Sources of work stress for hospice staff.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Yancik, Rosemary

LA- English
KP- sources of stress in hospice work
KP- nurses & social workers & psychologists & directors of volunteers
SU- Hospice; Nurses; Occupational Stress; Psychologists; Social Workers
AB- Investigated the major sources of stress in the work roles of hospice staff members. 93 Ss, aged 22–64 yrs, from 3 hospices participated. 75% were registered nurses, licensed practical nurses, and licensed vocational nurses; 25% were social workers, psychologists, occupational therapists, physical therapists, and directors of volunteers. 92% had some college education. Data were collected using a self-administered questionnaire. Findings indicated 3 major stress-producing areas—staff support issues, emotional concern for patients and their families, and management of the disease process. Lack of staff support proved to be the greatest overall producer of stress. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- development & leadership of staff support groups for reduction of stress
KP- nurses working in cancer center
SU- Neoplasms; Nurses; Occupational Stress; Social Support
AB- Describes the technical aspects of the development and leadership of nursing staff support groups—groups designed to reduce the effects of work-related stress by enhancing the nursing staff's problem-solving abilities. Among the topics discussed are the purpose of such groups, their format and structure, and the importance of an active leadership approach. Specific leadership techniques and strategies are described. Each topic is illustrated with examples gathered during 7 yrs of leading such groups at a cancer center. TI- Influence of gender on the problems of parents of fatally ill children.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cook, Judith A.
AF- Cook, Judith A., U Chicago, Committee on Human Development
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 2
IP- 1
SD- Spr 1984
YR- 1984
PM- Spr 1984
PG- 71-91
PC- 21
SP- 71
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v02n01_06
LA- English
KP- sex differences
KP- adjustment to fatal illness of child
KP- parents
SU- Coping Behavior; Fathers; Grief; Mothers; Terminally Ill Patients
AB- Conducted a study of 145 parents of children who were treated for cancer or blood disorders at a large urban pediatric hospital and who subsequently died, to examine the differences in the parents' experiences. 90 of the Ss were mothers and 55 were fathers; together they represented 92 families. 95% were White, 88% were married, and 65% were employed outside the home. Data were collected either by questionnaire (n = 58) or by interview (n = 87). Both mothers and fathers reported many problems that were unique and could be attributed to their differential roles in the family. Women reported such problems as shielding others, marital problems, concern for the child's morale, and emotional strain. Men reported such problems as feeling responsible for both work and family, exclusion from family, and wife's overinvolvement with the ill child. Implications of the qualitative and quantitative analyses of the data are discussed in relation to the influence of gender on parents' social construction of reality and to anticipatory and postdeath mourning. (47 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Fathers; Grief; Mothers; Terminally Ill Patients

TI- Gender differences in the processes leading to cigarette smoking.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Brunswick, Ann F.
AU- Messeri, Peter A.
AF- Brunswick, Ann F., Columbia U School of Public Health, Div of Sociomedical Sciences
AF- Messeri, Peter A.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 2
IP- 1
SD- Spr 1984
YR- 1984
PM- Spr 1984
PG- 49-69
PC- 21
SP- 49
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v02n01_05
LA- English
KP- school achievement during adolescence & sex differences
KP- onset of cigarette smoking
KP- 18–23 yr old urban Blacks
KP- 6–8 yr followup
SU- Academic Achievement; Blacks; Human Sex Differences; Tobacco Smoking
AB- Conducted a 2-wave study among urban Black adolescents to investigate the link between school achievement and smoking. In the late 1960's (mid-1967 to mid-1969), data were collected from 668 Black teenagers. Six to 8 yrs later (in 1975 and 1976), 536 of the original sample, aged 18–23 yrs, participated in the 2nd study. The 156 Ss who reported smoking at the 1st contact were eliminated from analysis, leaving a pool of 209 males and 171 females. The hypothesis that poor school achievement would have significant influence on the onset of smoking was confirmed. Results indicate that psychogenic variables (worry about school performance) significantly increased the risk of smoking among females but not among males and that perceptions of one's social opportunities, an indicator of differential socialization, added significantly to the risk of smoking among males but not among females. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Academic Achievement; Blacks; Human Sex Differences; Tobacco Smoking

LA- English
KP- development of self report for assessment of sexual functioning after treatment for gynecological cancer
KP- females with mean age of 56.5 yrs
SU- Gynecological Disorders; Measurement; Neoplasms; Psychosexual Behavior; Test Construction
AB- Discusses a 30-item self-report scale for the assessment of sexual functioning after treatment for gynecologic cancer that was developed and pilot-tested with 30 patients (average age 56.5 yrs) in a department of radiotherapy in Dijon, France. 22 of the Ss were married. Their diagnoses included all stages of cervical, uterine, and ovarian cancer. The scale appears to have satisfactory levels of reliability. Future administrations are needed to establish its validity as well as its applicability in non-French populations. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Social functioning of women with breast cancer: Validation of a clinical scale.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bloom, Joan R.
AU- Pendergrass, Susan M.
AU- Burnell, George M.
AF- Bloom, Joan R., U California, School of Public Health, Berkeley
AF- Pendergrass, Susan M.
AF- Burnell, George M.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 2
IP- 1
SD- Spr 1984
YR- 1984
PM- Spr 1984
PG- 93-101
PC- 9
SP- 93
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 9
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v02n01_07
LA- English
KP- discriminate validity of E. Heimler's social functioning scale
KP- 25–75 yr old mastectomy patients vs healthy females
SU- Human Females; Mastectomy; Rating Scales; Social Adjustment; Test Validity
AB- Tested the discriminate validity of E. Heimler's (1975) social functioning scale by comparing the social functioning scores of 136 women who had had a mastectomy with those of a sample of 147 healthy women. The Ss, aged 25–75 yrs, were administered Heimler's scale of social functioning, a coping response scale, and the Social Readjustment Rating Scale. Ss who had had mastectomies were interviewed from 1 wk to 2½ yrs after surgery. 75% were married, 44% were employed, 28% had regional lymph node involvement at the time of surgery, and 80% had a 2-step procedure. Results show that the Ss who had had mastectomies perceived their social functioning to be less satisfactory than did the controls. They also used more maladaptive coping mechanisms and experienced more life changes, providing evidence of the discriminate validity of Heimler's scale in differentiating mastectomy patients from healthy women. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Human Females; Mastectomy; Rating Scales; Social Adjustment; Test Validity

TI- The making of a cancer psychotherapist.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Klagsbrun, Sam
AF- Klagsbrun, Sam, Four Winds Hosp, Katonah, NY
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 4
SD- Win 1983

PG- 55-60

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 6

DO- 10.1300/J077v01n04_06
LA- English
KP- role of cancer psychotherapists
SU- Neoplasms; Psychotherapists; Psychotherapy; Therapist Role
AB- An oncotherapist must be knowledgeable concerning cancer treatment, particularly rehabilitative measures. The therapist must be able to explain the treatment to the patient, prepare him/her for possible side effects, and anticipate potential psychological problems arising from the disease and treatment. Particular attention needs to be paid to issues such as depression and anxiety, loss of interests, and damage to self-image. Oncotherapists should be skilled in family therapy techniques and be able to improve communication among family members, incorporate medical staff in therapy when appropriate, and educate family members about the hospital systems they depend on. The importance of leadership skills and issues related to the termination of treatment are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Issues related to psychosocial intervention with Hispanic families in a pediatric cancer setting.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Schaefer, Diana S.
AF- Schaefer, Diana S., Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr, Dept of Social Work, New York, NY
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1

SD- Win 1983

PG- 39-46

SP- 39
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

SN- 0734-7332, Print

DO- 10.1300/J077v01n04_04
LA- English
KP- psychosocial intervention issues
KP- Hispanic families confronted with diagnosis of childhood cancer
KP- implications for mental health professionals
SU- Family; Mental Health Services; Neoplasms; Sociocultural Factors; Latinos/Latinas
AB- Attempts to sensitize mental health professionals to the special needs of Hispanic families confronted with a diagnosis of childhood cancer. This diagnosis can be especially devastating to the family that lives in another country or in Puerto Rico and brings the child to the US for treatment. Hispanic family structure, culture, and belief systems are discussed using illustrative case vignettes. The Spanish-speaking mental health professional in a cancer-care setting can help the family adjust to its new surroundings by (1) enlisting friends and members of the extended family as sources of emotional support and concrete assistance and (2) educating other staff about the need for flexibility when dealing with the family. Early intervention can help these families adapt to the requirements of the medical institution, cope with diagnosis and treatment, and adjust to a new living environment. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Use of hypnotic techniques with oncology patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Araoz, Daniel L.
AF- Araoz, Daniel L., Long Island U
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 4
SD- Win 1983
YR- 1983
PM- Win 1983
PG- 47-54
PC- 8
SP- 47
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 8
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n04_05
LA- English
KP- hypnosis
KP- pain & negative psychological factors
KP- cancer patients
SU- Hypnotherapy; Neoplasms; Pain
AB- Discusses the uses of hypnosis in the treatment of cancer patients. Four basic methods for the management of pain by hypnosis are outlined: hypnotic analgesia, modification of the painful stimulus, displacement of pain, and dissociation from pain. The value of hypnosis in controlling the physiological concomitants of treatment and the negative psychological effects of cancer are also examined. Hypnotic imagery can be used to induce relaxation, reduce anxiety and distress, and to control anticipatory nausea in chemotherapy. Positive mental imagery helps patients detach themselves from the constant obsession with cancer, allows them to engage in positive goal-directed behavior, and encourages them to think of a more pleasant future. Hypnosis can also bring about changes in perceptions, attitudes, and beliefs that will enhance self-esteem. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Hypnotherapy; Neoplasms; Pain
MN- Psychological Stress

TI- A noncategorical approach to psychosocial research.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Jessop, Dorothy J.
AU- Stein, Ruth E.
AF- Jessop, Dorothy J., Yeshiva U, Albert Einstein Coll of Medicine
AF- Stein, Ruth E.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 4
SD- Win 1983
YR- 1983
PM- Win 1983
PG- 61-64
PC- 4
SP- 61
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 4
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n04_07
LA- English
KP- noncategorical approach
KP- psychosocial research of chronic disease
SU- Disorders; Experimentation; Neoplasms
AB- Argues that the attempt to understand the meaning of a disease in the lives of patients and their families requires an approach that considers the commonalities among disease entities rather than the character of the specific disease. The limitations of the disease-specific model are especially noticeable with respect to the psychosocial effects of chronic disease. Several studies of chronic disease in children have indicated that diagnostic groupings provided little information about psychological and social outcomes and that such outcomes were related to the uncertainty or ambiguity of the condition. It is suggested that a noncategorical approach to psychosocial research is necessary to generate the numbers of cases necessary to perform sophisticated analyses of the data. (6 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Disorders; Experimentation; Neoplasms
CL- Psychological & Physical Disorders (3200)
PO- Human (10)

TI- Psychosocial screening of cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Worden, J. William
AF- Worden, J. William, Harvard Medical School, Boston
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 4
SD- Win 1983
YR- 1983
PM- Win 1983
PG- 1-10
PC- 10
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 10
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n04_01
LA- English
KP- development & validation of screening instrument
KP- prediction of level of emotional distress 2–6 mo after cancer diagnosis
KP- adult oncology patients
SU- Distress; Neoplasms; Prediction; Screening Tests; Test Construction
AB- Describes the development and validation of a screening instrument for predicting the level of emotional distress that newly diagnosed cancer patients may experience 2–6 mo after diagnosis. The initial evaluation consisted of a semistructured interview, psychological testing with the TAT and MMPI, and use of rating scales such as the Profile of Mood States with 120 adult oncology patients. A multiple regression analysis was used to identify the best predictors of emotional distress. After the instrument was developed and calibrated, it was revalidated in a subsequent study of 381 cancer patients, 86% of whom were correctly identified in terms of the predicted level of emotional distress. The limitations and clinical usefulness of this approach are discussed. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Cancer Inventory of Problem Situations: An instrument for assessing cancer patients' rehabilitation needs.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Schag, Cyndie C.
AU- Heinrich, Richard L.
AU- Ganz, Patricia A.
AF- Schag, Cyndie C., VA Medical Ctr, Psychosocial Research Program Behavioral Rehabilitation Research Lab, Sepulveda, CA
AF- Heinrich, Richard L.
AF- Ganz, Patricia A.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 4
SD- Win 1983
YR- 1983
PM- Win 1983
PG- 11-24
PC- 14
SP- 11
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n04_02
LA- English
KP- reliability & validity of Cancer Inventory of Problem Situations
KP- documentation of psychosocial & physical problems
KP- cancer patients with mean age 60 of yrs
SU- Inventories; Needs Assessment; Neoplasms; Test Reliability; Test Validity
AB- Describes an initial study evaluating the psychometric properties of the Cancer Inventory of Problem Situations (CIPS), a newly developed instrument for documenting the psychosocial and physical problems of cancer patients. The CIPS was completed by 306 cancer patients (mean age 60 yrs). 71 Ss completed a 2nd CIPS 1 wk later; 87 Ss completed the SCL-90-R, an index of psychological distress; and 22 Ss participated in a comprehensive interview. The CIPS had excellent test–retest reliability and also correlated highly with the SCL-90-R. Agreement in the types of problems identified by the CIPS and a trained interviewer was also excellent. The CIPS was more sensitive than the interview for assessing problems in 7 categories, including pain, activity, and significant relationships. Content validity was reevaluated and shown to be excellent. The items in the CIPS were factored into subscales of problem categories with alpha coefficients indicating internal consistency. The study indicated that the CIPS is reliable and valid and can be used in clinical settings to assess the problems of individual cancer patients and in research settings to begin documenting the day-to-day problems of patients with different types of cancer. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Inventories; Needs Assessment; Neoplasms; Test Reliability; Test Validity
MN- Pain; Psychological Stress
CL- Clinical Psychological Testing (2224)

TI- The Anamnestic Comparative Self-Assessment for measuring the subjective quality of life of cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bernheim, Jan L.
AU- Buyse, Marc
AF- Bernheim, Jan L., Free U of Brussels, Jules Bordet Inst, Belgium
AF- Buyse, Marc
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 4
SD- Win 1983
YR- 1983
PM- Win 1983
PG- 25-38
PC- 14
SP- 25
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n04_03
LA- English
KP- validation of Anamnestic Comparative Self-Assessment scale
KP- assessment of subjective quality of life
KP- 16–81 yr old patients with malignancies
SU- Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Rating Scales; Self Evaluation; Test Validity
AB- The Anamnestic Comparative Self-Assessment (ACSA) is a method by which cancer patients numerically express their overall subjective level of the quality of life. A personal scale of well-being is constructed around the patient's memory of the best and worst periods in his/her life experience. The method was validated in a pilot study of 65 16–81 yr old patients with various malignancies. The ACSA was sensitive to performance status, prognosis, level of anxiety, and the aggressiveness and results of treatment. The scoring to the ACSA is illustrated via the case of a 59-yr-old male, and the advantages of the ACSA are discussed in terms of its avoidance of observer bias and the comparative nature of the evaluation it provides of the impact of the disease and its treatment. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Rating Scales; Self Evaluation; Test Validity
MN- Life Experiences

KP- current status of & future directions for supportive family focused care
KP- coping
KP- family members with cancer
SU- Coping Behavior; Family Relations; Neoplasms; Treatment
AB- Presents a clinician's views on the current status of family-focused cancer care and on future directions for supportive interventions to help families cope with cancer. Developmental considerations (i.e., the age of the family unit and the impact of cancer on the developmental crises being faced) are discussed, as are special or high-risk groups (i.e., families exhibiting denial or an anger–guilt response). A family assessment framework is presented that encourages assessment of the family structure, boundaries, and family function over time. Recommendations on future care opportunities are proposed. TI- Coping with the psychosocial stresses of oncology care.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sparks, T. Flint
AF- Sparks, T. Flint, Westlake Psychotherapy Ctr, Austin, TX, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6
IP- 1-2
SD- 1988
YR- 1988
PM- 1988
PG- 165-179
PC- 15
SP- 165
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
LA- English
KP- conceptual model of coping with psychosocial stresses of oncology care
KP- health & mental health professionals
SU- Coping Behavior; Models; Neoplasms; Occupational Stress; Oncology
AB- Presents a conceptual model that maps out the process of coping with the psychosocial stresses of oncology care. The model is taken from crisis theory and is initially presented in a form that describes patients coping with the crises of physical illness. A translation of the model describes the processes involved in coping with the psychosocial stresses of treating physical illness. Emphasis is placed on the adaptive tasks that confront oncology professionals and the coping skills they must use to meet the demands of these adaptive tasks. The tasks are framed in an interpersonal context with the relationships among the self, patient, family members, and other staff as the principal elements. Social support and the development of support groups are defined as the most powerful tools for coping with the ongoing psychosocial stresses of oncology care. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Models; Neoplasms; Occupational Stress; Oncology
MN- Medical Personnel; Mental Health Personnel

TI- Psychiatric aspects of psychosocial distress in cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Goldberg, Richard J.
AF- Goldberg, Richard J., Rhode Island Hosp, Providence, US

VI- 6

LA- English
KP- identification & management of delirium & depression
KP- cancer patients
SU- Delirium; Major Depression; Neoplasms; Treatment
AB- Reviews the identification and management of the 2 most common psychiatric disorders in cancer patients, delirium and depression. Physical consequences of cancer and its treatment can account for disorders of mood, thought, or behavior that appear to be indistinguishable from psychological, social, behavioral, or existentially mediated distress. Common physiologic disorders in patients that present as psychosocial distress and questions about mental status that are important in detecting organic mental disorders and the differential evaluation of depressive symptoms are addressed. Issues involved in the use of psychotropic drugs are also summarized. The psychiatrist is placed in the context of a multidisciplinary team and the specific psychiatric contribution to the overall management of cancer patients is described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Psychosocial care of the cancer patient: Guidelines for the physician.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Blum, Ronald H.
AU- Blum, Diane S.

LA- English
KP- psychosocial assessment & intervention by physicians
KP- cancer patients
SU- Evaluation; Neoplasms; Physicians; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment
AB- Presents specific guidelines that physicians can use for the psychosocial assessment of and intervention with the cancer patient. The overall goal is to provide the patient with hope balanced with reality at all stages of the disease. Methods are given for assessment and intervention at 4 specific points in the disease: (1) the initial meeting between patient and physician, (2) the completion of treatment, (3) the time when treatment fails, and (4) the terminal stage. Clinical examples are used to illustrate the process. The benefits of psychosocial assessment and intervention for the patient, family, and health care team are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- issues in & assessment of & interventions for family coping
KP- family members with breast or other cancer
KP- literature review
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Family Relations; Literature Review; Neoplasms
AB- Reviews the literature to identify coping issues and factors associated with family functioning when a family member has cancer and relates these to specific issues that arise when breast cancer occurs. The approaches to assessment and intervention also are examined. Most studies place primary emphasis on the patient's problems rather than on the family's, and assessment and intervention models are generally aimed toward chronic illness and all cancers. There is a need to understand how the specific factors affect families and to identify high-risk families who cannot adjust successfully. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- coping style & expression of anger & health related locus of control & disease related factors
KP- prediction of psychosocial adjustment
KP- 32–69 yr old females with breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Social Adjustment
AB- 67 32–69 yr old women treated for breast cancer completed a battery of psychological tests to examine which psychological variables contributed most to several indexes of adjustment. Measures included the Psychosocial Adjustment to Illness Scale and the Buss-Durkee Hostility-Guilt Inventory. An avoidant style of coping was associated with poorer adjustment on several different indexes, and an active coping style was associated with better adjustment on several indexes. Denial was related to poor adjustment on only 1 index, orientation to health care. Day-to-day stresses were an important predictor of both psychological and domestic adjustment. Health locus of control and the stage and duration of cancer were not related to any adjustment indexes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

LA- English
KP- sustained socioemotional support during radiation treatment
KP- depression & psychological adaptation
KP- 18–83 yr olds with cancer
KP- 2 mo followup
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Major Depression; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy; Social Support
AB- Tested the stress buffering hypothesis, a hypothesized relationship between level of social support during a life-threatening health crisis and subsequent amelioration of psychological distress, with a longitudinal, quasi-experimental research design. 181 18–83 yr old adult patients recently diagnosed with cancer and about to undergo curative radiation therapy participated. Perceived satisfaction with socioemotional support was assessed at treatment onset and at its completion 6 wks later. Ss' responses were used to develop an index of sustained social support. Distress associated with depressive symptoms was assessed at the completion of treatment and 2 mo later using the SCL-90 (Revised). Depression at 2-mo follow-up was not significantly related to level of support after controlling for depression when treatment was completed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Major Depression; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy; Social Support

LA- English
KP- perceived family functioning & childrearing & other psychosocial needs & stresses
KP- cancer patients & their spouses
SU- Family Relations; Needs; Neoplasms; Spouses; Stress
AB- Conducted tape-recorded interviews with 30 female and 24 male adult cancer patients and their spouses to (1) allow Ss to share thoughts, feelings, and perceptions of their experiences; (2) enable Ss, who were in the child-rearing stages of the family life cycle, to describe the stresses created in their families by the experience of cancer; (3) assess Ss' perceptions of the helpfulness of staff in a university hospital specializing in cancer treatment and research; and (4) use this information to suggest ways that health care providers can respond more effectively to the psychosocial needs of such families. Hospital-based sources of stress included uncertainty and lack of personal control and waiting for test results. Home-based sources of stress included communication between spouses and with children, and feelings of guilt. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- social validity of problem specification stage of behavior analytic model
KP- assessment of coping with outpatient chemotherapy
KP- 38–79 yr olds with cancer & their family members & nurses & oncologist
SU- Chemotherapy; Coping Behavior; Drug Therapy; Models; Neoplasms
AB- Reports social validity data from the problem-specification stage of the behavior analytic model for assessing how cancer patients cope with outpatient chemotherapy. 47 problem situations were generated, and social validity data were collected from 73 38–79 yr old voluntary participants. Ss included 29 cancer patients and 20 of their family members, 23 nurses, and 1 oncologist. All Ss were either involved or familiar with the administration of chemotherapy. The top 10 socially valid problem situations are presented, as are grouped data for 6 categories of problem situations, according to their reported frequency and severity. Problem situation categories included anticipated treatment consequences, anxiety related items, and communication with physician. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Assessment of health-related quality of life: Factor scales for patients with breast cancer.
