LA- English
KP- factor analysis of linear analog self assessment scales
KP- assessment of health related quality of life
KP- females with breast cancer vs benign breast disease
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Factor Structure; Health; Quality of Life; Rating Scales
AB- Condensed information about health-related quality of life for patients with breast cancer, obtained using linear analog self-assessment (LASA) scales, into 4 summary scores using factor analysis. Ss included 35 women with histologically established benign breast disease receiving postsurgical follow-up and 60 breast cancer patients undergoing treatment. Three factor scales, incorporating 16 LASA scales related to general health, have been designated Physical, Emotional, and Social Health; the 4th factor scale, Disease-Related, incorporates 11 LASA scales related to breast cancer and its treatment. These factor scales were compared with the Duke-University of North Carolina Health Profile and performed satisfactorily. The factor scales provide a compromise between attempts to condense results into a single overall score and the reporting of results for each LASA scale. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Factor Structure; Health; Quality of Life; Rating Scales

TI- Medical students' attitudes toward cancer: Concepts of professional distance.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Margolies, Robert
AU- Wachtel, Alan B.
AU- Sutherland, Kathleen R.
AU- Blum, Ronald H.
AF- Margolies, Robert, New York U Cancer Ctr
AF- Wachtel, Alan B.
AF- Sutherland, Kathleen R.
AF- Blum, Ronald H.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 3
SD- Fal 1983
YR- 1983
PM- Fal 1983
PG- 35-49
PC- 15
SP- 35
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n03_03
LA- English
KP- patients' prognosis & age & sex
KP- attitudes toward cancer patients vs other patient groups
KP- 1st vs 2nd yr medical students
SU- Client Characteristics; Demographic Characteristics; Medical Students; Neoplasms; Student Attitudes
AB- Investigated whether incoming 1st-yr medical students have more negative attitudes toward cancer patients than toward other patient groups and whether their attitudes vary with respect to patients' prognosis, age, and sex. The relation of attitudes and previous experience with cancer was also examined. 323 1st- and 2nd-yr students were administered a description of a patient, with different key words. Five independent variables were manipulated: 4 characteristics of patients and Ss' class year. Evaluative attitudes related to the degree of professional distance that Ss preferred to maintain with different types of patients were assessed on a 6-point Likert scale. Factor analysis of the scale yielded 4 factors used in the data analysis. ANOVA demonstrated Ss' overall preferences for maintaining greater professional distance from cancer patients than from heart patients, and from psychiatric patients than from cancer patients. The analyses also showed that Ss preferred to maintain greater professional distance from patients with a poor prognosis than from patients with a good prognosis and from male patients than from female patients. After 1 yr of medical school, Ss perceived cancer patients as easier to manage. Previous experience with cancer was related to an increased desire to work with cancer patients, but it was also related to a perception of cancer patients as more difficult to manage. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Characteristics; Demographic Characteristics; Medical Students; Neoplasms; Student Attitudes

TI- Attitudes and behaviors of primary care physicians with respect to cancer prevention.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Kerner, Jon F.
AU- Strickman, Nancy A.
AU- Bleadingheiser, Linda J.
AF- Kerner, Jon F., Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr, Office of Cancer Control, New York, NY

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1

SD- Fal 1983

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- attitudes & behaviors concerning cancer prevention & management
KP- general practitioners vs family practitioners vs internists
SU- Family Physicians; General Practitioners; Internists; Neoplasms; Preventive Medicine
AB- Surveyed 752 primary care physicians in the New York/New Jersey metropolitan area to determine the attitudes and behaviors of different physician groups concerning cancer prevention and management. Results are presented for 165 general practitioners, 177 family practitioners, and 190 internists. Focus was on the cancer prevention behaviors of these Ss in relation to providing advice and literature on smoking cessation, teaching breast self-examination, and instructing patients about the 7 warning signs of cancer. Ss' attitudes about cancer screening and aggressive treatment were also evaluated. In general, a lower percentage of general practitioners provided information about cancer prevention to patients than did family practitioners and internists, although this difference was small in relation to the high level of cancer prevention behaviors reported by all Ss. General practitioners also had significantly more negative attitudes about the efficacy of cancer screening and the value of aggressive treatment for cancer. The possible reasons for these differences are discussed in the context of other group differences, and the implications for cancer prevention programs targeted to the public are reviewed. (21 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Family Physicians; General Practitioners; Internists; Neoplasms; Preventive Medicine

TI- Effects of age and marital status on the emotional distress after a mastectomy.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Metzger, Loya F.

LA- English
KP- age & marital status
KP- emotional recovery
KP- mastectomy patients with mean age of 52 yrs
SU- Age Differences; Emotional Adjustment; Marital Status; Mastectomy
AB- Used regression analysis to assess how marital status affected the emotional recovery of 652 mastectomy patients (average age 52 yrs) of different ages. SES, employment, and parental status were used as controls to permit a clearer understanding of how marital status affected Ss' coping with this life crisis. Ss were interviewed and administered the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale 1 yr after undergoing mastectomy. Results indicate that although younger Ss were more likely to fear recurrence of the disease and to worry about disfigurement resulting from surgery, they apparently had resources that protected them against depression. The status of being married, generally believed to be a buffer against stressful life events, was found to afford limited protection at best. Never-married Ss were significantly less likely to worry about recurrence and experience less depression. (58 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Age Differences; Emotional Adjustment; Marital Status; Mastectomy

LA- English
KP- obstacles to compliance with treatment
KP- cancer patients receiving radiotherapy
SU- Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy; Treatment Compliance
AB- Describes the obstacles to compliance with treatment among cancer patients receiving radiotherapy. Some forms that failure to comply may take include delay in seeking treatment, refusal of treatment recommendations, premature termination of treatment, and loss to follow-up after treatment. The possible factors that give rise to difficulties at each stage and the means by which these difficulties may be prevented or managed, including patient education and orientation, attention to patient–staff relationships, awareness of the behavioral and psychological changes that seriously ill patients and their families undergo, accessibility of psychiatric intervention, and use of community resources, are considered. Three case histories of women in their late 50's and 60's are provided, which illustrate typical problems and methods of identifying patients at risk for noncompliance before problems develop. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Evaluation of psychosocial problems of the home-bound cancer patient: The relationship of disease and the sociodemographic variables of the patients to family problems.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Wellisch, David K.
AU- Fawzy, Fawzy I.
AU- Landsverk, John A.
AU- Pasnau, Robert O.
AU- Wolcott, Deane L.
AF- Wellisch, David K., U California, School of Medicine, Los Angeles

LA- English
KP- sociodemographic & disease-related characteristics
KP- psychosocial problems
KP- families of home-bound married breast & lung & cervical cancer patients
KP- implications for home health agencies
SU- Adjustment; Client Characteristics; Demographic Characteristics; Family; Neoplasms
AB- Evaluated the records kept by home health agencies on 447 home-bound married cancer patients with breast, lung, or cervical cancer to determine the types of psychosocial problems experienced by the families in home care. Data were collected in a 2-stage record-auditing procedure. The 1st stage consisted of the gathering of relevant sociodemographic and medical data. In the 2nd stage, 2 coders completed the Psychosocial Problem Data Sheet for each S. Results show that families of older male patients with lung cancer felt more overwhelmed and depressed than other families, and families of younger female patients with cervical cancer were more likely to have interpersonal frictions and difficulties in the role shifts mandated by the illness. Implications for intervention based on these findings are discussed. Agencies should provide home services that decrease isolation and increase the sense of support of these families. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Client Characteristics; Demographic Characteristics; Family; Neoplasms

TI- Fieldwork in clinical and home settings.

AU- Speedling, Edward J.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology

PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 9
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n03_06
LA- English
KP- fieldwork research with families trying to cope with social & psychological dislocations of serious illness
SU- Coping Behavior; Data Collection; Disorders; Family; Methodology
AB- Discusses fieldwork done with families trying to cope with the social and psychological dislocations caused by serious illness. It is suggested that observing families as they live through this process can provide vital information about what they need at different stages of the process and how the current system for delivering care affects the quality of coping. The fieldwork approach is to begin gathering data soon after the crisis-initiating event (e.g., a diagnosis or an exacerbation of symptoms) and to continue until some event, either in the course of the illness itself or in the family process, signals that a resolution has occurred. Each member of the family is included in the study, as are the primary providers of care. Data are collected both during hospitalization (preferably in the hospital) and at home after discharge. Methods for gaining access, managing the necessary interactions, and handling the postdischarge phase are described. It is concluded that the best data in a family field study are obtained when family members become active participants in the research process. Researchers and their Ss must work to develop mutual understanding and trust, and ways in which researchers can help foster this trust are described. (7 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Data Collection; Disorders; Family; Methodology
CL- Research Methods & Experimental Design (2260)
CL- Psychological & Physical Disorders (3200)
PO- Human (10)
PT- Journal
PT- Peer Reviewed Journal

TI- The antiemetic effect of clinical relaxation: Report of an exploratory pilot study.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Scott, Diane W.
AU- Donahue, Dorothy C.
AU- Mastrovito, Rene C.
AU- Hakes, Thomas B.
AF- Scott, Diane W., Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr, New York, NY
AF- Donahue, Dorothy C.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1

PG- 71-84

SP- 71
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print

DO- 10.1300/J077v01n01_07
LA- English
KP- clinical relaxation program
KP- emetic cancer chemotherapy
SU- Drug Therapy; Hospitalized Patients; Neoplasms; Relaxation Therapy; Side Effects (Drug)
AB- 10 42–67 yr old women receiving highly emetic cancer chemotherapy received an experimental clinical relaxation program designed to diminish nausea and vomiting. The experimental protocol consisted of pretreatment education-counseling and use of slow-stroke back massage, guided imagery, and progressive relaxation in concert with continuous attendance and coaching by the investigator during the chemotherapy experience. Results indicate that duration of emetic response, frequency of vomiting, intensity of episodic effort, and volume of emesis were reduced substantially when compared to the known clinical course for patients receiving these agents. Further, a pattern of emetic response characterized by 3 phases was identified. This may provide criteria allowing for more precise patient assessment and improved anti-emetic regimen evaluation. In addition, data gathered provide a base for development of an emetic response rating scale. (37 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Drug Therapy; Hospitalized Patients; Neoplasms; Relaxation Therapy; Side Effects (Drug)

LA- English
KP- accountability in cancer patient visiting programs
KP- volunteers
SU- Hospital Programs; Institution Visitation; Neoplasms; Professional Standards; Volunteers
AB- Patient visitors bring a special perspective to the increasingly popular spectrum of self-help programs for cancer patients. There is little empirical research; however, of the efficacy of these interventions. The present author contends that research should examine the role of volunteers; locus of responsibility for program coordination; and guidelines for recruitment, screening, training, and continuing education. Findings can be used to develop standardized protocols to ensure that volunteers will be held accountable for their performance. Some benefits and costs of professionally directed patient visiting programs for both cancer patients and volunteer counselors are discussed. LA- English
KP- factors predictive of risk of institutionalization
KP- cancer patients aged 65 yrs & older
SU- Geriatric Patients; Institutionalization; Neoplasms
AB- Explored factors predictive of risk of institutionalization in 121 cancer patients (aged 65 yrs or older) referred for visiting nurse services at time of discharge from 3 acute care teaching hospitals. Data on physical condition, psychological, mental, and social variables were collected at discharge and again 4 mo later. Analysis focused on the relationship between medical and psychosocial factors and the risk of rehospitalization or institutionalization in an extended care facility. The speculation that physical disability, psychological and mental factors, community resources, and social support would all influence an elderly cancer patient's risk for institutionalization in a long or short-term care facility was supported. The key factor identified related to the rapidity of physical and functional deterioration. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- development of hospice care & implications of new hospice reimbursement legislation
SU- Health Insurance; Hospice; Laws
AB- Discusses (1) the current status of hospice care in the US as an approach consonant with the needs of the terminally ill and (2) implications of new legislation that make it a cost-effective alternative to standard inpatient care. The impact of hospice reimbursement legislation on discharge planning, home care, use of staff, and the integration of hospice and acute care is described for use by practitioners and health care administrators. It is concluded that regulations currently under development will further define the implementation of this legislation. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Family environment as a predictor of adjustment to metastatic breast carcinoma.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Spiegel, David
AU- Bloom, Joan R.
AU- Gottheil, Ellen
AF- Spiegel, David, Stanford U School of Medicine
AF- Bloom, Joan R.
AF- Gottheil, Ellen
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1

PM- Spr 1983
PG- 33-44
PC- 12
SP- 33
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 12
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n01_04
LA- English
KP- family environment
KP- psychological adjustment to metastatic carcinoma of breast
KP- human females with mean age of 54.5 yrs
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Family; Home Environment; Human Females
AB- Studied the effects of family environment on the psychological adjustment of 54 women (average age 54.5 yrs) with metastatic carcinoma of the breast over a 1-yr period. Family environment was assessed using the Family Environment Scale (FES) and a descriptive checklist, and adjustment was measured using the Profile of Mood States (POMS). Ss described their families as supportive and relatively free of conflict, and their spouses or other family members agreed moderately with them. S's mood disturbance during the year was made the dependent variable in a stepwise multiple regression analysis, with FES subscale scores at the beginning of the year and other control variables as predictors. Better adjustment was predicted by more expressiveness and less conflict and moral-religious orientation in the family. Findings indicate that the family is a crucial factor in patient adjustment and that "conspiracies of silence" in the family may be harmful. A clinical illustration is presented. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Family; Home Environment; Human Females
MN- Terminal Cancer

TI- Research issues in psychosocial oncology.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Siegel, Karolynn
AF- Siegel, Karolynn

VI- 1

LA- English
KP- research issues in psychosocial oncology
SU- Experimentation; Medical Psychology; Neoplasms; Oncology
AB- The development of an integrated body of knowledge and theory in any field of inquiry requires a progression of research studies. The sequence can be conceptualized as proceeding from descriptive studies (usually sparked by clinical insights at the earliest stage of the investigation) to correlational research and then to predictive studies. The present author illustrates this sequence of research stages using an example from psychosocial research in oncology concerning self-help groups of cancer patients. It is concluded that the psychosocial oncology clinician should carefully choose the research design that is appropriate given the state of existing knowledge on the issues being investigated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- ethical issues in diagnosis & treatment of & research on cancer
SU- Neoplasms; Professional Ethics
AB- Outlines ethical issues in cancer diagnosis, treatment, and research. TI- Current theory of psychogenic effects on cancer incidence and prognosis.

LA- English
KP- theory of psychogenic effects
KP- cancer incidence & prognosis
KP- literature review
SU- Epidemiology; Literature Review; Neoplasms; Prognosis; Psychodynamics
AB- A review of the literature indicates that evidence both supports and rejects the view that psychological factors and/or stress are related to increased risk of cancer incidence, relapse, and mortality in humans. Issues relating to genetics and to stress are addressed. Reasons are given why one should be cautious in generalizing to the human case from animal data on stress. Present evidence, including demographic data, suggests that if psychological factors and stress do have an effect on incidence of cancer in the human, it is small. The relationship of psychological factors and stress to cancer prognosis is felt to be more likely. Theoretical speculations about recent relapse and survival findings and associated hypotheses are provided. (85 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Epidemiology; Literature Review; Neoplasms; Prognosis; Psychodynamics
MN- Etiology; Theories

LA- English
KP- school attendance
KP- 2–18 yr old cancer patients
SU- Neoplasms; School Attendance; Students
AB- In a study on absenteeism among pediatric patients, school attendance records were collected on 239 2–18 yr olds (age at diagnosis) treated for cancer at the University of Kansas Medical Center and Denver Children's Hospital. Whenever possible, records were obtained for 5 consecutive years: from 1 yr before diagnosis until 3 yrs afterwards. Although patients from both centers had a high rate of absenteeism throughout the 5-yr period, they missed the most days during the year of diagnosis (mean 43 days). However, even 3 yrs after diagnosis, Ss missed significantly more school than did other children in the 2 states. (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Improving physician–patient communications in cancer treatment.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Morrow, Gary R.
AU- Hoagland, Alice C.
AU- Carpenter, Paul J.
AF- Morrow, Gary R., U Rochester Medical Ctr
AF- Hoagland, Alice C.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1983
YR- 1983
PM- Sum 1983
PG- 93-101
PC- 9
SP- 93
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 9
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n02_07
LA- English
KP- improvement of communications
KP- comprehension & recall of written & spoken medical information during cancer treatment
KP- physicians & patients
SU- Neoplasms; Physicians; Therapeutic Processes; Verbal Communication
AB- Among the problems that are increasingly recognized as impediments to clear and effective communications about oncology treatment are the lack of readability of informed consent documents and difficulties in communicating complicated medical instructions orally. Among the techniques for increasing the readability of written communications such as consent forms are the use of short words, simple declarative sentences, and analyses of readability using standard assessment approaches. Strategies for improving patient recall of orally presented information include using specific, definite advice rather than abstract, obscure suggestions and dividing information into 5 distinct components. It is concluded that steps can be taken to increase patients' understanding and comprehension of both written and spoken medical information during oncologic treatment and that findings from psychosocial studies can point out specific guidelines for more effective physician–patient communication. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Some social-demographic characteristics of patients self-referred for a clinical trial of laetrile.

LA- English
KP- social-demographic characteristics
KP- terminally ill cancer patients self referred for clinical trial of laetrile
KP- implications for clinicians
SU- Antineoplastic Drugs; Client Characteristics; Drug Therapy; Experimental Subjects; Terminal Cancer
AB- At Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, data were collected on 15 patients who were self-referred for a clinical trial of laetrile. As a group, they appeared to be typical middle-class people: They lived in urban areas, were above average in education, had stable job histories, and had well-developed social-support networks. Some data suggest, however, that this group of patients differed from typical cancer patients in several ways. A substantial proportion did not comply with the recommended treatment; expressed ambivalent, noncommittal, or negative feelings about conventional medical care; and had a history of emotional difficulties. Implications for clinicians are noted. (12 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- application of principles of behavioral medicine
KP- comprehensive cancer treatment
KP- adult & pediatric patients
SU- Behavior Therapy; Neoplasms; Behavioral Medicine
AB- The application of principles of behavioral psychology to treat aversion reactions to chemotherapy, fear of medical procedures, and psychosomatic symptoms in adult and pediatric cancer patients represents a broadening of psychosocial oncology's domain. The authors discuss these applications, focusing on theoretical premises of behavioral medicine and on specific clinical examples. Attention is also given to the integration of behavioral medicine within comprehensive cancer treatment. It is argued that this new area of psychosocial oncology provides an effective means of treating previously unaddressed problems and is compatible with other approaches. TI- Adult cancer patient education: An overview.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Blumberg, Barbara D.
AU- Kerns, Paul R.
AU- Lewis, M. Jane
AF- Blumberg, Barbara D., US Dept of Health & Human Services, National Cancer Inst Office of Cancer Communications Coping with Cancer Program, Bethesda, MD

TI- Anticipatory grief reconsidered.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Siegel, Karolynn
AU- Weinstein, Lois
AF- Siegel, Karolynn, Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Ctr, Dept of Social Work, New York, NY
AF- Weinstein, Lois
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 1
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1983
YR- 1983
PM- Sum 1983
PG- 61-73
PC- 13
SP- 61
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 13
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v01n02_04
LA- English
KP- anticipatory grief
KP- literature review
SU- Grief; Literature Review
AB- Anticipatory grief is a process in which an individual confronted with impending loss initiates the grieving process in anticipation of that event. It is assumed to be a positively adaptive response to expected loss because it provides a person with an opportunity to rehearse the bereaved role and begin working through the profound changes that typically accompany loss, thereby mitigating the trauma associated with actual bereavement. The authors critically review the empirical literature on anticipatory grief and highlight the inconsistent findings about whether the phenomenon exists and whether its effects are beneficial. (37 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Grief; Literature Review
CL- Personality Traits & Processes (3120)
PO- Human (10)
MD- Literature Review
PT- Journal

KP- treatment changes & psychosocial rehabilitation
KP- cancer survivors
SU- Neoplasms; Psychosocial Rehabilitation; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- Discusses changes in cancer (CC) treatment that have a significant impact on the rehabilitation (REH) of CC patients and the psychosocial challenges engendered by such changes. LA- English
KP- needs based support program
KP- 40–60 yr old cancer survivors
SU- Needs; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders); Social Support
AB- Conducted a needs assessment survey among 200 former patients who had been treated for diverse types of cancer to develop a support program for cancer survivors. 45% of Ss were aged 40–60 yrs. Ss reported the greatest level of concern about their (1) general physical health and recurrence of the disease, (2) ability to plan for the future, (3) finances, and (4) general frame of mind. Resources that Ss reported using included family, friends, and hospital professional staff at all levels. 32% of Ss had received no help or information from any source. Results indicate that former cancer patients desire and need additional services and their projected use of such services is high. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- child's cognitions about disease & treatment side effects
KP- development of psychologically oriented interventions
KP- 5–12 yr olds with leukemia
SU- Child Attitudes; Leukemias; Mental Health Services; Side Effects (Treatment)
AB- Suggests that the treatment protocol for childhood leukemia should include psychologically oriented interventions to counteract the aversive and distressing sequelae of treatment. Information is presented that was obtained from 32 leukemic children (aged 5–12 yrs) concerning their cognitions about the disease and the impact of the side effects of the disease and its treatments. Issues addressed include procedures (e.g., hypnosis) for attenuating the effects of treatment-related procedures, family-related concerns, and school reentry problems of leukemic children. TI- Some social and emotional consequences of breast cancer and mastectomy: A content analysis of 87 interviews.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published

LA- English
KP- social & emotional concerns
KP- female 29–69 yr olds with breast cancer who had mastectomy 6–26 mo earlier
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Mastectomy; Social Adjustment
AB- Content analyses of interviews with 87 women (aged 29–69 yrs) who had undergone a modified radical mastectomy within the previous 6–26 mo suggested that the most common concerns among these Ss were (1) an inability to engage in vigorous physical activity, (2) the possibility that the cancer would return, and (3) resentment or worry that they had not received the best possible medical care. Problems resulting from the supposed stigmatizing effects of cancer were reported by fewer than 10% of Ss. Many Ss reported closer family ties and a more positive outlook on life. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Emotional Adjustment; Mastectomy; Social Adjustment
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)

LA- English
KP- hope
KP- health care provision & survivorship
KP- cancer patients & their families
SU- Expectations; Health Care Delivery; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- Explores the concept of hope as a key element in providing planned, deliberate health care to patients with cancer and their families. Hope should be recognized as crucial to survivorship, and procedures for instilling a sense of hope should be included in the interdisciplinary plan of care. The nursing process (assessment, diagnosis, planning, implementation, evaluation) is used as a logical, data-based, problem-solving approach to the provision of high quality health care for the patient–family system. PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cassileth, Barrie R.

PG- 47-57

LA- English
KP- satisfaction & psychosocial & medical status & patient initiated physician changes
KP- adults in cancer treatment
SU- Adjustment; Client Attitudes; Medical Treatment (General); Neoplasms; Satisfaction
AB- Assessed the relationships among patient satisfaction (SAT), psychosocial status, medical status, and patient-initiated changes in physicians in 128 adult patients who had been recently diagnosed with cancer. Ss were administered the Patient Satisfaction Questionnaire, the Profile of Mood States, and the Brief Symptom Inventory. SAT was independent of demographic, clinical, and other psychosocial variables. Although Ss' emotional status changed markedly over time, their SAT with their medical care and treatment remained constant and at high levels. The construct SAT may provide a meaningful measure of patients' adaptation or well-being and may predict undesirable behaviors in cancer patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- iatrogenic infertility
KP- female 25–39 yr olds with cancer
SU- Infertility; Neoplasms; Side Effects (Treatment)
AB- Discusses the diagnosis of cancer and the possibility of iatrogenic infertility secondary to cancer treatment as equal life crises for oncology patients in their reproductive years. Case examples of 3 female cancer patients (aged 25–39 yrs) illustrate the multiple human costs of neglecting iatrogenic infertility as a clinical problem and examine the painful clinical, ethical, and existential dilemmas caregivers confront in the face of such human longing for life. An expanded role for the oncology social worker is suggested. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- methodology for research on quality of life
KP- patients with breast or colon or lung cancer
SU- Experimentation; Methodology; Neoplasms; Quality of Life

LA- English
KP- normal childhood development & related psychosocial problems
KP- children with cancer
SU- Childhood Development; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Social Adjustment
AB- Discusses psychosocial problems encountered by children with cancer during the course of the illness. The challenges faced by the patient are considered from the perspective of normal childhood development, focusing on preschool, latency, and adolescence stages of development. General principles for use with these young patients include (1) meeting the child at his/her developmental level, (2) gaining the child's trust, and (3) recognizing that the child has coping skills. The ways in which the role of the health care worker extends beyond direct interaction with the child are examined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- guidelines for structuring social work interventions in assessment & enhancement of hope
KP- cancer patients
SU- Coping Behavior; Counseling; Emotional States; Neoplasms
AB- Outlines a framework developed from concepts of Viktor Frankl's (1962) logotherapy and from recent research in psychosocial oncology that focuses on hope in counseling cancer patients. Five guidelines for assessing and enhancing a patient's hope, based on this framework, are presented. Special attention is given to the tasks of identifying a patient's source of hope, distinguishing authentic hope from denial, and using hope as a means of changing maladaptive coping behaviors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- clinical utility of Quality of Life Index in cancer rehabilitation program
KP- 20–95 yr old patients
SU- Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Rating Scales; Rehabilitation
AB- Examined the usefulness of the Quality of Life Index (QLI) in a clinical setting. 283 patients (aged 20–95 yrs) referred to a cancer rehabilitation service during a 1-yr period were assessed, and the physicians who referred them were surveyed to determine their opinions about the usefulness of the QLI. Although significant variations were found in the QLI scores by type of cancer, all Ss scored highest in the support category. The QLI is useful in identifying patterns and areas of need, rather than in making decisions about the care of individual patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- circumstances surrounding depression & grief reactions to death of spouse
KP- 28–81 yr old spouses of deceased cancer patients
SU- Death and Dying; Depression (Emotion); Grief; Neoplasms; Spouses
AB- Interviewed 112 spouses (aged 28–81 yrs) of deceased cancer patients about the circumstances of their spouses death, self-reported depression, and severity of their grief. Ss who reported a high degree of emotional distress following the death tended to be younger, lived alone, reported having been upset just before the death, had avoided thinking about the possibility of their spouse's death, and reported that the patient had died at home. TI- A comparison of perceptions of breast cancer patients with those of other female patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Hailey, B. Jo
AF- Hailey, B. Jo, U Southern Mississippi, Hattiesburg, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 7
IP- 3
SD- 1989

PG- 91-101

SP- 91

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 11
SN- 0734-7332, Print

DO- 10.1300/J077v07n03_06
LA- English
KP- attitudes toward & perceptions of females with breast vs lung cancer vs heart attack
KP- college students
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward)
AB- 79 female and 20 male undergraduates read a description of a seriously ill woman who was the victim of either breast cancer, lung cancer, or a heart attack, and imagined that the patient was a family friend. Ss' responses to a questionnaire regarding their perceptions of and reactions to the patients revealed more negative perceptions of women with breast or lung cancer compared with heart attack victims. Ss perceived both cancer patients as more depressed and likely to need counseling than the heart attack victim. The lung cancer patient was viewed as having the poorest chance of survival, while the breast cancer patient was judged least at fault for her illness than were the other 2 patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward)

TI- Adolescents' perceptions of social support after the death of a parent.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Gray, Ross E.
AF- Gray, Ross E., Sunnybrook Medical Ctr, Dept of Psychology, Toronto, ON, Canada
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 7
IP- 3
SD- 1989
YR- 1989
PM- 1989
PG- 127-144
PC- 18
SP- 127
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 18
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v07n03_09
LA- English
KP- perceptions of social support following death of parent
KP- adolescents
SU- Adolescent Attitudes; Death and Dying; Parents; Social Support
AB- 34 females and 16 males who had lost a parent through death during adolescence (mean age 14.9 yrs at time of parental death) were interviewed. All deaths had occurred within 5 yrs and not less than 6 mo before the study was initiated. Half the Ss were members of a peer-support group. All Ss were administered a battery of psychological tests, and answered questions concerning help they received in dealing with their loss. Ss descriptions of helpfulness was scored using a modified version of Gottlieb's (see record [rid]1979-23439-001[/rid]) classification system for informal helping behavior. When asked to describe the types of help received during their bereavement and to rate the usefulness of such help, most Ss reported that a peer (40%) or surviving parent (28%) had been most helpful, primarily through emotionally supportive behavior. The source of support had often influenced the style of support and Ss' perceptions of its value. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adolescent Attitudes; Death and Dying; Parents; Social Support
MN- Family Relations; Grief; Peer Relations
CL- Physical & Somatoform & Psychogenic Disorders (3290)
PO- Human (10)
AG- Adolescence (13-17 yrs) (200)
MD- Empirical Study
PT- Journal
PT- Peer Reviewed Journal
AT- Journal Article

TI- The experience of loneliness among young adult cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Friedman, Gaby
AU- Florian, Victor
AU- Zernitsky-Shurka, Esther
AF- Friedman, Gaby, Northern Israel Oncology Ctr, Rambam Medical Ctr, Haifa, Israel
AF- Florian, Victor
AF- Zernitsky-Shurka, Esther
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 7
IP- 3
SD- 1989
YR- 1989
PM- 1989
PG- 1-15
PC- 15
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v07n03_01
LA- English
KP- levels of loneliness in various life situations
KP- 19–45 yr old cancer patients
KP- implications for psychosocial professionals
SU- Loneliness; Neoplasms
AB- Examined feelings of loneliness in various life situations among young adult cancer patients. Ss (aged 19–45 yrs) were divided into the following groups: 27 patients diagnosed within the previous 3 mo, 33 patients diagnosed from 1–3 yrs prior to the study who were in remission and not receiving treatment, and 38 controls. Ss completed a brief demographic questionnaire and the revised UCLA Loneliness Scale and responded to an open-ended question about loneliness. Unmarried Ss expressed higher levels of loneliness than did all other Ss. Approximately half the patients felt lonely in illness-related situations, whereas no healthy S expressed that reaction. Implications of the study for psychosocial professionals who work with cancer patients are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Loneliness; Neoplasms
MN- Experiences (Events); Psychosocial Factors
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
AG- Adulthood (18 yrs & older) (300)

TI- Social support, sense of control, and coping among patients with breast, lung, or colorectal cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ell, Kathleen O.
AU- Mantell, Joanne E.
AU- Hamovitch, Maurice B.
AU- Nishimoto, Robert H.
AF- Ell, Kathleen O., U Southern California, School of Social Work, Los Angeles, US
AF- Mantell, Joanne E.
AF- Hamovitch, Maurice B.
AF- Nishimoto, Robert H.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 7
IP- 3
SD- 1989
YR- 1989
PM- 1989
PG- 63-89
PC- 27
SP- 63
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 27
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v07n03_05
LA- English
KP- social support & sense of control & coping behavior & adaptation to cancer
KP- 35–85 yr olds with breast or lung or colorectal cancer
SU- Adjustment; Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Social Support
AB- Investigated social support (SP), sense of control (SC), and coping behavior (CB) in relation to patients' adaptation to cancer, as well as relations between SP, and several variables: SC, CB, characteristics of the illness, and severity of noncancer-related stressors. Among 369 Ss (aged 35–85 yrs) 168, 51, and 75 were breast, lung, and colorectal cancer patients, respectively. Ss were administered the following measures within 3–6 mo after the diagnosis of cancer: a modified version of the Interview Schedule for Social Interaction; a 5-item scale to assess Ss' sense of mastery; items that reflect reliance on religion; cognitive restructuring items; and a mental health inventory. Results indicated significant independent associations between SP and SC and adaptation that underscore the need to examine SP and SC within an overall structure of coping with serious illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Adjustment; Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Social Support
CL- Cancer (3293)

TI- The impact of testicular cancer on the work lives of survivors.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Edbril, Susan D.
AU- Rieker, Patricia P.
AF- Edbril, Susan D., Boston Coll, MA, US

LA- English
KP- work satisfaction & emotional state & quality of work life & psychological well being
KP- 19–59 yr olds with testicular cancer
SU- Neoplasms; Occupational Adjustment; Quality of Work Life; Testes
AB- 74 patients with cancer of the testis (aged 19–59 yrs) who had completed treatment 2–20 yrs before the study completed a work-related questionnaire, a scale to measure work satisfaction, the profile of mood states, and a scale to measure whether patients believed that men should conceal emotions. The cancer experience did not seriously disrupt their ability to work, job mobility, or career plans. Work may serve an important psychological function after treatment and for a subgroup of survivors, it may provide a means of managing depression and anxiety. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Neoplasms; Occupational Adjustment; Quality of Work Life; Testes

TI- Predicting conflict with staff among families of cancer patients during prolonged hospitalizations.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Zabora, James R.
AU- Fetting, John H.
AU- Shanley, Virginia B.
AU- Seddon, Carole F.
AU- Enterline, John P.
AF- Zabora, James R., Johns Hopkins Oncology Ctr, Patient & Family Services, Baltimore, MD, US
AF- Fetting, John H.
AF- Shanley, Virginia B.
AF- Seddon, Carole F.
AF- Enterline, John P.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 7
IP- 3
SD- 1989
YR- 1989
PM- 1989
PG- 103-111
PC- 9
SP- 103
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 9
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v07n03_07
LA- English
KP- efficacy of Family Adaptability Cohesion Evaluation Scale
KP- prediction of conflict with hospital staff
KP- families of cancer patients
SU- Conflict; Family Members; Hospitalized Patients; Medical Personnel; Statistical Validity
AB- Investigated the ability of the Family Adaptability-Cohesion Evaluation Scale (FACES II; D. H. Olson et al, see record [rid]1980-27831-001[/rid]) to predict in 80 families of cancer patients (aged 14–63 yrs), those families likely to engage in conflict with medical staff (sensitivity) and those families not likely to engage in conflict with staff (specificity). 40 families were involved in a retrospective analysis, and 40 families were involved in a prospective analysis. Following a patient's discharge or death, staff judged whether a family had demonstrated any of 6 behaviors likely to lead to conflict with staff during the patient's hospitalization. FACES II demonstrated sensitivity superior to its specificity. Although FACES II predicted all families that actually came into conflict with staff, it also predicted that more than twice as many families would generate conflict. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Conflict; Family Members; Hospitalized Patients; Medical Personnel; Statistical Validity
MN- Measurement; Neoplasms
CL- Clinical Psychological Testing (2224)
CL- Health & Mental Health Services (3370)

KP- symposium on quality of school experience
KP- confidence & knowledge of illness & treatment
KP- teachers of children with cancer
SU- Inservice Teacher Education; Knowledge Level; Neoplasms; School Environment; Teachers
AB- Reviews a 1-day symposium conducted for educators of children who have cancer and designed to inform them of the effects of the disease on school performance and help them manage the children's educational experience. Questionnaire data show that the program significantly improved the educators' confidence in dealing with pediatric cancer patients as well as their knowledge about the disease and its treatment. The symposium's content is described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- An evaluation of the psychosocial problems of the homebound cancer patient: Relationship of patient adjustment to family problems.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Wellisch, David K.
AU- Wolcott, Deane L.
AU- Pasnau, Robert O.
AU- Fawzy, Fawzy I.

LA- English
KP- demographic & medical characteristics & family problems & caretaker availability
KP- mood disturbance & role conflicts & self care problems
KP- moderately to gravely ill homebound cancer patients
SU- Emotional States; Homebound; Neoplasms; Role Conflicts; Self Care Skills
AB- Examined the relationship between cancer patients' mood disturbance, role conflicts, and self-care problems and 4 family psychosocial variables in a large sample of homebound patients ranging from moderately to gravely ill. A hierarchical multiple regression model was developed to assess the impact of Ss' demographic and medical characteristics, number of family caretakers available, and family problems related to Ss' adjustment. Family problems accounted for significantly more variance and explained the 3 outcome variables more than the other predictor variables. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- role perceptions & responsibility expectations & training requirements & work satisfaction
KP- hospice staff vs volunteers
KP- implications for management techniques
SU- Employee Interaction; Hospice; Medical Personnel; Role Perception; Volunteers
AB- Administered a questionnaire assessing volunteers' training, assessment, stress, and working relationships with hospice staff to 17 hospice volunteers (aged 18–64 yrs) and 25 staff (mean age 36 yrs). Research found significant differences between staff and volunteers across a variety of factors, including role perceptions, responsibility expectations, training requirements, and work satisfaction. Suggestions are outlined for improving communication and interaction between staff and volunteers and for reducing stress and eventual burnout in both groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Accuracy of estimates of delay in seeking breast cancer diagnosis and treatment.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Owens, R. Glynn
AU- Heron, Kate
AF- Owens, R. Glynn, U Liverpool, New Medical School, England
AF- Heron, Kate
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology

LA- English
KP- questionnaire vs guided recall
KP- assessment of breast self examination & time elapsed between symptom detection & diagnosis/treatment
KP- 18–75 yr old breast cancer patients
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Health Care Utilization; Self Examination (Medical); Symptoms
AB- Administered a questionnaire assessing breast self-examination and the amount of time that elapsed between symptom detection and diagnosis/treatment of 46 breast cancer patients (aged 18–75 yrs). Ss' delay estimates were compared with a 2nd estimate obtained during a "guided recall" interview. Results reveal little difference in the mean estimates of delay obtained from the 2 methods and support the validity of broad delay categories. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Mastectomy versus conservative surgery: Psychosocial effects of the patient's choice of treatment.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Leinster, Samuel J.
AU- Ashcroft, Jennifer J.
AU- Slade, Peter D.
AU- Dewey, Michael E.
AF- Leinster, Samuel J., U Liverpool, England
AF- Ashcroft, Jennifer J.
AF- Slade, Peter D.
AF- Dewey, Michael E.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 7
IP- 1-2
SD- 1989
YR- 1989
PM- 1989
PG- 179-192
PC- 14
SP- 179
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v07n01_12
LA- English
KP- choice of mastectomy vs lumpectomy plus radiotherapy vs random entry in either treatment
KP- psychosocial adaptation
KP- 20–70 yr old females with early breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Choice Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Mastectomy; Surgery
AB- 59 women (aged 20–70 yrs) with early breast cancer were offered the choice of a mastectomy, lumpectomy plus radiotherapy, or entry in a trial in which the allocation to either type of treatment was randomized. Other patients, for whom it was decided that a mastectomy was the only viable treatment on medical grounds, were offered breast reconstruction. Psychosocial adaptation was measured using tests of anxiety, depression, marital adjustment, body satisfaction, self-esteem, sociability, and life change. It was found that Ss who rated high in the degree of concern about appearance (i.e., the younger patients) tended to choose conservative surgery or reconstruction when a mastectomy was necessary. Generally, the adjustment to treatment was good in all the groups. Tailoring the treatment to Ss' preferences resulted in low psychological morbidity. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Choice Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Mastectomy; Surgery
MN- Radiation Therapy
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)
PO- Human (10)
AG- Adulthood (18 yrs & older) (300)

TI- The psychosocial status of cancer patients after cessation of treatment.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Carpenter, Paul J.
AU- Morrow, Gary R.
AU- Schmale, Arthur H.
AF- Carpenter, Paul J., U Rochester Medical Ctr, Psychosocial Oncology Unit, NY, US
AF- Morrow, Gary R.
AF- Schmale, Arthur H.

VI- 7
IP- 1-2
SD- 1989
YR- 1989
PM- 1989
PG- 95-103
PC- 9
SP- 95

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 9
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- psychosocial status
KP- 18–45 yr olds with early stage Hodgkin's disease within vs with more than 2 yrs of radiation treatment
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy; Treatment Termination
AB- Compared the psychosocial status of 15 patients (aged 18–45 yrs) with early-stage Hodgkin's disease who had completed radiation therapy within the previous 2 yrs with the status of 28 age-matched patients with early-stage disease who had completed the same treatment more than 2 years earlier. Measures used include the Beck Depression Inventory, the State-Trait Anxiety Scale, Psychosocial Adjustment to Illness Scale, and the SCL-90. The 2 groups differed on attitudes toward their interpersonal relationships with their physicians. The impact of the cancer experience may have had a subtle effect on patient's psychosocial well-being (based on uncertainty about long-term survival) lasting long after treatment has ended. Conceptualization of the long-term survivor is discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy; Treatment Termination
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)

TI- Effect of employment on coping with chronic illness among patients with hairy cell leukemia.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Magid, Dawn M.
AU- Golomb, Harvey
AF- Magid, Dawn M., U Chicago Medical Ctr, Joint Section of Hematology/Oncology, IL, US
AF- Golomb, Harvey
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 7
IP- 1-2
SD- 1989
YR- 1989
PM- 1989
PG- 1-17
PC- 17
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v07n01_01
LA- English
KP- employment
KP- mood states & coping strategies
KP- adult males with hairy cell leukemia
SU- Chronicity (Disorders); Coping Behavior; Emotional States; Employment Status; Leukemias
AB- Examined the role of employment in coping with a chronic illness by administering a questionnaire assessing mood states and coping strategies to 104 men diagnosed with hairy cell leukemia. Comparisons were drawn between Ss who were employed, had left the workplace voluntarily, and had left the workplace involuntarily. Tensions and depression proved to be significantly higher in the involuntarily unemployed work group than in the other 2 groups, and these Ss tended to use emotionally focused coping strategies more often than the others. Findings suggest that the denial of the opportunity to work after a diagnosis of cancer may affect patients' overall adjustment to their illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Chronicity (Disorders); Coping Behavior; Emotional States; Employment Status; Leukemias

TI- Attributions of control, experienced meaning, and psychosocial well-being in patients with advanced cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Lewis, Frances M.
AF- Lewis, Frances M., U Washington School of Nursing, Seattle, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 7
IP- 1-2
SD- 1989
YR- 1989
PM- 1989
PG- 105-119
PC- 15
SP- 105
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v07n01_08
LA- English
KP- attributed control over health & experienced meaning of personal status
KP- anxiety & self esteem
KP- 21–79 yr old advanced cancer patients
SU- Anxiety; Health Attitudes; Meaningfulness; Neoplasms; Self Esteem
AB- Examined the effects of attributed control over personal health and experienced meaning of personal status on anxiety and self-esteem in 57 advanced cancer patients (aged 21–79 yrs). The extent to which Ss attributed meaning to their situation was a significant predictor of both higher self-esteem and lower anxiety. However, neither externalized control nor longer experience with cancer predicted levels of either anxiety or self-esteem. Results suggest that a sense of meaning in late-stage disease is an important focus for therapeutic exchange. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Anxiety; Health Attitudes; Meaningfulness; Neoplasms; Self Esteem
CL- Cancer (3293)

TI- A simple, rapid method for assessing psychological distress in cancer patients: Evidence of validity for linear analog scales.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sutherland, Heather J.
AU- Lockwood, Gina A.
AU- Cunningham, Alastair J.
AF- Sutherland, Heather J., Ontario Cancer Inst, Div of Biological Research, Toronto, Canada
AF- Lockwood, Gina A.

KP- validity of self report questionnaire
KP- assessment of dysphoric mood
KP- cancer patients
SU- Major Depression; Neoplasms; Questionnaires; Self Report; Test Validity
AB- Describes the validation of a simple and rapid (1-min) self-report questionnaire designed to assess dysphoric mood and consisting of 6 linear analog self-assessment (LASA) scales derived from the Profile of Mood States (POMS). Tests for associations between the POMS-LASA scales and 2 established questionnaires, the SCL-90 (Revised) and the POMS, using a validation of samples of 42 cancer patients. Results showed high correlations between the 3 scales. The use of the questionnaire in clinical settings and research protocols is discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- Profile of Mood States test score norms
KP- assessment of moods after diagnosis & before treatment
KP- adult cancer patients
SU- Emotional States; Neoplasms; Profiles (Measurement); Test Norms
AB- Presents data from the Profile of Mood States (POMS) administered to 923 recently diagnosed, previously untreated cancer patients (mean age 59.6 yrs). Ss' responses to the POMS were significantly different from those of 2 normative samples, 856 undergraduates and 1,000 psychiatric patients. The students showed a slightly higher level of distress than the cancer patients, while the cancer patients reported more vigor and less tension, anger, depression, and confusion than the psychiatric patients. TI- Coping with the psychosocial stresses of oncology care.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sparks, T. Flint
AF- Sparks, T. Flint, Westlake Psychotherapy Ctr, Austin, TX, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6
IP- 1-2
SD- 1988
YR- 1988
PM- 1988
PG- 165-179
PC- 15
SP- 165
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
LA- English
KP- conceptual model using crisis theory & adaptive tasks in interpersonal context
KP- coping with psychosocial stresses of oncology care
KP- health care professionals
KP- implications for social support
SU- Coping Behavior; Medical Personnel; Neoplasms; Occupational Stress; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Presents a conceptual model that maps out the process of coping with the psychosocial stresses of oncology care. The model is taken from crisis theory and is initially presented in a form that describes patients coping with the crises of physical illness. A translation of the model describes the processes involved in coping with the psychosocial stresses of treating physical illness. Emphasis is placed on the adaptive tasks that confront oncology professionals and the coping skills they must use to meet the demands of these adaptive tasks. The tasks are framed in an interpersonal context with the relationships among the self, patient, family members, and other staff as the principal elements. Social support and the development of support groups are defined as the most powerful tools for coping with the ongoing psychosocial stresses of oncology care. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Medical Personnel; Neoplasms; Occupational Stress; Psychosocial Factors
MN- Models; Social Adjustment; Social Support; Oncology
CL- Professional Psychological & Health Personnel Issues (3400)
PO- Human (10)

LA- English
KP- guidelines for psychosocial assessment & intervention using hope balanced with reality
KP- physicians treating cancer patients & their families
SU- Diagnosis; Neoplasms; Physicians; Psychosocial Factors; Treatment
AB- Provides guidelines that physicians can use for the psychosocial assessment of and intervention with the cancer patient. The overall goal is to provide the patient with hope balanced with reality at all stages of the disease. Methods are given for assessment and intervention at 4 specific points in the disease: (1) the initial meeting between patient and physician, (2) the completion of treatment, (3) the time when treatment fails, and (4) the terminal stage. The benefits of psychosocial assessment and intervention for the patient, family, and health care team are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- problems & social aspects of coping with chemotherapy side effects
KP- 38–79 yr old outpatients with cancer & their relatives & nurses
SU- Coping Behavior; Drug Therapy; Neoplasms; Outpatient Treatment; Side Effects (Drug)
AB- Reports social validity data from the problem-specification stage of the behavior analytic model for assessing how cancer patients cope with outpatient chemotherapy. 47 problem situations were generated, and social validity data were collected from 29 patients (aged 38–79 yrs) receiving chemotherapy, 20 relatives familiar with patients' treatment, and 23 nurses regularly involved with chemotherapy. The top 10 socially valid problem situations are presented, (e.g., concerns about postteatment nausea and vomiting), along with data for 6 categories of problem situations, grouped according to their reported frequency and severity. TI- The effects of breast cancer on the family: A review of the literature.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Pederson, Lucille M.
AU- Valanis, Barbara G.
AF- Pederson, Lucille M., U Cincinnati, OH, US
AF- Valanis, Barbara G.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6
IP- 1-2
SD- 1988
YR- 1988
PM- 1988
PG- 95-118
PC- 24
SP- 95
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 24
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
LA- English
KP- family coping behaviors & functioning & approaches to assessment & intervention
KP- families with member who has breast cancer
KP- literature review
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Coping Behavior; Family Members; Family Relations; Literature Review
AB- Reviewed the literature to identify coping issues and factors associated with family functioning when a family member has cancer and to relate these to specific issues that arise when breast cancer occurs. The approaches to assessment and intervention also were examined. Most studies placed primary emphasis on the patient's problems rather than on the family's, and assessment and intervention models were generally aimed toward chronic illness and all cancers. There is a need to understand how the specific factors affect families and to identify high-risk families who cannot adjust successfully. It is concluded that further research should compare families who enhance their lives by coping well with those who cope dysfunctionally. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Social support and cancer: Sustained emotional support and successful adaptation.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Irwin, Patrick H.
AU- Kramer, Simon
AF- Irwin, Patrick H.
AF- Kramer, Simon
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6
IP- 1-2
SD- 1988
YR- 1988
PM- 1988
PG- 53-73
PC- 21
SP- 53
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 21
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
LA- English
KP- social support during life threatening health crisis
KP- support satisfaction & adjustment & distress & depression
KP- 18–83 yr old cancer patients in radiation therapy
KP- 2 mo followup
SU- Distress; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Social Support; Stress
AB- Studied the relationship between level of social support (SS) during a life-threatening health crisis and subsequent amelioration of psychological distress (i.e., the stress buffering hypothesis). 181 patients (aged 18–83 yrs) who had recently been diagnosed with cancer and were about to undergo radiation therapy were followed through 2 mo posttreatment. Perceived satisfaction with SS was assessed at the onset of treatment and at its completion 6 wks later. Ss' responses were used to develop an index of sustained SS. Distress associated with depressive symptoms was assessed at the completion of treatment and 2 mo later using the SCL-90 (Revised). Depression at the 2-mo follow-up was not significantly related to level of SS after controlling for depression when treatment was completed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Distress; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Social Support; Stress
MN- Depression (Emotion); Followup Studies; Radiation Therapy; Satisfaction

TI- Psychiatric aspects of psychosocial distress in cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Goldberg, Richard J.
AF- Goldberg, Richard J., Rhode Island Hosp, Providence, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 6
IP- 1-2
SD- 1988
YR- 1988
PM- 1988
PG- 139-163
PC- 25
SP- 139
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 25
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
LA- English
KP- diagnosis & treatment of delirium & depression
KP- physicians treating cancer patients with apparent psychosocial side effects from treatment or disease
SU- Delirium; Major Depression; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Side Effects (Treatment)
AB- Reviews the identification and management of 2 common psychiatric disorders in cancer patients: delirium and depression. Physical consequences of cancer and its treatment can account for disorders of mood, thought, or behavior that appear indistinguishable from psychological, social, behavioral, or existentially mediated distress. Recognizing a medical basis for psychosocial distress is important because (1) the impairment often has a specific, treatable cause and (2) the failure to treat may lead to premature loss of function. Common physiologic disorders in patients that present as psychosocial distress are reviewed, and issues involved in the use of psychotropic drugs are summarized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- factor analysis of linear analog self assessment scales
KP- validity of factors representing physical & emotional & social health & disease related quality of life
KP- breast cancer patients
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Factor Analysis; Health; Quality of Life; Self Evaluation
AB- Information about health-related quality of life for 95 women with breast cancer, obtained using a series of linear analog self-assessment (LASA) scales, was condensed into 4 summary scores using factor analysis. Three of these factor scales, incorporating 16 LASA scales related to general health, were designated Physical, Emotional, and Social Health; the 4th factor scale, termed Disease-Related, incorporated 11 LASA scales related to breast cancer and its treatment. These factor scales were compared with an established instrument for assessing health status, the Duke-University of North Carolina Health Profile, and were found to perform satisfactorily. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- concept of stillpoint in counseling process
KP- cancer patients & their families
SU- Counseling; Neoplasms
AB- Discusses the concept of stillpoint and its relationship to counseling. It is suggested that through counseling, the therapist helps create the stillpoint experience—a sense of calm and strength that assists cancer patients and their families to function effectively simultaneously with threat. Described is a model of counseling for the cancer setting that emphasizes the importance of the therapeutic relationship. A case example is presented in which the concept of stillpoint was used in counseling a young married woman. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- cancer amputation during adolescence or early adulthood
KP- long term psychosocial outcome
KP- 17–38 yr old survivors
SU- Amputation; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Readjustment
AB- Assessed the educational, vocational, and psychosocial status of 20 long-term survivors (aged 17–38 yrs) who had undergone amputation for cancer during adolescence or early adulthood. When they were interviewed, all Ss had survived their diagnosis for at least 5 yrs, were disease free, and were not receiving cancer-related therapy. Results indicate that the majority of patients had adjusted well to their disabilities and led full and functional lives. 85% worked at least part-time, 85% were either married or dating a steady partner, and nearly 50% had at least some college education. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- psychological aspects of childhood cancer
KP- literature review
SU- Literature Review; Neoplasms; Psychodynamics
AB- Reviews recent empirical literature on childhood cancer, especially the data-based psychological studies published during the past 5 yrs. Studies are delineated into 4 primary areas: psychosocial functioning of the child and his or her family, adherence to therapeutic regimens, nausea and vomiting, and pain from diagnostic and treatment procedures. It is suggested that future research should involve large-scale prospective longitudinal studies, based on the collaboration of many cancer centers, that utilize multivariate statistical procedures. TI- Decisions about marriage and family among survivors of childhood cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Teeter, Marilyn A.
AU- Holmes, Grace E.
AU- Holmes, Frederick F.
AU- Baker, Ariel B.
AF- Teeter, Marilyn A., U Kansas Coll of Health Sciences & Hosp School of Medicine, Kansas City, US
AF- Holmes, Grace E.
AF- Holmes, Frederick F.
AF- Baker, Ariel B.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 4
SD- Win 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Win 1987
PG- 59-68
PC- 10
SP- 59
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 10
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n04_05
LA- English
KP- marriage & family planning decisions
KP- adult survivors of childhood cancer
SU- Early Experience; Family Planning Attitudes; Marriage Attitudes; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- Compared interview data from 263 adult survivors of childhood cancer and 369 adult sibling controls regarding their decisions to marry and have children. The survivors were more likely to report not marrying for health reasons. Although the long-term survivors did not have significantly more documented or suspected infertility problems, they were less likely than controls to have been pregnant or involved with a pregnancy and were more likely to have been advised by a physician to avoid a pregnancy. When the frequency of birth defects among 253 offspring of the survivors was compared with the frequency of defects among 595 offspring of controls, the outcome of pregnancy among survivors and controls proved to be equally favorable. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Early Experience; Family Planning Attitudes; Marriage Attitudes; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders)

TI- The concepts and assessment of depression in oncology.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Snaith, R. P.
AF- Snaith, R. P., St James's University Hosp, Dept of Psychiatry, Leeds, England
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 3
SD- Fal 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Fal 1987
PG- 133-139
PC- 7
SP- 133
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 7
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n03_07
LA- English
KP- concepts & assessment of depression
KP- cancer patients
SU- Major Depression; Neoplasms
AB- Discusses 2 types of disordered mood, both called depression, and emphasizes the need to distinguish between them to provide effective therapy. The 1st type is psychogenic and can be understood through knowledge of the person's personality and past and present experiences; this type can be treated with counseling and psychotherapeutic approaches. The 2nd kind is biogenic; this is an illness to be considered within the medical context and that usually responds to antidepressant drugs but is resistant to psychological treatment. It is suggested that distinguishing between the 2 types is particularly difficult in instances of chronic, painful illnesses. The use of depression rating scales and mood disorder scales is discussed as an aid in distinguishing between these 2 types of depression. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Major Depression; Neoplasms
MN- Terminally Ill Patients
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
PT- Journal
PT- Peer Reviewed Journal

TI- Differences in emotional well-being and communication styles between mothers and fathers of pediatric cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Shapiro, Johanna
AU- Shumaker, Sally
AF- Shapiro, Johanna, U California School of Medicine, Irvine, US
AF- Shumaker, Sally
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5

LA- English
KP- psychological well being & communication styles
KP- mothers vs fathers of pediatric cancer patients
SU- Communication; Family Relations; Mental Health; Neoplasms
AB- Investigated 26 pairs of mothers and fathers of pediatric cancer patients to explore the relationship between parental communication patterns and parental psychological well-being and possible differences between the communication styles of mothers and fathers. Results indicate that, for mothers, open and frequent communication had a positive effect on emotional well-being, and spousal communication was particularly important. In comparison with fathers, mothers had significantly more positive perceptions of the family's overall emotional climate, evaluated the patient as significantly better adjusted, and communicated significantly more often and openly with the patient. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Communication and cancer: Issues confronting patients, health professionals, and family members.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Northouse, Peter G.
AU- Northouse, Laurel L.
AF- Northouse, Peter G., Western Michigan U, Kalamazoo, US
AF- Northouse, Laurel L.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 3
SD- Fal 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Fal 1987
PG- 17-46
PC- 30
SP- 17
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 30
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n03_02
LA- English
KP- communication issues
KP- cancer patients & their family members & health professionals
KP- literature review
SU- Family Relations; Interpersonal Communication; Literature Review; Neoplasms
AB- Reviews the literature (over 200 clinical papers and research studies) published between 1966 and 1986 that focuses on communication dimensions of the cancer experience. The review analyzes communication issues from 3 perspectives: the patient, the health professional, and the family. The literature indicates that the major communication issues for patients are related to maintaining a sense of control, seeking information, disclosing feelings, and searching for meaning. For health professionals, the primary communication issues center on imparting information, communicating hope, and sharing control. Major issues facing family members pertain to the concealment of feelings, acquiring information, and coping with helplessness. A methodological critique of the literature is also provided. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Family Relations; Interpersonal Communication; Literature Review; Neoplasms
MN- Family Members; Medical Personnel; Terminally Ill Patients

LA- English
KP- psychosocial factors
KP- employment adjustment & employers' practices
KP- cancer survivors
KP- literature review
SU- Employment Status; Literature Review; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Reviews the literature relating to employment of cancer survivors. Research concerning the vocational adjustment of survivors of childhood-, adolescent-, and adult-onset cancer is discussed. Employers' practices toward employees who develop cancer and in hiring former cancer patients are addressed, and health care providers' practices regarding employment of survivors are noted. State and federal laws provide a potential source of help for the person who does develop problems. The authors postulate that improved survival rates and current publicity and openness about cancer are serving to ameliorate the cancer patient's employment problems. TI- Social support and marital adjustment after breast cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Lichtman, Rosemary R.
AU- Taylor, Shelley E.

LA- English
KP- perceptions of social support & marital adjustment following diagnosis
KP- breast cancer patients & their husbands or significant others
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Male Female Relations; Marital Relations; Social Support
AB- Interviewed 78 breast cancer patients and their significant others to assess perceptions of social support following a diagnosis of cancer. Results indicate that supportive close relationships during and after an episode of cancer were associated with positive patient adjustment. The evidence suggested that most cancer patients can expect that support to be forthcoming. Approximately three-quarters of the 78 patients in the present study reported that their relationships, including those with family and friends, continued to be warm and helpful after the cancer episode. The remaining one-fourth had at least 1 troubled relationship, and many more experienced isolated instances of rejection or withdrawal. Strained communication was a common problem in this group, particularly when the patient felt that her fears were discounted by those close to her. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Male Female Relations; Marital Relations; Social Support
MN- Husbands

TI- The psychosocial impact of cancer: Cancer patients and healthy controls.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Heinrich, Richard L.
AU- Schag, Cyndie C.
AF- Heinrich, Richard L., Veterans Administration Medical Ctr, Behavioral Rehabilitation Research Lab, Sepulveda, CA, US
AF- Schag, Cyndie C.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 3
SD- Fal 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Fal 1987
PG- 75-91
PC- 17
SP- 75
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n03_04
LA- English
KP- psychological & psychosocial distress
KP- cancer patients
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
AB- Investigated 25 adult cancer patients and 32 healthy control Ss to determine the impact of living with incurable cancer on psychological distress, sleep, physical abilities, quality of life, marital distress, patterns of daily living, and fund of illness-related information. It was hypothesized that cancer patients would have higher levels of psychological distress, more impaired physical abilities, poorer quality of life, and more marital distress than would the healthy controls because of the deleterious effects of cancer. It was also hypothesized that the cancer patients would be less physically active, spend more time alone in passive activities, and spend less time in work and recreational activities. Findings show that, although the results indicate considerable support for these hypotheses, the patients appeared to be less distressed and more active than anticipated. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors
MN- Terminally Ill Patients
