LA- English
KP- quality of life & psychosocial outcomes
KP- survivors of childhood cancer
KP- treatment implications
KP- literature review
SU- Early Experience; Literature Review; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- Discusses how advances in cancer treatment have led to dramatic improvements in survival from childhood cancer, creating numerous long-term physiological, cognitive, and psychosocial consequences of the disease and its treatment. The research literature related to late effects in pediatric cancer survivors and their families and to interventions to address their needs is discussed, with a primary emphasis on psychosocial outcomes. It is proposed that future research and clinical developments are dependent on one another and that approaches developed for survivors of childhood cancer can serve as models for all cancer survivors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Personality characteristics and psychosocial adjustment of long-term survivors of childhood cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Chang, Pi-nian
AU- Nesbit, Mark E.
AU- Youngren, Nancy
AU- Robison, Leslie L.

VI- 5

SD- Win 1987
YR- 1987

SP- 43
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- personality traits & psychosocial adjustment
KP- 11–25 yr old survivors of childhood cancer
SU- Early Experience; Neoplasms; Personality Correlates; Psychosocial Readjustment; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- Administered psychological tests and structured interviews to 42 survivors of childhood cancer to assess their psychosocial adjustment. The Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI) was administered to each survivor, and the Personality Inventory for Children was administered to the parents. The Q-sort technique was used to assess the degree of psychopathology of each MMPI profile. 33% of the survivors exhibited clinical evidence of at least a moderate degree of emotional difficulty. The structured interviews and MMPI test results revealed agitation, restlessness, social withdrawal, and passivity as frequent behavioral difficulties. Parents' reports of their children's personalities were highly correlated with the survivors' MMPI profiles. The development of age-appropriate independent tasks appeared to be most difficult for survivors. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Early Experience; Neoplasms; Personality Correlates; Psychosocial Readjustment; Recovery (Disorders)

LA- English
KP- age at diagnosis & psychological symptoms & good vs poor treatment adjustment
KP- identification of need for psychotherapy
KP- young adult survivors of Hodgkin's disease
SU- Client Characteristics; Early Experience; Neoplasms; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- Divided a sample of 42 young adults who survived Hodgkin's disease in childhood into those who had adjusted well to their illness and its treatment (n = 29) and those who had adjusted poorly (n = 13). Canonical discriminant function analysis of 12 variables derived from a priori hypotheses resulted in the entry of 3 significant discriminating variables: psychological symptomatology, age at diagnosis, and self-reported adjustment to illness. Data are discussed in relation to classifying survivors of pediatric cancer and targeting those in need of psychotherapeutic interventions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Psychosocial risks and invulnerability: A review of the theoretical and empirical bases of preventive family-focused services for survivors of childhood cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Barbarin, Oscar A.
AF- Barbarin, Oscar A., U Michigan, School of Social Work, Ann Arbor, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 4
SD- Win 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Win 1987
PG- 25-41
PC- 17
SP- 25
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n04_03
LA- English
KP- psychosocial risk factors for maladjustment in childhood cancer
KP- survivors & their families
KP- implications for preventive intervention
SU- At Risk Populations; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Recovery (Disorders)
AB- Describes childhood cancer as a series of chronic, uncontrollable, and stressful life events that may have lasting impact on survivors and their families. Several risk factors are discussed that increase the child and family's vulnerability to maladjustment: (1) the severity and spacing of medical and other life stresses; (2) iatrogenic physical impairment; (3) social stigma; and (4) an interrelated cluster of poverty, ethnicity, and a single-adult family structure. Three sources of invulnerability to maladjustment (individual coping style, family functioning, and social support) may increase resiliency in the face of stress and thus reduce the risk of long-term dysfunction. The risk of psychological maladjustment points to the need for preventive family-focused intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- At Risk Populations; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Recovery (Disorders)
MN- Early Experience; Family; Prevention

TI- Psychosocial consequences of bone marrow transplantation in children: A preliminary communication.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Pot-Mees, Carien C.
AU- Zeitlin, Harry

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- bone marrow transplantation
KP- psychosocial adjustment
KP- 2.5–16 yr old patients & their families
SU- Bone Marrow; Emotional Adjustment; Family; Social Adjustment; Surgery
AB- Studied psychosocial effects of bone marrow transplantation (BMT) among 15 pediatric patients (aged 2 and a half to 16 yrs) and their families. Assessment procedures proved to be acceptable to patients, parents, and siblings, and the research methods proved to be feasible. Before BMT, the majority of the parents showed depressive symptoms, whereas most of the children were relatively well adjusted. During treatment, patients exhibited behavioral and emotional changes. Since some family members were separated from the family in all families, the parents' and siblings' ability to cope was affected. New behavior problems occurred far more frequently among siblings who were bone marrow donors than among the other siblings. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- informal decision analysis as psychological aid
KP- choice of lumpectomy vs mastectomy with vs without reconstruction
KP- female breast cancer patients
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Decision Making; Mastectomy; Surgery
AB- 43 women with breast cancer received either mastectomy or lumpectomy plus radiotherapy. Whenever medically feasible, the Ss were allowed to choose their own treatment. When they needed help in deciding, an informal decision analysis based on the principles of Bayesian decision analysis was conducted to help them choose. Those who needed a mastectomy were offered breast reconstruction. Tests of anxiety, depression, body satisfaction, marital adjustment, self-esteem, sociability, and life change were administered to the Ss before surgery and at intervals up to 1 yr after treatment to assess their psychological adaptation to treatment. Psychological adaptation has been good in all groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Decision Making; Mastectomy; Surgery
MN- Coping Behavior; Human Females
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)
PO- Human (10)
PO- Female (40)

TI- Use of hypnosis in the treatment of cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Kaye, Janet M.
AF- Kaye, Janet M., Medical Coll of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Sum 1987
PG- 11-22
PC- 12
SP- 11
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 12
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n02_02
LA- English
KP- hypnotherapy with psychotherapy
KP- disease & treatment related symptoms
KP- 24–72 yr old cancer patients
SU- Hypnotherapy; Neoplasms; Psychotherapy
AB- Discusses the use of hypnotherapy in conjunction with psychotherapy to ameliorate disease- and treatment-related symptoms in 12 adult cancer patients. Reasons for S referral were nausea, vomiting, anxiety, depression, anorexia, and pain. Hypnotherapy included trance induction, total body relaxation, visualization, and use of hypnotic suggestion to facilitate removal of noxious symptoms. The mean number of psychotherapy sessions was 9, and the mean number of hypnotherapy sessions was 4. Nine Ss received hypnotherapy because psychotherapy and other modalities had failed to relieve their symptoms; 3 received it for relief of symptoms and supportive therapy. Most of the Ss were terminally ill. Hypnotherapy was successful in relieving symptoms in 8 of the 12 Ss. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Hypnotherapy; Neoplasms; Psychotherapy
CL- Clinical Hypnosis (3351)

PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Stam, Henderikus J.
AU- Steggles, Shawn

VI- 5

LA- English
KP- psychometric & conceptual issues in prediction of onset or progression of testicular cancer from psychological variables
SU- Neoplasms; Prediction; Psychometrics; Psychosocial Factors; Testes
AB- Reviews several representative studies that attempt to predict the onset or progression of testicular cancer from psychological variables and reviews the psychometric and conceptual issues they raise. Assessment measures discussed include the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI), Personal Orientation Inventory, and Derogatis Sexual Functioning Inventory. It is argued that this research strategy, although sometimes interesting from a scientific perspective, consists of the implicit adoption of the medical model into psychosocial oncology research. The utility of this model from the perspectives of the researcher and the patient is questioned. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- psychosocial support received from mother
KP- pregnant 15 yr old with Hodgkin's disease
KP- case report
SU- Adolescent Pregnancy; Mother Child Relations; Neoplasms
AB- Describes the case of a 15-yr-old pregnant female also diagnosed with Hodgkin's disease, focusing on the emotional support the S received from her mother. Although the S had a therapeutic abortion, she was encouraged to tell her mother of the pregnancy. It is suggested that sharing this information resulted in a closer relationship between the two that helped the S through radiation therapy and that continued even after the S was well. LA- English
KP- psychosexual adjustment
KP- endometrial cancer patients & their spouses
SU- Adjustment; Gynecological Disorders; Neoplasms; Psychosexual Behavior
AB- Studied the psychosexual adjustment of 22 endometrial cancer patients and 14 of their spouses, using semistructured interviews and questionnaires. Significant decreases in the frequency of and satisfaction with sexual relations from their precancer levels were reported by the patients and their husbands. Three-quarters of the patients reported sexual difficulties, primarily physical discomfort owing to anatomical changes and a decrease in vaginal lubrication. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- The relationship between depression and reinforcing events in cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bisno, Betsy
AU- Richardson, Jean L.
AF- Bisno, Betsy, Veterans Administration Outpatient Service, Los Angeles, CA, US
AF- Richardson, Jean L.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Sum 1987
PG- 63-71
PC- 9
SP- 63
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 9
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n02_06
LA- English
KP- unpleasant events & depressive symptoms
KP- 31–82 yr old newly diagnosed cancer patients receiving radiation therapy
SU- Experiences (Events); Major Depression; Neoplasms
AB- Investigated depressive symptoms of 53 newly diagnosed adult cancer patients receiving radiation therapy and the relationship of these symptoms to P. M. Lewinsohn's (1974, 1982) behavioral model of depression. Depressive symptoms were measured using the Beck Depression Inventory (BDI). Over 75% of the Ss were not depressed. Analyses were consistent with Lewinsohn's model. Unpleasant and pleasant events cross-products accounted for a significant amount of variance in BDI scores. The subscales of unpleasant events most strongly correlated with depression were (1) perceptions that others were dissatisfied with them, (2) perceptions that others were infringing on them, and (3) concerns over poor work performance. The subscales of pleasant events that inversely correlated most strongly with depression were feelings of good health and leisure-time activities. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Experiences (Events); Major Depression; Neoplasms
MN- Radiation Therapy
CL- Cancer (3293)
PO- Human (10)
AG- Adulthood (18 yrs & older) (300)
MD- Empirical Study

KP- patients surviving cancer
SU- Advocacy; Neoplasms; Self Help Techniques
AB- Reviews the roles of mutual-help movements and disease lobbies and suggests a strategy for a stepwise movement toward a national organization for cancer survivors that might be called The Cancer Consort. It is argued that although 5 million Americans, or 2% of the population, are survivors of cancer, this group remains a quiet constituency that has no national organization to focus its common concerns or represent its problems. LA- English
KP- psychosocial perceptions pressuring medical decision making
KP- home iv hyperalimentation
KP- 11 yr old male with progressive brain tumor
KP- implications for withdrawal of nourishment from terminally ill
SU- Brain Neoplasms; Clinical Judgment (Not Diagnosis); Nutrition; Terminally Ill Patients; Treatment Withholding
AB- Presents the case of an 11-yr-old boy who had a relentlessly progressive brain tumor involving the upper cervical cord. Nutritional support was maintained by intravenous hyperalimentation (IVH) at home, which seemed contraindicated. However, the S had 18 mo of totally uneventful IVH, with good weight gain and a quality of life that was fully acceptable to him and his family. This case is discussed in the light of 2 differing perceptions of IVH. The ethnic and economic background of the S is reviewed, including the psychosocial perceptions that pressure medical decision making. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- emotional & financial burden & disease status
KP- physical & instrumental & administrative needs for services
KP- 13–90 yr old advanced cancer patients
SU- Client Characteristics; Needs Assessment; Neoplasms
AB- Needs assessment data collected from 217 cancer patients (aged 13–90 yrs) and family members who were already receiving agency services were used to examine the interrelationships among 3 categories of need: physical, instrumental, and administrative. Categories of need also were examined as a function of emotional and financial burden. Age, duration of disease, education, income, sex, marital status, living arrangements, and pain status were found to be related to degree of need within categories. TI- Conflicts in cancer care: The role of moral reflection.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Shelp, Earl E.
AF- Shelp, Earl E., Baylor Coll of Medicine, Ctr for Ethics, Medicine, & Public Issues, Houston, TX, US
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 1
SD- Spr 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Spr 1987
PG- 51-64
PC- 14
SP- 51
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n01_06
LA- English
KP- moral conflicts in cancer treatment
KP- role of physicians & patients
SU- Morality; Neoplasms; Therapeutic Processes; Treatment
AB- Asserts that moral disagreements in cancer care are operationally similar to moral disagreements in the care of patients with other diseases. Conflicts between individuals tend to reflect the morally pluralistic character of the environment where health care is provided. By engaging in moral analysis or reflection, these conflicts may be better understood and perhaps resolved. Thus, ethics may engender mutual respect and clarify points at which disputants agree, resulting in a continual clinical relationship. Three case vignettes illustrate how conflicts grounded in moral disagreement can arise in the care of people who have cancer, and how fundamental moral differences can affect clinical relationships. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Morality; Neoplasms; Therapeutic Processes; Treatment
MN- Professional Ethics
CL- Health & Mental Health Treatment & Prevention (3300)

TI- High social desirability in patients being treated for advanced colorectal or bladder cancer: Eventual impact on the assessment of quality of life.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Hürny, Christoph
AU- Piasetsky, Eugene
AU- Bagin, Robert
AU- Holland, Jimmie C.
AF- Hürny, Christoph, University Hosp Insel, Medical Div Lory, Bern, Switzerland
AF- Piasetsky, Eugene
AF- Bagin, Robert
AF- Holland, Jimmie C.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 5
IP- 1
SD- Spr 1987
YR- 1987
PM- Spr 1987
PG- 19-29
PC- 11
SP- 19
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 11
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v05n01_02
LA- English
KP- social desirability & impact on quality of life assessment
KP- 34–75 yr old chemotherapy patients with advanced colorectal vs bladder cancer
SU- Bladder; Colon Disorders; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Social Desirability
AB- 81 patients (aged 34–75 yrs) undergoing chemotherapy for advanced cancer (41 Ss had colorectal cancer, 40 had bladder cancer) participated in a comparative study of social desirability (SOD). Among other psychometric tests, the Marlowe-Crowne Social Desirability Scale (MCS) was used to assess SOD. A 2-sample t-test showed no significant difference in mean MCS scores between the 2 groups, but both mean scores were substantially higher than those found in samples of the general population. It is suggested that since the ages of Ss in the present study clustered around the median of 60.6 for colorectal cancer and 62.5 for bladder cancer, it is probable that the high SOD observed was due in part to advanced age but also in part to having cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Bladder; Colon Disorders; Neoplasms; Quality of Life; Social Desirability
MN- Chemotherapy; Client Characteristics
CL- Cancer (3293)

TI- Psychological distress in reaction to lung cancer as a function of spousal support and coping strategy.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Quinn, Mary E.
AU- Fontana, Alan F.
AU- Reznikoff, Marvin
AF- Quinn, Mary E., Lincoln Hall, Lincolndale, NY, US
AF- Fontana, Alan F.
AF- Reznikoff, Marvin
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 4
IP- 4
SD- Win 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Win 1986
PG- 79-90
PC- 12
SP- 79
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 12
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v04n04_07
LA- English
KP- spousal support & coping strategies
KP- psychological distress
KP- male lung cancer patients & their wives
KP- 4 mo followup
SU- Coping Behavior; Distress; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Social Support
AB- Administered a battery of tests (e.g., coping scale, intimacy interview) to 60 male lung cancer patients (mean age 62.92 yrs) and their spouses 1 mo after diagnosis and to 44 of the couples 4 mo after diagnosis. Results show that support was significantly related to psychological distress as well as to change in distress. The coping strategies of wishfulfilling fantasy (WFF) self-blaming denial, and emotional expression were significantly related to greater distress; WFF was significantly related to change in distress. Results indicate that the spouse's support serves a beneficial function for lung cancer patients in ameliorating psychological distress and that WFF is a detrimental strategy for coping with psychological distress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Distress; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Social Support
MN- Followup Studies; Lung; Wives

KP- cognitive & behavioral strategies for maintaining control
KP- 21–79 yr olds with late stage cancer
SU- Coping Behavior; Neoplasms; Terminally Ill Patients
AB- Examined how 57 adults (aged 21–79 yrs) with late-stage cancer described their noncontrollable situation and the things over which they maintained control despite their disease. Analysis showed 4 cognitive and behavioral strategies that characterized the Ss' experience with cancer—monitoring progress, waiting it out, refocusing control, and turning it over. Properties of each strategy are described. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

AU- Baider, Lea

LA- English
KP- attitudes toward & adjustment to & coping with mastectomy
KP- Moslem vs Jewish females
KP- Israel
SU- Client Attitudes; Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Judaism; Mastectomy
AB- 10 Arab Moslem women (mean age 47.6 yrs) who had a mastectomy were studied in interviews as well as through the Brief Symptom Inventory and the Psychosocial Adjustment to Illness Scale. The Moslem Ss' perceptions about and attribution of the disease were different from those of 20 Jewish women (mean age 47.7 yrs), demonstrating a delay in recognizing the disease and in seeking medical help as well as a lack of information about and discussion of the disease. Findings highlight the need to learn more about the impact of a culture on a patient's health-disease orientation before efficient medical services can be supplied. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Attitudes; Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Judaism; Mastectomy

VI- 4

SP- 135
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- need for & use of & satisfaction with psychosocial community services
KP- AIDS patients & family members
SU- Community Mental Health Services; Community Services; Family Members; Health Care Utilization; Social Services
AB- Assessed the needs of 71 acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) patients and 7 family members for psychosocial services, the extent of their use of such services, and the level of their satisfaction with services received from community-based service organizations. Patients expressed the need for many kinds of services, including those that provide medical information, medical referrals, and practical help as well as support groups and individual therapy. Although most patients were satisfied with the services they had used, they were most satisfied with individual therapy and with services that provided transportation, food, and clothing. Results show that community organizations that serve AIDS patients should provide a wide range of psychosocial services. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- The male role and mastectomy: Support groups and men's adjustment.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Sabo, Donald
AU- Brown, Joseph
AU- Smith, Carol
AF- Sabo, Donald, D'Youville Coll
AF- Brown, Joseph
AF- Smith, Carol
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 4
IP- 1-2
SD- Spr-Sum 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Spr-Sum 1986
PG- 19-31
PC- 13
SP- 19
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 13
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v04n01_02
LA- English
KP- male role concept & participation in support group
KP- adjustment to wife's mastectomy
KP- husbands
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Husbands; Mastectomy; Sex Roles; Social Support
AB- Explored the psychosocial aspects of 24 husbands' reactions and adjustments to their wives' mastectomy through in-depth interviews, clinical observations of a multisession men's support group, in which 6 Ss participated, and test–retest analysis of questionnaire data. Sex-role theory was used to explain how factors related to the male role complicate men's adjustment. Ss placed a high priority on their wives' adjustment but kept their own feelings at bay. Ss' adoption of a "protective guardian" role during their wives' hospitalization fostered denial and later blocked communication between spouses. Questionnaire data indicate that support group members became significantly more communicative with spouses about mastectomy issues than did control group members. These quantitative findings parallel clinical observations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Husbands; Mastectomy; Sex Roles; Social Support
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)

KP- psychosocial issues
KP- choice of mastectomy vs lumpectomy & radiation therapy
KP- females with early stage breast cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Decision Making; Mastectomy; Psychosocial Factors; Radiation Therapy
AB- Women diagnosed with early stage breast cancer are increasingly given the choice of mastectomy or lumpectomy and radiation therapy as primary treatment. It is suggested that high-quality provision of health care should include attention to psychosocial as well as medical issues during this decision-making process. Six case examples are used to demonstrate the importance of exploration of feelings during this period to facilitate a decision that may be satisfactory psychologically as well as medically. LA- English
KP- compliance with treatment regimens & use of traditional vs nontraditional health care alternatives
KP- cancer patients
SU- Decision Making; Health Care Utilization; Neoplasms; Treatment Compliance
AB- Reviews the literature regarding the following choices that cancer patients make about treatment: (1) to continue with recommended regimens, (2) to comply with those regimens or seek other opinions from within the health care system, or (3) to try unproven methods of treatment. It is noted that clinical research is needed to establish the prevalence of patient noncompliance and use of unproven treatments as well as to ascertain the reasons behind patients' actions. Understanding the cancer patient's motivations for decisions can contribute to more effective clinical practice and to modification of the cancer care system so that it is more responsive to patients' needs. TI- Assessment of anticipatory nausea and vomiting in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy: Theoretical and methodological considerations.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Nicholas, Donald R.
AU- Hollandsworth, James G.
AF- Nicholas, Donald R., Ball State U, Teachers Coll
AF- Hollandsworth, James G.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 4
IP- 1-2
SD- Spr-Sum 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Spr-Sum 1986
PG- 61-75
PC- 15
SP- 61
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- model of autonomic & behavioral & cognitive responses
KP- assessment of anticipatory nausea & vomiting & anxiety
KP- 31–64 yr old female cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy
SU- Anxiety; Expectations; Nausea; Neoplasms; Vomiting
AB- Nausea and vomiting that occur before or during a chemotherapy infusion is called conditioned or anticipatory nausea and vomiting (ANV). The 3-systems model of emotion is proposed as a heuristic device for the development of assessment procedures for ANV and chemotherapy-related anxiety; this model could facilitate the matching of the response patterns of individual patients with available treatment interventions. The construct of anxiety is discussed, a mode-by-method matrix for classifying assessment procedures is introduced, and current assessment procedures for ANV are reviewed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Coping with childhood cancer: A conceptual view.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Van Dongen-Melman, J. E.
AU- Pruyn, J. F.
AU- Van Zanen, G. E.
AU- Sanders-Woudstra, J. A.
AF- Van Dongen-Melman, J. E., Sophia Children's Hosp, Dept of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry, Rotterdam, Netherlands
AF- Pruyn, J. F.
AF- Van Zanen, G. E.
AF- Sanders-Woudstra, J. A.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 4
IP- 1-2
SD- Spr-Sum 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Spr-Sum 1986
PG- 147-161
PC- 15
SP- 147
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v04n01_11
LA- English
KP- stress coping model & attribution & social comparison theories
KP- analysis of psychosocial functioning
KP- children with cancer & their families
SU- Attribution; Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Social Adjustment; Social Comparison
AB- Presents a conceptual framework for studying the impact of childhood cancer on the psychosocial and social functioning of the patient and the family. A literature-based model about coping with stress, and 2 psychosocial theories of human behavior—attribution and social comparison theory—are presented. The model (1) describes problems people experience when confronted with a threatening situation; (2) provides a classification of problems that has a manageable number of categories to which problems can be assigned; and (3) gives insight into some important coping strategies that children and their parents use to lessen the impact of those problems. The problem categories and coping strategies of the model are illustrated from findings described in the literature and from information obtained during interviews with patients and parents. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Attribution; Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Social Adjustment; Social Comparison
MN- Family Members; Models; Neoplasms; Psychosocial Factors; Stress Reactions; Theories
CL- Cancer (3293)

LA- English
KP- family structure & roles & relations
KP- coping with stress & emotional adaptation
KP- families in which member has cancer
KP- clincal implications
SU- Coping Behavior; Emotional Adjustment; Family Members; Family Relations; Family Structure
AB- Discusses the physiological, emotional, and behavioral consequences of cancer on the well members of the family. The connection between individual and interpersonal coping with stress and the family's ability to adapt, especially in relation to the influence of the family structure, roles, and relationships on the development of individual members and their perceptions of the patient and the patient's illness are emphasized. Three examples are presented to illustrate the effect of the family's organization on the process of adaptation and the appropriate clinical responses to 2 types of families—the enmeshed family and the disengaged family. The principles of clinical intervention with a family in which a member has cancer are summarized. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Symptom distress, psychosocial variables, and survival from lung cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Kukull, Walter A.
AU- McCorkle, Ruth
AU- Driever, Marie
AF- Kukull, Walter A., U Washington, Seattle
AF- McCorkle, Ruth

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 4
IP- 1-2
SD- Spr-Sum 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Spr-Sum 1986
PG- 91-104
PC- 14
SP- 91
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v04n01_07
LA- English
KP- symptom distress & social dependence & mood & awareness & personality traits & demographic characteristics
KP- prediction of survival
KP- patients with inoperable lung cancer
KP- 4 yr longitudinal study
SU- Distress; Emotional States; Personality Correlates; Psychosocial Factors; Symptoms
AB- 53 patients (mean age 62 yrs) with inoperable lung cancer were interviewed 1 and 2 mo postdiagnosis to obtain data on their level of symptom distress, as well as on selected psychosocial and demographic variables. Ss were then followed for about 4 yrs, at which time 45 had died of lung cancer, 2 had died of other causes, 4 remained alive, and 2 were lost to follow-up. Ss' postdiagnosis symptom distress score was the most important predictor of survival (from among 8 variables considered) after adjusting for age, functional status, and personality traits. Thus, the magnitude of symptoms that patients report soon after diagnosis may influence how long they live. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Distress; Emotional States; Personality Correlates; Psychosocial Factors; Symptoms
MN- Death and Dying; Demographic Characteristics; Longitudinal Studies; Lung Disorders; Neoplasms; Prediction

TI- Perceptions of the cancer patient: Causal explanations and personal attributions.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Curbow, Barbara
AU- Andrews, Roxanne M.
AU- Burke, T. Adam

VI- 4
IP- 1-2
SD- Spr-Sum 1986

PG- 115-134

PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 20
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v04n01_09
LA- English
KP- causal explanations & patient's role in etiology of illness
KP- perceptions of & relations with cancer patients
KP- college students vs 23–75 yr old female nurses
SU- Attribution; Health Personnel Attitudes; Neoplasms; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Social Interaction
AB- Examined 3 questions via 2 studies with 225 undergraduates and 612 nurses (aged 23–75 yrs): (1) Do people make different causal explanations for cancer than for other illnesses? (2) Are the causal explanations people make related to other perceptions of the patients? (3) Is blame for an illness associated with other perceptions of the patient? The students judged cancer to be caused less by person-related factors than are some other illnesses, although they linked personal responsibility with other negative perceptions of the cancer patient and reported a greater inclination to avoid cancer patients whom they perceived to be responsible for their illness. The nurses indicated a similar pattern, except they did not link personal responsibility for etiology with avoidance of cancer patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Attribution; Health Personnel Attitudes; Neoplasms; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Social Interaction
MN- Avoidance; Etiology; Nurses

LA- English
KP- psychosocial problems & group treatment
KP- females with metastatic breast carcinoma
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Group Counseling; Human Females; Psychosocial Rehabilitation
AB- Reviews the literature on the psychosocial problems of cancer patients—defined within the 4 areas of affect, physical symptoms, social support, and cognition—and describes a process of group treatment used in a 1-yr study of women who had metastatic carcinoma of the breast. Ss met weekly in group sessions led by therapists in a manner designed to address each category of psychosocial problems. The major outcome variables measured were affect and pain. As compared with women who did not receive intervention, group members experienced significant reductions in mood disturbance and in the reactive component of pain, although the frequency and duration of pain attacks were similar in both groups. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Sex differences in psychological distress during definitive radiation therapy for cancer.

LA- English
KP- psychological distress & coping
KP- female vs male patients receiving definitive radiotherapy for cancer
SU- Coping Behavior; Distress; Human Sex Differences; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy
AB- Assessed psychological distress in 181 patients (aged 17+ yrs) who were receiving definitive radiotherapy for cancer to determine whether there was evidence that men and women differ in initial psychological need and the effectiveness of their coping in the absence of any programmatic intervention. In repeated psychometric assessments, patients reported significantly less depression and anxiety after treatment, although depressive symptoms were still higher than nonpatient norms for both sexes in the 3-mo period between the onset of treatment and second follow-up interview. There were no apparent differences between the men and women in reduction of psychic distress, which indicates that the men and women were equally effective in coping with their disease and treatment. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- High compliance with fluoride treatment by patients irradiated for head and neck tumors: A theoretical interpretation.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Bransfield, Diana D.
AU- Horiot, Jean-Claude
AU- Bône, Marie-Christine
AF- Bransfield, Diana D., Vanderbilt U

LA- English
KP- compliance with dental fluoridation program
KP- patients irradiated for head & neck cancer
SU- Dental Treatment; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy; Treatment Compliance
AB- Describes a 2-yr randomized trial to compare the efficacy of fluoride gel and fluoride toothpaste. 220 patients irradiated for head and neck cancer had an overall compliance rate of 93% with the dental program. Though the difference was not significant, the fluoride gel group had a slightly higher compliance rate than the fluoride toothpaste group. The compliance behavior is interpreted using the health belief model and learning theories, and suggestions are offered for future research. It is concluded that new health behaviors that can be incorporated into existing habituated stimulus-response sequences are likely to result in long-term maintenance of those behaviors and yield high compliance rates among patients. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Dental Treatment; Neoplasms; Radiation Therapy; Treatment Compliance

KP- behavioral techniques for control of chemotherapy side effects
KP- cancer patients

AB- Discusses 3 general issues to be considered in implementing a program of behavioral intervention to assist cancer patients: (1) how to train patients in behavioral techniques, (2) how to implement the use of those techniques in a clinical setting, and (3) how to enhance the rapport between patients and therapists. The use of audiotapes to teach patients the techniques of active or passive relaxation with guided imagery is described. These tapes provide a cost-effective and therapeutically valid method of helping patients control the aversive effects of chemotherapy and other medical procedures. TI- Gay grief: An examination of its uniqueness brought to light by the AIDS crisis.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Klein, Sandra J.
AU- Fletcher, William
AF- Klein, Sandra J., AIDS Project Los Angeles, Grief Recovery Group, CA
AF- Fletcher, William
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 4
IP- 3
SD- Fal 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Fal 1986
PG- 15-25
PC- 11
SP- 15
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 11
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v04n03_02
LA- English
KP- psychosocial support in grief recovery group & grief issues
KP- 32–64 yr old homosexual males who had lost partners to acquired immune deficiency syndrome
SU- Grief; Group Counseling; Immunologic Disorders; Male Homosexuality; Social Support
AB- Explores the issue of psychosocial support for persons with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) by describing experiences with a group that offers support to persons with AIDS and to their significant others. 32 men (aged 32–64 yrs) attended the grief recovery group (GRG) under the auspices of the AIDS Project Los Angeles over an 18-mo period. Most had lost a partner to the effects of AIDS. Although feelings of grief are similar among all people experiencing a loss, the unique needs of this population became obvious. Social stigma, homophobia, fear of contracting the disease or of being a carrier, and special reentry and dating problems are only a few of the concerns that complicate their grief. Traditional and nontraditional grief groups are compared, and the authors' experiences from the GRG are described. It is concluded that to become more effective, caregivers must be willing to recognize and resolve their personal feelings about loss and homosexuality. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Grief; Group Counseling; Immunologic Disorders; Male Homosexuality; Social Support
CL- Group & Family Therapy (3313)

TI- Assessment of denial in cancer patients: Implications for intervention.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Wool, Margaret S.
AU- Goldberg, Richard J.
AF- Wool, Margaret S., Rhode Island Hosp, Dept of Psychiatry, Providence
AF- Goldberg, Richard J.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 4
IP- 3
SD- Fal 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Fal 1986
PG- 1-14
PC- 14
SP- 1
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v04n03_01
LA- English
KP- aspects of denial
KP- patients with cancer
KP- treatment implications
SU- Client Attitudes; Denial; Neoplasms; Treatment
AB- Discusses the concept of denial in cancer patients and considers ways of establishing its presence and distinguishing it from other mechanisms. An exploratory study of 15 cancer patients (mean age 65.7 yrs) exhibiting extreme denial resulted in the delineation of 4 major aspects of denial: (1) denial of the physical manifestations of the disease; (2) denial of the diagnosis; (3) denial of the implications of the illness; and (4) denial, or isolation, of affect associated with the illness. Since denial can be adaptive or maladaptive, specification of the type of denial a patient manifests and its adaptive or maladaptive functions aid in the decision to try to reduce or modify the denial. It is suggested that denial be viewed from the standpoints of its relationship to help-seeking behavior, compliance with medical treatment, psychological well-being vs mood disturbance, and the capacity to sustain needed social support. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Attitudes; Denial; Neoplasms; Treatment
MN- Coping Behavior
CL- Health & Mental Health Treatment & Prevention (3300)
PO- Human (10)
AG- Adulthood (18 yrs & older) (300)
MD- Empirical Study

LA- English
KP- emotional & psychosocial adjustment
KP- patients 20 yrs & older with recurrence of breast or colon or lung or gynecologic cancer or melanoma or Hodgkin's disease
SU- Distress; Emotional Adjustment; Neoplasms; Relapse (Disorders)
AB- Assessed the emotional and psychosocial status of 102 patients (aged 20+ yrs) who had a recurrence of 1 of 6 types of cancer: breast, colon, lung, gynecologic, Hodgkin's disease, or malignant melanoma. Ss contrasted their current experience with their experience at the initial diagnosis. Test scores, personality inventories, and common clinical characteristics such as stage of disease were also used in the comparisons. Although recurrence is an ominous development, no research evidence was found that it is actually more distressing and menacing than the 1st diagnosis. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

TI- Perceptions of cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Gutteling, Jan M.
AU- Seydel, Erwin R.
AU- Wiegman, Oene
AF- Gutteling, Jan M., Twente U of Technology, Enschede, Netherlands
AF- Seydel, Erwin R.

VI- 4

SD- Fal 1986

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis

LA- English
KP- prior experience & knowledge of cancer & attitudes toward & anxiety about cancer & preventive behavior intentions
KP- females participating in mass screening for cervical cancer
KP- Netherlands
KP- implications for health education
SU- Anxiety; Health Attitudes; Human Females; Knowledge Level; Neoplasms
AB- Measured anxiety about cancer, prior experience with cancer, knowledge of cancer, attitudes toward health, and intentions to engage in preventive behavior in 479 Dutch women who, because of their age, had been invited to participate in mass screenings to detect cervical cancer. The Dutch version of the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory was used to validate the fear-of-cancer measure. Ss with a low level of fear of cancer knew more about the disease, had greater intentions to behave preventively and a lesser estimation of their chance of getting the disease, and felt that cancer was less threatening than did those with higher levels of anxiety. Prior experiences with cancer were related to a greater knowledge of the disease and Ss' higher estimation of their chance of getting it. Health educators may have a more difficult time reaching persons who have a low educational level and a high level of anxiety about cancer because these 2 factors seem to inhibit the acceptance of information about health. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Anxiety; Health Attitudes; Human Females; Knowledge Level; Neoplasms
MN- Health Education; Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward); Prevention

TI- Family affective climate during the childhood of adult cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Grassi, Luigi
AU- Molinari, Sergio
AF- Grassi, Luigi
AF- Molinari, Sergio
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 4
IP- 3
SD- Fal 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Fal 1986
PG- 53-62
PC- 10
SP- 53
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 10
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v04n03_05
LA- English
KP- family affective & emotional climate in early childhood
KP- 31–70 yr old females with breast or uterine cancer
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Early Experience; Emotions; Mother Child Relations; Uterus
AB- A consecutive series of 72 women (31–70 yrs old) presenting symptoms suggesting cancer (26 breast lumps and 46 abnormal uterine bleeding) completed the Family Attitude Questionnaire (FAQ) on the day they were admitted to the hospital. The total cancer group had lower scores than the total benign group on the following scales: Closeness to Parents, Demonstrativity, Good Paternal Relationship, Paternal Demonstrativity, and Good Maternal Relationship. When the patients were separated according to tumor site, the uterine cancer group reported lower scores on the Closeness to Parents, Good Paternal Relationship, and Paternal Demonstrativity scales than did patients with benign lesions. Unlike the controls, the breast cancer patients showed negative attitudes toward the mother only (Good Maternal Relationship and Maternal Demonstrativity subscales). It is concluded that some complex association exists between cancer and the affective and emotional climate in the family during early childhood. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Early Experience; Emotions; Mother Child Relations; Uterus
MN- Father Child Relations; Home Environment; Neoplasms

TI- A comprehensive approach to the assessment of cancer patients' rehabilitation needs: The Cancer Inventory of Problem Situations and a companion interview.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Ganz, Patricia A.
AU- Rofessart, Jacqueline
AU- Polinsky, Margaret L.
AU- Schag, Cyndie C.
AU- Heinrich, Richard L.
AF- Ganz, Patricia A., VA Medical Ctr, Dept of Medicine, Sepulveda, CA
AF- Rofessart, Jacqueline
AF- Polinsky, Margaret L.

SD- Fal 1986
YR- 1986
PM- Fal 1986
PG- 27-42

SP- 27

LA- English
KP- comprehensive structured interview vs Cancer Inventory of Problem Situations
KP- assessment of rehabilitation needs
KP- 25–73 yr old cancer patients
SU- Interviews; Needs Assessment; Neoplasms; Rehabilitation; Screening Tests
AB- Describes a comprehensive approach to needs assessment for cancer patients that was developed to provide specific rehabilitation interventions. 24 patients (aged 25–73 yrs) were evaluated independently using a comprehensive, structured interview and the Cancer Inventory of Problem Situations (CIPS) by R. L. Heinrich et al (see record [rid]1985-00151-001[/rid]). General content areas and specific items from both instruments were compared for each patient, and a rate of agreement between the 2 instruments was calculated. The instruments showed a high rate of agreement for physical and treatment-related problems; however, the rate of agreement was lower for more personal and sensitive areas such as marital distress, finances, and sexual dysfunction. Overall, the CIPS appeared to be a more sensitive screening instrument for rehabilitation needs, but the personal interview provided useful background information and can be used as a companion to the CIPS. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Interviews; Needs Assessment; Neoplasms; Rehabilitation; Screening Tests

LA- English
KP- sex education & counseling
KP- adjustment to radical surgery
KP- pelvic or genital cancer patients & their partners
SU- Genital Disorders; Neoplasms; Sex Therapy; Sexual Function Disturbances; Surgery
AB- Describes a program of sex education and counseling for both patient and partner when radical pelvic or genital surgery is indicated. It is recommended that counseling begin with assessment and sex education at the time treatment is determined and that the counselor follow the patient or couple during the hospitalization and several times during the 1st yr after surgery so that problems that require more intensive sex therapy can be identified. It is suggested that counseling is especially important for Ss who are unmarried, have an ostomy, or are considering reconstructive surgery. Effects of surgery for pelvic or genital cancer on male and female sexual physiology are listed, and treatment techniques to overcome female dyspareunia and organic erectile dysfunction are discussed. (37 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- psychosocial & demographic characteristics & extent of surgery & therapy
KP- esophageal or electrolaryngeal speech or nonverbal methods of communication after laryngectomy
KP- 54–65 yr old patients
SU- Demographic Characteristics; Larynx; Oral Communication; Recovery (Disorders); Surgery
AB- Identified variables that discriminated among methods of communication, using 60 patients (primarily aged 54–65 yrs) who had experienced total laryngectomies from 5 mo to 3 yrs 6 mo earlier. Data were collected on support from family, friends, and other laryngectomees; characteristics of the voice therapy experience; extent of surgery; time since surgery; and demographic characteristics. Support from family and friends and time spent practicing esophageal speech made significant contributions to differences among all 3 methods: esophageal or electrolaryngeal speech and nonverbal methods. Ss using nonverbal communication had the most extensive disease and were discriminated on the basis of the time since surgery. (29 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

LA- English
KP- Cancer Prevention Clinic
KP- provision of genetic & medical information to assist in prevention
KP- cancer-prone families
SU- At Risk Populations; Family; Health Care Services; Neoplasms; Preventive Medicine
AB- Describes a clinic and research service operating since 1981, designed primarily to provide genetic and medical information that will facilitate primary as well as secondary prevention of cancer among individuals who are at greater than average risk for developing the disease because of a family history of cancer. The services provided by the clinic are discussed from 3 standpoints: (1) the clinic population and the structure of the clinic service, (2) specific informational and psychological needs or concerns that clients present and how the staff addresses those needs, and (3) psychosocial barriers that interfere with the clinic's goals and suggestions for circumventing those barriers. The suggestion is made that the clinic's structure could be adapted for health maintenance organizations where the emphasis is on prevention and where multiple disciplines are already represented among the staff. TI- Perceptions of social support among patients with recently diagnosed breast, endometrial, and ovarian cancer: An exploratory study.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Smith, Elaine M.
AU- Redman, Robert
AU- Burns, Trudy L.
AU- Sagert, Kristin M.
AF- Smith, Elaine M., U Iowa Coll of Medicine, Iowa City
AF- Redman, Robert
AF- Burns, Trudy L.
AF- Sagert, Kristin M.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 3
IP- 3
SD- Fal 1985
YR- 1985
PM- Fal 1985
PG- 65-81
PC- 17
SP- 65
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print

LA- English
KP- social support
KP- adjustment to breast & endometrial & ovarian cancer diagnosis & treatment
KP- 20–54 yr old female patients
SU- Breast Neoplasms; Client Characteristics; Emotional Adjustment; Ovaries; Social Support
AB- Explored the role of social support in ameliorating the stressful effects of cancer diagnosis and treatment in 357 patients, aged 20–54 yrs, with female reproductive cancer. Ss were asked (1) what types of supportive persons were available (e.g., spouse, friends, relatives, children) and the level of support these persons had provided since the cancer had developed (social support network), (2) whether various socioemotional and instrumental tasks were beneficial (social support), and (3) whether Ss were experiencing marital difficulties or felt isolated or lonely (effects of stress). Results indicate that the husband was the most important member of the support network for married Ss and that relatives were the most important member for single Ss. Few felt isolated or lonely or reported stress in their marriages because of the cancer. The most beneficial type of support activity was socioemotional—listening to or talking with the patient about the disease. Other beneficial social support behaviors varied according to marital status, age, and socioeconomic factors. (45 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Breast Neoplasms; Client Characteristics; Emotional Adjustment; Ovaries; Social Support
MN- Human Females; Neoplasms; Uterus

LA- English
KP- psychological & personality disturbance
KP- male testicular cancer patients
SU- Neoplasms; Psychopathology; Testes
AB- Tested the hypothesis that severe psychopathology is more prevalent among testicular cancer patients than among comparison groups. 59 men, average age 33.8 yrs, completed the Millon Clinical Multiaxial Inventory. 29 Ss showed no nonpsychotic symptoms, 19 showed mild-to-moderate nonpsychotic symptoms, and 11 showed moderate-to-severe nonpsychotic symptoms. The most prevalent symptoms were anxiety and somatic concern, followed by depression, substance abuse, and hypomania. Symptoms seemed to be associated with basic personality structure. Data do not support the hypothesis. (6 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)

KP- coping processes

AB- Studied parental adjustment in 46 mothers (aged 23–54 yrs) of pediatric cancer patients (aged 3–18 yrs). Self-report measures suggested that emotion-focused coping was positively related to maternal maladjustment. When Ss who participated were compared with the 43% of parents who chose not to, 1 difference was noted: The children of nonparticipants were in more life-threatening stages of the disease than were the children of Ss. LA- English
KP- Public Law 94-142 & implementation of individual education plan
KP- students with cancer
SU- Individualized Instruction; Laws; Neoplasms; Special Education Students
AB- Discusses the various aspects of implementing Public Law 94-142 (which requires every state to provide a free and appropriate education in the least restrictive environment for all handicapped 3–21 yr olds) on behalf of students with cancer. Children with cancer can continue their school in as normal a manner as possible with an individual education plan (IEP) developed by teachers, hospital staff, parents, and in some cases the children themselves. Creativity, flexibility, and individuality are the keys to successful implementation of the IEP. (7 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Individualized Instruction; Laws; Neoplasms; Special Education Students

TI- A therapeutic play group for hospitalized children with cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Cooper, Sharon E.
AU- Blitz, Joyce T.
AF- Cooper, Sharon E., Archdiocese of Philadelphia, Catholic Social Services, PA
AF- Blitz, Joyce T.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 3
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1985
YR- 1985
PM- Sum 1985
PG- 23-37
PC- 15
SP- 23
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 15
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v03n02_03
LA- English
KP- therapeutic play group
KP- knowledge of & compliance & coping with illness & treatment & hospitalization
KP- 2.5–12 yr olds hospitalized with cancer
SU- Hospital Programs; Hospitalized Patients; Neoplasms; Play Therapy
AB- Discusses the therapeutic play group program developed at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center"s 42-bed pediatric unit that is used to educate the patients (aged 2.5–12 yrs) about their illness and treatment; to enhance their compliance with the medical treatment; and to help them cope with their diagnosis, treatment, and hospitalization. The program focuses on prevention, involves co-leadership by a social worker and a nurse, and integrates what is learned in the group into the patients" care plans. The approach to play therapy utilized in this program places equal emphasis on (1) teaching and education, (2) addressing the children"s perception of their illness by dealing directly with the symbolic content of play, and (3) establishing an atmosphere of normality for the children. Common clinical issues encountered in the groups are discussed, and case examples are presented that illustrate the important functions of play in the intellectual and emotional lives of children. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Hospital Programs; Hospitalized Patients; Neoplasms; Play Therapy
MN- Client Education; Coping Behavior; Treatment Compliance

TI- Tolerance of pain by cancer patients in hyperthermia treatment.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Rozensky, Ronald H.
AU- Honor, Laurie Feldman
AU- Tovian, Steve M.
AU- Herz, Gordon
AU- Holland, Margaret
AF- Rozensky, Ronald H., Evanston Hosp, Dept of Psychiatry, IL
AF- Honor, Laurie Feldman
AF- Tovian, Steve M.
AF- Herz, Gordon
AF- Holland, Margaret
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 3
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1985
YR- 1985
PM- Sum 1985
PG- 75-82
PC- 8
SP- 75
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 8
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v03n02_06
LA- English
KP- personality & coping styles
KP- tolerance for pain in hyperthermia treatment
KP- 24–70 yr old cancer patients
SU- Coping Behavior; Hyperthermia; Neoplasms; Pain Perception; Physical Treatment Methods
AB- Discusses hyperthermia, which is the artificial inducement of abnormally high blood temperature designed to cause tumor tissue to retain heat and which has additive or synergistic effects with radiation and chemotherapy. Because of the clinically administered high temperature, cancer patients often experience pain and discomfort. 30 cancer patients, aged 24–70 yrs, undergoing hyperthermia treatment as part of their overall cancer care were administered the Millon Behavioral Health Inventory to determine which of them were able to tolerate the hyperthermia regimen. It was found that the Ss who were more hopeful about the future, less sensitive, more cooperative, more forceful, less responsive to pain, and less emotionally reactive were more tolerant of the hyperthermia treatment. The data also suggest that Ss who were less anxious and relied on coping styles characterized by a greater locus of internal control were able to tolerate discomfort better. It is suggested that any intervention that reduces anxiety (e.g., cognitive reinterpretation) also reduces the subjective intensity of pain. (27 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2013 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Coping Behavior; Hyperthermia; Neoplasms; Pain Perception; Physical Treatment Methods
MN- Personality Correlates
CL- Behavioral & Psychological Treatment of Physical Illness (3361)

KP- organizational climate & staffing of & patients admitted to demonstration hospices funded by National Cancer Institute
KP- 9-mo longitudinal study

AB- Reported on a study of 3 demonstration hospices funded by the National Cancer Institute by presenting information on the origin and organization of each hospice, its staffing pattern, the characteristics of patients admitted during the 9-mo study period, and patient use of the hospice program (home care or inpatient). Only 258 of the original 604 patients completed the study. These Ss were clearly healthier than those who did not, which may confound interpretation of the data. TI- A follow-up study of role functioning and the psychological environment of families of cancer patients.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Vess, James D.
AU- Moreland, John R.
AU- Schwebel, Andrew I.
AF- Vess, James D., Ohio State U
AF- Moreland, John R.
AF- Schwebel, Andrew I.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 3
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1985
YR- 1985
PM- Sum 1985
PG- 1-14
PC- 14
SP- 1

P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 14
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v03n02_01
LA- English
KP- role assignment & conflicts & marital communication & family environment
KP- cancer patients & their spouses with children at home
KP- 5-mo followup
SU- Family Relations; Marital Relations; Neoplasms; Role Conflicts; Role Perception
AB- 54 married cancer patients and their spouses with children at home completed a series of psychological instruments and participated in an intensive structured interview at Time 1. Five months later (Time 2), 29 of the 45 surviving Ss and their spouses again completed the instruments on family role, marital communication, and family environment. It was found that families who used achieved rather than ascribed role-assignment methods before the onset of cancer, families with older children who could adopt expanded role functions, and families with more interspouse communication experienced less disruption, less role conflict, and less role strain over time. Recommendations for helping cancer patients and their families cope more effectively with the stress of cancer and its treatment are presented. (18 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Family Relations; Marital Relations; Neoplasms; Role Conflicts; Role Perception

TI- Psychosocial aspects of AIDS and AIDS-related complex: A pilot study.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Donlou, John N.
AU- Wolcott, Deane L.
AU- Gottlieb, Michael S.
AU- Landsverk, John
AF- Donlou, John N., U California School of Medicine, Los Angeles
AF- Wolcott, Deane L.
AF- Gottlieb, Michael S.
AF- Landsverk, John
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 3
IP- 2
SD- Sum 1985
YR- 1985
PM- Sum 1985
PG- 39-55
PC- 17
SP- 39
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 17
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077V03n02_04
LA- English
KP- demographic characteristics & social support & self esteem & mood & psychosocial needs
KP- homosexual or bisexual male outpatients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome or related complex
SU- Emotional Adjustment; Immunologic Disorders; Self Esteem; Social Adjustment; Social Support
AB- Studied the psychosocial status of 21 homosexual or bisexual male outpatients with acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) or AIDS-related complex and measured their self-reported demographic characteristics, social support, self-esteem, mood state, and psychosocial needs. Ss manifested a marked mood disturbance, and one-third reported low self-esteem. Ss also indicated that the devastating effects of AIDS on their work life were secondary to their great fatigue, the effects of the medical treatment, and the effects of the illness on their physical appearance. In addition, they reported diminished social interactions since the onset of their illness, but they did not report any relationship disturbances with family members. Profound illness-related psychosocial stress was also reported. Further research may reveal that there are psychosocial and physical phases of the illness of AIDS, as there are in cancer, and that premorbid psychosocial characteristics of Ss may help discriminate those who are at risk for developing emotional distress during the illness. (45 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Emotional Adjustment; Immunologic Disorders; Self Esteem; Social Adjustment; Social Support
MN- Bisexuality; Demographic Characteristics; Human Males; Male Homosexuality
CL- Immunological Disorders (3291)

TI- Effects of interview context on a self-report scale of depressive symptoms.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Metzger, Loya F.
AU- Rogers, Theresa F.
AU- Bauman, Laurie J.
AF- Metzger, Loya F., Columbia U
AF- Rogers, Theresa F.

SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 3

LA- English
KP- sociodemographic characteristics & length & context of interviews
KP- scores on depression scale & responses to attitudinal questions
KP- females who had vs had not undergone mastectomy
SU- Depression (Emotion); Human Females; Interviews; Mastectomy; Measurement
AB- Discusses the reasons for the conflicting results of a study of the recovery of 652 women (mean age 52.4 yrs) who had undergone a mastectomy, in which the respondents' mean score on the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES—D) was 3 points lower (indicating less depression) than the mean score of a sample of 433 women (mean age 45.8 yrs) from the general population interviewed as a comparison group. The social and demographic characteristics of the 2 groups were similar, as were the Ss' responses to other attitudinal questions. In addition, patterns of association between variables were similar in both populations. Because the only difference between the 2 groups of Ss was in their responses on the CES—D, the authors conclude that the answers of the mastectomy Ss were influenced by the point at which the CES—D was administered during the interview. However, the data suggest that the better-educated Ss were less affected by the context of the interview and that the difference between the responses of the 2 groups was less on items that called for a more direct report of behavior and feelings. (19 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Depression (Emotion); Human Females; Interviews; Mastectomy; Measurement
MN- Attitudes; Demographic Characteristics; Emotional Adjustment; Female Attitudes; Methodology

TI- An empirical assessment of the effects of cancer on family role functioning.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Vess, James D.
AU- Moreland, John R.
AU- Schwebel, Andrew I.
AF- Vess, James D., Ohio State U, Columbus

VI- 3

PG- 1-16

PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v03n01_01
LA- English
KP- reallocation of roles & psychosocial environment
KP- cancer patients & their families
KP- ongoing longitudinal study
SU- Family Relations; Neoplasms; Roles
AB- Reports on the initial results of a longitudinal study of 54 cancer patients and their families. The study focused on the impact of cancer on the family's reallocation of roles and on the psychosocial environment by applying a developmental model to the analysis of roles in the family throughout its life cycle. Instruments included the Washington Family Role Inventory, Marital Communication Inventory, Family Environment Scale, and interviews conducted to evaluate substages of the family life cycle. Results indicate that the spouses' communication patterns strongly influenced how well roles were enacted, the amount of role strain and role conflict, and the level of cohesion and conflict in the family. The method that the family used for reassigning roles also significantly influenced how well roles were performed and the level of cohesion in the family. (20 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Family Relations; Neoplasms; Roles
MN- Longitudinal Studies; Social Environments

KP- religious issues
KP- 23–70 yr old hospitalized cancer patients seen in psychiatric consultation
KP- implications for comprehensive care for cancer patients
SU- Neoplasms; Religious Beliefs
AB- In an evaluation of 50 23–70 yr old male and female consecutively hospitalized cancer patients seen in psychiatric consultation, 32 patients were concerned with religious issues. 13 patients mentioned religion spontaneously, and 18 were actively struggling with several forms of religious problems. Only 9 appeared to have discussed these concerns with other members of the hospital staff. Implications for the provision of more comprehensive care to patients with cancer are noted. TI- Psychological characteristics: A pretreatment survival marker of patients with testicular cancer.
PS- Publication Status: Fully Published
AU- Edwards, Jacquelyn
AU- DiClemente, Carlo
AU- Samuels, Melvin L.
AF- Edwards, Jacquelyn, U Texas Medical Ctr, M. D. Anderson Hosp & Tumor Inst, Houston
AF- DiClemente, Carlo
AF- Samuels, Melvin L.
SO- Journal of Psychosocial Oncology
VI- 3
IP- 1
SD- Spr 1985
YR- 1985
PM- Spr 1985
PG- 79-94
PC- 16
SP- 79
PU- US : Haworth Press
P2- United Kingdom : Taylor & Francis
PN- 16
SN- 0734-7332, Print
SN- 1540-7586, Electronic
DO- 10.1300/J077v03n01_06
LA- English
KP- psychological profile as pretreatment indicator of survival after chemotherapy
KP- males with testicular cancer
SU- Client Characteristics; Endocrine Neoplasms; Prognosis; Testes; Treatment Outcomes
AB- Prior to chemotherapy, 26 males with testicular cancer (mean age 24.9 yrs) were given a battery of psychological tests, including the Minnesota Multiphasic Personality Inventory (MMPI), Personal Orientation Inventory, and Derogatis Sexual Functioning Inventory. Results reveal that these men had a narrower range of sexual experiences than the test norms. In addition, their psychological profile was indicative of an adolescent identity crisis. The 19 long-term survivors (alive 7 yrs after testing) had a lower self-regard and more emotional symptoms, were more introverted, and tended to express more anxiety, depression, and hostility than did the 7 short-term survivors (who died within the 1st yr). Data suggest the possibility of a psychological profile of testicular cancer patients that may be used as a pretreatment indicator of probable long-term survival after chemotherapy. They also indicate that the sometimes annoying behavior of long-term survivors can be viewed as successful coping mechanisms. (17 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
MJ- Client Characteristics; Endocrine Neoplasms; Prognosis; Testes; Treatment Outcomes
MN- Chemotherapy; Drug Therapy; Psychodynamics

DO- 10.1300/J077v03n01_03
LA- English
KP- degree of mental & physical suffering & stage & primary site of disease
KP- cancer patients who committed suicide
KP- Sweden
KP- 1973–76
SU- Neoplasms; Suicide
AB- Analyzed the medical records of 88 cancer patients who died by suicide in Sweden from 1973 to 1976 for data on the primary site of the cancer, the stage of the disease, and the degree of physical and mental suffering before the suicide. More than half the suicides occurred within the 1st yr of the diagnosis. Nearly two-thirds of the patients were in an advanced or terminal phase and had severe symptoms of the disease. (25 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2012 APA, all rights reserved)
